abstract: Kem Sokha, co-founder of the defunct Cambodia National Rescue Party, was accused of conspiring to overthrow the government and sentenced to 27 years of house arrest.
lead_paragraph: Kem Sokha, Cambodia’s most prominent opposition politician who is still in the country, was sentenced to 27 years of house arrest Friday on a charge of treason and barred from running or voting in elections.

headline: 6 Paperback Books to Read This Week
abstract: New releases include titles by Jennifer Egan, Eloghosa Osunde and more.
lead_paragraph: New releases include titles by Jennifer Egan, Eloghosa Osunde and more.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of "Creed III."
lead_paragraph: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of "Creed III."

headline: How a Relationship Coach Resolves Conflict
abstract: Navigating relationship issues can be tough. Elizabeth Earnshaw, a licensed marriage and family therapist, is here to help.
lead_paragraph: Navigating relationship issues can be tough. Elizabeth Earnshaw, a licensed marriage and family therapist, is here to help.

headline: Black Soldiers Cycled 1,900 Miles Across the U.S. So He Did, Too.
abstract: A remarkable journey from Montana to St. Louis by 20 Black infantrymen in 1897 seemed doomed to obscurity until Erick Cedeño, a bicyclist, retraced their journey.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1897, 20 Black U.S. Army infantrymen cycled 1,900 miles on fixed-gear, state-of-the-art bikes from Fort Missoula, Mont., to St. Louis. The Army ordered the grueling expedition to see whether soldiers could form a bicycle corps. Newspapers chronicled their progress as they pedaled 50 miles a day in mud and sand, through Montana’s snowy mountains and across Nebraska’s burning plains. The 41-day undertaking was a bit of lost military history until Erick Cedeño, a long-distance cyclist and a model based in Santa Monica, Calif., reenacted it in June of last year, on the expedition’s 125th anniversary.

headline: Would You Want to Be a Social Media Star?
abstract: Have you ever dreamed of turning a following into a career?
lead_paragraph: Have you ever dreamed of becoming a social media star? Of turning your life into content? Of gaining hundreds, thousands, even millions of followers and turning that following into a career?

headline: What a Poetic Mind Can Teach Us About How to Live
abstract: The poet Jane Hirshfield invites us to embrace habits of deep noticing and attention — and observe the beauty that unfolds.
lead_paragraph: “Poetry is the attempt to understand fully what is real, what is present, what is imaginable, what is feelable, and how can I loosen the grip of what I already know to find some new, changed relationship,” the poet Jane Hirshfield tells me. Through poetry, she says, “I know something new and I have been changed.”

headline: Life After the Spanish Civil War, Captured in a Teeming Novel
abstract: Some 300 characters — bartenders, deadbeats, dreamers — animate Madrid in “The Hive,” by the Nobel laureate Camilo José Cela.
lead_paragraph: There is a kind of unscrupulous writer well suited to tell a certain kind of story. Were Céline a man of greater probity, we’d know less about the Vichy government in exile. Curzio Malaparte’s bloodcurdling anecdotes about the Nazi war criminal Hans Frank came from sharing a dinner table with him, not to mention Malaparte’s own dalliances with Fascism.

headline: Need to Write Your Vows? A.I. Can Help.
abstract: Artificial intelligence is steadily becoming a trusty tool for composing wedding speeches. Should it be?
lead_paragraph: Josh Withers likes it when the couples he marries mess up their vows, such as when someone says, “I take you as my awfully wedded,” instead of the standard “lawfully wedded.”

headline: Why Do So Many Men Avoid Doctor’s Visits?
abstract: Experts share tips for getting over the resistance.
lead_paragraph: Last year, my husband Tom received this memorable text from his father: “FYI, getting brain surgery tomorrow. Don’t worry. I’ll be fine.”

headline: Margaret Atwood Is Still Sending Us Notes From the Future
abstract: Her new story collection, “Old Babes in the Wood,” offers elegiac scenes from a marriage plus a grab bag of curious fables.
lead_paragraph: There are authors we turn to because they can uncannily predict our future; there are authors we need for their skillful diagnosis of our present; and there are authors we love because they can explain our past. And then there are the outliers: those who gift us with timelines other than the one we’re stuck in, realities far from home. If anyone has proved, over the course of a long and wildly diverse career, that she can be all four, it’s Margaret Atwood.

headline: A Picaresque Silk Road Adventure About Storytelling Itself
abstract: In Daniel Nayeri’s new middle grade novel, a runaway orphan boy joins a caravan and falls under the sway of its loquacious leader.
lead_paragraph: Forget Botox, diets, oils, lotions. Humanity discovered the antidote to aging millenniums ago: storytelling. In the narrating and the hearing of a story, in the creating and the disseminating of a story (and, one hopes, in the reviewing), everyone is young again.

headline: With Indian Wells Days Away, Novak Djokovic Hopes for a Miracle
abstract: The world No. 1, Djokovic remains unvaccinated against Covid-19 and still cannot enter the United States without an exemption. He has asked for one and is awaiting an answer.
lead_paragraph: Novak Djokovic, last seen winning the Australian Open with a three-centimeter tear in his hamstring, has been back on the tennis court this week, steaming his way through the field at the Dubai Championships until Daniil Medvedev stopped him on Friday in the semifinals.

headline: Big Money, Big Houses and Big Problems in Brooklyn Heights
abstract: In Jenny Jackson’s debut novel, “Pineapple Street,” readers get a tour of a world they might learn not to envy by the end of the book.
lead_paragraph: A certain Great American Novelist known for writing about the very rich was of the opinion that they were different from you and me. They were, and a century later, they still are, and we still want to read about them, for reasons both obvious (mainly to do with schadenfreude) and less so (mainly because, at the end of the day, we may not be so different at all).

headline: New Condos and Old Townhouses Lead the Pack in February Sales
abstract: The priciest sale, at $33.8 million, was for a condo at 220 Central Park South, and a converted former firehouse sold for $25.5 million on East 90th Street.

headline: How to Keep Revenge Spending From Ruining Your Retirement
abstract: Once the worst of the pandemic passed, some of us turned from being savers to spenders — setting ourselves up for potential disaster.
lead_paragraph: In the first couple of months this year, thousands of American workers at companies like Google and Twitter have lost their jobs. Interest rates on car loans, credit cards and mortgages are higher than ever, and inflation keeps rising. And the talk of a recession in 2023 hasn’t gone away.

headline: Do Dining Sheds Still Make Sense?
abstract: They were crucial for restaurants and cooped-up New Yorkers during the pandemic. Now their usefulness is being debated.
lead_paragraph: When the city’s outdoor dining program began in the summer of 2020, it was rightly celebrated as salvation — keeping restaurants in business after months of forced closure and delivering to us a lost and desperately needed sociality. As the world opened up, however slowly and hesitantly, the program lost its glow in various quarters — particularly residential neighborhoods, where the experience was typified by too much noise and garbage and a Malthusian growth in the rat community. Complaints were made; petitions were signed; lawsuits were filed. Then in August, in a gesture of apparent compromise to the dissenters, Mayor Eric Adams announced an initiative after eating outside one night. The city had torn down 24 abandoned dining sheds — “eyesores,” he called them — belonging to restaurants that had shut down.

headline: Were These Photographs Voyeurism, or Art?
abstract: Arne Svenson’s window-peeping images of his neighbors from a decade ago are on view in Santa Monica. They are beautiful — and still unsettling.
lead_paragraph: When Arne Svenson’s photographic series “The Neighbors” was first exhibited in New York in 2013, the uproar overwhelmed the pictures. Press commentators got so riled up over how Svenson had used a telephoto lens to peer at the unaware people living across the street from his TriBeCa building — and published the images without their consent — that it was hard to judge how the photographs measured up artistically.

headline: Tips on Buying Tickets the Next Time Your Favorite Singer Is in Town
abstract: Our columnist thought she’d gotten a good deal on Bruce Springsteen tickets. But could she have gotten a better one? Here’s what she learned.
lead_paragraph: First: Hearing Bruce Springsteen live in concert last week was fantastic, and I’d buy tickets again.

headline: Defending Its Rankings, U.S. News Takes Aim at Top Law Schools
abstract: The publication accuses Yale and other schools of trying to evade accountability — and sidestep a likely end to affirmative action — by opting out of its ratings.
lead_paragraph: U.S. News & World Report said little last fall as Yale, Harvard and other elite law schools announced that they would no longer submit data to the publication’s rankings, charging that the influential list was an engine of inequality.

headline: The Truth About the ‘Censorship’ of Roald Dahl
abstract: The corporate context in which the changes were made is what should really worry us.
lead_paragraph: When it was reported last month that hundreds of words had been changed or removed in the most recent British editions of “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory,” “Matilda” and other books by Roald Dahl in an effort to make them less offensive, everyone from the queen consort and the British prime minister to the head of PEN America expressed outrage. Salman Rushdie referred to the edits as “censorship.”

headline: My Father’s Death, an Envelope of Cash, a Legacy in Music
abstract: When the pianist Adam Tendler received a strange and unexpected inheritance, he turned it into a project about remembrance and reconciliation.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: The Fastest Man in Baseball Says He Can Go Even Faster
abstract: Baseball wants more stolen bases, and Garrett Mitchell, a rookie outfielder for the Milwaukee Brewers, is happy to oblige.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — The fastest man in the major leagues sounded almost embarrassed. Yes, Garrett Mitchell, a rookie center fielder for the Milwaukee Brewers, had a home-to-first sprint speed of 4.01 seconds last season. Yes, that was the fastest time of more than 500 players tracked by Major League Baseball’s Statcast system.

headline: Why Alex Murdaugh’s Quick Conviction Worries Me
abstract: The case was built on a trove of digital data. Could the jury have given it due consideration in just three hours?
lead_paragraph: As I watched the gripping murder trial of the prominent South Carolina attorney Alex Murdaugh over the last few weeks, I found myself wrestling with difficult questions about how data from smartphones and other digital technologies should be relied upon in the criminal justice system. We are all being constantly and intimately tracked by our gadgets, but the voluminous records produced by these devices are not always easy to interpret.

headline: ‘Excuse After Excuse’: Black and Latino Developers Face Barriers to Success
abstract: A racial wealth gap and discrimination that sets a higher bar for would-be developers seeking loans have contributed to the lack of representation.
lead_paragraph: Out of roughly 112,000 real estate development companies in the United States, about 111,000 of them are white owned. Those numbers are bad, but at the top of the market, they’re even worse: Of 383 top-tier developers that generate more than $50 million in revenue annually, one is Latino; none is Black, according to a new report.

headline: Everyone Loves Flaco the Escaped Owl. But Why, Exactly?
abstract: Owls have beguiled humans forever. And it’s easy to see ourselves in a chubby little homebody who ditched his one-room apartment for the great outdoors.
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, there was an owl named Flaco who lived in a small zoo in the middle of a big park in America’s largest city. His story was a cliffhanger about escape and freedom and resilience.

headline: How Michael B. Jordan and Jonathan Majors Fought Harmoniously
abstract: One’s a big name, and one’s about to be. But to get along on ‘Creed III,’ they had to let go of ego and trust each other to pull no punches.
lead_paragraph: “Creed III” offers two well-matched face-offs — one onscreen, one off.

headline: Mutant, Parasitic Impostor Queens Lurk in Ant Colonies
abstract: Scientists isolated a “supergene” that seems to transform raider ants into freeloaders with attributes similar to queens found in other species.
lead_paragraph: To thrive, ant colonies rely on everyone pulling their weight. For raider ants, this means diligent scouts track down other nests, then direct hundreds of savage foragers to attack. They return with pincers gripping dead young ants to feed the settlement. Clones are produced. The colony thrives.

headline: How Great Art Gets Lost — and Found Again
abstract: The rediscovery of forgotten works always comes with the realization that they have been with us all along.
lead_paragraph: Every artist hopes for two things: that their work will be appreciated in their lifetime. And that it’ll endure after their death.

headline: Learning to Become a Better Grandfather
abstract: Without cultural norms to guide them, some men are forging a new grandparenting path.
lead_paragraph: When Ted Page became a grandfather in 2014, he wanted to hear other men’s stories, “real experiences that hopefully would guide newcomers,” he recalled.

headline: As A.I. Booms, Lawmakers Struggle to Understand the Technology
abstract: Tech innovations are again racing ahead of Washington’s ability to regulate them, lawmakers and A.I. experts said.
lead_paragraph: In recent weeks, two members of Congress have sounded the alarm over the dangers of artificial intelligence.

headline: They Sneaked Into a Derelict Arms Plant: Instagrammers or Spies?
abstract: Three people, including two Russians, arrested on charges of entering an abandoned rifle factory have puzzled Albanian authorities at a time when suspicions about Moscow have been mounting.
lead_paragraph: The three espionage suspects — two Russians and one Ukrainian — were hardly discreet.

headline: A Mad Dash as Commuters Deal With New L.I.R.R. Service
abstract: The railroad’s long-awaited expansion to the East Side of Manhattan has unexpectedly added travel time for some Brooklyn-bound commuters.
lead_paragraph: Shouts and expletives rang out at a station in Jamaica, Queens, on Thursday morning as commuters raced to catch connecting trains during the first week of a Long Island Rail Road schedule that has benefited some passengers but upended rush hour for those traveling to Brooklyn.

headline: The E.U. Offered to Embrace Ukraine, but Now What?
abstract: The European Union and NATO have promised a path to membership for the embattled country. But real partnership will hold risks and benefits for both sides.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — When the European Union offered Ukraine a path to membership last year, it was in many ways an emotional response to the Russian invasion. Leaders were under pressure to show solidarity with the victims of aggression, even though many opposed the idea.

headline: The Pilot or the Marine? Biden May Soon Announce His Pick for Top Officer.
abstract: Officials say the president’s list of candidates to replace Gen. Mark A. Milley is down to two names.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the battle to become the country’s most senior military officer — a position inhabited at the moment by one of the most voluble of men and a frequent target of the right — it has come down to a choice between the fighter pilot and the Marine infantryman.

headline: A Warning for the Newest Victims of Federal Neglect and Corporate Greed in Ohio
abstract: I grew up near a toxic disaster. The years ahead in East Palestine could be tough.
lead_paragraph: Dead birds still fall from the sky near my hometown. Their bodies hit the ground as part of the fallout of an environmental disaster that dates back to the 1970s, the result of corporate pollution that made the county I grew up in the home of one of Michigan’s most notorious Superfund sites.

headline: Building a New Canon of Black Literature
abstract: Which older novels, plays and poems by African American writers are being — or should be — rediscovered?
lead_paragraph: I FIRST HEARD the name J. California Cooper last November. Cooper, who died in 2014 at 82, was the author of five novels, seven short-story collections and 17 plays. Her books are folksy, funny and wise. They center on Black characters, most of them women. As Alice Walker, 79, who published Cooper’s debut collection of fiction, “A Piece of Mine” (1984), wrote, Cooper “reminds us of Langston Hughes and Zora Neale Hurston.”

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, March 3, 2023
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: Everyone Pivots to A.I., and Bad News for Crypto
abstract: Is crypto dead? Or only mostly dead?
lead_paragraph: Snapchat launches a chatbot. Meta plans to “turbocharge” its A.I. work. Elon Musk explores “BasedAI.” At this point, who isn’t making an A.I. play?

headline: Black Equestrians Want to Be Safe. But They Can’t Find Helmets.
abstract: For Black riders with natural hair, finding a helmet that fits can be virtually impossible. Some are trying to raise awareness of the problem, but manufacturers say it’s not a simple fix.
lead_paragraph: Chanel Robbins has been riding horses most of her life, ever since her grandmother traded a cow from their family’s farm in Ontario for a pony when she was 7.

headline: Rules to Curb Illicit Dollar Flows Create Unintended Hardships for Some Iraqis
abstract: The regulations were meant to prevent dollar transfers to corrupt actors. But they have ended up harming ordinary Iraqis who need U.S. currency for legitimate purposes.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — When the United States and Iraq recently put tough new international banking rules into effect, the intent was to stem the illicit flow of dollars to criminal actors and money launderers, including those helping groups in Iran and Syria.

headline: Paid Accounts on Facebook and Instagram Arrive in Australia
abstract: Users had mixed feelings about the new subscription service, which bestows exclusive features and a verification check mark.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, Meta, the parent company of Facebook and Instagram, announced a new service that would give users exclusive features and a coveted blue verification check mark.

headline: Why Russia Is Taking Thousands of Ukrainian Children
abstract: The story of one girl who ended up in a Russian foster family shows the damage done by this mass transfer, which is part of a vast propaganda campaign.
lead_paragraph: As Russian troops pushed into Ukraine, children who were fleeing newly occupied territories were swept up. Many became part of a Russian effort to portray itself as a charitable savior.

headline: The U.S. will send more ammunition to Ukraine.
abstract: The United States is set to send more aid to Ukraine, most of it ammunition for equipment such as HIMARS rocket launchers, before an anticipated Russian assault this spring.
lead_paragraph: The United States is set to send more aid to Ukraine, most of it ammunition for equipment such as HIMARS rocket launchers, before an anticipated Russian assault this spring.

headline: A New Child Care Requirement
abstract: A great idea — or a problem for semiconductor makers?
lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans work less than they used to, or not at all, because they can’t find someone to take care of their children. The lack of adequate child care not only keeps parents from trying to earn a paycheck but damages the economy overall. It’s one of the biggest reasons that American companies are struggling to find workers.

headline: Sci-Fi Style Comes Down to Earth
abstract: Rick Owens has become one of the greatest designers in Paris by building his own world. Construction continues at Givenchy while, at Schiaparelli, Daniel Roseberry lays a new ready-to-wear foundation.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Rick Owens, paramour of the strange and the so-called prince of the underground, can seem like he’s on another planet, but he may actually be the most relevant designer of the season.

headline: Gucci Gets Back in the Saddle
abstract: The fashion house revives an equestrian-inspired shoulder bag that debuted in 1981.
lead_paragraph: In the late 1800s, a teenage Guccio Gucci left Florence, Italy, and headed off to London, where he found work as a porter at the Savoy Hotel. Fascinated with the lifestyles of its international guests, he was inspired to inaugurate his own brand of leather travel goods. After apprenticing at the historic Milanese luggage manufacturer Franzi, he opened his first atelier in 1921 on Florence’s Via della Vigna Nuova, where he began making his own exquisite steamer trunks using Tuscan and imported leathers; he also designed walking sticks and umbrellas.

headline: China Increasingly Seen as Antagonist in Diplomatic Talks Around the World
abstract: Tensions over China arise in many gatherings of global leaders and diplomats, as Beijing increasingly plays a spoiler role, often siding with Russia.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — When the top diplomats of four major Asia-Pacific nations met here in the Indian capital on Friday to discuss issues in the region, one had a direct message for the behemoth whose shadow loomed over the talk.

headline: Why Lawmakers Aren’t Rushing to Police A.I.
abstract: Artificial intelligence tools are proliferating throughout society, and getting more powerful. Washington has failed to keep pace.
lead_paragraph: For corporate America, the biggest trend to latch onto at the moment is artificial intelligence, stoked by the popularity of ChatGPT. (Among the latest adopters is Instacart, which is building a ChatGPT-powered chatbot into its grocery-shopping app.) But worries about the dangers of widespread A.I. use are growing as well.

headline: Why Countries Are Trying to Ban TikTok
abstract: Governments have expressed concerns that TikTok, which is owned by the Chinese company ByteDance, may endanger sensitive user data.
lead_paragraph: In recent months, lawmakers in the United States, Europe and Canada have escalated efforts to restrict access to TikTok, the massively popular short-form video app that is owned by the Chinese company ByteDance, citing security threats.

headline: Best Places to Enjoy Art in California
abstract: Readers recommend their favorite museums and art destinations, including several hidden gems.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND — On a recent visit to the Oakland Museum of California, I marveled at a gargantuan oil painting of 1849 San Francisco, in which gold-rush arrivals rode horses down dirt roads and cooked over campfires in what would eventually become the heart of the city’s Financial District.

headline: Condemning Murdaugh’s ‘Lies,’ Judge Sentences Him to Life in Prison
abstract: The sentence was the maximum that the judge could hand down for the murders of Alex Murdaugh’s wife and son, given that prosecutors had not sought the death penalty.
lead_paragraph: WALTERBORO, S.C. — A judge sentenced Alex Murdaugh to life in prison on Friday for the murders of his wife and son, condemning the once-wealthy and influential Southern lawyer to spend the remainder of his life behind bars, a powerful rebuke from the rural South Carolina legal system that his family dominated for more than a century.

headline: ‘I Can’t Find My Child’: Agony as Search of Greek Train Crash Wraps Up
abstract: The authorities were planning to start clearing the debris after Greece’s deadliest rail disaster, with some relatives receiving confirmation that their loved ones had died, while others had to wait.
lead_paragraph: The fire service in Greece started winding down a gruesome search on Friday at the scene of the country’s deadliest train crash on record as the authorities informed the relatives of some victims identified by their DNA and other families desperately sought information about missing loved ones.

headline: Netflix’s ‘Drive To Survive’ remade Formula 1 for America
Liverpool, Napoli and the Problem With Systems
abstract: As system clubs start to falter, the future seems to belong to the teams and coaches who are willing to be a little more flexible.
lead_paragraph: There is no such thing as a 4-3-3. The same goes for all those pithy threads of numbers that are hard-wired into soccer’s vernacular, the communal, universal drop-down list of legitimate patterns in which a team might be arrayed: 3-5-2 and 4-2-3-1 and even the fabled, fading 4-4-2. They are familiar, reflexive. But none of them exist. Not really.

headline: The U.S. will send $400 million in new military aid to Ukraine, including precision-guided rockets.
abstract: Western leaders have warned of a looming artillery shortage for Ukraine as its troops burn through thousands of shells each day in trying to push back Russian forces.
lead_paragraph: The United States will rush more precision-guided rockets and additional ammunition to Ukraine to help resupply what officials have described as Kyiv’s dangerously low artillery stockpile.

headline: Alabama Mining Strike Ends Without a Deal After Nearly 2 Years
abstract: The strike at the Warrior Met Coal mine was one of the longest in U.S. history, but the price of coal soared during the walkout, giving the company leverage.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of coal miners in Alabama have been told by their union that they can start returning to work before a contract deal has been reached, bringing an unceremonious end to one of the longest mining strikes in U.S. history.

headline: For Sale: Memories From One of Hollywood’s Most Enduring Love Stories
abstract: More than 300 items that belonged to Paul Newman and Joanne Woodward will be sold in June in a series of auctions run by Sotheby’s in New York.
lead_paragraph: Shackles from the film “Cool Hand Luke”; a script from the 1963 comedy “A New Kind of Love”; the wedding dress that Joanne Woodward wore the day she married Paul Newman in 1958.

headline: Portraits of Elvis and Dreamlike Visions at the 31st Outsider Art Fair
abstract: Let our critic guide you through the bed rugs, the handmade playing cards and unexpected moments of beauty that stop you in your tracks.
lead_paragraph: The 31st annual Outsider Art Fair, which opened Thursday night at the Metropolitan Pavilion in the Chelsea neighborhood and runs through Sunday, is New York’s largest clearinghouse of work by self-taught and marginalized artists. In some respects it’s fairly constant. Major dealers like the Ricco/Maresca Gallery (Booth A11) of Manhattan and the Fleisher/Ollman Gallery (Booth A5) of Philadelphia tend to stick to the same large exhibition spaces, and you can always find work by mainstays of the “outsider” genre: Drawings by Bill Traylor, the formerly enslaved person who produced hundreds of unforgettable animal silhouettes in his 80s, and by Martín Ramírez, known for the tunnels and dreamlike cowboys he made in California mental institutions, are scattered all over the fair.

headline: Retelling the Story of Abstract Expressionism Through Women Artists
abstract: In London, a new exhibition highlights how the movement emerged across the world during the mid-twentieth century.
lead_paragraph: When the landmark Abstract Expressionism show “The New American Painting” arrived at London’s Tate gallery in 1959, it featured work by 17 artists: all of them American, and 16 of them men. Financed in part by the C.I.A. to promote liberty and independence as American ideals, the show toured throughout Europe.

headline: Can Patrick Kane Lift the Rangers as the N.H.L. Playoffs Loom?
abstract: The three-time Stanley Cup winner with Chicago desperately wanted a trade to New York. He got his wish, and will be tested Saturday when the Rangers play the Bruins, the N.H.L.’s top team.
lead_paragraph: The most stirring moments for Patrick Kane came in the pregame warm-up and player introductions, which is an indication of how things went on his first night playing for the Rangers. Kane skated onto the ice at Madison Square Garden about a half-hour before the opening face-off on Thursday, and fans greeted him with a standing ovation, holding up signs of appreciation and cheering his every move until he skated off.

headline: King Charles Will Travel to France and Germany for First State Visits
abstract: Britain’s new monarch and his wife, Camilla, the queen consort, will attend state banquets in Paris and Berlin later this month.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — King Charles III and Camilla, the queen consort, will travel to France and Germany this month, making their first state visits since Charles ascended to the throne in September, Buckingham Palace said on Friday.

headline: A Visit to One of the War’s Most Violent Front Lines
abstract: I recently traveled to the Donetsk region, where I got to know some of the soldiers. Here’s what they told me.
lead_paragraph: I recently traveled to the Donetsk region, where I got to know some of the soldiers. Here’s what they told me.

headline: The Power of Breath Work
abstract: Breathing correctly is a skill — and learning to control it can improve your health, mood and well-being. Here are a few simple exercises to help you get started.
lead_paragraph: Breathing correctly is a skill — and learning to control it can improve your health, mood and well-being. Here are a few simple exercises to help you get started.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Julia Moskin brings us four recipes for beef stew from across the globe.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Julia Moskin and I have been eating together, cooking together, hammering out sentences together and just generally marveling at the great caper of a life in journalism for the entirety of my adult life. I trust her taste and judgment and, always, her recipes.

headline: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks are all thrillers, with scares coming from a single-family cult, a monster drug deal and other weirdness.
lead_paragraph: The writer-director Corey Deshon wastes no time establishing the depraved scenario that fuels his slow-burn thriller. In the opening minutes, a man who goes by Father (Casper Van Dien, maniacal) bludgeons a woman to death on a desolate hillscape. Cut to Father taking a hood off a young woman (Vivien Ngo) whom he has kidnapped so that his son, known as Brother (Ian Alexander), can have a new “sister” to replace the one Father just killed.

headline: Lit Trivia: How Many Science Fiction and Fantasy Trilogies Do You Know?
abstract: There’s nothing like a good three-book series to get you deep into new worlds. Try this quiz to see how much you know about popular and recent literary trios.
lead_paragraph: There’s nothing like a good three-book series to get you deep into new worlds. Try this quiz to see how much you know about popular and recent literary trios.

headline: The media industry raced to capitalize on interest in the trial.
abstract: Every so often, a trial seems to captivate the nation. This year, it was the Alex Murdaugh murder case.
lead_paragraph: The media industry helped generate interest in the six-week murder trial of Alex Murdaugh, who was convicted Thursday evening of murdering his wife, Maggie, and their son, Paul.

headline: Amazon Pauses Work on 2nd Headquarters in Virginia
abstract: The delay is the latest reminder that the tech industry’s pandemic-fueled boom has slowed and another indicator of how remote work has changed office-space needs.
lead_paragraph: When Amazon said in 2018 that it planned to build a second headquarters in Virginia, along with a sister office complex in New York, it was a symbolic moment for the tech industry’s increasing importance to the American economy.

headline: What Phone and Other Data Showed About the Night of the Murders
abstract: Law enforcement officials built their double-murder case against Alex Murdaugh using a wealth of data to track his movements around the time of the killings.
lead_paragraph: As they built their case against Alex Murdaugh, law enforcement officials used a wealth of data to detail the key moments on the night his younger son, Paul Murdaugh, and his wife, Maggie Murdaugh, were murdered.

headline: The Coal Challenge
abstract: Relatively optimistic forecasts for global warming assume that developing countries will quit coal rapidly. South Africa’s case shows that it won’t be easy.
lead_paragraph: Getting rid of coal is often seen as the easier part of the global transition to renewable energy. Developed countries have made great strides in abandoning coal, and investors have long avoided it.

headline: In ‘A Spy Among Friends,’ B.F.F. Betrayal at an International Level
abstract: A twisty MGM+ series tells the story of Kim Philby, a British agent secretly working for the Soviet Union, and Nicholas Elliott, his closest friend.
lead_paragraph: “Why wasn’t he in custody?” asks the MI5 officer Lily Thomas. It is January 1963, and Thomas is talking about Kim Philby, a British intelligence agent who, after being exposed as a Soviet spy, has escaped to Moscow. Nicholas Elliott, Philby’s closest friend and a fellow member of the foreign intelligence agency MI6, looks slightly nonplused. “Well, that’s not how we —” he begins, before coming to an abrupt halt.

headline: Thai Hunger Strikers Calling for Changes to Monarchy Are at Risk of Dying
abstract: The two young women have not had food for 44 days, part of a campaign urging the government to repeal a law that criminalizes criticizing the royal family.
lead_paragraph: A stream of protesters outside the Supreme Court in Bangkok held up the three-fingered salute — a symbol of defiance against the government. “Fight, fight, fight,” they yelled to two young women who were taken out of a makeshift tent in stretchers, both so weak that they could not open their eyes.

headline: Tyre Nichols’s Photography Will Soar on Desert X Billboards
abstract: The outdoor art exhibition in California will feature six photographs that Nichols took in Memphis, where he was fatally beaten by police officers.
lead_paragraph: PALM SPRINGS, Calif. — Tyre Nichols, the 29-year-old Black man who died in January after a brutal beating by Memphis police officers, never had the chance to exhibit the photographs he took of his adopted hometown. But starting this weekend, a selection will appear on roadside billboards as part of the Desert X biennial — a highly adventurous and occasionally political art exhibition that can be viewed at outdoor sites across the Palm Springs area.

headline: Sharing It All After Baring It All
abstract: Known first as a provocative Instagram influencer and sex blogger, Eileen Kelly is now equally frank about her mental health struggles.
lead_paragraph: On a freezing January afternoon, the podcaster and influencer Eileen Kelly welcomed a reporter into her spacious Lower East Side loft. She was wearing her show’s merch — a sweatshirt emblazoned with the word “Prozac” (she also sells Wellbutrin and Lexapro versions). Glass vases on a nearby credenza held six dried bouquets, gifts from ex-boyfriends she has kept for years. Two red candles burned beside a tray of snacks.

headline: Review: The Philharmonic Departs From Business as Usual
abstract: “The March to Liberation” offers a rarity that should be more regular: a world premiere, a symphony and an oratorio, all by Black composers.
lead_paragraph: Gustavo Dudamel, recently named, to cheers, as the New York Philharmonic’s next music director, will arrive to lead the orchestra officially in 2026. But the time before then shouldn’t be thought of something to be endured or, at worst, a slog.

headline: A Battle Over Murals Depicting Slavery
abstract: Reaction to a dispute between an artist and a Vermont school. Also: Corporal punishment; Ron DeSantis; caregivers; the Colorado River; guns and crime.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Dasha Zhukova’s Artful Rise
abstract: The oligarch’s ex-wife had carefully built a place for herself in the art world. And then, Putin’s war started.
lead_paragraph: “If there’s one place in the world that’s fighting today for freedom and democracy, where people — men, women and children, everybody — are dying as we are having dinner right now, that is Ukraine,” chef José Andrés told a well-heeled crowd at the Museum of Modern Art in November, as he accepted an Innovator Award from the Wall Street Journal Magazine, a Ukrainian flag pin on his lapel. Attendees rose to their feet and broke into applause.

headline: ‘Women Talking’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: The screenwriter and director Sarah Polley narrates a sequence from her film.
lead_paragraph: The screenwriter and director Sarah Polley narrates a sequence from her film.

headline: How an Apology Creates a Turning Point in ‘Women Talking’
abstract: The screenwriter and director Sarah Polley narrates a sequence from her film, which is nominated for best picture and adapted screenplay.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: When Winter Meets Spring, It’s Time for These Vegetarian Soups
abstract: Parmesan cabbage, coconut curry sweet potato and a golden beet borscht: These three are heavy enough for a chilly day but light enough for spring.
lead_paragraph: Late last month in Prospect Park, I ran past a patch of purple crocuses practically glowing in the sun. March temperatures may slouch below freezing and snow may blanket the ground, but nothing can stop the lengthening days from enticing shoots from the soil and people’s moods out of their wintry doldrums. It can snow all it wants, but come the thaw those crocuses will still be fresh and upbeat.

headline: F.B.I. Queries for U.S. Messages Collected Without Warrants Are Said to Drop ‘Dramatically’
abstract: A report about a warrantless surveillance program detailed new limits imposed since 2021, but it did not provide a number for how often the F.B.I. searched it for Americans’ information in 2022.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — F.B.I. searches for Americans’ information that is collected using a high-profile surveillance tool have “dramatically decreased” since summer 2021, when the bureau overhauled its system after a judge accused it of widespread violations, according to a new government report.

headline: The Sordid Secrets of Cities
abstract: Machine politics, corruption and violence.
lead_paragraph: Two themes ran through my reader emails this week. The first is that many American subscribers wanted to know how they can watch the latest season of “Babylon Berlin.” If that’s you, then I’m sorry: Netflix hasn’t released it in the U.S. yet, (it’s already available online where I live), but my understanding is that the truly dedicated among you can order DVDs online.

headline: Nicki Minaj Returns Ready to Rumble, and 8 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Kali Uchis and Summer Walker, Arlo Parks, 6lack and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Shrimp Tacos to Make Right Now
abstract: Yewande Komolafe’s bright new recipe is the best possible counter to drab, gray days.
lead_paragraph: I’ve just returned to New York from sun-soaked Miami, where the gray weather is hovering somewhere between “meh” and “blah.” Reader, I’m over it. I’m ready for spring.

headline: New York Republicans Are on a Roll. So Why Can’t They Pick a Leader?
abstract: Although Republican victories in New York helped the G.O.P. take control of the House, the state party is torn over how closely to align itself with ex-President Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: The Republican Party in New York, fresh off one of its best elections in two decades, is somehow entangled in turmoil.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Jane Hirshfield
abstract: The Mar. 3, 2023 episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Jane Hirshfield. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: In the Toy Kitchen, Tacos, Lumpia and Charcuterie Are on the Menu
abstract: Food toys have evolved to reflect more diverse cuisines and up-to-date eating habits.
lead_paragraph: At home in Patterson, N.Y., Rebecca Rivera’s 6-year-old son, Sergio, likes to play chef with his stuffed animals. He feeds them sushi made of wood, and gives his favorite salmon nigiri pieces to Sonic the Hedgehog and Mario, his most beloved toys. Intrigued and inspired by his playtime, Sergio asked his mother if sushi was real — and if he could try it at a restaurant.

headline: Jesse Treviño, Chicano Artist Whose Muse Was San Antonio, Dies at 76
abstract: After losing his dominant right hand from a Vietnam War injury, he began chronicling Mexican American culture with his left.
lead_paragraph: Jesse Treviño, a lauded Mexican American artist who lost the use of his dominant right arm in a land mine explosion as a soldier in the Vietnam War, but who went on to conjure vast murals and dramatic paintings with his left arm that were displayed in three presidential libraries and the Smithsonian Institution, died on Feb. 13 in San Antonio. He was 76.

headline: Love Letter: ‘Maybe It Was a Bit Weird’
abstract: On their second date, he gave her his only olive.
lead_paragraph: After their first date, the olive fell from his tree.

headline: In Chernobyl’s Stray Dogs, Scientists Look for Genetic Effects of Radiation
abstract: A new study is the first step in an effort to understand how exposure to chronic, low-level radiation has affected the area’s dogs.
lead_paragraph: After the disaster at the nuclear power plant in Chernobyl, Ukraine, in 1986, local residents were forced to permanently evacuate, leaving behind their homes and, in some cases, their pets. Concerned that these abandoned animals might spread disease or contaminate humans, officials tried to exterminate them.

headline: Nobel Prize Is No Defense Against Jail for a Winner in Belarus
abstract: Ales Bialiatski, last year’s Nobel Peace Prize laureate, has been sentenced by Belarus to 10 years in prison, on charges that rights advocates have dismissed as politically motivated.
lead_paragraph: Unsettled by the war in neighboring Ukraine and the increasing militancy of some opposition groups, Belarus on Friday sentenced Ales Bialiatski — a veteran human rights activist who was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in October — to 10 years in prison, according to Viasna, the group that he helped found.

headline: Wonking Out: Peering Through the Fog of Inflation
abstract: If you aren’t feeling a bit lost, you aren’t paying attention.
lead_paragraph: Economists have been arguing fiercely about inflation for around two years now, and that’s fine.

headline: The Democrats’ SOS Candidate Keeps His Options Open
abstract: Gov. J.B. Pritzker of Illinois has maintained his political organization, built a progressive record and is open about his ambitions. For now, he says, they don’t include the White House.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Gov. J.B. Pritzker of Illinois sat comfortably in an office board room high above the Loop on Monday and halfheartedly batted away the notion that he was preparing a run for the White House.

headline: Can We Fire Our Employee? His Father Just Died.
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on what employers owe their workers.
lead_paragraph: We have an employee we would like to have fired months ago because of his lack of reliability and poor work ethic. He has been with our company for almost a decade — since he graduated from college — but his productivity and commitment have been declining for a long time. We knew his father was dying of cancer and therefore decided not to fire him during this difficult period. The problems with his work ethic, however, long predated that illness. His father has now died. How long do we need to wait before we can let him go?

headline: What a Visit to Disney World Reveals About America
abstract: Politics, decadence and pantheism in the Magic Kingdom.
lead_paragraph: Walt Disney World is back in the culture-war news this week, thanks to Gov. Ron DeSantis’s appointment of a new board, filled with his ideological allies, to oversee infrastructure in Disney’s Florida real estate empire. As it happens, I’m now a certified expert on Disney World, as my wife and I recently took our children there for the first time, and let me tell you, there’s a lot to say about the place. Our several days there were intense enough that I could probably get multiple newsletters out of the experience, but I’ll just try to cram a bunch of ideas into this one, much the way I packed my kids into roller coaster cars and sent them hurtling away.

headline: A Year Into War, Russian Artists Still Must Navigate a Tricky Path
abstract: A production of “War and Peace” in Germany, with a heavily Russian cast and production team, must balance competing demands brought on by the invasion of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: A production of Prokofiev’s “War and Peace” that opens this weekend at the Bayerische Staatsoper was never supposed to be this contentious.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week
abstract: The late-night hosts had their hands full this week with the annual Conservative Political Action Conference and Rupert Murdoch admitting that Fox News hosts endorsed lies about the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: The late-night hosts had their hands full this week with the annual Conservative Political Action Conference and Rupert Murdoch admitting that Fox News hosts endorsed lies about the 2020 election.

headline: Why the Student Debt Pause Became a Political Trap
abstract: Debtors have gotten out of the habit of making monthly payments.
lead_paragraph: You lend a friend $1,000 and tell him to pay you back when he gets back on his feet. Of course, he says. A year goes by, then two, then three. He seems to be back on his feet, but the money isn’t back in your pocket. And now if you ask what happened to your thousand bucks, you seem like the bad guy.

headline: The U.S. attorney general meets with Zelensky during a surprise visit to Ukraine.
abstract: A major topic of talks was how to hold Russia accountable for any war crimes committed over the past year.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland made an unannounced visit to Ukraine on Friday to reaffirm America’s commitment to help hold Russia responsible for war crimes, a Justice Department spokeswoman said.

headline: Conservative Media Pay Little Attention to Revelations About Fox News
abstract: Even in today’s highly partisan media world, experts said, the lack of coverage about the private comments of Fox’s top executives and hosts stands out.
lead_paragraph: Fox News and its sister network, Fox Business, have avoided the story. Newsmax and One America News, Fox’s rivals on the right, have steered clear, too. So have a constellation of right-wing websites and podcasts.

headline: Lawmakers Clamor for Action on Child Migrant Labor as Outrage Grows
abstract: Members of Congress are pressing for changes to the law and the Biden administration’s approach as federal and state enforcement agencies begin a crackdown on companies that employ underage migrants.
lead_paragraph: Members of Congress are pressing for stricter laws to prevent and penalize the use of child labor and tougher vetting by the Biden administration of adults who take custody of unaccompanied migrant children, as revelations about the exploitation of underage migrants by employers have prompted outrage among policymakers.

headline: Revisiting ‘Wisconsin Death Trip,’ 50 Years Later
abstract: The Times’s critic Dwight Garner looks back on Michael Lesy’s cult classic of documentary literature, which was first published in 1973.
lead_paragraph: It’s been 50 years since Michael Lesy’s influential cult classic “Wisconsin Death Trip” was published. A documentary text of found material, the book gathered prosaic historical photos of Wisconsin residents from the turn of the 20th century and paired them to haunting effect with fragmentary newspaper archives from the same time period reporting on often garish deaths — what our critic Dwight Garner, evaluating the book for its anniversary, called “horrific local news items that point, page by page, toward spiritual catastrophe. Nearly every person in it looks as if they are about to be struck by lightning.”

headline: ‘Hercules’ Review: An Underpowered Hero in a Far From Perfect Package
abstract: A new production of the Disney musical at the Paper Mill Playhouse falls short of inspiring awe.
lead_paragraph: It always puzzled me why it’s taken so long for “Hercules,” arguably Disney’s most Broadway-ready animated film musical, to get a proper staging. Sure, it’s got lightning-hurling gods and thunderous titans running amok, but if the omnipotent entertainment company can make nannies and carpets fly onstage, it can certainly find a way to bring to life the myth of Zeus’ mortal son, whose daring deeds, its song “Zero to Hero” goes, make great the-a-ter.

headline: Justin O. Schmidt, Entomologist Known as ‘King of Sting,’ Dies at 75
abstract: Studying the venom of bees, wasps and ants, he was stung hundreds of times and famously ranked the stings in a colorful pain scale index.
lead_paragraph: Justin O. Schmidt, an intrepid entomologist who measured the agony of insect stings by allowing himself to be stung hundreds of times in creating a renowned and vividly descriptive pain scale that ranked them, died on Feb. 18 in Tucson, Ariz. He was 75.

headline: Biden’s World Bank Pick Looks to Link Climate and Development Goals
abstract: Ajay Banga will begin a monthlong “global listening tour” to drum up support for his nomination to be the bank’s next president.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration’s nominee to be the next president of the World Bank, the international development and climate institution, is embarking on a monthlong sprint around the globe to solidify support for his candidacy.

headline: Lesion Removed During Biden’s Physical Was Cancerous
abstract: President Biden’s physician said that the lesion was basal cell carcinoma, a common and relatively unaggressive form of skin cancer, and that no further treatment was needed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden had a cancerous lesion removed from his chest during his physical last month, the president’s doctor said Friday.

headline: Have a Question About Preparing for the Next Pandemic? Ask the Experts.
abstract: Times Opinion wants to address your questions about pandemic preparedness.
lead_paragraph: Three years after our lives were upturned by the Covid-19 pandemic, questions remain. What have we learned? What about our leaders and policymakers? What happens next time?

headline: Biden and Scholz Vow to Work Together to Support Ukraine
abstract: During a meeting with the German chancellor, Olaf Scholz, President Biden said the two countries had worked in “lockstep” to provide aid to Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: During a meeting with the German chancellor, Olaf Scholz, President Biden said the two countries had worked in “lockstep” to provide aid to Ukraine.

headline: Tesla Could Start Making Cars in Mexico Next Year, Governor Says
abstract: The governor of Nuevo León said a Tesla official had told him that the company’s plant there would be among its biggest and go up in record time.
lead_paragraph: Tesla’s new factory in the Mexican state of Nuevo León will cost $5 billion, will employ up to 7,000 people and could start churning out cars as early as next year, the state’s governor said on Friday.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: The Hotel Pennsylvania’s disappearing act. Also in this edition: 36 hours in Rio de Janeiro and why everyone loves Flaco the escaped owl.
lead_paragraph: The Hotel Pennsylvania’s disappearing act. Also in this edition: 36 hours in Rio de Janeiro and why everyone loves Flaco the escaped owl.

headline: Biden Awards Medal of Honor to Black Vietnam Veteran
abstract: Col. Paris Davis’s nomination in 1965, for saving three teammates while injured in battle, hit a wall. It was revived in recent years.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nearly 60 years after one of the first Black officers in the Special Forces was nominated — and then overlooked — for the nation’s highest military honor, President Biden on Friday awarded the Medal of Honor to that officer, Col. Paris Davis, for exemplifying “everything our nation is at our best.”

headline: The Steak House With N.F.L. Deals on the Menu
abstract: When the N.F.L.’s power brokers meet at St. Elmo Steak House in Indianapolis, trades, contracts and shrimp cocktail are all on the table.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — A waiter led Thomas Dimitroff past the tightly spaced wooden tables and around a corner to a table on the first floor of St. Elmo Steak House. Dimitroff, a former general manager of the Atlanta Falcons, looked around in bewilderment as he pulled his chair in.

headline: Former Army Private Sentenced to 45 Years in Neo-Nazi Plot to Kill Soldiers
abstract: Prosecutors said he planned an attack on his own U.S. Army unit, sharing sensitive details about it with a white supremacist, neo-Nazi and pro-jihadist group.
lead_paragraph: A former U.S. Army private was sentenced on Friday to 45 years in prison after he pleaded guilty last year to charges that he had shared sensitive information with a Satanist neo-Nazi group in a plot to kill members of his own unit while they were serving overseas, federal prosecutors said.

headline: Bernadette Carey Smith, Black Reporter in Mostly White Newsrooms, Dies at 83
abstract: She was one of the first Black female journalists at The New York Times and The Washington Post. The Times put her on the staff of a women’s news section.
lead_paragraph: Bernadette Carey Smith, who in the 1960s was one of the first Black women to be hired as a reporter at The New York Times and The Washington Post, died on Dec. 5 at an assisted living complex in Tuckahoe, N.Y. She was 83.

headline: ‘1 + 1’ Review: She Just Wants to Be His Plaything
abstract: Stale views of gender dynamics power Eric Bogosian’s play about an aspiring actress caught in the clutches of a duplicitous man.
lead_paragraph: The actor and playwright Eric Bogosian blazed a career on Off Broadway stages in the 1980s and ’90s by mucking around in mankind’s basest instincts. In plays like the 1988 Pulitzer Prize finalist “Talk Radio,” about a self-destructive shock jock, and in monologue collections including “Drinking in America,” Bogosian dared audiences to face the darkest recesses of masculinity even as he compelled them to recoil. But his latest play is more likely to induce a cringe.

headline: Walgreens Says It Won’t Offer the Abortion Pill Mifepristone in 21 States
abstract: The decision applies to conservative states whose attorneys general threatened Walgreens and other pharmacies with legal action if they dispensed the pill there.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks after Republican attorneys general in 21 states sent letters threatening legal action against retail pharmacy chains if they dispensed the abortion pill mifepristone, Walgreens said it would not distribute the pill in those states.

headline: Republicans Use Arcane Political Tactic to Thwart Democrats
abstract: The party has used resolutions of disapproval to confound President Biden and Democrats, forcing them to make tough decisions and debate issues they would prefer to avoid.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republicans have settled on their procedural weapon of choice for this Congress — and they have it trained squarely on Democrats anxious about their 2024 prospects.

headline: ‘The Holly’ Review: The Tragic Case of a Denver Activist
abstract: Julian Rubinstein’s investigative documentary traces the engrossing case of a Denver community organizer, Terrance Roberts, who faced charges of attempted murder
lead_paragraph: At the point where Julian Rubinstein’s investigative documentary “The Holly” begins, an entire biopic’s worth of drama has already happened. After years in gangs and prison, Terrance Roberts became an activist and founded a successful youth program to rejuvenate a troubled Denver neighborhood known as the Holly. Then, in 2013, while organizing a peace rally in the area, he shot a gang member he knew, and was arrested and charged with attempted murder.

headline: Black Vietnam Veteran Is Awarded Medal of Honor
abstract: President Biden awarded the Medal of Honor to Col. Paris Davis, who saved three fellow soldiers in the midst of battle after sustaining multiple gun shot injuries.
lead_paragraph: President Biden awarded the Medal of Honor to Col. Paris Davis, who saved three fellow soldiers in the midst of battle after sustaining multiple gun shot injuries.

headline: What Parents Should Know About Bacteria and Breast Pumps
abstract: Federal health officials are reminding parents of infants to properly sterilize breast pump equipment after a baby died last year from a rare bacterial infection.
lead_paragraph: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention issued a new report this week urging parents and caregivers to carefully clean and sanitize breast pump equipment, after an infant died last year from a rare bacterial infection linked to a contaminated breast pump.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Staten Island Man Sentenced to 18 Months in Prison for Attacks on Jews
abstract: Saadah Masoud wanted to punish supporters of Israel, prosecutors said. His assaults came amid a rising wave of antisemitism in the United States.
lead_paragraph: In spring 2021, Saadah Masoud traveled to a pro-Israel rally in Manhattan, asked a man wearing a necklace with a large Star of David whether he was Jewish and then punched him in the face.

headline: In Rare Conviction, Contractor Is Held Liable in Construction Death
abstract: The homicide conviction came nearly five years after a worker was crushed to death by 15,000 pounds of building materials at a Brooklyn construction site.
lead_paragraph: Nearly five years after a construction worker was crushed to death by 15,000 pounds of building materials at a work site in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, the contractor who oversaw the site was found guilty Thursday of homicide, in a rare instance of a construction company being held criminally liable in the death of a laborer.

headline: Rafael Viñoly, Global Architect of Landmark Buildings, Dies at 78
abstract: Uruguayan-born and New York-based, he was responsible for major commercial and cultural buildings in nearly a dozen countries.
lead_paragraph: Rafael Viñoly, a Uruguayan-born architect whose New York-based firm, founded in 1983, was responsible for major commercial and cultural buildings in nearly a dozen countries, died on Thursday at a hospital in Manhattan. He was 78.

headline: Stranded in California’s Heavy Snow
abstract: Back-to-back storms left many people stuck as snow piled high. More is still in the forecast.
lead_paragraph: Record snowfall and freezing temperatures have altered the landscape and lives of millions of people in California in recent weeks. The mountains behind the iconic Hollywood sign in Los Angeles are dusted in white. Yosemite National Park is closed to the public, and mountain roads are coated with black ice.

headline: Steve Mackey, a Mainstay of the Britpop Band Pulp, Dies at 56
abstract: Shortly after he joined that long-running group in 1987, it rose from obscurity to chart-topping success in what came to be called the Cool Britannia era.
lead_paragraph: Steve Mackey, the lauded bassist, songwriter and producer who made his name laying down dance-floor-friendly grooves for the British band Pulp during its 1990s pinnacle, as it transformed itself from a little-known art-rock collective to a festival-headlining Britpop powerhouse, died on Thursday. He was 56.

headline: As Ukraine Clings to Bakhmut, What’s Its Strategy and What’s at Stake?
abstract: Ukraine is determined to hold the eastern city as long as it can. How high a price is it willing to pay? What might force its withdrawal? And what would a retreat look like — and mean?
lead_paragraph: The commander of Ukraine’s ground forces visited soldiers in Bakhmut for the second time in less than a week on Friday, a reflection of the precarious position Ukrainian forces find themselves in as they cling to their positions in the battered city.

headline: Severe Storm Pummels U.S. South
abstract: A powerful storm system unleashed strong winds, tornadoes and heavy rain across the South.
lead_paragraph: A powerful storm system unleashed strong winds, tornadoes and heavy rain across the South.

headline: Fatal Overdoses of 2 Who Died After Leaving Gay Bars Are Ruled Homicides
abstract: The New York City medical examiner’s findings came about a year after one of the victims was found abandoned in the back of a taxi.
lead_paragraph: The fatal overdoses of two men who died and were robbed after leaving gay bars in Manhattan last year were ruled homicides on Friday by the New York City medical examiner’s office.

headline: Pierre Apraxine, 88, Assembler of a Remarkable Trove of Photos, Dies
abstract: Working with a paper magnate (and without a budget), he helped put together a collection that transformed the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s photography department.
lead_paragraph: Pierre Apraxine, a courtly, self-taught connoisseur of photography who helped build one of the greatest private holdings of pictures, the Gilman Paper Company Collection, which vaulted the Metropolitan Museum of Art to the forefront of photography institutions when it acquired the archive in 2005, died on Feb. 26 at his home in Manhattan. He was 88.

headline: Biden Meets With German Chancellor Amid Concerns Over Ukraine and China
abstract: President Biden said he and Germany’s chancellor, Olaf Scholz, would work in “lock step” to provide military support to Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden and Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany on Friday showed a united front on the war in Ukraine, vowing to keep Western support intact amid mounting concerns that China could move to supply weapons to Moscow.

headline: The Quest to Restore Notre Dame’s Glorious Sound
abstract: In Paris, experts are modeling ways to revive the burned cathedral’s centuries-old acoustics. A Times interactive shows how space can affect what we hear.
lead_paragraph: In Paris, experts are modeling ways to revive the burned cathedral’s centuries-old acoustics. A Times interactive shows how space can affect what we hear.

headline: In Southern California, Snow Has Trapped People for Days
abstract: A week of intense snowfall in the San Bernardino Mountains has left residents and tourists rationing food and pleading for help.
lead_paragraph: John Radleigh thought he was ready for the snowstorm that pounded the mountains in Southern California for a week. A general contractor who has lived for more than five decades in Lake Arrowhead, a vacation hamlet, he had a backup generator and gas for his snowblower. He had enough food to hunker down with his family and chains for his car tires.

headline: Pennsylvania Airport Closed After Suspicious Package Is Found in Checked Bag
abstract: The terminal at University Park Airport in State College, Pa., was evacuated on Friday night. Officials later said that there was nothing hazardous inside the bag.
lead_paragraph: A small airport in Pennsylvania was closed on Friday night after a suspicious package was detected in checked luggage on a flight bound for Chicago.

headline: All Over the Board
abstract: Ryan McCarty’s Saturday puzzle brings the smoke.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is Ryan McCarty’s 20th Saturday construction for The Times. As always, it’s smooth and full of artful deception and interesting trivia. I had the most trouble with the eastern third of the grid, where every entry to the right of 22-Down was hard fought and befuddling at first. More than one entry took extra thought even after every letter had been filled in, and one three-letter entry took a Google search — but it turned into something interesting, so no hard feelings.

headline: Tom Sizemore, Intense Actor With a Troubled Life, Dies at 61
abstract: He earned praise for his work in films like “Saving Private Ryan” and “Black Hawk Down.” He also served prison time for drug possession and domestic abuse.
lead_paragraph: Tom Sizemore, a tough-guy actor whose career, which included roles in major films like “Saving Private Ryan” and “Black Hawk Down,” was overshadowed at times by his problems with substance abuse and the law, died on Friday in Burbank, Calif. He was 61.

headline: How Xi Jinping Plans to Bolster Confidence in China After Covid Missteps
abstract: When its top legislature meets, Beijing will lay out a vision for reviving economic growth and strengthening the Communist Party’s grip after a chaotic reopening.
lead_paragraph: China’s leaders are set to use a gathering of the top legislature starting Sunday to outline plans to restore public confidence and bolster economic growth after a year of uncertainty, disruption and discontent around the government’s Covid restrictions.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Amazon Pauses Work on Campus in Virginia
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, March 4, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “Events really did change. We did have a pandemic, remote work became a thing. But I think this is yet another cautionary tale, perhaps the ultimate cautionary tale, of not betting a whole community on a company.”

headline: Corrections: March 4, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, March 4, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about a report by House Democrats detailing interviews and statements from three witnesses testifying before the Select Subcommittee on the Weaponization of the Federal Government referred imprecisely to the relationship between the Center for Renewing America and the Conservative Partnership Institute. The center is affiliated with the institute and sustained mostly by donations; it is not largely funded by the institute.

headline: Woman Arrested After Three Children Are Killed in Texas
abstract: The killings happened on Friday in Italy, Texas, after a caseworker visited the home and ordered that the children be removed, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A woman has been arrested in connection with the killings of three children, including 5-year-old twins, and injuring two others on Friday in Texas, the authorities said, after a Child Protective Services caseworker visited the home and ordered that the children be removed.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Retailers Lay Out a Downbeat Outlook as Inflation Squeezes Low-Income Shoppers
abstract: Despite better-than-expected earnings, retail executives predict that any sales growth will be much smaller than in years past.
lead_paragraph: As many of America’s best-known retailers reported better-than-expected quarterly earnings this week, buoyed by shoppers who continued to spend through stubbornly high inflation, they all seemed to arrive at the same conclusion: Conditions are about to get much, much worse.

headline: A Times TV Critic Feels Authenticity Is His Top Responsibility
abstract: James Poniewozik, chief TV critic at The Times, explains why HBO’s zombie series “The Last of Us” intrigued him and reveals why he avoids ‘self-editing.’
lead_paragraph: Which television show does James Poniewozik watch for leisure? Lately, the competition reality series “Survivor.”

headline: Your Pristine Hermès Bag, to Some, Looks Tacky
abstract: As a growing resale market has made the brand’s handbags available to more people, some say the image that they convey depends on their condition.
lead_paragraph: Jenny Walton had coveted an Hermès bag for years before finally buying one last fall.

headline: Diplomat Who Faced Brexit Freeze in U.K. Now Sees a ‘New Beginning’
abstract: As the European Union’s first ambassador in London, João Vale de Almeida had to fight even for official recognition. Prime Minister Rishi Sunak and the Windsor Framework are changing things, he says.
lead_paragraph: As the European Union’s ambassador to London, João Vale de Almeida had a ringside seat for the chaos overwhelming British politics last year, when all eyes were on the missteps, scandals and resulting downfalls of two prime ministers in quick succession.

headline: The Woman Shaking Up Italian Politics (No, Not the New Prime Minister)
abstract: Daughter of Italian and Jewish American parents, Elly Schlein wants to remake the center-left opposition to Giorgia Meloni, if only her party can survive it.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Growing up in Switzerland, Elly Schlein felt a little lost.

headline: Migrants’ Shipwreck Near Italy Claimed a Pro Athlete From Pakistan
abstract: Shahida Raza, a national soccer and field hockey player, wanted her disabled son to have a better life. The boat carrying her to Italy crashed just off the coast.
lead_paragraph: Shahida Raza played on Pakistan’s national soccer and field hockey teams, but her athletic prowess did not make her rich or allow her to emigrate to Europe legally.

headline: Nontraditional Runners Are Finding Their Stride Online
abstract: When local clubs don’t feel welcoming, recreational runners of various races, life stages and speeds are creating their own communities. The internet is helping them widen their reach.
lead_paragraph: New York is a diverse city, but when Maria Solis Belizaire started running in 2016, she didn’t see that reflected in the running community there.

headline: Are Butterflies Wildlife? Depends Where You Live.
abstract: A legal quirk leaves officials in at least a dozen states with little or no authority to protect insects. That’s a growing problem for humans.
lead_paragraph: A legal quirk leaves officials in at least a dozen states with little or no authority to protect insects. That’s a growing problem for humans.

headline: Your Boss’s Bathrobe Is Not Office Attire
abstract: Even at a start-up, even while waiting for a new office, you should not have to put up with working from the corporate HQ that is the boss’s kitchen.
lead_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

headline: It’s Not Over Until the Country Music Star Says So
abstract: In her second novel, “The Farewell Tour,” Stephanie Clifford follows a veteran singer who’s wrapping up a long career on her own terms.
lead_paragraph: “The Farewell Tour,” by Stephanie Clifford, is the story of Lillian Waters, a fictional country music singer in the vein of Dolly Parton and Loretta Lynn. I loved Clifford’s debut novel, “Everybody Rise,” a vibrant explosion of a book set among graduates of elite prep schools in 2006 Manhattan, so I was eager to follow Clifford into the world of what one character calls “hillbilly music.”

headline: Is the Entire Economy Gentrifying?
abstract: Companies are trying to maintain fat profits as the economy changes, making “premiumization” their new favorite buzzword.
lead_paragraph: Big companies are prodding their customers toward fancier, and often pricier, versions of everything from Krispy Kreme doughnuts to cans of WD-40.

headline: Time Is No Longer on Their Side
abstract: Fans are eager to start the pitch-clock era, but baseball’s pitching coaches are hard at work trying to adjust to one of the biggest changes in M.L.B. history.
lead_paragraph: For the past 150 years, baseball has sold the timeless nature of the sport. How long will today’s game take? However long it takes. But recently, the caretakers of the sport at its highest level — Major League Baseball — have seemed to fret that their game might need saving.

headline: On Wall St., ‘Socially Responsible’ Is Common Sense. In Congress, It’s Political.
abstract: Lawmakers are trying to restrict these investment choices in workplace retirement plans, but big fund managers are trying to give shareholders a voice.
lead_paragraph: A deeply rooted approach to investing and social action is taking its lumps.

headline: Dunk Was Chunky, but Still Deadly
abstract: A fossil fish called Dunkleosteus was less svelte shark and more rotund tuna, but that only made it a fiercer predator in the seas of the Devonian Period.
lead_paragraph: With a bite that could split a shark in two and an armored mug only a mother could love, Dunkleosteus was one of Earth’s earliest apex predators, terrorizing subtropical seas 360 million years ago during the Devonian Period. By some estimates, the monster fish measured as long as a school bus.

headline: ‘My Love, You Can Do This’: A Dangerous Journey in a Quest for a Better Life
abstract: It doesn’t have to be this way.
lead_paragraph: On a cold night in late February, a group of Venezuelan migrants huddled for warmth near a dumpster in the middle of nowhere, just a few hours outside Mexico City. They were waiting for “La Bestia,” the freight train migrants use to get from southern Mexico to the United States border.

headline: Remember Pamela Smart? ‘To Die For’ Convict Now Seeks Mercy.
abstract: The woman who became a national sensation in 1990 after her teenage lover killed her husband has become a prison preacher. She hopes New Hampshire will set her free.
lead_paragraph: Pamela Smart hung up her green prison uniform jacket and walked down a hallway as fellow inmates swept the floor around her. A gold cross hung from her neck representing the Christian faith she credits with helping her survive what she calls her “sentence of extermination” — life without parole.

headline: How the Fall of Roe Turned North Carolina Into an Abortion Destination
abstract: The state, which is near others with abortion bans and restrictions, has had a 37 percent rise in abortions since the constitutional right to abortion was overturned.
lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — Clinic by clinic, county by county and up to the highest levels of state government, no state embodies the nation’s post-Roe upheaval like North Carolina.

headline: Time Has Been Codified and Commodified. Jenny Odell Wants to Set It Free.
abstract: First Jenny Odell examined our obsession with productivity. Now she’s turned to our relationship with time — and what happens when you remove the grid.
lead_paragraph: For many people locked away during the pandemic in the summer of 2020, time felt different. Gummy and unfamiliar, it lacked the usual signposts of a commute, a day in the office, time in a classroom. A single day, or just an hour, felt like it could go on forever.

headline: A New Front Line in the Debate Over Policing: A Forest Near Atlanta
abstract: Six weeks after a protester was shot and killed, officials are bracing for more confrontations with activists seeking to stop a police and fire training center.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — When construction crews rolled into a patch of pine and maple trees southeast of Atlanta last month, the scene had more in common with a military incursion than a municipal building project in the suburbs. Police officers in armored trucks escorted construction workers as they cleared a pathway for heavy equipment and installed anti-erosion fences.

headline: How a Makeup Artist Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Originally from Milan, Angie Valentino honors her Italian heritage with flair in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Eight years ago, Angie Valentino, an award-winning makeup artist, moved from Milan — where she worked for brands like Fendi, Versace, Dolce & Gabbana and Philipp Plein — to New York. Since then, she has focused on private clients around the city, including Broadway and television performers. Ms. Valentino, 37, lives in Ridgewood, Queens.

headline: ‘Dilbert’ Is Canceled but Cubicle Comedians Live On
abstract: They weren’t fans of the comic strip, which was recently dropped from hundreds of newspapers, but their work builds on the office grind as comic premise.
lead_paragraph: Nothing about work is funny. Except when everything about work is funny.

headline: In West Bank, New Armed Groups Emerge, and Dormant Ones Stir
abstract: The small but influential Lions’ Den network has attracted young Palestinians disappointed by their leaders and angry at Israeli violence. Veteran fighters are restless, too.
lead_paragraph: After a violent uprising by Palestinians against Israel subsided nearly two decades ago, Abu Abdallah, then a leader of a Palestinian militia, stashed away his assault rifle and later became a civil servant in the West Bank city of Nablus.

headline: They Shared Erotic Images in a Group Chat. The Fine: $17,000.
abstract: A couple in Singapore created a Telegram account where they posted risqué content for subscribers. They were convicted of violating nudity and obscenity laws.
lead_paragraph: The video shows the woman in a spaghetti strap top and very short shorts strolling outside a mall in central Singapore. She looks around to make sure no one can see her. Then she pulls down her top, revealing a breast to her partner, who is filming her.

headline: Could the Next Great Author Be a Robot? We Asked (Human) Writers.
abstract: At the PEN America Literary Awards, David Sedaris, Judith Thurman and others discussed the role A.I. could play in literature.
