lead_paragraph: The Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant in southern Ukraine briefly moved to emergency generators on Thursday after Russian shelling cut its external power supply, prompting the top director of the United Nations’ nuclear watchdog to disparage the international community for failing to secure the complex.

headline: Shooting in Germany Leaves Several Dead
abstract: A police spokesman said there were no indications that a shooter remained at large in the attack, on a Jehovah’s Witness hall in Hamburg.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Several people were killed and several more were injured in a shooting in a Jehovah’s Witness hall in Hamburg, Germany, on Thursday night, in a rare mass shooting in the country.

headline: What Is a Blackout Rage Gallon
abstract: Many college students seem to love this alcohol-heavy concoction. College officials, not so much.
lead_paragraph: Before you ask, BORG — which is pronounced like the aliens from “Star Trek” — is an acronym for “blackout rage gallon.” The drink going by this name is a mixture of water, alcohol, sweet flavorings and some hangover remedy, like Liquid I.V. or Pedialyte.

headline: 12 Fashion Week Moments That Kept Us Talking
abstract: Including frog clogs, denim scraps, robot dogs and scented dresses.
lead_paragraph: Fashion weeks have been happening around the world for almost two straight months. They started with the men’s wear shows in January, which were followed by the couture shows, which were followed by the four consecutive fashion weeks in New York, London, Milan and Paris. (Somehow, Copenhagen managed to squeeze in its fashion week during this time, too.)

headline: Prosecutors Signal Criminal Charges for Trump Are Likely
abstract: The former president was told that he could appear before a Manhattan grand jury next week if he wishes to testify, a strong indication that an indictment could soon follow.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates on Donald Trump’s indictment.

headline: ‘65’ Review: What on Earth?
abstract: Millions of years ago, a guy from another planet landed on this one. Like most survivors, he had a moody little girl with him.
lead_paragraph: To paraphrase an old Monty Python sketch, nobody suspects the Cretaceous-Tertiary Extinction.

headline: F.D.A. Will Require Dense Breast Disclosure at Mammogram Clinics
abstract: The U.S. agency wants to ensure that doctors inform women that some breast anomalies require more examination.
lead_paragraph: In a long-awaited ruling, the Food and Drug Administration recommended on Thursday that all mammogram centers must tell women if they have dense breasts that could put them at increased risk for breast cancer.

headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.

headline: Honduras Lifts Longtime Ban on ‘Morning After’ Pills
abstract: President Xiomara Castro signed an executive order on Wednesday, lifting a 2009 ban on emergency contraceptive pills.
lead_paragraph: President Xiomara Castro of Honduras signed an executive order on Wednesday that lifted a longtime ban on emergency contraceptive pills, delivering on a campaign promise for a policy change that was sought by feminist groups for years.

headline: Men Found in Mexico With a Note Blaming Them for Attack on Americans
abstract: The note, which was purportedly written by a powerful drug cartel, apologized for the attack last week that left three people dead, and offered up five men it said were responsible.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Five men, lying face down with their hands tied, were found by the Mexican authorities on Thursday along with a letter purportedly written by a powerful criminal cartel, blaming the men for a recent attack on four Americans, according to two people familiar with the investigation.

headline: Captain America
abstract: When Mike Trout agreed to play in the World Baseball Classic, other stars flocked to join the United States squad. “I want in.”
lead_paragraph: TEMPE, Ariz. — Few people in baseball could tease Mike Trout about an unmet expectation. Tony Reagins, who drafted him for the Los Angeles Angels, has dared to try.

headline: Budget Wars: This Time Is Different
abstract: Biden is making sense. Republicans aren’t.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday the White House released its latest budget; Republicans haven’t offered a specific counterproposal, but they seem to be coalescing around a plan released by Russell Vought, Donald Trump’s last budget director. Neither plan will become law. Instead, they’re intended to position the two sides for the looming confrontation over the federal debt ceiling.

headline: The Self-Destructive Effects of Progressive Sadness
abstract: The recent emotional storm did nobody any good.
lead_paragraph: One well-established finding of social science research is that conservatives report being happier than liberals. Over the years, researchers have come up with a bunch of theories to explain this phenomenon.

headline: Biden Moves to Recapture the Centrist Identity That Has Long Defined Him
abstract: After two years championing progressive priorities, the president is speaking more to the concerns of the political middle as he prepares to announce a campaign for a second term.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In his announcement video kicking off his presidential campaign in the spring of 2019, Joseph R. Biden Jr. never mentioned the word “deficit.” Nor did the word escape his lips when he accepted the Democratic Party nomination a year later. Nor did it appear once in the party platform he approved.

headline: Russia Blasts Ukrainian Cities, Including Biggest Use of Advanced Missiles
abstract: Of 81 missiles fired, six were hypersonic weapons, among Russia’s newest and most advanced, which are all but impossible to shoot down.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Russia launched its biggest aerial barrage in weeks on Thursday, blasting targets across Ukraine with a diverse array of weapons, including its newest hypersonic missiles, in what it said was retaliation for an armed incursion into Russian territory last week.

headline: Shawn Kemp, Former N.B.A. Star, Released From Jail After Shooting
abstract: Mr. Kemp was arrested following reports of a shooting in a parking lot. Prosecutors decided not to file charges on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The retired N.B.A. star Shawn Kemp was released from jail on Thursday after prosecutors decided not to pursue immediate charges against him in connection with a shooting.

headline: Before Another Storm in the Tahoe Region, a Race to Clear Snow From Roofs
abstract: The one-two punch of heavy snow and rain poses a unique threat in an area beleaguered by precipitation.
lead_paragraph: TRUCKEE, Calif. — With an atmospheric river bearing down on California, Mike Culp climbed to the roof of his two-story home in the Lake Tahoe region to start shoveling off snow.

headline: What Tucker Carlson Really Thinks
abstract: It is not what he says when he’s on the air.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday evening, two news reports caught my attention. The first was an Emerson College poll of Republican primary voters in New Hampshire. Donald Trump holds an incredible 41-point lead over Ron DeSantis in the state that rescued Trump’s primary campaign after a second-place finish in Iowa in 2016. This result is in line with a series of national polls that also show Trump with a large lead over DeSantis. Trump is still the favorite to win the G.O.P. nomination. Any other conclusion at this early date is wishful thinking.

headline: In Louisville, Federal Report on Abusive Policing Comes as No Surprise
abstract: Many Black residents were skeptical that policing would improve because of the report, which found many instances of discriminatory behavior and civil rights violations.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — When the Justice Department announced this week that its investigation into the Louisville Metro Police Department had revealed a pattern of abusive and discriminatory behavior, Attorney General Merrick B. Garland summarized the findings as “heartbreaking.” The city’s mayor, Craig Greenberg, called the police tactics described in the report a “betrayal” as he promised change.

headline: Saudi Arabia Offers Its Price to Normalize Relations With Israel
abstract: The Saudi crown prince is seeking a civilian nuclear program and security assurances from President Biden, a steep price for an agreement long sought by Israel.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Saudi Arabia is seeking security guarantees from the United States, help with developing a civilian nuclear program and fewer restrictions on U.S. arms sales as its price for normalizing relations with Israel, people familiar with the exchanges say.

headline: Corrections: March 10, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, March 10, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about protests in Georgia against so-called foreign agents legislation misstated the given name of a former United States ambassador to Ukraine. He is John Herbst, not Robert.

headline: Kansas Coach Bill Self to Miss Big 12 Tournament With Health Issue
abstract: Self, 60, is being treated at a hospital for an illness, the school said. An assistant will lead Kansas, the reigning Division I champion that is once again at the top of the sport.
lead_paragraph: Coach Bill Self of Kansas, the reigning Division I men’s basketball champion and a top team this season, will miss the remainder of the Big 12 Conference’s tournament for health reasons, the university announced Thursday.

headline: Robert Blake, ‘Baretta’ Star Acquitted in Wife’s Murder, Dies at 89
abstract: His film and TV career began with “Our Gang” comedies and was highlighted by his performance as a killer in “In Cold Blood.” But he led a tempestuous life.
lead_paragraph: Robert Blake, an actor whose career portraying gritty characters like the television detective Tony Baretta was eclipsed by his trial and acquittal in the murder of his wife in 2001, died on Thursday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 89.

headline: ‘Dark Disabled Stories’ Review: When the World Isn’t Built for You
abstract: Ryan J. Haddad’s gracefully layered play about the lives of disabled people blasts away condescension and replaces it with comprehension.
lead_paragraph: Near the start of “Dark Disabled Stories,” the playwright-performer Ryan J. Haddad’s richly provocative new show at the Public Theater, he tells a funny, sexy anecdote about a hookup at a gay bar that didn’t go the way he’d hoped.

headline: Review: Jessica Chastain Plots an Escape From ‘A Doll’s House’
abstract: Jamie Lloyd’s compelling, surgically precise revival of Ibsen’s 1879 drama throbs like an episode of “CSI: Norway.”
lead_paragraph: Many plays end with a breathtaking coup, but Jamie Lloyd’s incisive Broadway revival of “A Doll’s House,” which opened on Thursday at the Hudson Theater, also begins with one. After all, it’s not every day you find Jessica Chastain rotating on a turntable like an angry bird in a giant cuckoo clock.

headline: Silicon Valley Bank’s Financial Stability Worries Investors
abstract: The bank, a linchpin of tech industry financing, is trying to persuade clients not to pull their money over concerns of a liquidity crisis.
lead_paragraph: Panic swept through the start-up industry on Thursday as investors at some venture capital firms urged portfolio companies to move their money from Silicon Valley Bank over concerns about the tech industry stalwart’s financial stability.

headline: Residents Fret Over Deaths in Southern California Mountains
abstract: Relatives and neighbors described heartbreaking ends for some of those who died during heavy snowstorms northeast of Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: The power had been out for a week with snow to the rafters in Crestline when the neighbors found 93-year-old Elinor “Dolly” Avenatti bundled up in a chair in front of her fireplace, which had gone cold. Barbie Hughes, 39, the clerk at the local hardware store, was hit by a vehicle on a dark, snow-covered road just after midnight near Big Bear Lake; she died at the hospital.

headline: Oregon Man Pleads Guilty in Woman’s Murder at Protest in Portland
abstract: Benjamin Smith, 44, aggressively approached a group of people attending a protest against police killings last year and shot at them, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A man who fatally shot a woman and injured four others last year at a protest against police killings in Portland, Ore., pleaded guilty on Wednesday to second-degree murder and other charges, the authorities said.

headline: Former Fox Employee Convicted of Bribery for Soccer Broadcast Deals
abstract: The employee, Hernán López, and an Argentine marketing firm were accused of helping make illegal payments for rights to tournaments in South America.
lead_paragraph: After hearing seven weeks of often-impenetrable testimony about television contracts, codes of ethics and the interpretation of Spanish phrases in emails sent more than a dozen years ago, a federal jury in Brooklyn on Thursday convicted a former Fox employee and an Argentine sports marketing firm of paying bribes in exchange for lucrative soccer broadcasting contracts.

headline: Xi Seals His Political Supremacy, Focusing on Economy and U.S. Rivalry
abstract: The Communist Party-controlled legislature endorsed Xi Jinping for an unprecedented third term as China’s president in a ritual ballot, cementing his dominance.
lead_paragraph: Xi Jinping solidified his status as China’s most powerful leader in decades by sweeping into a new term as president on Friday, as he steels the country for an era of superpower rivalry and seeks to revive a battered economy.

headline: Out of Control
abstract: Claire Rimkus offers up a fantastic puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Republicans Open Inquiry Into Treatment of Jan. 6 Defendants at D.C. Jail
abstract: House Republicans demanded answers about whether Jan. 6 prisoners were mistreated, part of a broader effort by the G.O.P. to rewrite the history of the riot.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Republicans on Thursday began their promised investigation into whether people charged with crimes in connection with the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol have been mistreated in jail, fulfilling a pledge G.O.P. leaders made to their right flank.

headline: Why China Is Tightening Its Oversight of Banking and Tech
abstract: A series of regulatory changes approved this week reflect the increasingly centralized control of Xi Jinping, newly confirmed for a third term as China’s president.
lead_paragraph: A real estate market that is threatening the financial system and holding back the economy. A tech industry that is being targeted by aggressive U.S. efforts to cut it off from the world. Tech companies that are trying to keep pace with fast-moving developments in artificial intelligence.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon change phases.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — Today’s passage is from “Welcome to the Universe,” by Neil deGrasse Tyson, Michael A. Strauss and J. Richard Gott, a 2016 book that has expanded into a variety of manuals and guides, on paper and multimedia. I remember reading the book when it came out and it really expanded my consciousness at the time. One of my favorite lines is featured in the book’s digital presentation: “When you are born, you become a citizen of the universe.”

headline: Quotation of the Day: After Derailment, Health Fears in an Ohio Town
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, March 10, 2023.

abstract: Use these maps to follow the storm’s forecast and impact.
lead_paragraph: Use these maps to follow the storm’s forecast and impact.

headline: Inside the ‘Top Chef’ Industrial Complex
abstract: Entering its 20th season, the sprawling Bravo franchise has changed the way Americans eat and become a mirror of the restaurant industry.
lead_paragraph: Buddha Lo was in real trouble.

headline: Former Ohio Legislator Found Guilty of Racketeering in $60 Million Scheme
abstract: Larry Householder, a former Ohio House speaker, and Matthew Borges, a former chairman of the Ohio Republican Party, were found guilty in a conspiracy that dated back to 2017, the Justice Department said.
lead_paragraph: A former Ohio House of Representatives speaker was found guilty on Thursday by a federal jury of participating in a racketeering conspiracy that involved nearly $61 million in bribes and a $1.3 billion bailout for two struggling nuclear power plants, the authorities said.

headline: A More Secure Future, Courtesy of a Green Card
abstract: The connection that Kirsten Erwin and Ricardo Kozuchowicz had when they first met was quickly overshadowed by his struggles to remain in the country.
lead_paragraph: Kirsten Paige Erwin said she felt an immediate sense of calm on her first date with Ricardo Kozuchowicz in March 2017.

headline: First, Dating Websites, Then an Assist From Destiny
abstract: Khushboo Chaudhary and Param Gupta chose to cancel their 300-person wedding in favor of a more intimate Indian wedding.
lead_paragraph: Khushboo Chaudhary was just stopping by a friend’s party in the East Village in March 2019 when she spotted Param Gupta, the man she had been talking with on Hinge.

headline: They Met the Day the World Shut Down
abstract: Courtney Smith and Andrew Fede had their first date on March 13, 2020. Lockdown eventually led to a lifetime commitment.
lead_paragraph: When Courtney Mashaye Smith told Andrew Jordan Fede that he seemed like someone who would be in business for himself, he felt seen in a way he had never experienced.

headline: Why Russia Has Such a Strong Grip on Europe’s Nuclear Power
abstract: New energy sources to replace oil and natural gas have been easier to find than kicking the dependency on Rosatom, the state-owned nuclear superstore.
lead_paragraph: The pinched cylinders of Russian-built nuclear power plants that dot Europe’s landscape are visible reminders of the crucial role that Russia still plays in the continent’s energy supply.

headline: In Dubai, a Wedding Steeped in Palestinian and Moroccan Culture
abstract: Nora Achmaoui and Khalid Alherani met on Instagram. One month later, they started a TikTok account that now has 1.3 million followers.
lead_paragraph: Nora Achmaoui made the first move on Khalid Alherani in September 2021 in typical Gen Z fashion: She liked two of his pictures on Instagram after finding his profile on her explore page.

headline: Different Visions for New York Herald Clash of Mayor and Council Speaker
abstract: The mayor wants tougher policing, while Adrienne Adams, the City Council speaker, wants to close Rikers. Also, a man is freed after 18 years in prison for a crime he didn’t commit.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at the different visions held by two powerful local elected officials, Mayor Eric Adams and the speaker of the City Council, Adrienne Adams. We’ll also find out how the wrong photo figured in the arrest and second-degree murder conviction of the wrong man in Brooklyn, and we’ll meet the new president of Barnard College.

headline: China Appoints Li Qiang, a Xi Loyalist, as Premier
abstract: The former Communist Party leader of Shanghai and now occupying the No. 2 spot, Mr. Li is among the men who will be leading the nation for the next five years.
lead_paragraph: Li Qiang, a longtime ally of China’s top leader and the man who oversaw last year’s bruising two-month Covid lockdown of Shanghai, was formally appointed the country’s premier on Saturday. He will face the challenge of trying to revive the economy, which is languishing from three years of Covid restrictions.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: The toll of Russia’s Thursday morning assault on Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: At least 10 people were killed yesterday after Russia launched its biggest aerial attack in weeks, hitting targets across the country with weapons including its newest hypersonic missiles, which can travel five times the speed of sound. The strikes knocked out power in several areas and damaged three electrical plants, Ukrainian officials said.

headline: The leaders of Britain and France met in Paris with Ukraine on the agenda.
abstract: The leaders of Britain and France, two of Ukraine’s biggest allies, were meeting in Paris on Friday to discuss issues including weapons and other support for Ukraine the day after Russia blasted Ukraine with advanced missiles.
lead_paragraph: The leaders of Britain and France, two of Ukraine’s biggest allies, were meeting in Paris on Friday to discuss issues including weapons and other support for Ukraine the day after Russia blasted Ukraine with advanced missiles.

headline: Stephen Colbert Is Not Paying $99 for Trump’s New Book
abstract: “Yes, it sounds expensive, but how should he know?” the “Late Show” host said. “He’s never bought a book.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Legacy of Australia’s Immigration Policies Haunts Survivors and Supporters
abstract: The country’s grueling detention programs have ensnared thousands — and appear to flout international law.
lead_paragraph: Last year, my colleague Yan Zhuang reported on a group of men who had been abruptly relocated to a motel in Melbourne after almost a decade of being detained in camps offshore. They had originally come to Australia seeking asylum.

headline: Robot Snakes
abstract: What do you think this image is communicating?
lead_paragraph: What do you think this illustration is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Investigating Hollywood’s ‘Fixer’
abstract: A Times documentary team interviewed Anthony Pellicano, a former private investigator who solved the problems of the rich and powerful through whatever means necessary.
lead_paragraph: Living in Los Angeles two decades ago, I had seen the headlines about Anthony Pellicano, the notorious private investigator who had defended people accused of rape, tapped phone lines, bribed police officers and was linked to a threat against a reporter in which a dead fish was left on her car.

headline: ‘Chang Can Dunk’ Review: That’s a Man’s Jam
abstract: A short teen channels his inner Kobe Bryant in this exhilarating, warmhearted Disney+ basketball comedy.
lead_paragraph: “Chang Can Dunk,” a funny and thoughtful high school comedy streaming on Disney+, exists at the intersection between jockdom and nerdery: If you know both the approximate value of a mint-condition Charizard Pokémon card and how to identify a pair of Nike Bruce Lee Kobe 5 Protos on sight, you’re sure to feel on solid footing.

headline: What Old Technology Do You Think Is Cool?
abstract: Point-and-shoot digital cameras are hot again. What retro tech do you love?
lead_paragraph: Do you think “old” technology is cool?

headline: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: This week's roundup includes “Checkout 19,” by Claire-Louise Bennett, Stewart O'Nan's "Ocean State" and much more.
lead_paragraph: This week's roundup includes “Checkout 19,” by Claire-Louise Bennett, Stewart O'Nan's "Ocean State" and much more.

headline: At This Year’s Oscars, Two Films Hit All ‘Four Quadrants’
abstract: In 1998, two seemingly unrelated things happened in the film business. More than 57 million people — a record number — watched the Academy Awards, and later that year the term “four-quadrant” movie appeared for the first time in Hollywood trade newspapers.
lead_paragraph: In 1998, two seemingly unrelated things happened in the film business. More than 57 million people — a record number — watched the Academy Awards, and later that year the term “four-quadrant” movie appeared for the first time in Hollywood trade newspapers.

abstract: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of "A Doll's House," starring Jessica Chastain.
lead_paragraph: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of "A Doll's House," starring Jessica Chastain.

headline: The Men — and Boys — Are Not Alright
abstract: Richard Reeves breaks down the evidence that many American males are falling behind in education, employment and health.
lead_paragraph: In 1972, when Congress passed Title IX to tackle gender equity in education, men were 13 percentage points more likely to hold bachelor’s degrees than women; today women are 15 points more likely to do so than men. The median real hourly wage for working men is lower today than it was in the 1970s. And men account for almost three out of four “deaths of despair,” from overdose or suicide.

headline: How 31 Presidential Budgets Compared With Reality
abstract: For all the toil that goes into them, the budgets very rarely correlate with the trajectory of federal spending, revenue or the deficit.
lead_paragraph: For all the toil that goes into them, the budgets very rarely correlate with the trajectory of federal spending, revenue or the deficit.

headline: My Year of Talking About Porn
abstract: How did I end up in the living room of an octogenarian, talking about the Kama Sutra? Let me explain.
lead_paragraph: “And did the topic of female masturbation ever come up, in those conversations with your friends?”

headline: A Representative Goes to A.I. School, and How to Ban TikTok
abstract: Also, how Waluigi may explain why A.I. chatbots are misbehaving.
lead_paragraph: Representative Don Beyer thinks artificial intelligence is “the most amazing technology since fire.” So what does it mean that most of Congress seems not to understand it? Then our colleague David McCabe discusses a bill that could dramatically expand the Biden administration’s power to ban TikTok.

headline: Digestion, Love and Medical Bills: 12 Health Podcasts Worth Listening To
abstract: Here are a dozen delightful and informative suggestions.
lead_paragraph: I try to take a long walk every day, but sometimes I need to bribe myself a little. Getting absorbed in a good podcast encourages me to stay out for longer stretches.

headline: A Knitwear Sensation at 83
abstract: How Delia Barry, the octogenarian who knitted Colin Farrell’s cozy “Banshees of Inisherin” sweaters, became an internet star.
lead_paragraph: When I first contacted Delia Barry, she asked to be called back later. It was a Wednesday afternoon in Greystones, Ireland, where she lives, and she was playing bingo. “It’s just more of a social gathering for local senior citizens, which I am one of,” Ms. Barry, 83, said by telephone.

headline: Help! I Canceled My Rental Because of a Wildfire. My Contract Says No Refund. Is That Fair?
abstract: A reader has been offered a credit she is finding hard to use. Who should bear the financial burden in a case of force majeure? Our columnist weighs the competing claims.
lead_paragraph: I booked a house on Lake Tahoe through Vrbo for my family to attend a wedding in September 2021. About two weeks before the wedding, we saw on the news that the Caldor wildfire had impacted the region, causing evacuations and blocked roads and filling the air with heavy smoke. Our group included young children, those with asthma and the elderly, for whom this environment would be a serious health risk. I canceled with Vrbo, but they would not refund me, offering me a credit toward a future rental through Evolve, the property manager, valid for two years. Evolve has significantly fewer listings than Vrbo, and I’ve been unable to find a satisfactory substitute anywhere on the California, Oregon or Washington coasts, for a visit with my son in Dillon, Colo., or to see family near Boston. With the deadline approaching, I feel like I’m being forced into a vacation I don’t want to take in a place I don’t want to go, and I want a refund. Can you help? Sally, Seattle

headline: Team Israel Leans In on Its David and Goliath Story
abstract: Israel’s World Baseball Classic roster is stacked with American major leaguers connecting with their Jewish heritage. In a tough group, they are still underdogs.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli national baseball team was the darling of the 2017 World Baseball Classic. Israel won its first four games at that tournament, with three notable upsets, and advanced to the second round. A documentary detailed the players’ memorable journey and a stuffed mascot — the Mensch on a Bench — gained worldwide fame.

headline: ‘I Don’t Know Why He’s Not More Famous.’ Meet the Man Republicans Can’t Get Enough Of.
abstract: A cult hero to young conservatives, hippie back-to-the-landers and marginalized environmentalists alike, Thomas Massie could shape the future of the GOP.
lead_paragraph: The self-proclaimed “greenest member” of Congress is a Republican from rural Kentucky. He lives in an off-the-grid home he built himself, using timbers cut and rock quarried from his family cattle farm. He pipes in water from a nearby pond, and powers the home with solar panels and a battery from a wrecked Tesla that he salvaged and retrofitted.

headline: Missing From Biden’s Budget: His Plan for Social Security
abstract: Like the president’s previous budgets, his latest proposal made no mention of any tax or spending increases linked to the program, which he had promised to shore up during his 2020 campaign.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden campaigned for the White House on a plan to shore up Social Security’s finances over the coming decades and increase benefits for the lowest-earning retirees, all by raising taxes on people earning more than $400,000 a year.

headline: A Colorado Ski Area With No Lift Lines? This One Has No Lifts at All.
abstract: At Bluebird Backcountry, you can feel the thrill of making fresh tracks without the constant fear of avalanches. And you can bring your dog.
lead_paragraph: I was breathing hard by the time I reached the 9,845-foot peak of Bear Mountain, and it wasn’t just because of the altitude. I had skied all the way up.

headline: When Cancer Upends Your Sex Life
abstract: Despite a wave of new research around cancer treatment and sexual health, women say their issues are still being dismissed. Here’s how and where to get help.
lead_paragraph: Débora Lindley López was 28 when she was diagnosed with Stage 3 breast cancer. Within three weeks, she began chemotherapy and was thrust into medically induced menopause. Ms. Lindley López developed vaginal dryness so severe that her skin began to deteriorate and was covered in small, paper cut-like tears. Urinating was uncomfortable; sex, agonizing.

headline: A Bank Failure Jolts Markets, Sending Stocks Down Sharply
abstract: The collapse of Silicon Valley Bank added to worries about the economy. The S&P 500 suffered its sharpest weekly decline of the year.
lead_paragraph: The collapse of a small bank in California on Friday set off a wave of concern over the health of the banking sector, amplifying fears for the broader economy and sending global stock markets lower.

headline: The Right’s Obsession With Wokeness Is a Sign of Weakness
abstract: Without a clear purpose, conservatives are desperate for a unifying enemy.
lead_paragraph: Leonard Leo, a leader of the right-wing Federalist Society, an extraordinarily effective legal organization, is broadening his ambitions. Leo is hoping to transform American culture the way he transformed the judiciary. In the words of an investigative report produced by ProPublica and Documented, he aims to build a sort of “Federalist Society for everything,” devoted to helping reactionaries consolidate power in realms like Wall Street, Silicon Valley, journalism, Hollywood and academia.

headline: More Retiree Health Plans Move Away From Traditional Medicare
abstract: Retirees whose former employers offer health coverage are being shifted to privately run Medicare Advantage, often against their wishes. The change saves millions for employers.
lead_paragraph: Bob Bentkowski, a retired New York City firefighter, has a rare, painful disease that caused his kidneys to swell almost to the size of basketballs. He needed a transplant, and in the fall of 2021, he found a donor after waiting for years — but he was unsure whether Medicare would cover his surgery.

headline: U.S. Employers Keep Hiring, but Signs of Easing Are Seen
abstract: The economy added 311,000 jobs in February despite higher interest rates. But hourly earnings rose more slowly as the pool of available workers grew.
lead_paragraph: The labor market continued its energetic expansion in February, extending a hotter-than-expected streak that has created abundant job opportunities while frustrating the Federal Reserve in its drive to contain stubborn inflation.

headline: Here’s Why the Science Is Clear That Masks Work
abstract: A respected science organization says its review of studies about respiratory viruses was misinterpreted to incorrectly claim masks were useless.
lead_paragraph: The debate over masks’ effectiveness in fighting the spread of the coronavirus intensified recently when a respected scientific nonprofit said its review of studies assessing measures to impede the spread of viral illnesses found it was “uncertain whether wearing masks or N95/P2 respirators helps to slow the spread of respiratory viruses.”

headline: Biden and E.U. Leader Seek Common Ground on Trade and Ukraine
abstract: President Biden and the European Commission president met to discuss how to effectively counter Russia and a potential trade deal for electric vehicles.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden and Ursula von der Leyen, the president of the European Commission, opened negotiations on Friday over the critical minerals used in electric vehicles amid concerns of a potential trade war triggered by the Biden administration’s signature clean energy legislation.

headline: What We Know About the Indictment of Donald Trump, and What Comes Next
abstract: Mr. Trump was indicted over his role in paying hush money to a porn star, and likely plans to turn himself in on Tuesday, a lawyer has said.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates on Donald Trump’s indictment.

headline: ‘Frankenstein’ Apartments and Weak Libraries: Is This New York’s Future?
abstract: After surviving the worst of the pandemic, the city now faces budget cuts that seem to promise even more disruption.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday afternoon, a number of local politicians and tenants’ groups came together in the East Village to draw attention to a practice known as “Frankensteining,” which, in the context of New York City’s housing crisis, has emerged as a newly born grotesquerie. The term refers to a loophole in an otherwise tenant-friendly 2019 law that allows landlords to circumvent rent regulations by reconfiguring an apartment — chopping it up or combining it with a second one or simply expanding it through the addition of hallway or other appropriated common space.

headline: What I Found When I Looked Into the Fate of Anna May Wong, a Hollywood Star
abstract: This year the Oscars are celebrating an unprecedented number of Asian artists. The recognition is long overdue.
lead_paragraph: As a mixed Asian kid growing up in the suburbs of Southern California in the 1990s, I was always searching television and movies for people who looked like me. Every glimpse of, say, Margaret Cho doing stand-up or BD Wong on “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” felt like an all-too-rare cause for celebration.

headline: Teens Are Stealing More Cars. They Learn How on Social Media.
abstract: Violent crime is largely receding from pandemic highs, but cities face a surge in car thefts, driven in part by videos that show how to hot-wire models by Kia and Hyundai.
lead_paragraph: One of the busiest places in Memphis these days is the impound lot north of downtown, where tow-truck drivers can sit in line for over six hours to make drop-offs, victims can wait weeks to get stolen vehicles back and some 2,700 cars are squeezed onto the grounds of an old farm-equipment factory.

headline: No Rest Between Censuses for Congressional Mapmakers
abstract: What used to be a once-a-decade redistricting fight between political parties is now in perpetual motion, and up to 29 seats in 14 states are already at risk of being redrawn.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For just about all of the nation’s history, politicians would fight over redistricting for a short period after each once-a-decade census, then forget about congressional maps until the next reapportionment.

headline: In ‘Scream VI,’ Ghostface Takes the 1 Train
abstract: In turning the subway into a vehicle of horror, the movie gets a number of things right — and a few wrong. But verisimilitude wasn’t the filmmakers’ main goal.
lead_paragraph: When Jason Voorhees took Manhattan, he rode the subway. Walter Hill’s gang members in “The Warriors” prowled the M.T.A. Now, Ghostface is riding the 1 train.

headline: How to Read the Oscars Red Carpet
abstract: Tracking the history of moviedom’s biggest night, a new book examines the glamour, societal changes and bloopers embodied in 95 years of step-and-repeat.
lead_paragraph: In a curious way, the Oscars are the culture’s yearbook. For nearly a century, the class heroes have annually paraded in front of the cameras for us to measure and judge, giving us an unexpected snapshot of shifts in our mores and expectations. And one of the delights of paging through Dijanna Mulhearn’s “Red Carpet Oscars,” an impressively researched and organized new book, with a foreword by Cate Blanchett, is how clearly it outlines both the evolution of the Academy Awards through clothing and an immutable truth about dress.

headline: The Social Rifts That Led to Israel’s Judicial Crisis
abstract: Israeli society is locked in a deep dispute over the future of its judiciary and democracy. The conflict is rooted in shifts of the last three decades.
lead_paragraph: When Israeli lawmakers passed a law in 1992 that would give judges the power to block future legislation, an argument broke out on the floor of Parliament that foreshadowed the fight over the judiciary that is engulfing Israel today.

headline: A Designer’s Home on Central Park, Where the Views Dictate the Décor
abstract: Adrienne Vittadini is known for her use of bold colors, often several at once. But not in her Fifth Avenue apartment, which is listed at $7.5 million.
lead_paragraph: Adrienne Vittadini was known for her signature bold colors and prints in the clothing and accessories she designed, but when it came to her sprawling Upper East Side home, a more neutral palette prevailed.

headline: Out-of-Towners Head to ‘Climate-Proof Duluth’
abstract: The former industrial town in Minnesota is coming to terms with its status as a refuge for people moving from across the country because of climate change.
lead_paragraph: DULUTH, Minn. — Surfing in Minnesota is just like surfing in Southern California, John Jenkins says, as long as you ignore the icicles on your wet suit.

headline: Composers Find Transcendence, and Inspiration, at the Club
abstract: The storied Berlin techno club Berghain has changed the way some composers think about and make music.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — In 2018, after a visit to Berghain, the storied techno club here, the saxophonist and curator Ryan Muncy called the composer Ash Fure, a friend and collaborator.

headline: What’s Holding Up New York’s Climate Progress? Apartment Buildings.
abstract: Many New York apartment buildings have less than a year to get in line with an ambitious climate mandate, or risk facing millions of dollars in penalties.
lead_paragraph: Craig Hart is troubled by a multimillion-dollar puzzle: How to get his condo building to conform with the city’s sweeping new climate law before potentially steep penalties begin next year.

headline: Kicked Out of Hospice, Malachy McCourt Wants One Last St. Patrick’s Day
abstract: The actor, writer, radio host, bartender and man about town is 91 years old, and he still has some stories to tell.
lead_paragraph: The news last summer hit his friends like a punch in the gut: Malachy McCourt had entered hospice care. It wasn’t a complete surprise. Mr. McCourt was about to turn 91, and he was once known as much for his drinking as for his status as a public raconteur. He was part of a lineage that includes Jimmy Breslin and Pete Hamill, bar-stool champions of the little guy and dispensers of hard-earned wisdom.

headline: As New York Weighs Library Cuts, Three New Branches Show Their Value
abstract: Facing a giant budget deficit, Mayor Eric Adams proposed cuts to New York libraries. But they play an outsize role in the city, offering services and safety.
lead_paragraph: A city is only as good as its public spaces. The Covid-19 pandemic was another reminder: For quarantined New Yorkers, parks, outdoor dining sheds and reopened libraries became lifelines.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, March 10, 2023
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: A Huge City Polluter? Buildings. Here’s a Surprising Fix.
abstract: Carbon capture might not work for all buildings. But some are giving it a try.
lead_paragraph: Carbon capture might not work for all buildings. But some are giving it a try.

headline: Georgia drops a draft ‘foreign agents’ law that set off mass protests over parallels to Russia.
abstract: Although the U-turn was considered a victory for civil society, activists on both sides of the issue suggested that the fight was not over.
lead_paragraph: TBILISI, Georgia — Georgia’s Parliament on Friday voted down draft legislation that set off a political storm and mass demonstrations this week over fears the measure would push the small former Soviet republic back into Moscow’s orbit.

headline: Protests and the Future of Democracy in Israel
abstract: A government plan to overhaul the Supreme Court has prompted some of the biggest demonstrations in the country’s history.
lead_paragraph: Almost immediately after taking power in December, Benjamin Netanyahu’s far-right coalition in Israel proposed a highly contentious overhaul of the Supreme Court.

headline: What Can a Half-Century-Old Magazine Teach Us Today?
abstract: The cluttered, lively ethos of Apartment Life offers an antidote to the chilly perfectionism of Instagram — and creative ideas that still feel relevant.
lead_paragraph: “Believe it or not, your next home could be in a dentist’s office,” a popular shelter magazine declared, referring to underused New York City commercial buildings that were being turned into apartments.

headline: Why Unions Matter So Much
abstract: Is the Democratic Party again starting to pay more attention to them?
lead_paragraph: For decades, the Republican Party has seemed to care more about labor unions than the Democratic Party has.

headline: German Police Had Spoken to Man Who Opened Fire at Jehovah’s Witness Hall
abstract: The attacker received a warning but was allowed to keep his weapons after the authorities received an anonymous letter about him, weeks before he killed six people at his former congregation.
lead_paragraph: Weeks before a gunman opened fire on his former congregation at a Jehovah’s Witness hall in northern Germany, the authorities got a tip that he “harbored a special rage” toward religious groups, officials said Friday. But when they checked on him, they said, they determined they did not have grounds to seize his weapons.

headline: ‘No Love Is Ever Wasted’
abstract: Even when it leads to heartbreak.
lead_paragraph: Twenty stuffed animals lay ominously shoulder-to-shoulder on their bellies in a perfect circle on the floor. My 11-year-old daughter, Mary, sat in the middle, as though performing some esoteric ritual.

headline: Troubles at Silicon Valley Bank Rock the Global Market
abstract: Shares in the bank, a go-to funder of tech start-ups, have fallen more than 60 percent in the past day as investors fear for its finances, and those of similarly sized lenders.
lead_paragraph: Shares in U.S. banks appear poised to slide again on Friday, after the sector suffered a $52 billion sell-off on Thursday, its worst drop in three years. Driving investor concerns is the health of Silicon Valley Bank, one of the biggest lenders to tech start-ups, which is urgently raising cash to shore up its finances.

headline: Prince Edward Receives a New Title on His Birthday
abstract: King Charles III named Edward, his youngest brother, the Duke of Edinburgh on his 59th birthday. The title was previously held by their father, Prince Philip.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — King Charles III granted his youngest sibling, Prince Edward, the title of Duke of Edinburgh, Buckingham Palace said on Friday, Edward’s 59th birthday.

headline: Five Children’s Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a musical adaptation of a Roald Dahl classic, an animated coming-of-age story and an assortment of lovable farm animals.
lead_paragraph: Every great kids’ movie needs a memorable villain, and Emma Thompson’s character in “Matilda,” with her yellow teeth and exaggerated physicality, is tough to forget. Adapted from the Olivier- and Tony Award-winning stage musical, this version of Roald Dahl’s beloved book gives kids someone to root for (Alisha Weir as the brilliant, telekinetic Matilda Wormwood) and a delicious antagonist in the form of a cruel, shoulder-padded boarding school headmistress named Agatha Trunchbull (Thompson). Matilda comes into the world like any cute baby — only, as she tells us in her introductory song, where other children’s parents say things like “She’s an angel,” Matilda’s tell her she’s “a good case for population control.” She finds acceptance via a teacher, Miss Honey (Lashana Lynch), and pushes back against the tyranny of Trunchbull, her parents and any adult who tries to crush her spirit. You might not want your kids to revolt in real life if it means they refuse to brush their teeth or go to sleep at night, but introducing them to a hero who’s a precocious little girl, rebelling out of a desire to be loved for who she is, sounds pretty good.

headline: Drum-and-Bass Is Rising Again, With Nia Archives in the Spotlight
abstract: The 23-year-old British musician is a breakout star of a dance-music revival largely led by Black women artists. Her new EP, “Sunrise Bang Ur Head Against Tha Wall,” is out Friday.
lead_paragraph: About 300 dance music fans were packed into a north London club late last year, waiting for Nia Archives, a jungle artist and D.J., to begin her set.

headline: Saudi Arabia and Iran Agree to Restore Ties, in Talks Hosted by China
abstract: The deal between regional rivals underlines China’s growing economic and political importance in the Middle East, and what some analysts say is waning American influence.
lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — After years of open hostility and proxy conflicts across the Middle East, Saudi Arabia and Iran have agreed to re-establish diplomatic ties, they announced on Friday, in a significant pivot for the two regional rivals that was facilitated by China.

headline: P.S.G.’s Star System Has Run Its Course
abstract: Even with Messi, Mbappé and Neymar, the French champion is a Champions League also-ran once again. Is buying local the way forward?
lead_paragraph: Nobody at Paris St.-Germain seemed particularly upset at being knocked out of the Champions League. Christophe Galtier, the coach, made all the right noises, of course. It was a terrible disappointment, he said. A great shame, because this is a competition that really means a lot to the club. Very sad for all concerned.

headline: One of the Oldest Restaurants in the Country Is in San Francisco
abstract: Tadich Grill, now in the city’s Financial District, opened in 1849, before California became a state.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Even on the rainiest of nights, the neon-lettered sign breaks through the fog, and the door opens into a dim, moody restaurant where a very long deco bar looks like the wooden deck of a ship.

headline: Check Fraud Is on the Rise. Here’s What You Can Do to Prevent It.
abstract: Even as fewer people use paper checks, there have been more reports of criminals stealing them from mailboxes and changing the dollar amount and name of the recipient, officials say.
lead_paragraph: If you use paper checks and send them through the mail, it may be time to stop.

headline: Which Stores Are Scanning Your Face? No One Knows.
abstract: Our reporter took a five-mile walk around Manhattan to find businesses that are using facial recognition technology.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: A (Literal) Passport Out of Russia: Give Birth in Argentina
abstract: Since the Ukraine war, pregnant Russians have been flocking to the South American country where obtaining citizenship is relatively easy — if your child is born there.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES, Argentina — The passengers drifted away until only the pregnant women remained at passport control.

headline: Giving the Middle Finger Is a ‘God-Given’ Right, a Quebec Judge Says
abstract: In dismissing a harassment case, the judge wrote that the right to make the obscene gesture is one “that belongs to every red-blooded Canadian.”
lead_paragraph: A Quebec judge declared last month, as he acquitted a man who had been accused of threatening and harassing his neighbor, that Canadians have a “God-given” right to give someone the middle finger.

headline: Who Built the Dominican Republic’s Dream Team? Their 42-Year-Old D.H.
abstract: Serving as general manager in addition to his hitting duties, Nelson Cruz assembled one of the best baseball lineups in recent memory for the World Baseball Classic.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The Dominican Republic’s team in the 2023 World Baseball Classic is a veritable dream team of stars.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Richard Reeves
abstract: A conversation with scholar Richard Reeves.
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Richard Reeves. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Californians Grow Weary as Storms Force Another Round of Evacuations
abstract: In some Central California communities, residents have had to pack up and leave several times already this year because of atmospheric rivers.
lead_paragraph: WATSONVILLE, Calif. — Evacuation orders were in force, announced late on Thursday through social media posts and over speakers used by the local police department. Another storm was approaching. Residents needed to get to safety.

headline: Miley Cyrus and Brandi Carlile’s Raw Duet, and 9 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Bartees Strange, Nicki Nicole, Caroline Rose and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: The quest to restore Notre Dame’s sound. Also in this edition: how Judy Blume finally got a “yes” from Hollywood, and the rise of designer ice.
lead_paragraph: The quest to restore Notre Dame’s sound. Also in this edition: how Judy Blume finally got a “yes” from Hollywood, and the rise of designer ice.

headline: The Past’s Treasures Are Not in Vogue, Except at This Art Fair
abstract: TEFAF Maastricht in the Netherlands is the last remaining fair for pre-20th-century works that is truly international. Can young collectors, who mostly prefer contemporary art, be encouraged to buy?
lead_paragraph: The bottom right-hand corner of the jack of hearts, a playing card associated with good fortune and happiness, has been carefully cut away. The back is inscribed, in Dutch, “My burden is heavy, goodbye my dear Femke, Born 1st September 1795,” by a mother who, two centuries, ago abandoned her baby as a foundling. She left the card with the child in the hope that, one day, mother and daughter could be reunited by matching that missing corner.

headline: An Ode to Inheritance and More: The Week in Reporter Reads
abstract: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: Jobs Report Gives Fed a Mixed Signal Ahead of Its March Decision
abstract: The Federal Reserve is anxiously parsing incoming data as it decides between a small or a large rate move this month.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials received a complicated signal from February’s employment report, which showed that job growth retained substantial momentum nearly a year into the central bank’s campaign to slow the economy and cool rapid inflation. But it also included details hinting that the softening the Fed has been trying to achieve may be coming.

headline: Californians Brace for More Rain and Snow as Next Storm Rolls In
abstract: A new atmospheric river was forecast to drop heavy precipitation in much of the state through the weekend, with central California expected to be hit the hardest.
lead_paragraph: A new atmospheric river was forecast to drop heavy precipitation in much of the state through the weekend, with central California expected to be hit the hardest.

headline: The Messenger, a Media Start-Up, Aims to Build a Newsroom Fast
abstract: The company, which will begin operating in May, plans to have around 550 journalists covering entertainment, politics and sports within a year.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Finkelstein’s winding career in publishing has included running and being a part-owner of The Hollywood Reporter and The Hill, a middle-market chronicler of Washington politics. In 2021, he sold The Hill to the broadcast giant Nexstar for $130 million.

headline: Barbara Bryant, First Woman to Lead the Census Bureau, Dies at 96
abstract: When she took over in 1989, she found herself dealing with controversies over the 1990 count, including the problem of overlooked populations.
lead_paragraph: Barbara Everitt Bryant, the first woman to lead the United States Census Bureau, who dived into roiling waters when she took the job in late 1989 as the agency was beginning the contentious decennial census of 1990, died on March 3 in Ann Arbor, Mich. She was 96.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Good morning. I’ve been going at it with the maul and wedges lately after work, breaking down a large tree that fell in the yard, gnarled green wood that will age into fuel for smoked ribs, crackling pizza and grilled cabbage. The work leaves me sore and starving.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I’ve been going at it with the maul and wedges lately after work, breaking down a large tree that fell in the yard, gnarled green wood that will age into fuel for smoked ribs, crackling pizza and grilled cabbage. The work leaves me sore and starving.

headline: A History Professor Takes On Hollywood
abstract: When Natalia Petrzela isn’t teaching or writing, she’s podcasting or getting into a scrape with a streamer. It’s all part of what it means to be a scholar in 2023.
lead_paragraph: The life of a scholar used to be simpler, with success or failure whittled down to an easy dictum: “Publish or perish.”

headline: Hollywood’s Climate Adviser
abstract: Only a tiny fraction of scripted movies and TV shows talk about climate change. Meet the woman trying to change that.
lead_paragraph: Climate change is one of the defining issues of our time, but you wouldn’t know it from watching the Oscars this Sunday.

headline: What is an atmospheric river?
abstract: Atmospheric rivers, named for their long, narrow shape and the prodigious amount of water they carry, are a type of storm that has a huge influence on California’s weather.
lead_paragraph: Atmospheric rivers are hugely influential for California’s weather and water supplies. They cause the state’s heaviest rains and feed the biggest floods. They drive its cycles of dry and wet, famine and feast. But they also cause a large share of the state’s levee breaches and debris flows.

headline: Answers to 7 Key Questions on the Saudi-Iran Deal
abstract: The regional rivals have agreed to re-establish diplomatic ties in an agreement brokered by China that could reverberate across the Middle East and beyond.
lead_paragraph: The announcement by Iran and Saudi Arabia that they are re-establishing diplomatic ties could lead to a major realignment in the Middle East. It also represents a geopolitical challenge for the United States and a victory for China, which brokered the talks between the two longstanding rivals.

headline: Biden Promised to Revisit Presidential Immunity. He Hasn’t.
abstract: The president, now facing a special counsel investigation, never followed through on a campaign pledge to direct the Justice Department to reconsider its view that sitting presidents cannot be indicted.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Joseph R. Biden Jr. was running for the White House in 2019, he sharply criticized the Justice Department’s longstanding view that presidents who commit crimes are immune from indictment while in office and promised to have it reconsider that position.

headline: How American Jews Feel About Israel
abstract: Readers discuss a column by Thomas L. Friedman saying U.S. Jews must “choose sides.” Also: A transition in food tastes; nude photos in Singapore.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: The Time for Prokofiev’s ‘War and Peace’ Is Now
abstract: After Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, this opera adaptation of Tolstoy seemed unperformable. But in Munich, it has become an urgent antiwar cry.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — Sergei Prokofiev died the same day as Joseph Stalin: March 5, 1953. It’s a coincidence you’re more likely to come across in the composer’s biography than in Stalin’s.

headline: Where Is Canada Hiding All Its Tornadoes?
abstract: North America’s northernmost country has the second most tornadoes in the world each year. But until recently, scientists had no idea when and where many of them actually occurred.
lead_paragraph: Tornadoes, one might think, should be easy to spot. They reach down like gnarled fingers in the heat of storms, ripping trees from the ground and blowing cars off the road, picking up Kansas farmhouses and transporting them to the land of Oz.

headline: Chinati Foundation Finds Its Next Director Close to Home
abstract: Caitlin Murray will lead the museum, a West Texas landmark that is carrying out costly restorations to uphold the vision of its founder, the artist Donald Judd.
lead_paragraph: The Chinati Foundation, the small but influential art museum in Texas founded by the artist Donald Judd, announced on Friday that it had found its next leader. Caitlin Murray, the director of archives and programs at the separate Judd Foundation, will head the organization.

headline: Its Georgia O’Keeffe Is Worth Millions. And Its Dorms Need Updating.
abstract: In the face of declining enrollment, Valparaiso University in Indiana wants to raise money to renovate two dormitories by selling treasures from its art museum. Not everyone is on board.
lead_paragraph: During his decades teaching literature at Valparaiso University, John Ruff looked beyond words, bringing his students to the school’s art museum to help them acquire what he called emotional wisdom. While discussing stories that originated in the Southwest, he would point out Georgia O’Keeffe’s “Rust Red Hills.” When he wanted to draw parallels to 19th-century American literature, Frederic E. Church’s “Mountain Landscape” was right there.

headline: Silicon Valley Bank Fails After Run on Deposits
abstract: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation took control of the bank’s assets on Friday. The failure raised concerns that other banks could face problems, too.
lead_paragraph: One of the most prominent lenders in the world of technology start-ups, struggling under the weight of ill-fated decisions and panicked customers, collapsed on Friday, forcing the federal government to step in.

headline: Francisco Ayala, Biologist and Defender of Evolution, Dies at 88
abstract: A leading evolutionary biologist who defended Darwin’s theory in books and in the courtroom, he was forced to retire amid charges of sexual harassment.
lead_paragraph: Francisco Ayala, one of the world’s leading evolutionary biologists and a champion of science against the forces of religious fundamentalism, who was forced to give up his university post late in life amid sexual harassment allegations, died on March 3 in Newport Beach, Calif. He was 88.

headline: Crowds gather to mourn ‘Da Vinci,’ a young Ukrainian soldier killed near Bakhmut.
abstract: Dmytro Kotsiubailo, better known as “Da Vinci,” was killed near Bakhmut on March 7.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Dmytro Kotsiubailo was a skinny teenager when he took to the barricades in Kyiv’s Independence Square nine years ago, joining thousands of Ukrainians demanding to be treated with dignity and freed from the yoke of Russia.

headline: ‘The State Failed These People. They Didn’t Have to Die Like This.’
abstract: The Turkish government’s disastrous response to the recent earthquakes has exposed the false promise of strongman rule.
lead_paragraph: ADIYAMAN, Turkey — Beneath each fresh mound in this rapidly expanding graveyard lies a tragedy. One morning at dawn, Zeki Karababa told me about his.

headline: How the Ohio Train Derailment and Its Aftermath Unfolded
abstract: The Feb. 3 derailment in East Palestine of a Norfolk Southern train carrying toxic chemicals set off an emergency response as residents worried about long-term health effects.
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 3, a Norfolk Southern train carrying toxic chemicals derailed in East Palestine, Ohio, igniting a fire and setting off fears of an explosion. The authorities carried out a controlled release and burn-off of some of the train’s hazardous cargo, but residents on both sides of the Ohio-Pennsylvania state line are concerned about the impact on their health and the environment.

headline: Interpreting the Week’s Most Important Stories
abstract: The larger themes behind the protests in Israel, the U.K.’s tough new immigration plan and a fight over U.S. labor unions.
lead_paragraph: I’m trying something a little different in today’s newsletter. A big part of what I try to do is to look for insights that explain the patterns and trends in world events, in ways that go beyond any single news story. Reading this newsletter should help you understand not just the latest development, but the bigger picture.

headline: Traute Lafrenz, Last Survivor of Anti-Hitler Group, Dies at 103
abstract: As a member of the White Rose, a small anti-Nazi resistance group, she used peaceful tactics to try persuading Germans to turn against Hitler.
lead_paragraph: Traute Lafrenz, the last survivor of the White Rose, a resistance movement in Nazi Germany whose opposition to Adolf Hitler led to swift and ferocious Gestapo repression and the beheading of its leaders, died on Monday at her home in Meggett, S.C., near Charleston. She was 103.

headline: Easy Ways to Be a Better Cook
abstract: Chicken breasts breaded in Ritz crackers from Eric Kim, craggy tofu in a star anise sauce from Yewande Komolafe, and even more brilliant recipes.
lead_paragraph: My colleague Alexa Weibel assembled this great list of dishes last week, richly annotated with her wisdom: “10 Brilliant Recipes That’ll Make You a Better Cook.”  Lex knows a lot about brilliant recipes; she created many New York Times Cooking gems, including our ombré gratin and five-ingredient creamy miso pasta (a fan favorite).

headline: Why ‘Everything Everywhere’ Will Probably Win Best Picture
abstract: The movies and the multiverse.
lead_paragraph: The odds-on favorite to win best picture at this weekend’s Oscars is not the best or even second-best movie among the nominees — those would be “Tár” and “Top Gun: Maverick,” respectively — but rather a movie that a remarkable number of people just passionately loved: “Everything Everywhere All at Once.”

headline: Review: In ‘Misty,’ a Restless Artist Grapples With a Gentrifying City
abstract: At the Shed, Arinzé Kene mixes spoken word, music and comedy to tell a story of racial tension and male identity in a changing London.
lead_paragraph: There are many ways to tell a story. Freestyle, direct address and a varied assortment of orange balloons are just a few of the expressive means deployed in “Misty,” which opened on Thursday at the Shed. This multidisciplinary piece, by the British writer and performer Arinzé Kene, uses an array of sights and sounds to toy with the perceptions of the people it presumes are watching.

headline: Third Black-Owned Company Emerges as Suitor for BET
abstract: Black Entertainment Television made the first Black billionaire in the United States. Will a Black executive buy it back?
lead_paragraph: When the cable giant Viacom bought Black Entertainment Television at the turn of the millennium for $2.34 billion, it made Robert L. Johnson, BET’s founder, the first Black billionaire in the United States.

headline: Title Search: Can You Find These 13 Hidden Novels From the 1980s?
abstract: It was a big, bold decade in many ways — but how many significant and award-winning books published in the ’80s do you recognize? Try this puzzle and find out.
lead_paragraph: It was a big, bold decade in many ways — but how many significant and award-winning books published in the ’80s do you recognize? Try this puzzle and find out.

headline: Five International Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a Kafkaesque South Indian comedy, a delirious British noir caper scripted by Alan Moore and a Czech body-horror movie that’ll get under your skin.
lead_paragraph: The new film by Lijo Jose Pellissery — the director of genre-bending gems like “Angamaly Diaries” and “Jallikattu” — is a quotidian slice of Kafka: a gentle, keenly observed comedy in which a man wakes up after some slumber not as a different creature, but simply as another man, with another name, family and memories. The curmudgeonly James (Mammootty), who hails from the South Indian state of Kerala, is on a pilgrimage through the neighboring state of Tamil Nadu with a large group of relatives and friends when the miracle happens. He awakens from a nap, stops the bus and calmly walks into the nearby village, believing he is Sundaram, the long-missing patriarch of a local family. His troupe, whom he no longer recognizes, chases him in chagrin; the villagers watch in amazement as he walks around nonchalantly, fluent in Tamil and in the intimate goings-on of the town.

headline: F.D.A. Approves New Nasal Spray for Migraines
abstract: Pfizer’s treatment applies an approach that is different from some other products, which doctors say may make it safer for people at risk of heart attacks or stroke.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration has approved a Pfizer nasal spray for treatment of migraines that uses a different therapy from other nasal products on the market for severe headache pain, the company said on Friday.

headline: Concussions Pose Particular Risks for Older Adults
abstract: Experts say patients can, and usually will, make a full recovery. Here’s what to know.
lead_paragraph: Senator Mitch McConnell, the 81-year-old Senate minority leader, received treatment for a concussion at a Washington hospital on Wednesday night. According to a spokesman, he was injured when he fell at the Waldorf Astoria hotel.

headline: Michael Tilson Thomas Revels in the Present With the New York Phil
abstract: Thomas, who is fighting brain cancer, conducted two ruminative works, Schubert’s “Great” Symphony and his own “Meditations on Rilke.”
lead_paragraph: The conductor Michael Tilson Thomas has always been a performer who communicates joy when sharing the music he loves. On Thursday, there was also a deep sense of gratitude: Speaking from the stage, he called his appearance with the New York Philharmonic “a lovely, affirming surprise.” Although he made no direct mention of his health, many in the audience understood the context: In the summer of 2021, Thomas, 78, learned that he had glioblastoma, an aggressive and terminal form of brain cancer. For him, every performance now is an opportunity to revel in the present.

headline: Nan Goldin Is Ready for Oscar Night
abstract: A quintessential New York artist prepares for the ultimate red carpet.
lead_paragraph: In the late 1970s, the photographer Nan Goldin began documenting hedonism and bohemia in New York City, chronicling the downtown lives of her friends and lovers with raw intimacy. Those images became a time capsule of a grittier city and established Ms. Goldin’s place as one of America’s most important photographers.

headline: Love Letter: Is Love Ever Wasted?
abstract: No, even if it ends in pain.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s Modern Love essay, the writer Kerry Egan argues that “No Love Is Ever Wasted.”

headline: Books About the Oscars
abstract: Just in time for the Academy Awards, our critic Alexandra Jacobs discusses two recent books on the subject, Michael Schulman’s “Oscar Wars” and Bruce Davis’s “The Academy and the Award.”
lead_paragraph: The 95th Academy Awards will be presented on Sunday evening in Hollywood, with top contenders including “Tár,” “Women Talking” and “Everything Everywhere All at Once.” For readers, it’s a perfect excuse to revisit two recent books about the Oscars.

headline: Banking Turmoil: What We Know
abstract: Regulators trying to stem panic among customers shut down Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank within days.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, Silicon Valley Bank, a lender to some of the biggest names in the technology world, became the largest bank to fail since the 2008 financial crisis. By Sunday night, regulators had abruptly shut down Signature Bank to prevent a crisis in the broader banking system. The banks’ swift closures have sent shock waves through the tech industry, Washington and Wall Street.

headline: What We’ve Learned (So Far) at the World Baseball Classic
abstract: Shohei Ohtani and Japan are a juggernaut, the Netherlands look tough, time zones can be confusing and an unfamiliar streaming service appears to be working out.
lead_paragraph: After a six-year wait, the World Baseball Classic roared to life again this week, with group play starting in Japan and Taiwan. Some of the tournament’s favorites, like the United States, the Dominican Republic and Puerto Rico, do not begin play until Saturday — their games are in Arizona and Florida — but the action in Asia has been everything the baseball world could hope for. Japan looks like a juggernaut, the Netherlands is off to a fast start and plenty of other teams are making a strong impression.

headline: At the End of a Hard Journey, Migrants Face Another: Navigating Bureaucracy
abstract: The Biden administration’s new rules have brought down a record number of border crossings, but critics say they expose the pitfalls of policies intended to manage an immediate problem.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Etienne Termulis spent nine days trying to make an appointment with the U.S. government for a chance to seek asylum.

headline: Friends of Eric Adams Have Paid Fraction of Sum Ordered in Federal Case
abstract: The operators of Mayor Eric Adams’s favorite Manhattan restaurant still owe the government hundreds of thousands of dollars as part of a decade-old criminal case, court records show.
lead_paragraph: More than eight years after being ordered in federal court to forfeit nearly $700,000 for financial crimes, two close friends of Mayor Eric Adams have repaid only a fraction of that sum despite operating numerous lucrative businesses, court records show.

headline: When You Think Oscars Fashion, Do You Think Versace?
abstract: The Italian brand held a splashy runway show in Los Angeles, making the most of a star-studded weekend.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — There was a moment during Versace’s runway show, held on the rooftop of a parking garage that had been glammed beyond recognition, as if the building itself had been Facetuned, that felt like attending service at a fashion megachurch.

headline: Cult-Favorite Brand Yeti Recalls 1.9 Million Coolers and Cases
abstract: Yeti Coolers voluntarily recalled millions of products after their magnetic closures detached and posed serious injury risk, the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission said.
lead_paragraph: About 1.9 million Yeti brand coolers and soft gear cases were recalled by the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission on Thursday because various products’ magnet closures could detach and cause serious injury.

headline: Our Granddaughter Is Rude and Ungrateful. What Can We Do?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on failures to acknowledge financial generosity.
lead_paragraph: My wife and I are retired, elderly and proud of our family, which includes three daughters and several grandchildren. Fortunately, we have had the ability to be financially generous with our family and have established educational trusts for each of our grandchildren’s college tuition. All of our grandchildren have been appreciative, except for the youngest, who is 17 and a senior in high school. She never thanked us for funding her educational trust, and she has also neglected to thank us for the birthday gifts we have given her the past several years. At family get-togethers, she is openly effusive in greeting her aunts, uncle and cousins, but ignores us unless we approach her.

headline: Review: In This Dance, Even the Nose Scratches Are Choreographed
abstract: “Blackbare in the Basement,” Jordan Demetrius Lloyd’s first evening-length commission, shows a distinct voice still developing.
lead_paragraph: Two men in lavender puffer vests and jean shorts strike a pose. Together, they scratch their noses. And then they go right back to the pose.

headline: Japan Buries Memories of Its Last War and Worries About Another
abstract: As survivors of the Tokyo firebombing fade away, Japan reassesses its longstanding pacifism.
lead_paragraph: The air-raid siren’s wail woke Yoshiko Hashimoto from her sleep. It was just after midnight on March 10, 1945, when the first of hundreds of American bombers appeared over Tokyo. Incendiary bombs soon crashed through tile rooftops, igniting fires in the surrounding thicket of tinderbox homes.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week
abstract: Former President Donald Trump was the talk of late night this week, including the discovery that Tucker Carlson privately reviled him. Here’s what the hosts had to say.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald Trump was the talk of late night this week, including the discovery that Tucker Carlson privately reviled him. Here’s what the hosts had to say.

headline: 22 Works of Fiction to Read This Spring
abstract: Watch for reality-bending explorations of time and space, a Western horror novel from Victor LaValle and new fiction from Han Kang. Plus: Tom Hanks (yes, that Tom Hanks) releases his debut novel.
lead_paragraph: Good news, fiction lovers: This season will bring plenty to delight you, no matter what you like to read.

headline: 19 Works of Nonfiction to Read This Spring
abstract: New memoirs, a landmark biography of Martin Luther King, Jr., a look at the woman who helped halt the rise of a K.K.K. leader — and more.
lead_paragraph: Watch for deeply-researched philosophical histories, biographies that bring well-known stories to light and meditations on art and new ways to live. There’s plenty to love among the nonfiction coming to bookshelves this spring.

headline: Hey, That Red Carpet Isn’t Red!
abstract: The 2023 Academy Awards carpet’s champagne hue — a break with a 62-year tradition of the bright red rug — is the latest arrival rug to opt for a colorful palette.
lead_paragraph: There are some fundamental truths in the world: The sky is blue. The grass is green. The Oscars red carpet is re —— champagne-colored.

headline: Real-Estate Broker Pleads Guilty in Homeless-Shelter Bribery Scheme
abstract: Sheina Levin was a former business partner of Victor Rivera, whose dealings were the subject of a New York Times investigation.
lead_paragraph: The owner of a Brooklyn real estate company pleaded guilty this week to paying hundreds of thousands of dollars in kickbacks to a homeless-shelter operator in a yearslong scheme to profit from programs meant to help homeless people.

headline: Overlooked No More: Dilys Winn, Who Brought Murder and Mystery to Manhattan
abstract: She opened Murder Ink, believed to be the nation’s first mystery bookstore, and brought fans together through interactive whodunits and other events.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: A Glimpse of DeSantis in Iowa: Awkward, but Still Winning the Crowd
abstract: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida visited Iowa on Friday, providing a window into his still-untested skills as a retail politician.
lead_paragraph: DAVENPORT, Iowa — Suzy Barker, a native Iowan dressed in an orange-and-blue University of Florida hoodie, waited in a crowd of fellow Republicans on Friday morning to meet Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida.

headline: How to Understand the Problems at Silicon Valley Bank
abstract: Interest rates have risen so quickly that some banks can’t keep up.
lead_paragraph: If you’re wondering why Silicon Valley Bank, one of the biggest lenders to tech start-ups, had to be taken over Friday by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, one good place to look is the Federal Reserve.

headline: After Years of Bickering, France and Britain Look for a New Start
abstract: The rapport between Emmanuel Macron of France and Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain hints at a mending of their countries’ relationship.
lead_paragraph: When President Emmanuel Macron of France welcomed Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain to Paris on Friday, commentators were quick to call it a communion of kindred spirits: Both are former investment bankers in their 40s. Both govern countries gripped by strikes, economic dislocation and political anxiety.

headline: Wonking Out: The Future of Taxes
abstract: Yes, the rich should pay more, but that won’t be enough.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s latest budget calls for maintaining and even expanding the social safety net, although it seeks to limit Medicare spending through tougher bargaining over drug prices.
