It nonetheless claims to reduce budget deficits, mainly by raising taxes on corporations and Americans with incomes over $400,000 a year.

headline: Canadian Supreme Court Judge Put on Leave During Review of Altercation in Arizona
abstract: The judge denied instigating the episode, which an oversight council has been investigating for several weeks.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — A member of Canada’s highest court confirmed on Friday that he had been placed on leave while a judicial body investigates his role in a violent altercation at an Arizona resort.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Silicon Valley Bank’s Collapse Causes Start-Up Chaos
abstract: Young companies raced to get their money out of the bank, which was central to the start-up industry. Some said they could not make payroll.
lead_paragraph: Ashley Tyrner opened an account with Silicon Valley Bank for her company, FarmboxRx, two years ago. She was setting out to raise venture capital and knew the bank was a go-to for the start-up industry.

headline: Former N.Y.P.D. Officer Is Convicted of Taking Part in Capitol Riot
abstract: Sara Carpenter yelled at, pushed against and slapped the arms of police officers, all while wielding a tambourine, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A former New York City police officer was convicted this week of several crimes for her role in the Capitol riot on Jan. 6, 2021, during which, prosecutors said, she pushed against and slapped the arms of police officers, all while yelling and wielding a tambourine.

headline: ‘Now He Must Pay:’ Kristin Smart’s Killer Is Sentenced to 25 Years to Life
abstract: Ms. Smart was a college student in San Luis Obispo, Calif., when she vanished while walking from an off-campus party to her dorm. The sentencing drew a raw response from her brother.
lead_paragraph: Paul Flores, who was found guilty last year of murdering Kristin Smart in 1996 when they were both university students, was sentenced on Friday to 25 years to life in prison, capping an emotional day for the Smart family, who waited more than a quarter of a century for some sense of justice.

headline: Michael Cohen to Testify at Grand Jury as Likely Trump Indictment Looms
abstract: Mr. Cohen, Donald J. Trump’s former fixer, is the key witness in a case built around a hush money payment to Stormy Daniels.
lead_paragraph: Michael D. Cohen, the former fixer who for years did Donald J. Trump’s dirty work, is expected to testify before a Manhattan grand jury next week, a sign that prosecutors are poised to indict the former president for his role in paying hush money to a porn star, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Saudi Deal With Iran Surprises Israel and Jolts Netanyahu
abstract: Israel had long hoped to isolate Iran and seal ties with Saudi Arabia. A thaw between Riyadh and Tehran has complicated that goal — and was perceived as politically damaging to the prime minister.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israeli leaders have for years considered Iran an existential threat, viewed Saudi Arabia as a potential partner and hoped that shared fears of Tehran might help forge formal relations for the first time with Riyadh.

headline: Criminals in Mexico Violated Their Unwritten Rule: Leave Americans Alone
abstract: While Mexicans are often caught in cartel violence, and the outside world barely notices, the criminal groups know that targeting Americans is bad for business.
lead_paragraph: The five men were left prostrate on the sidewalk outside their black pickup truck, their shirts pulled over their heads, bare torsos pressed against the ground, their bound hands spread before them almost in supplication.

headline: Suzy McKee Charnas, Writer of Feminist Science Fiction, Dies at 83
abstract: She was best known for the Holdfast Chronicles, a series about a dystopic world in which once-enslaved women conquer their former male masters.
lead_paragraph: Suzy McKee Charnas, an award-winning feminist science fiction writer who in a four-novel series created a post-holocaust, male-dominated society called the Holdfast that is liberated by an army of women, died on Jan. 2 at her home in Albuquerque. She was 83.

headline: George Santos Had Role in A.T.M. Fraud Scheme, Former Roommate Says
abstract: The former roommate, who pleaded guilty in 2017 and was deported, sent an affidavit to federal authorities accusing Mr. Santos of running a card-skimming operation.
lead_paragraph: In April 2017, the Seattle police arrested a Brazilian man they had caught installing a card-skimming machine on an A.T.M. near the famed Pike Place Market. As officers investigated, they connected the man to a Florida address where he once lived with George Santos, now a Republican congressman from New York.

headline: BBC in Turmoil as Revolt Over Gary Lineker’s ‘Match of the Day’ Suspension Spreads
abstract: One of England’s best-known sports personalities, he was taken off the air after criticizing a British government immigration proposal on social media. His ouster set off a staff boycott.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The BBC scrambled to rearrange hours of programming in real time on Saturday after the suspension of the popular host of its cornerstone soccer program set off a revolt by on-air talent, forcing the broadcaster to curtail major portions of its weekend sports coverage and leaving it to face accusations that Britain’s culture wars had bled into its decision-making.

headline: Alabama’s Championship Push Arrives With Murder Indictment
abstract: A former Crimson Tide player, Darius Miles, and Miles’s friend Michael Davis were indicted by a grand jury. At the Southeastern Conference tournament, Brandon Miller starred for Alabama after being interviewed as a witness in the case.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — The rousing cheers for Brandon Miller began during the announcement of the starting lineup and continued with each 3-pointer he knocked down, each rebound he gobbled up and each assist he dished out in Alabama’s 72-49 rout on Friday of Mississippi State in a Southeastern Conference men’s basketball tournament quarterfinal.

headline: Otis Taylor, Star Receiver for the Kansas City Chiefs, Dies at 80
abstract: An acrobatic player, he was the prototype for the big receivers who succeeded him. He caught a memorable touchdown in the Chiefs’ upset win in Super Bowl IV.
lead_paragraph: Otis Taylor, a graceful former star wide receiver for the Kansas City Chiefs who caught the touchdown pass that nailed down the team’s upset victory over the Minnesota Vikings in Super Bowl IV, died on Thursday. He was 80.

headline: Spot, Record Producer Who Captured the Fury of 1980s Punk, Dies at 71
abstract: A lifelong jazz aficionado, he changed course to produce bands like Black Flag and Hüsker Dü for the influential SST label.
lead_paragraph: Glen Lockett, an influential record producer who, working under the name Spot, helped define the jet-turbine sound of American punk rock in the 1980s, recording groundbreaking albums by Black Flag, Hüsker Dü, Minutemen and many others, died on March 4 in Sheboygan, Wis. He was 71.

headline: ‘Pericles’ Review: Shakespeare in the Blender
abstract: Target Margin Theater remixes one of the Bard’s lesser works, with uninspired results.
lead_paragraph: In the opening lines of Shakespeare’s chaotic “Pericles,” before the play and its prince go chasing off on a series of adventures, there is a phrase so genteelly creepy that 400 years haven’t diminished its power to make an audience’s skin crawl.

headline: In the San Bernardino Mountains, Coping With Mountains of Snow
abstract: A devastating winter storm in Southern California strands families in their homes, collapses roofs, and leaves behind widespread fears of more deaths not yet discovered.
lead_paragraph: CRESTLINE, Calif. — Goodwin & Sons Market, with its old-fashioned soda counter and sweet shop, has been a hub of civic life in Crestline, high in the San Bernardino Mountains, for nearly eight decades.

headline: D.C. Data Breach That Included Members of Congress Affected More Than 56,000
abstract: The Social Security numbers and personal information of thousands of people, including some lawmakers, were stolen in a hack of a D.C. health marketplace disclosed this week.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The data of more than 56,000 people, including Social Security numbers and other personal information, was stolen in a hack of the online health insurance marketplace for members of Congress and Washington, D.C., small businesses and residents, officials said in a statement on Friday night.

headline: The Second-Biggest Bank Failure
abstract: The swift collapse of Silicon Valley Bank on Friday was the second-largest bank failure in U.S. history.
lead_paragraph: The swift collapse of Silicon Valley Bank on Friday was the second-largest bank failure in U.S. history.

headline: Discomfiture
abstract: Tom Pepper pelts us with difficult clues, but we love it.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — There are constructors whose bylines on a Saturday crossword alert my spidey senses to an especially brutal challenge ahead, and now I have to add Tom Pepper to that group. This is only his fourth themeless Times puzzle (after two Fridays and another Saturday grid from December, a collaboration with Christina Iverson). I found it a cracking solve; there are eight debut entries, nearly all of them lengthy and interesting, as well as all the other ingredients I need to spice things up.

headline: Biden Administration Expected to Move Ahead on a Major Oil Project in Alaska
abstract: The decision would allow an enormous $8 billion drilling project in the largest expanse of pristine wilderness in the United States.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In one of its most consequential climate decisions, the Biden administration is planning to greenlight an enormous $8 billion oil drilling project in the North Slope of Alaska, according to two people familiar with the decision.

headline: To Fix a Broken Marriage, an Experiment With Polyamory
abstract: After 10 years together, a Bay Area couple opened their relationship. But contrasting sexual needs led to a permanent split.
lead_paragraph: In Unhitched, couples tell the stories of their relationships, from romance to vows to divorce to life afterward.

headline: Quotation of the Day: The Climate Problem of Aging Apartment Buildings
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, March 11, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “Local Law 97 is going to be hard. But would you rather your home be inundated with flooding or have 20 days over 90 degrees in the summer?”

headline: Corrections: March 11, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, March 11, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about Russia’s crucial role in Europe’s energy supply misstated the name of an organization that estimated the length of time necessary to design and deliver a nuclear fuel assembly. It is the International Energy Agency, not the International Energy Association.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: The Tech Worker With a 4-Hour Commute From the West Bank to Tel Aviv
abstract: Moha Alshawamreh is among the few Palestinians who work in Israel’s tech industry. His commute shows both the inequities of life in the West Bank and an exception to them.
lead_paragraph: As hundreds of Palestinians filed through an Israeli checkpoint one recent Monday morning, most were dressed for a day of manual labor. But there was at least one striking exception.

headline: In World Cup Run-Up, Qatar Pressed U.N. Agency Not to Investigate Abuses
abstract: Lobbying at the International Labor Organization dovetailed with an influence campaign that set off a corruption scandal at the European Parliament.
lead_paragraph: With a series of raids and arrests this winter, the Belgian authorities unearthed what they said was a dirty deal at the heart of the European Parliament. Politicians are charged with pocketing money to praise the tiny Gulf nation of Qatar and downplay its labor rights abuses in the run-up to the World Cup.

headline: Here’s How to Solve a 25-Story Rubik’s Cube
abstract: Cities are eager to turn office buildings into housing amid rising remote work. But that's harder than you might think.
lead_paragraph: Cities are eager to turn office buildings into housing amid rising remote work. But that's harder than you might think.

headline: It’s Like ‘Little Women’ — but With Basketball
abstract: In “Hello Beautiful,” Ann Napolitano puts a fresh spin on the classic story of four sisters.
lead_paragraph: “It is your God-given right as an American fiction writer,” Ursula K. Le Guin once said, to change point of view. But “you need to know that you’re doing it,” she warned, and “some American fiction writers don’t.”

headline: Chinese-Brokered Deal Upends Mideast Diplomacy and Challenges U.S.
abstract: The agreement negotiated in Beijing to restore relations between Saudi Arabia and Iran signaled at least a temporary reordering of the usual alliances and rivalries, with Washington left on the sidelines.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Finally, there is a peace deal of sorts in the Middle East. Not between Israel and the Arabs, but between Saudi Arabia and Iran, which have been at each other’s throats for decades. And brokered not by the United States but by China.

headline: Amoral Traitors? War Heroes? Survivors? Depends Whom You Ask.
abstract: Ian Buruma’s “The Collaborators” takes on three complex, disparate figures with notably controversial war records.
lead_paragraph: It sounds like a tasteless parlor game: What do a Dutch Jewish fixer, a gender-fluid Manchu princess and a lusty Nazi masseur have in common? At first glance, very little. Yet these three figures feature as the central characters in Ian Buruma’s new group biography, “The Collaborators.”

headline: The Radical Act of Eating With Strangers
abstract: What could be more optimistic than dining with eight people you’ve never met in hopes of making a new friend?
lead_paragraph: Julieanna Stolley showed up 15 minutes early to Anita Michaud’s party. It was too soon to arrive, she decided, so she paced up and down the block seven times before ringing the bell.

headline: Are Mushrooms Our Friends?
abstract: If “The Last of Us” has you unnerved by fungi, these six books can offer some new perspective. (Our spore-bearing, mysterious little neighbors aren’t completely evil — promise.)
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, the first season of the post-apocalyptic drama “The Last of Us,” a video game adaptation that has impressed critics and viewers with its sensitive depiction of people finding reasons to survive in a broken world, came to an end. And what broke that world? Well, that’s a complicated question. Human nature, for sure. Government overreach, arguably. And, oh yeah … mushrooms.

headline: How a Fashion and Culture Editor Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Aria Hughes likes to stay close to her home in Harlem, where she’ll enjoy an Ethiopian lunch, a park bench and maybe a matinee.
lead_paragraph: “I always knew that I wanted to write about fashion,” said Aria Hughes, the editorial creative director of Complex, a global youth entertainment network that covers pop culture, style, food, music, sneakers and sports.

headline: A Trip to Ukraine. A Jab at Ron DeSantis. What Is Phil Murphy Up To?
abstract: The New Jersey governor, re-elected in 2021, is term-limited and has an eye on Washington.
lead_paragraph: It was a whirlwind few days for New Jersey’s term-limited governor, Philip D. Murphy.

headline: Brett Goldstein Faces Life After ‘Lasso’
abstract: The Apple TV+ show’s breakout star is preparing to play a Marvel movie god when he’s not working on the hit streaming series “Shrinking.” But what he’s really after is human connection.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A few minutes into coffee last spring, Brett Goldstein wanted to show me something on his phone.

headline: Ja Morant’s Impact Can Be Bigger Than Basketball
abstract: The high-flying Memphis Grizzlies star has excited N.B.A. audiences with his play. But accusations of violent behavior have troubled the communities that need him most.
lead_paragraph: Mary Wainwright does not know Ja Morant, but she prays for him, worries about him and wishes she could sit down with the troubled young N.B.A. star to help “set him straight.”

headline: Eight-Legged Candy-Striper Killers Prowl Before the Sun Rises
abstract: A study of candy-striped spiders feasting on sleeping insects suggests there are many surprising arachnid behaviors still waiting to be discovered.
lead_paragraph: In hospitals, candy stripers are selfless volunteers. Candy-stripers of the eight-legged variety, however, appear not so benevolent. New research reveals that two species of candy-striped spider have secret night lives, leaving their cobwebs to carry out violent predation after dark.

headline: Inside Ron DeSantis’s Politicized Removal of an Elected Prosecutor
abstract: The Florida governor accused the Democratic prosecutor of undermining public safety. But a close examination of the episode reveals just how fueled it was by Mr. DeSantis’s political aims.
lead_paragraph: When Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida announced last summer that he had taken the extraordinary step of removing a local prosecutor from his job, he cast his decision as a bold move to protect Floridians.

headline: Highest Heating Costs in Years Strain Many in New England
abstract: In a region where most homes rely on oil heat and cold weather can last through April, the burden of high heating bills has been especially heavy this winter.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: In Fields Sown With Bombs, Ukraine’s Farmers Risk Deadly Harvest
abstract: Some who till the breadbaskets of Ukraine have already lost three seasons of planting to war. With mines and cluster bombs widely scattered, normal harvests seem far in the future.
lead_paragraph: BERYSLAV, Ukraine — Oleksandr Hordienko stepped gingerly into a wheat field that had recently served as a Russian tank position, following closely behind an assistant with a metal detector. He stopped when he came to a row of metal disks glinting in the late-winter sun.

headline: Oscar-Nominated Film Depicts Road to Justice That Is ‘Permanently Alive’
abstract: “Argentina, 1985” has resurrected the country’s military rule, which ended 40 years ago. The quest persists to hold those accused of crimes against humanity accountable.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — The bones of a man, brought into light in a laboratory, had spoken.

headline: Mel Brooks Isn’t Done Punching Up the History of the World
abstract: The comedian, at 96, is happy to inspire a new generation to make their own Hitler jokes.
lead_paragraph: Mel Brooks is a sophisticated guy. He collected fancy French wines and did a tasting on Johnny Carson’s show. He drops references to Nikolai Gogol’s “Dead Souls.” He was married for 40 years to that epitome of elegance, Anne Bancroft. He was a favorite lunch companion of Cary Grant, the suavest man who ever lived.

headline: Can the United Farm Workers Rise Again?
abstract: Decades after Cesar Chavez made the union a power in California fields, it has lost much of its clout. Membership dropped precipitously, from 60,000 to 5,500. It hopes a new law will turn the tide.
lead_paragraph: Veronica Mota marched under the sweltering sun, hoisting a cloth banner of Our Lady of Guadalupe above her head for miles.

headline: Inside the Global Race to Turn Water Into Fuel
abstract: Hundreds of billions of dollars are being invested in a high-tech gamble to make hydrogen clean, cheap and widely available. In Australia’s Outback, that starts with 10 million new solar panels.
lead_paragraph: For eons this has been a quiet, unremarkable place. Thousands of square miles of flat land covered in shrubs and red dirt. The sun is withering and the wind blows hard.

headline: Front Line Shifts in Russia’s and Ukraine’s Battle for Bakhmut, Analysts Say
abstract: Britain’s defense intelligence agency said that Russian forces had taken control of most of Bakhmut’s east, but advances farther west might be challenging.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine insisted on Saturday that its forces were fending off relentless Russian attacks in Bakhmut, even as Western analysts said that Moscow’s forces had captured most of the embattled city’s east and established a new front line cutting through its center.

headline: A National Medical License May Ease Canada’s Doctor Shortages
abstract: The Canadian Medical Association is pushing for a single license to eliminate the barriers between provinces and territories.
lead_paragraph: It won’t end the pronounced shortage of physicians that’s plaguing many parts of Canada. But the Canadian Medical Association has an idea that it thinks might help.

headline: It’s Oscar Time
abstract: Get your popcorn. Manage your expectations. The 95th Academy Awards are tomorrow.
lead_paragraph: The Oscars are tomorrow night. Have you filled out your ballot? Me neither, but that’s because I am still optimistic I’ll squeeze in a few more viewings of nominated films before the red carpet begins. (That’s at 6:30 p.m. Eastern; the ceremony starts at 8. The Times’s live coverage starts in the afternoon. Don’t forget to turn your clocks forward tonight!)

headline: China’s Role in Iran-Saudi Arabia Deal Shows Xi’s Global Goals
abstract: Brokering a rapprochement between the Middle Eastern rivals underscores the Chinese leader’s ambition of offering an alternative to a U.S.-led world order.
lead_paragraph: When Beijing stepped into the role of mediator this week in the surprise rapprochement between Saudi Arabia and Iran, it signaled a new level of ambition for Xi Jinping, China’s top leader, who has sought to burnish his image as a global statesman in an escalating rivalry with the United States.

headline: Why Are American Teens So Unhappy?
abstract: There are many reasons, readers say in response to columns by Ross Douthat and Michelle Goldberg.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Broken Bones, Broken Hearts and Broken Souls
abstract: An editor recommends old and new books.
lead_paragraph: Molly Young is on leave for the next several months. In her absence, colleagues from the Book Review will pick up the recommendation torch and appear in your inbox every two Saturdays.

headline: How Mikaela Shiffrin Won More World Cup Races Than Anyone
abstract: Shiffrin has now won 87 World Cup races, passing Ingemar Stenmark’s record that stood for 34 years. Her ski racing career has been a master class in evading common pitfalls.
lead_paragraph: Mikaela Shiffrin, who became the most successful ski racer in Alpine World Cup history with a record-setting 87th victory, winning her slalom race on Saturday in Are, Sweden, works out from April to October at a colossal gym inside the Westin hotel near her home in Edwards, Colo.

headline: Why Did Silicon Valley Bank Collapse?
abstract: DealBook unpacks what caused the biggest U.S. bank failure since the 2008 financial crisis — and what might come next.
lead_paragraph: The failure of Silicon Valley Bank was caused by a run on the bank. The company was not, at least until clients started rushing for the exits, insolvent or even close to insolvent. But banking is an enterprise that relies as much on confidence as on cash — and if that runs out, the game is over.

headline: Nikki Haley’s Résumé Is Perfect. It Might Not Matter.
abstract: What lane is left for women running for national office?
lead_paragraph: Last month, I listened to my former colleagues on Slate’s “Political Gabfest” podcast discuss Nikki Haley after she declared her run for president. John Dickerson, also of CBS News, explained that in a pre-Donald Trump world, you could make a strong case about Haley’s credentials for the job:

headline: Chris Rock Looks Very Small Right Now
abstract: I’m not sure there was anything he could have done to rise to the occasion, given his apparent inability to evolve as a comic.
lead_paragraph: After Will Smith slapped Chris Rock in front of the entire world at the 2022 Oscars, we wondered how Mr. Rock would respond. And then, just over a week before the 2023 Oscars, at a taping for his Netflix special in Baltimore — which happens to be Jada Pinkett Smith’s hometown (a particularly petty choice) — Mr. Rock entered the fray.

headline: My Life With Tom Cruise
abstract: How the ageless actor has held my — and our — unbroken attention for a lifetime.
lead_paragraph: The other night, after the dishes were washed, the coffee machine set, the dog let out and the kids asleep, I planted myself on the couch with the TV remote in one hand, scrolling, and my phone in the other, scrolling. Settling on the bigger screen, I clicked on “Mission: Impossible — Rogue Nation” to find Tom Cruise dangling by his fingertips from a Russian cargo plane while sporting a business casual suit.

headline: What Old and Young Americans Owe One Another
abstract: Social Security and Medicare should bring generations together, not tear them apart.
lead_paragraph: The latest round of rhetorical warfare about America’s old-age entitlement system has revealed the poverty of our political vocabulary.

headline: Who Benefits From Confrontation With China?
abstract: Pursuing disengagement from China is not in America’s national interest.
lead_paragraph: America’s increasingly confrontational posture toward China is a significant shift in U.S. foreign policy that warrants greater scrutiny and debate.

headline: People Have a Right to Nonreligious Rehab
abstract: All addiction treatment should be science-based.
lead_paragraph: In December, Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York unexpectedly vetoed a bipartisan bill that would have required judges to inform drug court participants of their right to choose nonreligious rehabilitation.

headline: Stripping Confederate Ties, the U.S. Navy Renames Two Vessels
abstract: The vessels will be named for Robert Smalls, a mariner who commandeered a Confederate ship to freedom from slavery, and Marie Tharp, an ocean geologist who studied continental drift.
lead_paragraph: One night in 1862, as the Civil War raged, an enslaved mariner named Robert Smalls seized an opportunity.

headline: Disinformation Is Not the Real Problem With Democracy
abstract: Americans increasingly lack the information they need to participate in the political process.
lead_paragraph: Next week I’m giving a talk on journalism and democracy, and I thought I would use the newsletter this weekend to think out loud about the subject.

headline: Corruption Watchdog Moves to Clear South African President in Cash-in-Couch Incident
abstract: After $580,000 was stolen from a sofa of President Cyril Ramaphosa, his head of security skirted regulations, but the president did not, according to a preliminary report by a corruption watchdog.
lead_paragraph: A powerful South African corruption watchdog has found that President Cyril Ramaphosa committed no wrongdoing in connection with the theft of more than half a million dollars stashed in a sofa at his game farm three years ago.

headline: Awards Season, With a Sustainable Twist
abstract: At the Green Carpet Fashion Awards, celebrities showed off their responsible gowns and suits and vegan leather.
lead_paragraph: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — On Thursday night, in a bit of counterprogramming to the stream of gowns, jewelry and tuxedos of awards season, the organization Eco-Age drew celebrities out to the Green Carpet Fashion Awards, an event spotlighting those in fashion and entertainment who are embracing sustainable practices.

headline: I’m Ready for Deliveries at My Door Again, but My Building Still Says No
abstract: Delivery culture has changed with the pandemic and the proliferation of online services. Some buildings are hesitant to go back to the old days.
lead_paragraph: Q: I live in an Upper West Side co-op building with about 80 apartments and a 24-hour doorman. During the pandemic, our building restricted takeout food deliveries, holding them at the front desk for residents to fetch themselves, rather than letting the delivery workers bring them to our doors. While other buildings have reversed similar policies, my building’s board has refused to restore door-to-door delivery, only saying some residents do not like the service. Plenty of us want to get takeout food delivered to our doors in our pajamas again. Does the board have the right to permanently revoke this service?

headline: Why Did Ultrathin Models Make a Comeback at Fashion Week?
abstract: Castings of midsize and plus size models fell by almost a quarter compared with last season, according to new data.
lead_paragraph: As Paris Fashion Week came to a close this week — and with it the season in fashion, after almost two months of men’s and women’s wear shows — one controversial industry trend reared its head once again: a lack of size diversity on the runways.

headline: Silicon Valley Bank Collapse Sets Off Blame Game in Tech Industry
abstract: The implosion of the Silicon Valley bank led to finger-pointing, as executives and investors jumped on the crisis for their own messaging.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For once, the crisis didn’t seem to revolve around a cryptocurrency company.

headline: Mary Bauermeister, Avant-Garde Artist and Host, Dies at 88
abstract: She played a key role in the freewheeling performance art of the 1960s, and her biggest impact may have come from the open house she kept in an attic studio.
lead_paragraph: Mary Bauermeister, a German artist who played a signature role in the development of the freewheeling performance art of the 1960s avant-garde, died on March 2 at a hospice in Bergisch Gladbach, Germany. She was 88.

headline: How Mia Couto’s Words Help Weave the Story of Mozambique
abstract: Couto’s language is enriched by his country’s idioms, voices — and possibilities. “We are still in the process of creating one nation,” he said, made of “different languages, different beliefs.”
lead_paragraph: MAPUTO, Mozambique — Sipping sparkling water in an upscale neighborhood of Maputo, Mozambique’s capital, Mia Couto, arguably the best-known writer in Portuguese-speaking Africa, leaned back to tell the story of the day when words failed him.

headline: Bud Grant, Longtime Minnesota Vikings Coach, Dies at 95
abstract: He took his Vikings, with Fran Tarkenton at quarterback and the famed Purple People Eaters defensive line, to four Super Bowls — although he lost each time.
lead_paragraph: Bud Grant, the stoic, strait-laced Hall of Fame coach who led the Minnesota Vikings for 18 years, building a team that went to four Super Bowls and was one of the best of the 1970s, died on Saturday at his home in Bloomington, Minn. He was 95.

headline: An Activist’s Flight Reveals Widening Repression in Algeria
abstract: Four years after a popular uprising fueled hopes for change and real democracy, the country’s government is using vaguely defined statutes to round up hundreds.
lead_paragraph: When Amira Bouraoui, an Algerian-French pro-democracy activist, boarded a plane to France from Tunisia last month, she thought her ordeal had finally come to an end.

headline: Trump Knows How to Make Promises. Do His Rivals?
abstract: Mike Pence and Nikki Haley somehow manage to propose ideas that are both implausible and unpopular.
lead_paragraph: To understand the resilience of Donald Trump’s influence in the Republican Party, the way he always seems to revive despite scandal, debacle or disgrace, look no further than the contrast between his early policy forays in the 2024 campaign and what two of his prospective challengers are doing.

headline: 3 Lessons From Silicon Valley Bank’s Failure
abstract: Here’s one takeaway: The bank’s extremely online clientele may have contributed to its downfall.
lead_paragraph: What can the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank teach us about the tech industry?

headline: School District Sued Over Handling of Student’s Pledge of Allegiance Protest
abstract: A South Carolina high school teacher shoved a student against a wall after the teenager refused to stop for the pledge on her way to class, according to a federal lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: The parents of a South Carolina ninth grader said in a federal lawsuit that a teacher pushed their daughter into a wall after she ignored demands to acknowledge the Pledge of Allegiance as it was broadcast over her high school’s intercom.

headline: This and That
abstract: You’ll need to see the big picture to figure out this Sunday gem by David Tuffs.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Stalker Fatally Shoots Audio Streamer and Husband, Police Say
abstract: The police in Redmond, Wash., said the gunman had been stalking the woman, who appeared on an audio stream on the social media app Clubhouse.
lead_paragraph: An audio streamer and her husband were fatally shot in Redmond, Wash., early on Friday morning by a fan who had been stalking the woman, the police said.

headline: As the Rains Ease in California, Many See the Damage Rise
abstract: While the storm slowed on Saturday, flooded rivers forced some residents to evacuate, while others surveyed the destruction that was left behind.
lead_paragraph: SPRINGVILLE, Calif. — Cassandra Honeyman spent Saturday helping salvage what she could from her aunt’s home. Ruined furniture sat on the back patio, and mud covered the interior of the one-story country house in Springville, a rural community of 1,100 in the Sierra Nevada foothills that is surrounded by green mountains and the Tule River in the San Joaquin Valley.

headline: What to Expect on Selection Sunday
abstract: The Big 12 should dominate the men’s bracket, while women’s teams will all want to avoid South Carolina’s region.
lead_paragraph: March may be 12 days old already, but its namesake madness doesn’t start until Sunday.

headline: Corrections: March 12, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, March 12, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about Rupert Murdoch’s management of his media outlets in the days following the 2020 presidential election misstated which publications Mr. Murdoch used to pressure former President Donald J. Trump to stop talking about voter fraud after the 2020 presidential election. Emails included in the defamation suit brought against Fox News showed that Mr. Murdoch directed Fox News and The New York Post to do so, not The Wall Street Journal.

headline: The Intersecting Meanings of ‘Gridlock’ in The Times’s Archives
abstract: Traffic jams. Political stalemates. Strollers at Walt Disney World. “Gridlock,” a term coined in the 1970s, has a short yet rich history in the newspaper.
lead_paragraph: In Word Through The Times, we trace how one word or phrase has changed throughout the history of the newspaper.

headline: ‘I Always Bought a Grapefruit From the Bodega Across the Street’
abstract: A morning routine in Park Slope, a standoff on the M11 and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Fox’s P.R. Woes May Not Directly Translate to Legal Ones
abstract: Some of the unflattering private messages among the network’s hosts and executives may never become evidence when Dominion Voting Systems’ defamation case against Fox News goes to trial.
lead_paragraph: For the past three weeks, a drip, drip, drip of disclosures have exposed widespread alarm and disbelief inside Fox News in the days after the 2020 presidential election, as the network became a platform for some of the most insidious lies about widespread voter fraud. These revelations are the most damning to rattle the Murdoch media empire since the phone hacking scandal in Britain more than a decade ago.

headline: Little-Known Lawyer, a Trump Ally, Draws Scrutiny in Georgia
abstract: A special grand jury looking into election meddling interviewed Robert Cheeley, a sign that false claims made by Donald J. Trump’s allies loom large in the case.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — At a Georgia State Senate hearing a few weeks after President Donald J. Trump lost his bid for re-election, Rudolph W. Giuliani began making outlandish claims. “There are 10 ways to demonstrate that this election was stolen, that the votes were phony, that there were a lot of them — dead people, felons, phony ballots,” he told the assembled legislators.

headline: A Column That Listens for What’s Not Being Said
abstract: Shop Talk examines the business jargon used by executives to elevate ordinary functions and conceal ugly truths.
lead_paragraph: Perusing LinkedIn might not seem like the typical way to spend your downtime. But for Lora Kelley, a New York Times business reporting fellow interested in the ways business shapes culture, the platform is a gold mine for reporting ideas.

headline: With Fingerprints, DNA and Photos, Turkey Seeks Families of the Missing
abstract: More than a thousand earthquake victims are still unaccounted for. Some families waited for days by ruined buildings, hoping to see bodies that never surfaced.
lead_paragraph: When a powerful earthquake struck southern Turkey last month, a lawyer concluded that her relatives had been buried in the rubble of their collapsed apartment.

headline: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Goes to the Oscars
abstract: Jenna Ortega hosted an episode that featured appearances by Fred Armisen and also took aim at Tucker Carlson and a Tennessee politician with questionable Instagram habits.
lead_paragraph: There was a time — say, just before a certain incident near the end of last year’s Academy Awards show — when the ceremony itself was a dignified proceeding and the embarrassment was largely confined to the preshow red carpet program.

headline: Yulia Navalnaya Will Step Out at the Oscars
abstract: The wife of the jailed Russian dissident Alexei Navalny plans to stride the carpet in a red Chloé gown to deliver a message of resistance.
lead_paragraph: When Yulia Navalnaya arrives at the Oscars on Sunday night, it will not be her first time on the red carpet. She was in London last month to collect a British Academy Film Award for “Navalny,” the Daniel Roher documentary that details events surrounding the near-fatal poisoning of her husband, the political dissident Alexei Navalny, and his subsequent arrest by Russian authorities.

headline: Making Deepfakes Gets Cheaper and Easier Thanks to A.I.
abstract: Meme-makers and misinformation peddlers are embracing artificial intelligence tools to create convincing fake videos on the cheap.
lead_paragraph: It wouldn’t be completely out of character for Joe Rogan, the comedian turned podcaster, to endorse a “libido-boosting” coffee brand for men.

headline: Adam Brody Feels All the Feels With Surfing, ‘Avatar’ and Cate Le Bon
abstract: The “Shazam!” star revives himself with sprinkle doughnuts, Frank Black’s “Teenager of the Year” and daily naps.
lead_paragraph: “Shazam!,” the 2019 DC Universe comic-adventure about some foster kids and their adult superhero alter egos, and its new sequel, “Shazam! Fury of the Gods,” might not change the arc of Adam Brody’s career exactly — though there are perks to being in a hit.

headline: The Impossible Allure of the Perfect Bracket
abstract: College basketball fans are on the hunt for the perfect bracket every year. The odds are not in their favor.
lead_paragraph: A blank college basketball bracket is a beautiful thing. It is a ski slope cloaked in fresh snow, enticingly unsullied, waiting to be slalomed upon.

headline: The Life of an Indian Princess, Cloaked in Mystery
abstract: After chancing upon a 1924 photo of Her Royal Highness Rani Shri Amrit Kaur Sahib in a Mumbai museum, an Italian journalist set out to discover who she was.
lead_paragraph: In 2007, the Italian journalist Livia Manera Sambuy stumbled across a nonfiction writer’s dream in a Mumbai museum: a tantalizing true story, unknown to the world. Alongside a 1924 photograph of an Indian princess — “tall, dark-skinned, her hair tied up,” wearing “a translucent sari, its edges embroidered with gold or silver thread” — there was a caption that identified her as “Her Royal Highness Rani Shri Amrit Kaur Sahib.” It noted that she had been arrested by the Gestapo during World War II in occupied Paris, charged with selling her jewelry to help Jews leave the country, and had died while imprisoned.

headline: What Would You Wear to the Oscars?
abstract: For nominees who aren’t household names, it can take some resourcefulness to get dressed for one of the biggest nights of their careers.
lead_paragraph: In 1997, Jessica Yu won an Academy Award for her short documentary “Breathing Lessons: The Life and Work of Mark O’Brien.” “What a thrill,” she said in her acceptance speech. “You know you’ve entered new territory when you realize that your outfit cost more than your film.”

headline: From ‘Hitler’ to ‘Sharing One Fate’: Saudi-Iran Pact Could Transform the Middle East
abstract: Both countries as well as the broader region have much to gain from the reset in relations — if the agreement truly holds.
lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — Only five years ago, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, the de facto ruler of Saudi Arabia, derided Iran’s supreme leader, saying he “makes Hitler look good.” Last week in a development that had the world doing metaphorical double takes, the Saudis not only re-established diplomatic relations with Tehran but also spoke gauzily of the countries “sharing one fate.”

headline: Fathers Gained Family Time in the Pandemic. Many Don’t Want to Give It Back.
abstract: A substantial share of fathers who took on more domestic work during lockdowns have kept it up, new data shows, and rearranged their work lives to do so.
lead_paragraph: When the pandemic hit, Steve Gaffney was laid off from his longtime job at a company that provided lighting for events. Three weeks later, his daughter Morgan was born.

headline: Restoring Glory of Angola’s Carnival, With a Puny Budget but Much Passion
abstract: A singer and son of a music legend is trying to once again make the Carnival celebration a highlight of the year — and to make it a year-round force for positive change in Angola.
lead_paragraph: The singer stood in a rubble-strewn courtyard in one of the hard-knock neighborhoods of Luanda, Angola’s capital, antsy as he got the performers in line for their final rehearsal before the big competition.

headline: ‘Million-Dollar Staircase’ Adds a New Face: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
abstract: After 125 years, the male-dominated architectural fixture of New York’s Capitol is getting an update.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, N.Y. — Even then, the gender imbalance was glaring.

headline: Saudi Aramco Reports Record Profit as Fossil Fuels Remain ‘Essential’
abstract: Saudi Arabia’s national oil company earned $161 billion last year, a nearly 50 percent jump over 2021, and said demand for oil would continue.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Aramco, the national oil company for Saudi Arabia, reported on Sunday that the company last year had net income of $161.1 billion — a 47 percent increase over 2021 and a record since Aramco started offering shares on the local Tadawuhl stock exchange in 2019.

headline: Ukraine Steps Up Calls for Evacuation of Kupiansk Under Relentless Russian Shelling
abstract: Attacks on the northeast town in the Kharkiv region of Ukraine continued on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Months after Russian soldiers were driven out of Kupiansk, Ukrainian authorities are stepping up efforts to evacuate civilians from the town in the Kharkiv region of northeast Ukraine amid relentless Russian shelling.

headline: What if the Next Pandemic Happens Tomorrow?
abstract: Eight experts debate what to do.
lead_paragraph: Eight experts debate what to do.

headline: How to Prepare for the Next Pandemic
abstract: America should be ready for Disease X.
lead_paragraph: Late last year, I participated in an exercise meant to play out what might happen if the world was presented with a new disease spreading quickly, with no warning.

headline: What Really Controls Our Global Economy
abstract: Economic zones are fundamental to understanding modern-day capitalism.
lead_paragraph: After decades of giddy globalization, the pendulum is swinging back to the nation.

headline: This Changes Everything
abstract: I have tried to spend time regularly with the people working on A.I. I don’t know that I can convey just how weird that culture is.
lead_paragraph: In 2018, Sundar Pichai, the chief executive of Google — and not one of the tech executives known for overstatement — said, “A.I. is probably the most important thing humanity has ever worked on. I think of it as something more profound than electricity or fire.”

headline: Don’t Let the Culture War Degrade the Constitution
abstract: Our right to free expression should not be contingent on our ability to gain political control.
lead_paragraph: The Constitution of the United States, properly interpreted, provides a marvelous method for handling social conflict. It empowers an elected government to enact even contentious new rules while protecting the most fundamental human rights of dissenting citizens. Political defeat is never total defeat. Losers of a given election still possess their basic civil liberties, and the combination of the right to speak and the right to vote provides them concrete hope for their preferred political outcomes.

headline: A Chinese Commonwealth? An Unpopular Idea Resurfaces in Taiwan.
abstract: The war in Ukraine is causing many Taiwanese to rethink their relationship with China.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Three months after Russia invaded Ukraine, Annette Lu, a former vice president of Taiwan, stood before reporters to promote a wildly unpopular idea. China and Taiwan, she said, should form a commonwealth that would be integrated economically, like the European Union, but remain separate politically. She called it One Zhonghua — a word that means “Chinese” in a cultural, ethnic or literary sense but is distinct from the word that refers to China in a political sense. It was a wink at the Chinese Communist Party’s insistence that there is only one China and that Taiwan is an inextricable part of it.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘Can Germany Be a Great Military Power Again?’
abstract: Leery of Russian aggression, Europe’s economic giant is making a historic attempt to revitalize its armed forces. It has a long way to go.
lead_paragraph: After Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February last year, Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany told Parliament that the attack was a Zeitenwende — a historic “turning point” for Europe and Germany. The risk of a large land war in Europe had previously been considered far-fetched, but recent years of Russian aggression have inspired fear in Germany and a 100-billion-euro fund to bolster its military.

headline: Will the Future of Alaska’s Wild Lands Hang on a Dispute Over a Gravel Road?
abstract: A federal court will rule soon on whether the Interior secretary can swap government land so a road can be built through a wilderness wildlife refuge.
lead_paragraph: In June 1962, I graduated from high school, purchased my first airline ticket and set off for Alaska. I had talked myself into a summer job with the United States Fish and Wildlife Service. My job included weekly flights with a bush pilot delivering supplies to points all over the Alaska Peninsula.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Turkey’s Effort to Find Traces of Loved Ones
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 12, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “I can’t find my father anywhere in the world — not under the rubble, not in the hospitals, not anywhere.”

headline: The First Book of Spring
abstract: A book can be an accomplice in a coup against winter.
lead_paragraph: The first day of spring is technically a date on the calendar. But your first day of spring is subjective.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | March 13, 2023
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:

headline: The Real Problem With the ‘He Gets Us’ Ads
abstract: Those slick ads for Jesus are trivial. Our reaction to them is troubling.
lead_paragraph: About a year ago, I noticed a “He Gets Us” ad on a billboard. I gathered that the “he” in “He Gets Us” referred to Jesus, but beyond that I didn’t pay it a lot of attention.

headline: Haunted by His Sister’s Killing, a Brother Gets Answers More Than 46 Years Later
abstract: The killing of Carol Sue Klaber, 16, in Kentucky in 1976 traumatized a family and left relatives and the authorities searching for the person responsible.
lead_paragraph: The detectives would arrive soon, so Thomas Klaber made deli sandwiches and coffee at his Cleveland home as he wondered what new information they had about the killing of his younger sister more than four decades ago.

headline: Authorities Reinstate Alcohol Ban for Aboriginal Australians
abstract: The reaction to a rise in crime has renewed hard questions about race and control, and about the open wounds of discrimination.
lead_paragraph: Geoff Shaw cracked open a beer, savoring the simple freedom of having a drink on his porch on a sweltering Saturday morning in mid-February in Australia’s remote Northern Territory.

headline: Regulators Close Another Bank and Move to Protect Deposits
abstract: The Treasury, Federal Reserve and Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation unveiled a plan to contain fallout from Silicon Valley Bank’s collapse, and said taxpayers would not bear the costs.
lead_paragraph: Federal regulators announced on Sunday that another bank had been closed and that the government would ensure that all depositors of Silicon Valley Bank — which failed Friday — would be paid back in full as Washington rushed to keep fallout from the collapse of the large institution from sweeping through the financial system.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Ricotta pasta alla vodka, cauliflower shawarma and more recipes.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. One of the many things I love about the community we’ve built here at New York Times Cooking is the notes that subscribers add to the recipes. The notes are, for the most part, helpful and kind, often funny and probing. And if there are plenty who say they substituted sardines for the chicken and the recipe’s awful, there are many more who bring their history and culture to bear in what they write, and who lift us all with their experience.

headline: War in Ukraine Puts Centuries of Swiss Neutrality to the Test
abstract: The Alpine state makes arms that Western allies want to send to Kyiv. Swiss law bans this, driving a national debate about whether its concept of neutrality should change.
lead_paragraph: In Eastern Europe, Ukrainians are in the trenches. Farther west, European capitals are grappling with a new order in which war is no longer theoretical. Yet, tucked away in the heart of the continent, the Swiss are fretting over loftier ideals.

headline: The Week in Business: Fox News Anchors’ Private Messages
abstract: President Biden offers a proposed budget. Jobs numbers once again soared past analysts’ forecasts. And we’ll get a new inflation figure this week.
lead_paragraph: New documents released last week revealed the disconnect between the Fox News anchors’ privately held opinions and those they espoused publicly — and shared with millions of viewers — on their television programs. In particular, Tucker Carlson’s views on Donald J. Trump and the outcome of the 2020 presidential race have been shown to contrast sharply with the messaging of his show, which supported Mr. Trump and promoted his unfounded belief that the election had been stolen. Yet at the same time, Mr. Carlson was sending texts to members of his staff about Mr. Trump like “I hate him passionately.” He is not the only Fox employee to be featured in the documents, which are part of the $1.6 billion defamation suit against Fox News by the voting technology company Dominion Voting Systems and include the messages of other network stars like Laura Ingraham. But Mr. Carlson’s texts include some of the starkest language about the former president and drew special attention from the White House in a statement on Wednesday criticizing Mr. Carlson for his on-air portrayal of the Jan. 6 Capitol attack as a largely peaceful event.

headline: Spiraling Dispute With Star Host Puts BBC’s Reputation on the Line
abstract: The British public broadcaster’s suspension of one of its highest-profile sports anchors has grown into a wider controversy that poses risks to its reputation for neutrality and independence.
lead_paragraph: As an English soccer star, Gary Lineker was renowned for never having been penalized with a yellow or red card in his 16-year career. As a politically opinionated sports broadcaster for the BBC, Mr. Lineker has tangled regularly with the officials, and his suspension over a Twitter post on immigration this week escalated into a crisis that now engulfs the British Broadcasting Corporation.

headline: Jesus Alou, Youngest in Trio of Baseball-Playing Brothers, Dies at 80
abstract: He and his brothers, Felipe and Matty, were the only three brothers in major league history to play together in a single game.
lead_paragraph: Jesus Alou, who joined with his brothers Felipe and Matty in blazing a trail for Dominican natives in the major leagues, died on Friday. He was 80.

headline: ‘Potent’ Nor’easter to Bring Heavy Snow, Forecasters Say
abstract: The storm could produce snowfall rates of two inches or more an hour, with areas of higher elevation getting accumulations of more than a foot, forecasters said.
lead_paragraph: A late-winter nor’easter is expected to bring widespread heavy, wet snow, rain and gusty winds to parts of the Northeast that had otherwise had a largely snowless season starting Monday night and lasting into Wednesday, according to the National Weather Service.

headline: At Least 8 Dead After Boats Capsize in Human Smuggling Attempt in San Diego
abstract: Searchers recovered bodies, life jackets and fuel barrels in what one official described as “one of the worst maritime smuggling tragedies” in recent years.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Along a San Diego beach chewed away by winter swells, at least eight people died after the small boats they were in capsized in what the authorities said on Sunday was a human smuggling operation gone awry.

headline: Finding Refuge, and More, in the Arts
abstract: Readers identify with David Brooks’s account of how art enriches his life. Also: Latinx; Asian Americans’ rightward shift; altering art.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Pat McCormick, Olympic Diving Champion, Is Dead at 92
abstract: The first diver to sweep the gold medals in two Olympics, she won numerous national championships in a career that ended when she was still in her 20s.
lead_paragraph: Pat McCormick, the first diver to sweep the gold medals in two Olympics, died on Tuesday at an assisted living facility in Santa Ana, Calif. She was 92.

headline: Oscars 2023 Winners: The Complete List
abstract: The list of winners for the 95th Academy Awards.
lead_paragraph: The 95th Academy Awards were held Sunday night at the Dolby Theater in Los Angeles. “Everything Everywhere All at Once,” the proudly weird sci-fi movie from Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert, swept most of the top categories, including best picture and directing.

headline: Review: A Pianist’s Inheritance Inspires Little Masterpieces
abstract: Adam Tendler’s program of works that he commissioned from 16 composers after the death of his father is emotionally involving and musically rewarding.
lead_paragraph: When the pianist Adam Tendler received an inheritance — really, a manila envelope stuffed with cash — it did not take him long to think of a smart way to put it to use.

headline: Before the Oscars, the Parties Are Everything
abstract: The celebrities are having a ball, everywhere the fashion brands play host.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Late Saturday afternoon, the best actress nominee Michelle Yeoh — decked out in a shimmering pink Armani top, a chunky diamond-encrusted, oval-shaped bracelet on one wrist and a six-figure, skeleton-dial Richard Mille timepiece on the other — stood by a glass staircase in front of Giorgio Armani’s mammoth Beverly Hills boutique.

headline: ‘History Will Hold Donald Trump Accountable’ for Jan. 6, Pence Says
abstract: At a Washington dinner event, Mike Pence criticized the president he served under as well as Republicans who are minimizing the Capitol riot.
lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Mike Pence, delivering his strongest public rebuke yet to the president who made him his running mate, said on Saturday night “that history will hold Donald Trump accountable” for the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol, which he called “a disgrace.”

headline: Judge in Abortion Pill Case Set Hearing but Sought to Delay Telling the Public
abstract: Saying he wanted safe and orderly proceedings, Judge Matthew J. Kacsmaryk asked lawyers not to disclose the hearing and planned to add it to the public case file only the evening before.
lead_paragraph: The federal judge in a closely watched lawsuit that seeks to overturn federal approval of a widely used abortion pill has scheduled the first hearing in the case for this week, but he planned to delay making the public aware of it, according to people familiar with the case.

headline: What Do You Think of the Oscars Show?
abstract: The Times invites readers to share their comments and observations about the 2023 Academy Awards.
lead_paragraph: As The Times covers the 95th Academy Awards, from the (not actually red) red carpet to the best picture announcement, we invite readers to share their comments here.

headline: Your Monday Briefing: China’s Saudi-Iran Deal
abstract: Also, Xi Jinping loyalists stack China’s leadership and Australia revives an Aboriginal alcohol ban.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia and Iran announced that they had agreed to re-establish diplomatic ties on Friday after years of fighting proxy conflicts. The deal, facilitated by China, highlights Beijing’s growing importance in the Middle East — and, some say, the U.S.’s waning influence there.

headline: Who Are You Wearing? For Costume Designers, the Answer May Be ‘Me.’
abstract: The five Oscar nominees for costume design approach red-carpet fashion with an eye toward storytelling.
lead_paragraph: Last year, their work transported audiences to Paris and to Graceland, to an underwater kingdom, to parallel dimensions with googly-eyed rocks and hot dog fingers — and to the decadent depths of 1920s Hollywood.

headline: Biden Administration Approves Huge Alaska Oil Project
abstract: The administration also announced new limits on Arctic drilling in an apparent effort to temper criticism over the $8 billion Willow oil project, which has faced sharp opposition.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration gave formal approval Monday for a huge oil drilling project in Alaska known as Willow, despite widespread opposition because of its likely environmental and climate impacts.

headline: 2023 Oscars: Every Look From the Not-So-Red Carpet
abstract: Hollywood’s brightest stars battled to make the biggest splash on the champagne carpet before the 95th Academy Awards.
lead_paragraph: For the 95th Academy Awards, some things changed — crisis management team, check; red carpet replaced with neutral color, check — but other things stayed very much the same.

headline: Silicon Valley Bank Collapse Threatens Climate Start-Ups
abstract: The bank had relationships with more than 1,500 companies working on technologies aimed at curbing global warming.
lead_paragraph: As the fallout of the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank continued to spread over the weekend, it became clear that some of the worst casualties were companies developing solutions for the climate crisis.

headline: Bamboozled
abstract: Sam Koperwas and Jeff Chen are just giving you a hard time.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: 2023 N.C.A.A. Men’s Tournament Bracket
abstract: Follow the latest scores and bracket updates as the tournament unfolds.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest scores and bracket updates as the tournament unfolds.

headline: How the Slap Has Changed the Oscars
abstract: Here’s a look at the fallout from last year’s Oscars, when Will Smith slapped Chris Rock onstage.
lead_paragraph: The Slap is sure to figure into the Oscars this year, even if the academy would prefer we all move on from the shocking moment on March 27, 2022, when Will Smith slapped Chris Rock onstage. The organization has said tonight’s telecast will not dwell on the episode. Then again, it has set up a crisis team to deal with any unexpected developments at the ceremony, proof that the incident continues to cast a long shadow. It will inform what you will — and won’t — see at the Dolby Theater tonight.

headline: Seedings for N.C.A.A. Men’s Tournament Show Wide-Open Field
abstract: Alabama, Houston, Kansas and Purdue earned No. 1 seeds in a tournament where top teams seem more beatable than usual, and others that usually might be considered upstarts have viable paths to the championship.
lead_paragraph: When the N.C.A.A. Division I men’s basketball tournament committee members hunkered down in Indianapolis over the weekend, they pored over spreadsheets, stared at a bank of televisions, sharpened their pencils and massaged their temples to figure out how to best seed the 68-team tournament field.

headline: A Camera Containing Radioactive Material Is Missing in the Houston Area
abstract: While multiple layers of protection surround the radioactive material, and levels of radiation outside the camera are not dangerous, it should be handled with care, state officials said.
lead_paragraph: An industrial camera that contains sealed-off radioactive material has been missing for several days in the Houston area after workers noticed it was gone from their work site, the Texas Department of State Health Services said.

headline: 2023 N.C.A.A. Women’s Tournament Bracket
abstract: Sixty-eight teams will take their shot at the national championship. See the bracket here.
lead_paragraph: Sixty-eight teams will take their shot at the national championship. See the bracket here.

headline: Ke Huy Quan Wins Best Supporting Actor Oscar, Capping a Remarkable Comeback
abstract: “My journey started on a boat. I spent a year in a refugee camp. And somehow, I ended up here on Hollywood’s biggest stage,” he said in his acceptance speech.
lead_paragraph: Ke Huy Quan won the Oscar for his supporting role in “Everything Everywhere All At Once” at the 95th Academy Awards on Sunday night, completing one of the most impressive Hollywood comebacks of all time.

headline: South Carolina Tops N.C.A.A. Women’s Tournament Field
abstract: There are challengers, of course, but no team is tougher on paper than the undefeated, reigning champion Gamecocks.
lead_paragraph: When the 68-team field for the N.C.A.A. Division I women’s basketball tournament was announced on Sunday night, the least surprising selection was the No. 1 overall seed: South Carolina. The Gamecocks, who are also the reigning champion, will anchor a portion of the bracket that has its regional in nearby Greenville, S.C.

headline: Jimmy Kimmel Addressed ‘the Slap’ in His Opening Monologue
abstract: Kimmel’s remarks also included joking jabs at some of Hollywood’s most famous figures.
lead_paragraph: In naming Jimmy Kimmel the host for a third Oscars, this year’s producers, Glenn Weiss and Ricky Kirshner, cited the veteran’s readiness to handle anything that live television might throw at him.

headline: Jamie Lee Curtis Wins Best Supporting Actress, Her First Oscar
abstract: “I know it looks like I’m standing up here by myself, but I am not. I am hundreds of people,” she said in her acceptance speech.
lead_paragraph: After a tight three-way race, “Everything Everywhere All at Once” co-star Jamie Lee Curtis won the supporting actress Oscar at the 95th Academy Awards on Sunday night, pulling ahead of Angela Bassett (“Black Panther: Wakanda Forever”) and Kerry Condon (“The Banshees of Inisherin”).

headline: Lesson Plan: A New Child Labor Crisis in America
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn about how migrant children work brutal jobs across the United States. Then they consider what they would do if they were president.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “Alone and Exploited, Migrant Children Work Brutal Jobs Across the U.S.” by Hannah Dreier and “The Daily” episode “A New Child Labor Crisis in America”

headline: ‘The Last of Us’ Season 1 Finale: A Deadly Operation
abstract: Ellie grapples quietly with the shock of last week’s events. Joel goes into full video game mode.
lead_paragraph: As I mentioned back when “The Last of Us” premiered, I have never played the video game, so I can’t compare the show’s action sequences with how they come across in the original. I can say this though: In the season finale, there is a climactic shootout that closely resembles what most people think of when they imagine a game with a lot of killing, as Joel blasts his way through staircases and hallways, leaving a trail of corpses.

headline: North Korea Launches Cruise Missiles From Submarine
abstract: The missile test, the first of its kind carried out by the North, took place as South Korea and the United States were about to begin joint military exercises.
lead_paragraph: North Korea said on Monday that it had fired two strategic cruise missiles from a submarine, its first such missile test, as South Korea and the United States were about to begin a major joint military exercise.

headline: Risky Bet on Crypto and a Run on Deposits Tank Signature Bank
abstract: Regulators said keeping open the 24-year-old institution, which held deposits from law firms and real estate companies, could threaten the financial system’s stability.
lead_paragraph: Signature Bank, a New York financial institution with a big real estate lending business that had recently made a play to win cryptocurrency deposits, closed its doors abruptly on Sunday, after regulators said that keeping the bank open could threaten the stability of the entire financial system.

headline: To Perform ‘Hold My Hand,’ Lady Gaga Goes au Naturel
abstract: The artist wasn’t even set to take the stage. Instead she exchanged her initially glamorous look for a stripped-down one to suit her intense delivery.
lead_paragraph: After originally not even being set to perform, Lady Gaga made a big impression on Sunday night when she took the stage to sing the Oscar-nominated “Hold My Hand,” which she wrote with BloodPop for “Top Gun: Maverick.”

headline: Ride to Survive
abstract: The Natural Selection Tour pushes snowboarders beyond their comfort zone. The start line? A helicopter.
lead_paragraph: The Natural Selection Tour pushes snowboarders beyond their comfort zone. The start line? A helicopter.

headline: ‘Naatu Naatu’ From ‘RRR’ Wins Best Original Song
abstract: The rollicking dance hit beat out two songs featuring American pop megastars.
lead_paragraph: “Naatu Naatu,” the rollicking dance hit from the Indian blockbuster “RRR,” won the Oscar for best original song, beating out two songs featuring American pop megastars.

headline: The Daniels Become the Third Directing Duo to Win an Oscar
abstract: Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert won for their multiverse mash-up, “Everything Everywhere All at Once,” making them the rare set of paired directors to win the big prize.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert won the best director Oscar for their poignant, warmhearted multiverse mash-up, “Everything Everywhere All at Once,” on Sunday night, making them the rare set of paired directors to win the big prize.

headline: Michelle Yeoh Makes History as the First Asian Best Actress Winner at the Oscars
abstract: All season long the star of “Everything Everywhere All at Once” has spoken of the obstacles she and other people of color faced in Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: Michelle Yeoh won the best actress Oscar at Sunday night’s ceremony for her role as a beleaguered wife, mother and laundromat owner whose life is turned upside down when she is thrown into multiple parallel universes in A24’s genre-bending hit “Everything, Everywhere All at Once.” The victory makes her the first Asian star to win best actress in the 95-year history of the Academy Awards.

headline: Why Were Oscar Nominees Wearing Blue Ribbons? They Stand #WithRefugees.
abstract: The pins were initiated by the United Nations Refugee Agency to support people who fled their homes to escape persecution.
lead_paragraph: The Oscar-winning director Guillermo del Toro and the nominated actress Cate Blanchett were among several participants at the Academy Awards on Sunday who donned blue ribbons in support of refugees who fled their homes to escape war, conflict and persecution.

headline: Review: The Increasingly Ordinary Oscars
abstract: A show that’s become a shrink-wrapped, anodyne exercise stuck safely to the script.
lead_paragraph: To paraphrase Greta Garbo, give me back my slap.

headline: Tips to Win an N.C.A.A. Pool Are Everywhere. Many of Them Are Bad.
abstract: It’s easy to pick a bracket with a solid chance for a middling finish. It’s harder to cut through some mediocre advice to push toward a win.
lead_paragraph: As you prepare to fill out your annual N.C.A.A. tournament bracket, grimly determined not to throw away your entry fee yet again, you might be tempted to seek help. There are plenty of articles, websites and message board posts out there that presume to offer the secret to making winning selections.

headline: One Percent of the Budget for Parks? A Bargain, Says a Nonprofit
abstract: New York spends less on its parks than other major cities. Now is not the time to cut funding for them, says New Yorkers for Parks.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. Many New Yorkers who had not spent much time in the city’s 1,700 parks discovered them when so much else was off limits during the pandemic. We’ll look at a report from a nonprofit parks advocacy group that says the parks need a bigger share of the city budget.

headline: ‘Everything Everywhere All at Once’ Is Big Winner at the Oscars
abstract: The futuristic film from the studio A24 won seven awards, including for best picture, directing and in three of the four acting categories.
lead_paragraph: In the late 1960s, young cineastes shook up a moribund film industry by delivering idiosyncratic, startlingly original work. The moment became known as New Hollywood.

headline: Michelle Yeoh: The Crisis That Changed My Life 8 Years Ago Keeps Happening
abstract: As a goodwill ambassador for the United Nations Development Program, I have seen up close how crises like earthquakes can expose deep existing inequalities.
lead_paragraph: Over the past few weeks, many people around the world joined me in celebrating my career firsts — from winning my first Golden Globe, Screen Actors Guild Award and Independent Spirit Award to earning my first Oscar (for actress in a leading role). While I am grateful for this unforgettable moment in my professional life, I want to redirect that global spotlight to an issue that is very personal to me and warrants the world’s attention.

headline: Our Favorite Photos From the Oscars Red* Carpet
abstract: *Yeah, yeah, champagne.
lead_paragraph: For most people who set foot on it, the Oscars red (or in this case, champagne-colored) carpet is the highly choreographed, giddy culmination of months of strategizing, hobnobbing, speechifying and celebrating — like election night with better fashion.

headline: 21 Looks That Did the Most at the Oscars
abstract: The greater the fashion risk, the greater the reward.
lead_paragraph: Color was already a buzzword by the time the first stars showed up at the 95th Academy Awards, thanks to the new champagne rug that replaced the traditional red carpet.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: The collapse of three U.S. banks in a week.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. is racing to contain the consequences of the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank, the largest American bank to fail since the financial crisis in 2008. Federal regulators announced that the government would ensure that all depositors of Silicon Valley Bank would have access to all of their money starting today, and that the losses would not be borne by American taxpayers.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Lucky Hank’ and ‘The Hours’
abstract: A new comedy series starring Bob Odenkirk comes to AMC, and the Metropolitan Opera’s adaptation of “The Hours” premieres on PBS.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, March 13-19. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Something Is Missing From Americans’ Greatest Fears. It’s the Bomb.
abstract: Arms control began at a low point during the Cold War. Are we there again?
lead_paragraph: The announcement last month by President Vladimir Putin of Russia that his country would suspend participation in the last remaining nuclear arms control pact with the United States set off long-dormant alarm bells. American nuclear forces went on red alert, people rushed to restock nuclear shelters, toilet paper and powdered milk vanished from grocery shelves … at least in Mr. Putin’s dreams, given his fantasy of restoring Russia to the salad days of Cold War brinkmanship.

headline: Word of the Day: guile
abstract: This word has appeared in 21 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word guile has appeared in 21 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Dec. 3 in “Messi’s Score Sets Tone for Argentina in World Cup Win” by James Wagner:

headline: Zelensky names a soldier whose death was captured on video a Hero of Ukraine.
abstract: The Ukrainian soldier who was fatally shot in a chilling video that emerged last week has been named a Hero of Ukraine by President Volodymyr Zelensky.
lead_paragraph: The Ukrainian soldier who was fatally shot in a chilling video that emerged last week has been named a Hero of Ukraine by President Volodymyr Zelensky.

headline: Grain deal, Bakhmut and more: What to watch for this week.
abstract: Senior Russian officials were meeting with representatives of the United Nations in Geneva on Monday to discuss extending an agreement that allows cargo ships to transport Ukrainian grain past a Russian blockade.
lead_paragraph: Senior Russian officials were meeting with representatives of the United Nations in Geneva on Monday to discuss extending an agreement that allows cargo ships to transport Ukrainian grain past a Russian blockade.

headline: Stocks Are Poised to Rise Monday as Regulators Act on Silicon Valley Bank
abstract: Officials in Japan, South Korea and India, some of Asia’s largest economies, assuaged concerns of a global ripple effect coming from the United States.
lead_paragraph: After a tumultuous couple of days, stock markets in the United States were poised to rise on Monday as regulators moved to limit the contagion from the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank.

headline: As Economy Falters, China’s New Premier Tries to Boost Business Confidence
abstract: Li Qiang, the country’s No. 2 leader, sought to reassure entrepreneurs who have been wary of making new investments.
lead_paragraph: China’s new premier, the country’s No. 2 leader after Xi Jinping, sought on Monday to reinvigorate confidence in the faltering economy, promising that private-sector companies would be treated equally with state-owned ones and that the property rights and other interests of entrepreneurs would be strictly respected.

headline: 2024 Republicans Converge on Iowa
abstract: The next presidential campaign has barely begun, but official and undeclared candidates are already trying to win over Iowa voters.
lead_paragraph: The next presidential campaign has barely begun, but official and undeclared candidates are already trying to win over Iowa voters.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: In Budget Talks, Biden Rejects Hard Choices of the Past
abstract: The president has met Republican demands for debt reduction with a plan to trim deficits by taxing companies and the rich.
lead_paragraph: Months after losing control of the House in 2010, President Barack Obama and his vice president, Joseph R. Biden Jr., released a budget proposal that bowed to Republican warnings about the need to rein in spending by promising a freeze in popular programs like education.

headline: An A.I. Start-Up Boomed, but Now It Faces a Slowing Economy and New Rules
abstract: Using A.I. tools in hiring is one of the most promising and contentious uses of the technology. The experience of a company called Eightfold AI shows the challenges.
lead_paragraph: In 2016, two computer scientists, both Google alumni, bet that artificial intelligence could help make smarter hiring and promotion decisions.

headline: Opioid Settlement Hinders Patients’ Access to a Wide Array of Drugs
abstract: An agreement between attorneys general and major drug distributors increased scrutiny on medications for A.D.H.D., addiction, anxiety and pain.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a year after a sweeping opioid settlement imposed new requirements on the companies that provide medications to pharmacies, patients across the United States are having difficulty obtaining drugs to treat many conditions, including anxiety, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and addiction.

headline: UPenn Accuses a Law Professor of Racist Statements. Should She Be Fired?
abstract: Amy Wax and free speech groups say the university is trampling on her academic freedom. Students ask whether her speech deserves to be protected.
