lead_paragraph: Amy Wax, a law professor, has said publicly that “on average, Blacks have lower cognitive ability than whites,” that the country is “better off with fewer Asians” as long as they tend to vote for Democrats, and that non-Western people feel a “tremendous amount of resentment and shame.”

headline: HSBC to Buy Silicon Valley Bank’s British Subsidiary
abstract: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak said the country’s financial system was in good health and would not suffer from the demise of Silicon Valley Bank.
lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley Bank’s British subsidiary will be acquired by the banking giant HSBC, the Bank of England announced on Monday as it emphasized the stability of the nation’s banking system.

headline: Kenzaburo Oe, Nobel Laureate and Critic of Postwar Japan, Dies at 88
abstract: With his powerful novels and essays, Mr. Oe tried to ensure that Japan learned the lessons of its 20th-century militarism.
lead_paragraph: Kenzaburo Oe, a Nobel laureate whose intense novels and defiant politics challenged a modern Japanese culture that he found morally vacant and dangerously tilted toward the same mind-set that led to catastrophe in World War II, died on March 3. He was 88.

headline: Guerrilla Gardeners Meet Billionaire Doomsayer. Hurly-Burly Ensues.
abstract: “Birnam Wood,” by the Booker Prize winner Eleanor Catton, is a fast-moving ecological novel and a generational cri de coeur.
lead_paragraph: Eleanor Catton’s third novel, “Birnam Wood,” is a big book, a sophisticated page-turner, that does something improbable: It filters anarchist, monkey-wrenching environmental politics, a generational (anti-baby boomer) cri de coeur and a downhill-racing plot through a Stoppardian sense of humor. The result is thrilling. “Birnam Wood” nearly made me laugh with pleasure. The whole thing crackles, like hair drawn through a pocket comb.

headline: How Much Skin Should I Show Under a Sheer Dress?
abstract: A reader who bought a see-through dress wonders if any “underwear protocol” exists in 2023.
lead_paragraph: Like so much else when it comes to dress these days (trends, dress codes), there is no longer a specific underwear protocol for what to wear under a sheer outfit — only a variety of options. That’s good news on one hand: It’s great to have the freedom to make your own choices, free of strict social dictates. On the other hand, it’s stressful: Who needs so many more everyday decisions in their life?

headline: Why Fox’s Call on Arizona, Which Was Right, Was Still Wrong
abstract: It was more a risky guess than a sound decision, and easily could have led to a missed call.
lead_paragraph: If you’re a subscriber to this newsletter, my guess is you’d be interested in my colleague Peter Baker’s article about the drama at Fox News in the aftermath of its decision to call Arizona for Joe Biden on election night.

headline: How the Most Delicious Wines Stay True to Themselves
abstract: The desire to achieve greatness in wine often means figuring out how others define it. But the most original wines begin with smaller ambitions.
lead_paragraph: There’s an old joke about a street with four restaurants side-by-side. The first has a sign saying, “Best Food in the City,” and its tables are sparsely populated. The second says, “Best Food in the Country,” and even fewer people are inside. The third says, “Best Food in the World,” and it’s empty. The fourth says, “Best Food on the Block,” and it’s packed.

headline: How Can Schools Engage Students Who Are at Risk of Dropping Out?
abstract: Cater to their interests? Relax some of the rules? Emphasize socialization? Or something else?
lead_paragraph: Do you know people who nearly dropped out of high school or college, who went through with dropping out or who paused their education for a time before returning? Have you ever thought about quitting school yourself?

headline: In Matthew Desmond’s ‘Poverty, by America,’ the Culprit Is Us
abstract: The new book by the sociologist and author of “Evicted” examines the persistence of want in the wealthy United States, finding that keeping some citizens poor serves the interests of many.
lead_paragraph: Over the past decade or two, it has become fashionable to attribute major social ills to underlying “systemic” and “structural” causes. There seem to be several drivers of this tendency: the growing prominence of economists in public debates; the rise of the explanatory bloggers turned Substackers, who like to demonstrate their cool erudition by elevating intellectual arguments over moral ones; and the post-Ferguson racial awakening, with its emphasis on the deeply ingrained inequities that underlie present-day disparities.

headline: Just How Hypocritical Are the Supreme Court’s Conservative Justices Willing to Be?
abstract: Why critics are saying that the conservative justices are exercising political, not judicial, power.
lead_paragraph: Much of the public debate after the recent oral arguments before the Supreme Court in a pair of challenges to President Biden’s student loan debt forgiveness program has focused on the legal merits of the policy. In particular, many critics of the court flagged how some of the Republican-appointed justices couched their hostility to the program in terms of “unfairness,” a policy concern far more than a legal one.

headline: Two Hairstylists on Respect and Navigating Egos (Hint: It’s Not the Celebrities)
abstract: Chris McMillan, creator of “The Rachel,” and Bryce Scarlett, who styles Margot Robbie among others, on what it takes to stand out when you’re trying to make hair look natural.
lead_paragraph: Back in 1995, when Jennifer Aniston, starring on the hit show “Friends” in its first season, was trying to grow out her hair, she asked her friend Chris McMillan for a trim. Neither could have predicted that cut — which would become known as “The Rachel,” named for Ms. Aniston’s character — would become arguably the most famous haircut in half a century.

headline: Elizabeth Warren: Silicon Valley Bank Is Gone. We Know Who Is Responsible.
abstract: The recent bank failures were entirely avoidable.
lead_paragraph: No one should be mistaken about what unfolded over the past few days in the U.S. banking system: These recent bank failures are the direct result of leaders in Washington weakening the financial rules.

headline: My State’s Anti-Drag Campaign Is Beyond Ludicrous
abstract: If Tennessee Republicans were serious about protecting children, our public schools would be fully funded, and the state wouldn’t be awash in guns.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Soon after we moved to Nashville in 1987, I started hearing stories about a brilliant Belle Meade man who didn’t exactly behave according to Belle Meade norms. Neil Cargile was the president of a Nashville-based dredging company with business the world over. Born into wealth in 1928, he played football for Vanderbilt, flew planes for the Navy, married and divorced — twice — and fathered three children. He was a small-government conservative. He was also famous in Nashville for his pleasure in wearing women’s clothes on social occasions. Mr. Cargile called his alter ego “SheNeil.”

headline: After Nearly Three Years in Shelters, a Job and a Studio in New York
abstract: A student got a design degree in Los Angeles, but Covid derailed his plans for a fashion career. A job interview and a housing voucher finally turned things around.
lead_paragraph: Brandon Wells grew up in Oshkosh, Wis., dreaming of conquering big cities and streetwear fashion. He sketched designer jeans and hooded sweatshirts in his free time, all the while plotting his exit. “I knew I was leaving as soon as I graduated from high school,” he said.

headline: Tucker Carlson Is No Less Dangerous
abstract: They say that hypocrisy is the homage that vice pays to virtue, but in this case it’s the tribute that cynicism pays to cowardice.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: Bret, we have all kinds of deeply important issues to tackle. But let’s start with Tucker Carlson. We’ve learned he didn’t really believe all the stuff he said on TV about a “stolen” election. Shocking!

headline: And the Best Acting Oscar Goes to … a Man and a Woman. Why?
abstract: Categories split between actors and actresses need to evolve. But we also need to ditch our gendered notions of what constitutes great acting.
lead_paragraph: For over three hours on Sunday night, we watched beautiful people pass golden statuettes back and forth while bestowing awards on worthy winners. As usual, four of the Oscar categories — best actor, supporting actor, actress and supporting actress — were divided by gender. None of the others were. There is no award for “best sound editing by a female” or “best screenplay by a gentleman.” So why are acting awards split up this way?

headline: Biden Unveils Landmark Submarine Deal With Australia and Britain
abstract: The arrangement is part of a broader effort to counter China’s military development and assertive territorial claims across Asia.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — President Biden took his most aggressive step yet on Monday to counter China’s military expansion in the Asia-Pacific region, formally unveiling plans with Britain and Australia to develop and deploy nuclear-powered attack submarines.

headline: At White House, Asian American Liaison Juggles Celebrations and Crises
abstract: Erika Moritsugu, the first White House A.A.P.I. liaison, is in charge of both promoting the community’s representation and responding to its tragedies at a time of rising racism.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Bulldozing. Kidnapping Claims. Inside a Battle Over a Tribe’s Future.
abstract: What’s behind the internal power struggle within the Cayuga Nation in New York?
lead_paragraph: SENECA FALLS, N.Y. — Along a stretch of County Road 124 in New York’s picturesque Finger Lakes region, men stand guard at a barbed wire blockade, tending a fire they keep burning around the clock and protecting a two-story home that is on the verge of collapse.

headline: When the Light, Shadow and Stars Aligned: Standing Where Ansel Adams Stood
abstract: An enigmatic photograph by America’s most famous landscape photographer led to a forensic hunt to identify exactly when and where it was taken.
lead_paragraph: Ahead of me, an arc of 12,000-foot peaks corralled the top of a canyon. On my left, the white crags of Glacier Ridge were colored by the setting sun. Only an hour of daylight remained. I was looking for a rock feature that goes unnamed on most maps, but is known by climbers as Horn Peak. It should have been just north of Elizabeth Pass in California’s Sierra Nevada. But with barely two miles until I reached the top of the trail, it was nowhere to be found.

headline: Teachers, Facing Increasing Levels of Stress, Are Burned Out
abstract: According to one recent analysis, over half of teachers surveyed are considering quitting. Here are five that already have.
lead_paragraph: Driving home one day in the fall of 2021 from her job as an art teacher at a low-income public charter school near Sacramento, Calif., Ruth Santer fell asleep at the wheel. She often came home physically spent after a day of arriving early, wielding heavy art supplies and staying late to prepare art materials, all while managing a full classroom of middle school students. The work had always been strenuous but pandemic stresses had added to her level of exhaustion.

headline: Colleges Have Been a Small-Town Lifeline. What Happens as They Shrink?
abstract: Declining student enrollment is hitting the rural areas that rely on universities. They’re trying to adapt to survive.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: ‘Russia Outside Russia’: For Elite, Dubai Becomes a Wartime Harbor
abstract: In the exclusive neighborhoods and palatial shopping malls of the United Arab Emirates’ biggest city, wealthy Russians can build a new life without having to cut ties to their home country.
lead_paragraph: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — On an artificial island on the edge of the Persian Gulf, Dima Tutkov feels safe.

headline: Roku, Roblox and Other Companies Used Silicon Valley Bank
abstract: The failed bank had said it provided services to nearly half of all venture-backed technology and life-science companies in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley Bank, which described itself as the “financial partner of the innovation economy,” provided services to nearly half of all venture-backed technology and life-science companies in the United States, according to its website.

headline: What Is E.S.G., and Why Are Republicans So Mad About It?
abstract: President Biden’s first veto could be in defense of an investment philosophy most Americans have never heard of.
lead_paragraph: The principle behind E.S.G. is that investors should look beyond just whether a company can make a profit and take into account other factors, such as its environmental impact and action on social issues.

headline: Best and Worst Moments From the 2023 Oscars
abstract: Michelle Yeoh made history, Ke Huy Quan made us tear up and Cocaine Bear made us cringe. These were just some of the highs and lows.
lead_paragraph: What will go wrong? After several years of missteps and controversies, that was the question hanging over the Oscar telecast on Sunday night. But the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences pulled off a largely controversy-free ceremony that seemed to keep everything on track, or at least didn’t go off the rails. It came in close to on time, featured several emotional moments and even set some records. Here are the highs and lows as we saw them.

headline: BBC Ends Suspension of Top Sports Host After Staff Mutiny
abstract: The move calmed a crisis at the publicly funded broadcaster after Gary Lineker, a former soccer star, was removed from a flagship show because of a tweet about immigration policy.
lead_paragraph: The BBC made peace with its most famous sports anchor, Gary Lineker, announcing a deal on Monday to put him back on television after a suspension that ignited a national debate over free expression and political pressure at Britain’s public broadcaster.

headline: A New Bank Panic?
abstract: It’s a day of uncertainty for the U.S. economy.
lead_paragraph: Today is a day of uncertainty for the American economy.

headline: ‘The Last of Us’ Finale: First-Person Shooter
abstract: In its stunning first-season finale, “The Last of Us” became a video game — and, in the process, morally potent TV.
lead_paragraph: If you watch HBO’s “The Last of Us” there’s a good chance you know it’s based on a video game, even if you’ve never held a controller in your life. (I’ve never played the game, though before I reviewed the series I watched a 10-hour play-through video on YouTube, which I can safely say was a first in my career as a TV critic.)

headline: China’s New Premier Needs to Revive Growth. How Far Will Loyalty Get Him?
abstract: Li Qiang’s business-friendly reputation could bolster confidence in China’s economy. But he is stepping into a role with diminished power under Xi Jinping.
lead_paragraph: Before Li Qiang was appointed China’s No. 2 leader this past week, he oversaw Shanghai, a city that, for a time early last year, was celebrated for trying to contain Covid with relative restraint. City officials wanted to avoid the economic devastation of a full-scale lockdown and instead opted for limited restrictions that applied to, in one instance, a single milk tea shop.

headline: Parents of L.S.U. Student Who Died After Hazing Are Awarded $6.1 Million
abstract: Maxwell Gruver, 18, died in 2017 after a fraternity event in which pledges were forced to chug alcohol. His parents said the jury’s verdict was a significant step in their goal to end hazing.
lead_paragraph: The parents of a Louisiana State University student who died in 2017 after an on-campus hazing event have been awarded $6.1 million by a jury in Baton Rouge, La., according to the family’s lawyer.

headline: A Loss to Mexico Gives the United States Uncomfortable Urgency
abstract: The World Baseball Classic’s compact schedule, and narrow margin for error, has a stacked group of U.S. batters sorely missing the star pitchers who stayed home.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — The World Baseball Classic is forever caught between what it is and what it should be. As entertainment — especially in person — it absolutely delivers. As a true test of international baseball supremacy, maybe not.

headline: $780,000 Homes in California
abstract: A two-bedroom cabin in Guerneville, a midcentury-modern retreat in Palm Springs and a Craftsman bungalow in Oakland.
lead_paragraph: This house is two miles from the center of Guerneville, a community on the Russian River that has been attracting weekenders from the Bay Area for more than a century. About 90 minutes from San Francisco, it is also an appealing location for part-time commuters drawn to the area’s outdoor recreation, as well as the farm-to-table dining.

headline: From Music to Writing, This Is How You Move On
abstract: It can be difficult to manage all the feelings that comes with heartbreak. You can compartmentalize. Or, you can create.
lead_paragraph: Sayre Quevedo had reached the end of a five-month affair with a married man when, in the middle of a snowstorm in the winter of 2017, he received a text from his former lover, asking to see him one last time.

headline: Investors Fear Bank Contagion, Despite a Sweeping Rescue Plan
abstract: Shares in regional lenders were under pressure, even after regulators unveiled a vast backstop for U.S. banks after Silicon Valley Bank’s collapse
lead_paragraph: Andrew here. Federal regulators on Sunday unveiled the most sweeping backstop for the U.S. banking system since the 2008 crisis, to limit carnage from the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank. The decision has shaken up global markets, with investors selling bank stocks and betting that the Fed would hold off on further interest rate rises.

headline: The fallout from Silicon Valley Bank’s collapse spreads to an Indian tech company.
abstract: Nazara Technologies, a mobile gaming company, said two of its subsidiaries had together more than $7.7 million in balances at the failed bank.
lead_paragraph: As regulators moved to limit the fallout from the demise of Silicon Valley Bank, the fortunes of a mobile gaming company in India showed the lender’s global reach.

headline: Federal Reserve’s Path Is Murkier After Bank Blowup
abstract: The Fed has been rapidly raising interest rates to fight inflation. But making big moves could be trickier amid instability.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve’s hotly anticipated March 22 interest rate decision is just a week and a half away, and the drama that swept the banking and financial sector over the weekend is drastically shaking up expectations for what the central bank will deliver.

headline: Wordle Wrap-Up: March 6 to 12
abstract: A recap of the Wordle answers for the past week.
lead_paragraph: Hi Wordlers! Welcome to Wordle Wrap-Up, a reminder of which words were answers this week. For stories, stats and brain teasers, sign up for the Gameplay newsletter. For a daily reminder to play Wordle, sign up for reminders.

headline: What to Know About Plans to Build Housing in People’s Park in Berkeley
abstract: Late last month, a San Francisco judge indefinitely halted construction.
lead_paragraph: How do you solve a problem like People’s Park? It all depends on whom you ask.

headline: This Chef’s SoHo Loft Is Strictly Invitation Only
abstract: Yann Nury’s New York atelier, where he hosts the lucky few for meals, doubles as a secret design haven.
lead_paragraph: WHEN THE FRENCH chef Yann Nury moved to New York 17 years ago to work in private events for the restaurateur Daniel Boulud, he’d often be sent to cook in Park Avenue penthouses — “some of the most beautiful places in the city,” he recalls. But the home he really coveted was a client’s loft on Wooster Street in Manhattan’s SoHo: “The rounded windows, the view … the fact that the whole space was shared. It’s always stayed in my mind,” he says. If Paris, where he’d worked for years at the esteemed French catering firm Lenôtre, is about “sophisticated luxury,” as Nury sees it, “New York is fancy street culture.”

headline: Inside the Governors Ball 2023 Oscars Party
abstract: Ke Huy Quan, Ruth Carter and Darren Aronofsky were among the stars and filmmakers celebrating at the academy’s big post-Oscars party.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — At the Governors Ball after the Oscars on Sunday evening, the line for the prime rib was often longer than the one to get Oscar trophies engraved. That was fine by the winners from “Everything Everywhere All at Once,” who swarmed the second queue and were jubilant after picking up seven Academy Awards at the ceremony earlier in the evening.

headline: International Court to Open War Crimes Cases Against Russia, Officials Say
abstract: The cases before the International Criminal Court would accuse Russia of abducting Ukrainian children and of deliberately targeting civilian infrastructure.
lead_paragraph: The International Criminal Court intends to open two war crimes cases tied to the Russian invasion of Ukraine and will seek arrest warrants for several people, according to current and former officials with knowledge of the decision who were not authorized to speak publicly.

headline: Can Oscar Fashion Be More Than Marketing?
abstract: Rihanna’s belly, Florence Pugh’s shorts and Cate Blanchett’s archival velvet brought new relevance to awards show dressing.
lead_paragraph: “Everything Everywhere All at Once” may have been the big winner of the 95th Academy Awards, a vote by the industry for idiosyncrasy in the face of corporate moviemaking, but on the red — whoops, sorry, champagne — carpet, classicism ruled.

headline: Mikaela Shiffrin’s New Head Coach Is a Trailblazer, and a Woman
abstract: Karin Harjo, head coach of the Canadian women’s Alpine team, will replace Shiffrin’s longtime coach, Mike Day, with whom she parted ways in February.
lead_paragraph: When Karin Harjo joined the U.S. ski team as an assistant coach in 2015, she was surrounded by female athletes representing dozens of countries during races and training. But she was the only woman on the mountain who was coaching with a national team.

headline: Biden Assures Americans: ‘Our Banking System Is Safe’
abstract: In a televised statement before the markets opened, the president said that deposits would still be available after the collapse of two major institutions and insisted that taxpayers would not bear the cost of any bailout.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden sought on Monday morning to head off any crisis of confidence following the failure of two major banks in recent days, insisting that Americans can have faith in the system even as he emphasized that the rescue does not constitute a taxpayer bailout.

headline: Smithsonian’s Museum of American Women Names Its Founding Director
abstract: Nancy Yao will lead the museum as it prepares to select an architect and finalize a location on the National Mall.
lead_paragraph: There are still many unanswered questions about the Smithsonian’s proposed American Women’s History Museum despite the new institution’s receiving congressional approval more than two years ago. Nobody knows how much construction will cost, what objects will be displayed in the galleries or precisely where the building will stand on the National Mall in Washington.

headline: Brown Widows Are Winning the Fight for Your Attic and Garage
abstract: The arachnids, which probably migrated to the United States from South Africa, seem to be attacking black widow spiders in some parts of the country.
lead_paragraph: Few spiders in the United States have a more fearsome reputation than black widows. But throughout the South, the bulbous arachnids with red hourglasses on their bellies are engaged in a lethal competition with the brown widow, a relative from abroad — and they’re losing.

headline: The Last Days of Soup Season
abstract: Warm up with a lemony fish and orzo soup, a pot of t’chicha and more recipes.
lead_paragraph: Spring might be just around the corner, as Toad’s friend Frog says, but it certainly doesn’t feel that way in New York yet. I still need to layer on scarf-hat-and-gloves before heading out to face the wind, but I make up for it with a hot bowl of soup for dinner. Recently I simmered a version of my turkey soup with beans and greens, substituting chickpeas for the white beans and lime for the lemon, and it warmed me head to toe.

headline: Lockdown With Grandma? It’s a Mixed Blessing.
abstract: Take one 24-year-old, add a seasoned family member and introduce a pandemic. Welcome to Cathleen Schine’s new novel!
lead_paragraph: In 19th-century English novels, there was a pattern that seemed to occur with alarming frequency: Fate — in the form of inclement weather, a twisted ankle, a touch of rheum — would strand a visitor at some neighboring estate for weeks at a time. As a teenage reader I used to envy those marooned guests, generally girls of marriageable age whose circumscribed lives needed some shaking up. A fortnight away from home with your own room and a besotted suitor (one always materialized) on the premises? Count me in. Also, let’s bring back “fortnight.”

headline: The F.B.I. Has an Art Crime Team. And These Days, It’s Busy.
abstract: A raid of the Orlando Museum of Art, in which 25 works attributed to Jean-Michel Basquiat were seized, has placed renewed spotlight on the unit.
lead_paragraph: For years they operated largely under the radar, though the work they did had the potential to capture the public’s imagination.

headline: When the Right Place at the Right Time Is Absolutely Wrong
abstract: In Vibhuti Jain’s debut novel, “Our Best Intentions,” a bloody crime scene and a missing suspect prompt a biting examination of race, wealth and privilege in a small suburban community.
lead_paragraph: So much of a successful life depends on chance — being in the right place at the right time, or, conversely, in the wrong place at the wrong time. It’s all about luck, happenstance, the roll of the dice … at least, that’s what we tell ourselves. Underneath all that chance is a fundamental truth: Some people have more access to the “right” places, and more resources and support to get out of the “wrong” ones. In her debut novel, “Our Best Intentions,” Vibhuti Jain uses a crime in an affluent Westchester suburb to reveal how views of right and wrong are shaded by privilege, status, color and, of course, money. Whose intentions are best, and for whom, exactly?

headline: When the Family Falls Apart
abstract: In Richard Mirabella’s debut novel, “Brother & Sister Enter the Forest,” the sudden reunion of estranged siblings leads to an overdue reckoning with past trauma.
lead_paragraph: Of all the sibling configurations sitting at the crowded dinner table of Western literature, the one that arguably receives the least amount of attention is that of brother and sister. Fiction shelves are crammed with competing brothers and vying sisters, as well as endless combinations of squabbling trios and embittered foursomes in which a brother and a sister sit within shin-kicking distance amid the bickering family cluster. But what about the peculiarly fraught, hard-to-classify dynamic of the boy and girl dyad, two siblings of different genders raised under like conditions but so often saddled with wildly divergent expectations? You’d have to go back to the Greeks, to overwrought Antigone, for a noble case of sister-brother sacrifice or to fairy tales like “Hansel and Gretel” for aspirational brother-sister cooperation.

headline: A Novel of Messy Relationships — Like the America It’s Set In
abstract: “Take What You Need,” by Idra Novey, depicts the complicated feelings of a young woman and her former stepmother, against a backdrop of artistic ambition, rural poverty and despair.
lead_paragraph: Idra Novey’s impressive new novel, “Take What You Need,” begins with Leah, one of two first-person narrators, speaking in the present tense as she drives from her home in Long Island City, Queens, to the small town in the southern Allegheny Mountains where she grew up. She has received a call from a man she doesn’t know, saying that her stepmother, Jean, has died and left Leah metalwork sculptures to which Jean devoted her last years.

headline: Is the American Catholic Church Fueling the Far Right?
abstract: In “Playing God,” the journalist Mary Jo McConahay argues that an alliance of extremely conservative bishops and Catholic activists is exerting a profound impact on our national politics.
lead_paragraph: Just how conservative is the Catholic Church? So conservative that, when Pope Francis recently said that homosexuality is a sin but not a crime, observers (correctly) took that for progress. The connection between Catholicism and conservatism runs deep. It goes back to at least the Counter-Reformation, when the church had to defend the religious status quo in Christian Europe against Protestants’ radical criticisms of its priests, its hierarchy and its doctrines. In its day, the Catholic Church opposed the Enlightenment. It rejected freedom of conscience. Church teaching was for a long time extremely skeptical of democracy.

headline: Stocks Wobble as Smaller Banks Plunge on Fears of Contagion
abstract: The volatile conditions led to trading in a dozen banks being halted after triggering so-called circuit breakers, established in part to prevent runaway crashes.
lead_paragraph: The stocks of U.S. regional banks plummeted on Monday, as investors reassessed how much such lenders were worth following the sudden collapse of Signature Bank and Silicon Valley Bank.

headline: Highlights From the 2023 Oscars: Awards, Speeches and Best Looks
What to Know About Tenure and Free Speech Protections
abstract: A conflict over a law professor at the University of Pennsylvania has stirred questions about what tenure means.
lead_paragraph: In higher education, there is one professional golden ticket: tenure. For academics, securing tenure — a highly coveted permanent teaching position at a college or university — usually requires years of education, a rise through the professorial ranks and scholarship. Its benefits are significant: job security that lasts indefinitely, better pay and prestige. One of tenure’s key protections is academic freedom, allowing professors to speak and work freely without fear of punishment by their institution.

headline: Gavel to Pass to New Chief Judge Overseeing Grand Jury in Trump Inquiry
abstract: James E. Boasberg will take over from Beryl A. Howell as the chief judge of the Federal District Court in Washington, a post that plays a key role in the special counsel investigations into Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The windows of the chambers of the chief judge of the Federal District Court of the District of Columbia overlook the Capitol grounds, a stately vista that turned into a crime scene on Jan. 6, 2021, when a pro-Trump mob attacked Congress in an attempt to stop the certification of the 2020 election.

headline: Red Beans and Rice Feed New Orleans’ Soul
abstract: The dish is central to the city’s identity — and central to it is the right bean.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — In this storied Louisiana city, where shrimp étouffée, gumbo and po’ boys loom large, red beans and rice stand above.

headline: I Love You, Now Leave Me Alone: What Friendship Means to an Introvert
abstract: It can be hard to reconcile the need for close connections with the urge to cancel plans. Experts say it’s a matter of taking control and finding your comfort zone.
lead_paragraph: Few things in life satisfy me as much as canceling social plans.

headline: ‘Navalny’ wins the Oscar for best documentary as the dissident’s wife issues a defiant message.
abstract: The film followed Aleksei Navalny, a prominent critic of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, as he investigated his own near-fatal poisoning in 2020.
lead_paragraph: “Navalny,” a film that followed the imprisoned Russian dissident Aleksei A. Navalny as he investigated his own near-fatal poisoning in 2020, won the Oscar for best documentary feature on Sunday, with Mr. Navalny’s wife and daughter appearing onstage to deliver a message of defiance.

headline: Michael Cohen Testifies in Grand Jury as Trump Indictment Appears Near
abstract: Mr. Cohen, Donald Trump’s onetime fixer, is a key piece of the puzzle in a case centered around a 2016 hush money payment to Stormy Daniels.
lead_paragraph: Michael D. Cohen, a crucial witness in the Manhattan district attorney’s criminal investigation into Donald J. Trump, testified in front of a grand jury on Monday, as prosecutors near a likely indictment of the former president.

headline: Review: A Handel Oratorio Gave the People What They Wanted
abstract: In “Solomon,” performed elegantly at Carnegie Hall by the English Concert and Clarion Choir under Harry Bicket, the chorus is the star.
lead_paragraph: “Swell the full chorus to Solomon’s praise,” a very full chorus sings in Handel’s “Solomon,” elegantly performed by the English Concert and Clarion Choir under Harry Bicket on Sunday at Carnegie Hall.

headline: Trump, Trailed by Prosecutors and DeSantis, Aims to Shore Up Iowa Support
abstract: The former president drew a warm reception in Davenport as he gave the early nominating state its first side-by-side comparison between him and Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, who visited days earlier.
lead_paragraph: DAVENPORT, Iowa — Ron DeSantis may be a rising star among Republicans, but the way Donald J. Trump’s arrival brought downtown Davenport to a halt on Monday suggested the former president remains, at least for now, the center of the party’s galaxy.

headline: On the Road With a Grandma Named Pincer
abstract: In “The Dog of the North,” Elizabeth McKenzie maps the zany travels of an injury-prone clan with a hole at its center.
lead_paragraph: In the road novel “The Dog of the South,” Charles Portis’s feckless hero Ray Midge traces a route from Little Rock to Belize in pursuit of an acquaintance named Guy Dupree, who has stolen his car, his credit cards and his wife. The dog of the title is the name of a bus belonging to a crooked doctor Ray encounters in Mexico. The dog is also a dog (Guy Dupree’s) and it’s also, arguably, Ray.

headline: Skip the Flight and the Ferry With ‘Food of the Italian Islands’
abstract: Dive into Katie Parla’s new cookbook, add a little spice to your coffee and more.
lead_paragraph: The destinations that the food writer Katie Parla covers in her cookbook “Food of the Italian Islands,” range from large and well-known — Sicily, Sardinia, Capri and Venice (yes, an archipelago knitted with bridges) — to mere freckles in the sea. Ms. Parla, who lives in Italy and has Sicilian roots, covers not just food but culture, history and geography, and there are enough sunny photos to make you consider booking a flight and checking ferry schedules. (Fair warning: She correctly notes “how unpleasant Capri can be in high season.”) Absent travel plans, you can still enjoy many regional pestos, caponata textured with celery, a citrus salad strewn with olives, Pantelleria’s mint and ricotta ravioli, and the local ways with chickpeas, lentils and anchovies. More challenging, and perhaps best sampled in situ, are grilled horse steak (carne di cavallo) and a poached spleen and lung sandwich from Palermo’s street food repertoire.

headline: Plans to Build AirTrain to La Guardia Are Officially Scrapped
abstract: Ballooning costs help doom what had been a pet project of former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.
lead_paragraph: There will be no AirTrain to La Guardia Airport.

headline: Morgan Wallen Returns to No. 1 With the Year’s Biggest Debut
abstract: The pop-country singer, who was briefly reprimanded by the industry after using a racial slur, has another blockbuster regardless: the 36-song “One Thing at a Time.”
lead_paragraph: Two years after being momentarily shunned by the music industry — but not most listeners — for using racist language, the pop-country singer Morgan Wallen has another blockbuster album on his hands: “One Thing at a Time,” his third LP, debuts at No. 1 this week on the Billboard chart with the largest sales of the year so far.

headline: Brendan Fraser Wants to Be Worthy of His Comeback
Barney Frank, a co-author of key banking legislation, was on the board of one of the failed banks.
abstract: Barney Frank, the former congressman from Massachusetts who helped write the Dodd-Frank Act — the legislation passed in the wake of the 2008 financial crisis with the intention of shielding the economy from a similar crisis — said on Monday he was disappointed in the decision of regulators to shut down Signature Bank on Sunday, where he had been a board member since 2015.
lead_paragraph: Barney Frank, the former congressman from Massachusetts who helped write the Dodd-Frank Act — the legislation passed in the wake of the 2008 financial crisis with the intention of shielding the economy from a similar crisis — said on Monday he was disappointed in the decision of regulators to shut down Signature Bank on Sunday, where he had been a board member since 2015.

headline: Smaller banks rush to reassure customers that they are on firm footing.
abstract: Smaller banks rushed to reassure customers and shareholders on Monday that they were on firmer financial footing than Silicon Valley Bank and Signature, the two lenders whose sudden failures prompted regulators to take extraordinary measures in hopes of staving off a cascading collapse. Shares of several regional banks fell sharply, triggering a series of temporary trading halts because of extreme volatility.
lead_paragraph: Smaller banks rushed to reassure customers and shareholders on Monday that they were on firmer financial footing than Silicon Valley Bank and Signature, the two lenders whose sudden failures prompted regulators to take extraordinary measures in hopes of staving off a cascading collapse. Shares of several regional banks fell sharply, triggering a series of temporary trading halts because of extreme volatility.

headline: A Conductor Arrives at Encores! With a Jerry Herman Rarity
abstract: Mary-Mitchell Campbell, the series’ new music director, will lead a restored performance of “Dear World,” starring Donna Murphy.
lead_paragraph: In 1969, the musical theater composer-lyricist Jerry Herman achieved a Broadway milestone. With the opening of “Dear World” — joining his earlier “Hello, Dolly!” and “Mame” — he had three shows running at the same time.

headline: Cyclone Freddy Persists, Leaving Scores More Dead in Africa
abstract: A storm that has broken records for its longevity — now 35 days — swept inland from the southeastern coast of Africa and is causing massive flooding and displacement.
lead_paragraph: LILONGWE, Malawi — Cyclone Freddy, the longest-lasting tropical cyclone ever recorded in the Southern Hemisphere, swept in from the southeastern coast of Africa and traveled to the landlocked nation of Malawi, where by Monday it was responsible for at least 99 deaths, government and relief officials said.

headline: Lifehacker, Enthusiasts’ Guide to Everything, to Be Sold to Ziff Davis
abstract: In the highly competitive world of digital publishing, so-called service journalism publications like Lifehacker are valuable properties.
lead_paragraph: Lifehacker, the online how-to guide for exercise, cooking, technology, parenting — and just about everything else — is being sold to the digital-media giant Ziff Davis, according to two people with knowledge of the deal.

headline: Why Would Someone Steal Unpublished Manuscripts?
abstract: Filippo Bernardini has been accused by the government of stealing over 1,000 book manuscripts. In court filings, he said he was motivated not by money but by a love of reading.
lead_paragraph: For more than five years, someone was stealing unpublished book manuscripts from editors, agents, authors and literary scouts. The question of who was behind the scheme baffled the publishing industry, but just as perplexing was another question: Why?

headline: Where to Stream ‘Everything Everywhere All at Once’ and More 2023 Oscar Winners
abstract: Most of the night’s winners can be watched at home. Here’s a guide to help you find the honorees.
lead_paragraph: Not since “Slumdog Millionaire” won eight Oscars in 2009 has a film blitzed the Academy Awards like “Everything Everywhere All at Once,” which won seven Oscars, including three of the four acting prizes along with best picture, director and original screenplay. Though only Showtime subscribers can stream the film currently, it’s available to buy on other digital platforms. But with the exception of “Avatar: The Way of Water,” which is still only in theaters, and the live-action short winner “An Irish Goodbye,” all of the night’s honorees are accessible through streaming services, digital outlets or both, with Netflix earning a particularly good haul with the war drama “All Quiet on the Western Front,” the stop-motion animated feature “Guillermo del Toro’s Pinocchio” and the documentary short “The Elephant Whisperers.” Here’s a complete rundown of winners that are only a click away:

headline: A Mossad Agent’s Treasure Trove of Photos
abstract: Sylvia Rafael worked undercover as a news agency photographer. Her pictures for the Israeli spy agency sat in its archives for decades before being released for a show.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 8, 1965, the chief of Israel’s foreign intelligence service, the Mossad, presented the country’s prime minister with a plan to assassinate several leading Palestinian militants based in Beirut, Lebanon, with letter bombs.

headline: The Vice President Question: The Stakes Are High
abstract: Readers respond to a guest essay about President Biden’s vice-presidential options. Also: Mike Pence; Chris Rock; rare texts; family values.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: Verdi’s Falstaff Is Back at the Met, Enlarging His Kingdom
abstract: Michael Volle puts his noble voice to delightfully undignified use as the title character in Robert Carsen’s still fresh production of “Falstaff.”
lead_paragraph: There’s a lot of fat-shaming in Verdi’s “Falstaff,” but the opera has never really been a candidate for revision or cancellation, probably because the victim of those insults refuses to see himself as one. Eloquent and self-aggrandizing, Falstaff proudly identifies with his stature.

headline: House Republicans Quietly Halt Inquiry Into Trump’s Finances
abstract: G.O.P. leaders are declining to enforce a court-supervised settlement for Mazars, Donald J. Trump’s former accounting firm, to turn over records in an investigation into whether he profited from the presidency.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Republicans have quietly halted a congressional investigation into whether Donald J. Trump profited improperly from the presidency, declining to enforce a court-supervised settlement agreement that demanded that Mazars USA, his former accounting firm, produce his financial records to Congress.Representative James R. Comer, Republican of Kentucky and the chairman of the Oversight and Accountability Committee, made clear he had abandoned any investigation into the former president’s financial dealings — professing ignorance about the inquiry Democrats opened when they controlled the House — and was instead focusing on whether President Biden and members of his family were involved in an influence-peddling scheme.

headline: This Year, a Plain Old Ordinary Oscars Was Something to Savor
abstract: After breathing a sigh of relief that the night went smoothly, our critics examine the acting wins as well as the track records of studios and Netflix.
lead_paragraph: It was business insistently as usual at the 95th annual Academy Awards, with the familiar dazzling smiles and designer threads, the showy glad-handing and flowing tears. What there wasn’t was a slap sequel. Instead, this year’s event went off smoothly, with regularly interspersed acceptance speeches from the team behind the fantasy adventure “Everything Everywhere All at Once,” which scooped up seven golden statuettes, including best picture. The New York Times’s co-chief film critics, A.O. Scott and Manohla Dargis, discussed the evening and the academy’s carefully staged return to (fingers crossed?) a new normal.

headline: 10 Years On, Pope Francis Faces Challenges From the Right and the Left
abstract: In an ideologically divided Roman Catholic Church, the right has accused him of going too far and the left of not going far enough.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Pope Francis once envisioned serving only a few years as pontiff. On Monday, he commemorated his 10th anniversary as leader of the world’s Roman Catholics, saying it seemed “like yesterday” that he took control of an ideologically divided church that has opposed him from the right for going too far and criticized him from the left for not going far enough.

headline: Bike-Path Attacker Will Get Life in Prison, Escaping Death Penalty
abstract: Sayfullo Saipov killed eight people in Manhattan, running them down with a 6,000-pound rented truck. Prosecutors had wanted him executed, but jurors deadlocked.
lead_paragraph: Sayfullo Saipov, a native of Uzbekistan who killed eight people in a 2017 terrorist truck attack on a Hudson River bike path, will be sentenced to life in prison after members of a Manhattan federal jury deadlocked as they decided his fate.

headline: Inside Vanity Fair’s Oscar Party: Every Star, All at Once
abstract: Winners and also-rans shared cocktails and In-N-Out burgers with moguls, musicians and models at the annual post-awards gala.
lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — On Sunday night at 10:30, the tented area along North Santa Monica Boulevard resembled an airport security line in which nearly every woman was wearing a slinky bedazzled gown by Versace, Dolce & Gabbana or Balenciaga and every man was in a tuxedo by Tom Ford or Giorgio Armani.

headline: Late-Winter Storm Brings Heavy Snow and Rain to the Northeast
abstract: A major storm dropped more than two feet of snow in portions of northwest Massachusetts and southern Vermont, while some cities only saw flurries or rain. The weather caused power outages and travel disruptions.
lead_paragraph: A late-winter storm dumped heavy, wet snow in parts of the Northeast on Tuesday, causing widespread power outages and dozens of flight disruptions.

headline: Jamie Lee Curtis Wins First Oscar for Best Supporting Actress
Ruth E. Carter Becomes First Black Woman to Win Two Oscars
abstract: The costume designer won an Academy Award for “Black Panther: Wakanda Forever,” adding to the history-making Oscar she won for the original “Black Panther” in 2019.
lead_paragraph: Ruth E. Carter, tasked with crafting the Afrofuturist costumes in “Black Panther: Wakanda Forever,” took home her second Oscar on Sunday night for costume design. Carter, who also won a statue for the 2018 film “Black Panther,” is not only the first Black woman to win two Academy Awards, but she is also the first person to win for both the original and the sequel of a movie. Onstage, she greeted audiences with a “Nice to see you again,” and thanked the academy for “recognizing the superhero that is a Black woman,” she said. “She endures, she loves, she overcomes.”

headline: A24 Achieves Art-House Supremacy With Triumphant Oscar Night
abstract: The independent studio behind “Everything Everywhere All at Once” and “The Whale” became the first to sweep the acting awards and win best director and best picture in the same year.
lead_paragraph: Six years after nabbing the best picture Oscar for “Moonlight,” the hip, art-house studio A24 succeeded at Sunday night’s Academy Awards on a scale that seemed to surprise even its executives, who entered the post-show Governor’s Ball with what-just-happened-looks on their faces.

headline: Once Underdogs, They’re Still Playing With Chips on Their Shoulders
abstract: No. 2-seed Marquette was picked ninth of 11 teams in the Big East preseason poll. The Golden Eagles’ point guard, Tyler Kolek, hasn’t forgotten.
lead_paragraph: Near the start of the college basketball season, a reporter told Marquette point guard Tyler Kolek that the Golden Eagles had been picked to finish ninth out of 11 teams in the Big East Conference.

headline: Another ‘Significant’ Atmospheric River Is Drenching California
abstract: More heavy rain is soaking the state on Tuesday, with the ground still saturated from the storms and flooding last week.
lead_paragraph: Another powerful atmospheric river arrived overnight in California, threatening to deliver strong winds, heavy rain and a new round of floods, avalanches and mudslides on Tuesday, while some residents have yet to recover from the storms that hammered the state last week.

headline: Drums, Dancing and Baseball as Miami Stadium Roars to Life
abstract: “This is our World Cup,” a fan said as the Dominican Republic, Nicaragua, Puerto Rico and Venezuela squared off at the World Baseball Classic.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Impromptu dance parties broke out in the concourses. A player banged a drum in the dugout while countless fans did so in the stands. Flags waved from the seats and hung over the railings. The usually sparsely populated stadium was filled with people, roars and music. No strike was too small to celebrate. Sitting was optional.

headline: Fatal Police Shooting Prompts Demand for Inquiry of Troubled Department
abstract: Najee Seabrooks, 31, was shot and killed by police officers in Paterson, N.J., after calling 911 to report he was experiencing a mental health crisis.
lead_paragraph: The morning he was shot dead, Najee Seabrooks had contacted two groups to report that he was suffering from a mental health crisis: the police and his friends at the Paterson Healing Collective, an anti-violence organization where he worked as a counselor.

headline: Is My Money Safe? Here’s What Is Covered, and How You Can Do More.
abstract: The F.D.I.C. and other entities will protect most people’s bank and brokerage balances. But it’s as good a time as any for consumers to create other backstops.
lead_paragraph: Customers of Silicon Valley Bank aren’t going to lose any of their deposits. Neither will the businesses or individuals who have money at Signature Bank.

headline: Masatoshi Ito, 98, the King of Convenience Stores in Japan, Dies
abstract: He introduced the American chain 7-Eleven to the country, covering the landscape with thousands of outlets and starting a retail revolution there.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Masatoshi Ito, who built a Japanese retail empire and helped fundamentally change the country’s consumer culture with the introduction there of the American convenience store 7-Eleven, died on Friday. He was 98.

headline: Fifteen Years After 2008, Why Do Banks Keep Failing?
abstract: It may be time for the F.D.I.C. to insure all bank deposits.
lead_paragraph: The weekend rescue of uninsured depositors in Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank was absolutely essential and absolutely frustrating. We have to stop getting ourselves into these messes, people.

headline: Oscars Draw 18.7 Million Viewers
abstract: The viewership rose a second consecutive year, but was still the third-least-watched Oscars on record.
lead_paragraph: ABC executives and much of Hollywood can breathe a sigh of relief.

headline: How Biden Got From ‘No More Drilling’ to Backing a Huge Project in Alaska
abstract: High gas prices, a looming election and fears of a costly legal battle seem to have shifted the political calculus for the president.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As a candidate, Joseph R. Biden promised voters worried about the warming planet “No more drilling on federal lands, period. Period, period, period.” On Monday, President Biden approved an enormous $8 billion plan to extract 600 million barrels of oil from pristine federal land in Alaska.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Silicon Valley Bank Isn’t Lehman
abstract: The issues facing the U.S. economy in 2023 are very different from those it faced in its last crisis, in 2008.
lead_paragraph: If there is one thing almost all observers of the economic scene have agreed about, it is that the issues facing the U.S. economy in 2023 are very different from those it faced in its last crisis, in 2008.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing: A U.S. Banking Crisis
abstract: Also, Russia is set to face war crimes charges and China’s new premier seeks to reassure investors.
lead_paragraph: President Biden tried to reassure Americans that the U.S. banking industry was safe, after federal regulators took over two failing banks in three days. Several midsize U.S. banks also scrambled to calm the fears of their customers.

headline: Silicon Valley Bank’s fall raises uncertainty for health care start-ups.
abstract: Investors in health care and biotech start-ups are grappling with a disruption to an industry that was already facing headwinds.
lead_paragraph: As the run on Silicon Valley Bank ripples across the economy, investors in health care and biotech start-ups are grappling with a disruption to an industry that was already facing headwinds.

headline: Biden Unveils Attack Submarine Deal With Australia and Britain
abstract: President Biden, along with leaders of Australia and Britain, announced plans to develop and deploy nuclear-powered attack submarines.
lead_paragraph: President Biden, along with leaders of Australia and Britain, announced plans to develop and deploy nuclear-powered attack submarines.

headline: McConnell, Released From Hospital, Will Undergo Inpatient Rehab
abstract: The Senate minority leader had been under observation since suffering a concussion during a fall on Wednesday. He also has a “minor rib fracture,” his office said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell, the Kentucky Republican and minority leader who suffered a concussion in a serious fall last week, was released from the hospital on Monday and will move to a physical rehabilitation center before returning to the Senate, according to his office.

headline: More Stars Dressed to the Nines? Yes!
abstract: It was only after the Academy Awards ended that some of the best looks came out. Here are 26 more outfits to ogle from Oscar night.
lead_paragraph: Though the 95th Academy Awards drew its fair share of memorable fashion, many of the night’s standout looks were not revealed until after the last Oscar was claimed and the parties began.

headline: Biden Extends Stay for Thousands of Ukrainians
abstract: One-year extensions for those who fled in the first months after Russia’s invasion will be granted on a case-by-case basis, officials said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration said on Monday that thousands of Ukrainians who fled to the United States in the first months after Russia invaded their country would be eligible to extend their stay, as the war in Ukraine continues into a second year.

headline: An Idaho College Removes Artwork About Abortion, Citing a State Law
abstract: Six works in a Lewis-Clark exhibition about health care were perceived to run afoul of a law that prohibits the use of state funds to “promote abortion” or “counsel in favor of abortion.”
lead_paragraph: Artwork about abortion is, historically speaking, vanishingly rare. And the future display of such work seems dimmer after a small public college in Idaho removed six works about abortion and birth control from an exhibition, citing a state anti-abortion law.

headline: Back-to-Back Bank Collapses Came After Deregulatory Push
abstract: Officials with Signature and Silicon Valley banks, which regulators seized in recent days, had called for looser financial requirements for midsize banks.
lead_paragraph: In the spring of 2018, President Donald J. Trump signed a law that watered down the landmark regulatory reform act that his predecessor had enacted following the global financial crisis. The changes won a surprising supporter: the liberal former congressman Barney Frank.

headline: Regional Banks Slammed by Fear of a Broader Financial Crisis
abstract: Across the country, banks of various sizes are battling market turmoil as customers rushed to withdraw their deposits and investors, worried about more bank runs, dumped bank stocks.
lead_paragraph: The unexpected seizure of two banks in three days by regulators intensified fears of a broader financial crisis, sending the stocks of more than two dozen banks into free fall on Monday, even as President Biden reassured Americans that the banking system was resilient and that customers’ money was safe.

headline: Russian Attacks Along a Wide Arc of Ukraine Yield Little but Casualties
abstract: Moscow’s forces have stepped up artillery and infantry assaults across eastern Ukraine, trying to improve their position before either side attempts a major breakthrough.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — From Kupiansk in the north to Avdiivka in the south, through Bakhmut, Lyman and dozens of towns in between, Russian forces are attacking along a 160-mile arc in eastern Ukraine in an intensifying struggle for tactical advantage before possible spring offensives.

headline: Dick Fosbury, 76, Whose ‘Flop’ Transformed the High Jump, Is Dead
abstract: His back-first, neck-down leaping style struck many as a novelty act. After he won Olympic gold in 1968, it came to dominate his sport.
lead_paragraph: Dick Fosbury, a gangly civil engineering student who shocked his peers, delighted sports fans and started a revolution in competitive high jumping with his backward leaps, died on Sunday at a nursing facility in Salt Lake City. He was 76.

headline: Was This a Bailout? Skeptics Descend on Silicon Valley Bank Response.
abstract: The government took drastic action to shore up the banking system and make depositors of two failed banks whole. It quickly drew blowback.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A sweeping package aimed at containing damage to the financial system in the wake of high-profile failures has prompted questions about whether the federal government is again bailing out Wall Street.

headline: Hate Crimes Rose 12 Percent in 2021, F.B.I. Finds
abstract: The data, culled from a new national tracking system and reports from cities, almost certainly undercounted attacks, experts said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hate crimes surged nearly 12 percent between 2020 and 2021, according to updated statistics released by the F.B.I. on Monday, but the data is far from complete and the actual numbers are likely to be higher, experts tracking the rise in bias-fueled violence said.

headline: Nashville Sues to Block Law That Would Shrink its Council by Half
abstract: The law would limit the size of a city or county legislative body to 20 members; the Nashville Metropolitan Council has 40.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — The metropolitan government of Nashville sued the State of Tennessee on Monday, asking a judge to block a new law that would slash the size of its governing body to 20 members, from 40.

headline: California Court Mostly Upholds Prop. 22 in Win for Uber and Other Gig Companies
abstract: The decision lessens the chances that gig drivers will be considered employees in the state, but it is expected to be appealed to the state Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: A California appeals court said on Monday that Proposition 22, the ballot measure passed by state voters in 2020 that classified Uber and Lyft drivers as independent contractors rather than as employees, should remain state law.

headline: Investigators Clear U.S. Soccer Coach in 1992 Incident
abstract: An inquiry found U.S. Soccer could rehire Gregg Berhalter as coach of the men’s national team. But investigators criticized the parents of Gio Reyna for their part in the controversy.
lead_paragraph: Gregg Berhalter, the coach who led the United States men’s soccer team at last year’s World Cup in Qatar, is eligible to return for the next World Cup cycle after investigators looking into his personal conduct cleared him to remain a candidate for the job, the U.S. Soccer Federation said on Monday.

headline: After Bank Debacle, Silicon Valley Reckons With Its Image
abstract: Even as start-ups and investors began recovering their money from Silicon Valley Bank, the episode exposed the tech industry’s vulnerabilities.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday afternoon, Prashant Fonseka was flying to San Francisco from Austin, Texas, with other techies returning from the South by Southwest conference. Midway through the flight, federal regulators announced the government would ensure that all depositors of Silicon Valley Bank — which had failed on Friday — would be paid back in full.

headline: ‘The Coast Starlight’ Review: Strangers on a Train
abstract: Keith Bunin’s gentle, rueful play at Lincoln Center’s Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater settles down among six passengers traveling from Los Angeles to Seattle.
lead_paragraph: A northbound trip on the Coast Starlight, a gleaming Amtrak sleeper, lasts about 35 hours. The train leaves Los Angeles in mid morning and delivers its passengers to Seattle late the next day. By contrast, “The Coast Starlight,” Keith Bunin’s play at Lincoln Center’s Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater, fills just a fraction of that time. A gentle, rueful play, directed with a steady and sympathetic hand by Tyne Rafaeli, it settles down among six passengers sharing a single coach. Narrow, nimble, self-contained, the ride it offers is as smooth as it is wistful. Because Bunin (“The Credeaux Canvas,” “The Busy World Is Hushed”) knows that any trip involves leaving something or someone behind.

headline: Abortion Opponents Want to Make Women Afraid to Get Help From Their Friends
abstract: A wrongful-death lawsuit in Texas is an act of intimidation.
lead_paragraph: The month after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, a mother of two in Texas who had filed for divorce from her husband discovered she was pregnant. Determined not to have another child and worried that her husband would try to use the pregnancy to make her stay with him, she did what many of us would do and turned to two friends for help.

headline: ‘How to Defend Yourself’ Review: The Murkiness of Consent, and Friendship
abstract: In Liliana Padilla’s play at New York Theater Workshop, college students find empowerment and life lessons in a DIY self-defense class.
lead_paragraph: If an attacker grabs you by the wrist, dip your elbow, turn your hand palm-up, twist and use leverage against the person’s thumb to extract yourself. If the attacker is straddling you, buck your hips, grab an arm and flip the person over.

headline: As M.L.B. Season Nears, Trevor Bauer Heads to Japan
abstract: Bauer, a star pitcher who was released by the Dodgers following the end of his domestic violence suspension, agreed to a one-year deal with the Yokohama BayStars.
lead_paragraph: More than nine weeks after the Los Angeles Dodgers cut him loose, and nearly two years after he last threw a pitch in a major league game, the free agent right-handed pitcher Trevor Bauer will attempt to rebuild his career and reputation overseas.

headline: Joe Pepitone, Rowdy Star When the Yankees Faded, Dies at 82
abstract: He had All-Star years, won three Gold Gloves, hit with power and was a fan favorite, but as the team’s fortunes dimmed, his renegade lifestyle had its costs.
lead_paragraph: Joe Pepitone, who won three Gold Gloves at first base and played in two World Series for the Yankees but who may be best remembered for his hair and his high jinks, has died at his home in Kansas City, Mo. He was 82.

headline: Thousands of Buildings Collapsed in One Turkish City. Thousands More May Have to Come Down.
abstract: Aerial imagery from the Turkish government shows astonishing destruction in Antakya, where a 7.8-magnitude earthquake struck on Feb. 6.
lead_paragraph: Aerial imagery from the Turkish government shows astonishing destruction in Antakya, where a 7.8-magnitude earthquake struck on Feb. 6.

headline: Ron DeSantis Says Protecting Ukraine Is Not a Key U.S. Interest
abstract: The Florida governor, on Tucker Carlson’s Fox News show, broke with Republicans to attack President Biden’s foreign policy and align more closely with Donald Trump as he weighs a presidential bid.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida has sharply broken with Republicans who are determined to defend Ukraine against Russia’s invasion, saying in a statement made public on Monday night that protecting the European nation’s borders is not a vital U.S. interest and that policymakers should instead focus attention at home.

headline: Who’s Solving This Puzzle?
abstract: Peter Gordon’s puzzle will have you cheering for the underdog.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: ‘Perry Mason’ Season 2, Episode 2 Recap: Mason for the Defense
abstract: Perry gets back to his true calling after his nose tells him something smells funny about the Brooks McCutcheon murder. That was fast.
lead_paragraph: You can take Perry Mason out of criminal defense lawyering, but you can’t take the criminal defense lawyer out of Perry Mason. That Perry discovers this with no evident chagrin is a testament to the truth of it. You don’t gain a sourpuss like his without a keen sense of the injustice of the world; on the evidence of last season, he has the legal know-how to do something about it, and he’s not about to forget it.

headline: Puerto Rico Combines for First Perfect Game in W.B.C. History
abstract: Four pitchers threw eight perfect innings against Israel before the game was ended, 10-0, by way of the tournament’s mercy rule.
lead_paragraph: With a nine-run lead in the eighth inning on Monday, Puerto Rico utility man Enrique Hernández stepped to the plate against Israel with two runners on base. He proceeded to lace the ball to left field, ending the game with a walk-off single that capped a four-pitcher perfect game and a 10-0 victory at the World Baseball Classic at loanDepot park in Miami.

headline: An Irishman Takes on the Word ‘Paddy’
abstract: The photographer Ross O’Callaghan, fighting a stereotype, asks his countrymen to carry Paddy proudly. And it’s back to the future for New York Republicans.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. We’ll find out about an unusual prelude to St. Patrick’s Day. We’ll also find out why the new state Republican Party chairman seems so familiar.

headline: Patricia Schroeder, Feminist Force in Congress, Dies at 82
abstract: In a long career in the House and armed with a barbed wit, she helped win legislation on family leave, pregnancy discrimination and other progressive causes.
lead_paragraph: Patricia Schroeder, a former leading feminist legislator who helped redefine the role of women in American politics and used her wit to combat sexism in Congress, died on Monday in Celebration, Fla. She was 82.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Repercussions from bank collapses in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: The unexpected seizure of two U.S. banks in three days by regulators intensified fears of a broader financial crisis, sending the stocks of more than two dozen banks across the country into free fall yesterday, even as President Biden reassured Americans that the banking system was resilient.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Quick Action Also Carries Inherent Risks
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, March 14, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “Crises don’t just happen — they’re not like the Immaculate Conception.”

headline: Corrections: March 14, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, March 14, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An Upshot article on Saturday about past presidential budgets misstated a promise made by President Biden. He said he would not raise taxes on Americans earning less than $400,000, not more than $400,000.

headline: Late Night Sums Up the Silicon Valley Bank Situation
abstract: “It’s pretty bad when the very first time you ever hear of a bank is when they’re going out of business,” Stephen Colbert said on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Word of the Day: unintelligible
abstract: This word has appeared in 23 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word unintelligible has appeared in 23 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 7 in “Americans Flunked This Test on Online Privacy” by Natasha Singer and Jason Karaian:

headline: Napoli’s New Artist Shares His Secret: ‘Freedom Is My Signature’
abstract: Khvicha Kvaratskhelia has become a star in nine months at Napoli. With his transcendent talent, things may only get better.
lead_paragraph: NAPLES, Italy — European soccer’s breakout star looks briefly uneasy. It is not the setting. That is just about perfect: He is leaning on a wrought-iron railing on the terrace of the Grand Hotel Parker’s, all cut-glass, belle epoque elegance, the city of Naples spilling out to the sea beneath him. At his back lurks Mount Vesuvius, wreathed in clouds.

headline: Daylight Saving Time
abstract: How does it affect you? Do you favor making it permanent? Why or why not?
lead_paragraph: Do you live in a place where you turned your clock forward by an hour on Sunday? If so, how do you feel about it? How has it affected you and those you live with?

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Aggressive Medical Care Remains Common at Life’s End
abstract: Most older cancer patients received invasive care in the last month of their lives, a new study finds. That may not be what they wanted.
lead_paragraph: In July, Jennifer O’Brien got the phone call that adult children dread. Her 84-year-old father, who insisted on living alone in rural New Mexico, had broken his hip. The neighbor who found him on the floor after a fall had called an ambulance.

headline: M.I.A. in 2024: The Republicans Trump Vanquished in 2016
abstract: None of these former candidates have made any concrete moves toward 2024 bids, signaling how many in the party see more long-term costs than benefits in opposing Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: If Donald J. Trump were not running for president in 2024, there’s a group of Republicans who could be expected to vie for the White House: the ones Mr. Trump beat in 2016.

headline: Heartbeat May Shape Our Perception of Time, Study Shows
abstract: Researchers have long assumed that the brain controls our sense of time. A new study suggests the heart plays an important role.
lead_paragraph: It is a truism that time seems to expand or contract depending on our circumstances: In a state of terror, seconds can stretch. A day spent in solitude can drag. When we’re trying to meet a deadline, hours race by.

headline: At Long Last, a Donkey Family Tree
abstract: In a new study, genetics and archaeology combine to reveal the ancient origins of humanity’s first beast of burden.
lead_paragraph: The donkey is a key, if increasingly marginalized, character in human history. Once venerated, the animal has been an object of ridicule for so long that the word “asinine” — derived from the Latin asinus, meaning “like an ass or a donkey” — means “stupid.” Donkeys and donkey work are essential to the livelihoods of people in developing countries, but elsewhere donkeys have all but disappeared.

headline: This Isn’t What Millennial Middle Age Was Supposed to Look Like
abstract: “Who has midlife crisis money? We just increase our Lexapro.”
lead_paragraph: “Who has midlife crisis money? We just increase our Lexapro.”

headline: How Can We Measure Droughts and Deluges? Weigh the Planet.
abstract: Using 20 years of satellite observations, researchers identified periods of extreme wetness and dryness, and found they were becoming larger, more frequent and more severe.
lead_paragraph: Using 20 years of satellite observations, researchers identified periods of extreme wetness and dryness, and found they were becoming larger, more frequent and more severe.

headline: How China Went From Economic Superstar to Faltering Giant
abstract: The analyst Dan Wang takes stock of how the country’s growth trajectory has changed.
lead_paragraph: In just a few years, the narrative on China has almost completely flipped. The dominant sentiments in America had been awe, envy and a kind of fear. China’s growth seemed relentless. Its manufacturing prowess was lapping ours. It weathered the pandemic without the mass death seen in the West. It could build housing and transit and infrastructure at a speed we could no longer even imagine.

headline: If You Made a Mixtape for Your Hometown, What Sounds and Songs Would You Include?
abstract: A Times interactive article documents the sounds that help give New York City its creative soul. What’s the soundtrack of your hometown?
lead_paragraph: If you were to walk through parks and on sidewalks in your community, or gather on stoops, in backyards or at local clubs, what kinds of music would you likely hear?

headline: Forget Utopia. Ignore Dystopia. Embrace Protopia!
abstract: Some proponents of protopian thinking believe that it can lead us to a better future. Others maintain we’re already living in a protopia.
lead_paragraph: In 2009, Kevin Kelly, the white-bearded futurist and co-founder of Wired magazine, was searching his brain for a word that did not yet exist.

headline: The Government Is This Close to Reining in Some of the Worst Air Pollution
abstract: Stricter limits on oil and gas industry practices like venting and flaring will provide immediate health and climate benefits.
lead_paragraph: ALBUQUERQUE — For one 73-year-old patient in our hospital system, the simple act of breathing has become so difficult that a short walk during a medical appointment caused his blood oxygen levels to dangerously plummet. A retired Marine, he has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and uses supplemental oxygen but can no longer walk to his pickup truck without a struggle.

headline: Yan Lianke’s Latest Satire Takes Aim at Religion in China
abstract: “Heart Sutra” focuses on faith under state control.
lead_paragraph: Dollar figures don’t show up in novels anymore, Thomas Piketty observes in “Capital in the Twenty-First Century.” Rising inequality has severed shared understandings of money, he says, whereas references to specific inheritances and yearly benefices reliably told 19th-century readers much about a character’s place in the world.

headline: The Subversive Wisdom of ‘Old Wives’ Tales’
abstract: Women’s care has always depended on women’s sharing stories with one another.
lead_paragraph: As a kid, I believed every last old wives’ tale. I was sure that if I read in the dark I would go blind. That if I swam in the lake after a generous lunch I might sink to the bottom. That if I swallowed my bubble gum, the kind that came with a tiny comic strip, the hardened pebble of it would ferment in my stomach for the next seven years, which was a whole lifetime to me then.

headline: How Adam Gopnik Learned to Box, Dance, Bake Bread and Drive a Car
abstract: In “The Real Work,” the longtime New Yorker staff writer dissects the process of mastering new skills by acquiring some himself.
lead_paragraph: At first, I was a little thrown by the subtitle of Adam Gopnik’s new book, “The Real Work: On the Mystery of Mastery.” Since Gopnik, a longtime staff writer at The New Yorker, has written so urbanely on what seems like every aspect of human creation but in particular those creations called art, I assumed that the mystery he wanted to investigate would be that of the mastery displayed by our most bravura artists.

headline: When the Alien From Space Is Both a Killer and a Gender Critique
abstract: In Dolki Min’s debut novel, “Walking Practice,” an extraterrestrial who crash-lands on Earth shows what it means to feel out of place in one’s body and its surroundings.
lead_paragraph: Mumu, the alien at the center of Dolki Min’s debut novel, “Walking Practice,” is lonely. Since crash-landing on Earth 15 years ago, they’ve been friendless and without kin. Isolated and with no one to talk to, they address the reader directly, teasing and taunting, drifting and digressing with a restlessly chatty charisma. “What’s all this nonsense, you say? Just think of it as the ramblings of a life-form pretending to be human.” Mumu’s playful voice surges from the page, entertaining us through even the most gruesome parts of their days — which are frequent, because Mumu stays alive by killing and eating people they meet via dating apps.

headline: Don’t Call It a Bailout: Washington Is Haunted by the 2008 Financial Crisis
abstract: The colossal bailouts after the 2008 collapse arguably saved the global economy, but they also provoked a ferocious popular backlash.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: We Should Give Up the Fantasy of Solving the Border Crisis
abstract: There are other, better ways to evaluate the health of our immigration system and to improve it.
lead_paragraph: How did President Biden go from denouncing the immigration policies of his predecessor to following in his footsteps by proposing a regulation that would make the vast majority of current asylum seekers ineligible? How did he go from decrying the detention of immigrant families to contemplating the mass use of it?

headline: The Trump Juror Who Got Under America’s Skin
abstract: Behind our institutions are ordinary people. Emily Kohrs is their new face.
lead_paragraph: Until last month, the special grand jury investigation in Fulton County, Ga., into whether Donald Trump and his associates meddled in the state’s 2020 election, was a black box — the latest in a series that have surrounded the former president since his first days in office. From Robert Mueller’s probe to state-level investigations into his organization’s business practices and his role in payments to the adult actress Stormy Daniels, the routine has been more or less the same. Reporters scour court filings and witness appearances for new tea leaves to read. Trump and surrogates denounce the latest witch hunt. Lawyers with blue wave emojis in their Twitter bios argue with serene confidence that this time (no, really) Trump’s luck has finally run out.

headline: She Dropped Everything to Meet the K-Pop Star of Her Fantasies
abstract: In Esther Yi’s weird and wondrous ‘Y/N,’ a bored young woman in thrall to a boy band buys a one-way ticket to Seoul.
