abstract: A recent study shows the U.S. states with the highest and lowest property taxes.
lead_paragraph: Buying a home in an area where property taxes are high can add a substantial amount to your monthly outlay. Unfortunately, taxes aren’t going away, but remember, they’re often the largest source of funding for schools, roads and infrastructure, garbage collection, law enforcement and other services we expect.

headline: The Poignant Music of Melting Ice: Have a Listen
abstract: Scientists and musicians are recording the sounds of unfreezing water to document and predict the effects of climate change. Can their work help slow it, too?
lead_paragraph: As soon as Martin Sharp opened the file, he knew the ice had been singing all summer.

headline: Kehinde Wiley’s New Exhibition Is a Chapel for Mourning
abstract: “An Archaeology of Silence” opens in San Francisco, after a string of police killings of Black men. Along with powerful art, it offers a respite room to those needing a break.
lead_paragraph: When Kehinde Wiley’s exhibition, “An Archaeology of Silence,” opens in the United States on March 18, the most important room some viewers might enter is one with no artwork at all.

headline: First Republic and other U.S. Regional Banks Remain a Source of Worry
abstract: Even as the stock price of Credit Suisse, the giant European lender, recovered after a plunge, shares of some midsize American banks plummeted on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The collapse of three midsize banks last week continues to reverberate across the U.S. financial system, with the focus turning to smaller lenders that investors think may wobble if nervous depositors decide to move their money to bigger institutions.

headline: Creating a Classroom Magazine That Can ‘Make People Listen’
abstract: In this eighth grade ELA class, students write, edit and design an opinion magazine they can share with the world.
lead_paragraph: As our 10th Annual Student Editorial Contest gets underway, we want to offer an alternative for the many middle school teachers who may be eager to participate, but who are unable to do so until their students turn 13.

headline: Judge Cites 1849 Slavery Law in Ruling Embryos Can Be Considered Property
abstract: One bioethics professor called the use of an antiquated law by a Circuit Court judge in Fairfax, Va., “reprehensible and offensive.”
lead_paragraph: A Virginia judge relied in part on a 19th century law that defined enslaved people as property in a recent decision to allow a divorced woman to pursue using embryos that she shared with her former husband — a ruling that has drawn criticism.

headline: ‘Boston Strangler’ Review: Chasing a Killer (and a Byline)
abstract: Keira Knightley plays a dogged journalist in this colorless true-crime drama streaming on Hulu.
lead_paragraph: You don’t have to look further than the pedestrian title to guess that Matt Ruskin’s “Boston Strangler” is a spiritless affair. That title is a sigh of resignation, an I-have-nothing moan, a cold shoulder to the movie’s stars. Apparently, it doesn’t even warrant a definite article.

headline: How California’s Elephant Seals Made a Remarkable Recovery
abstract: Hunted nearly to extinction, northern elephant seals, native to the waters off the West Coast, now number more than 175,000.
lead_paragraph: PESCADERO, Calif. — Before summiting the slippery beachside dunes, wind-whipped sand spraying my face, I could hear what was on the other side.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
abstract: This week’s homes are a five-bedroom in Northport, N.Y., and a four-bedroom in Greenwich, Conn.
lead_paragraph: A four-bedroom, three-bath, 2,966-square-foot house built in 1932, with a wraparound porch; hardwood floors and crown molding; a fireplace in the living room; an eat-in kitchen with stainless steel appliances, wine fridge, and marble and granite countertops; a dining room with deck access; an en suite primary-bedroom wing with vaulted ceilings, private deck, sky-lit office, walk-in closets and heated bathroom floors; a third-floor bonus room; a mudroom with a washer/dryer; a yard with a koi pond and a pergola; and an attached two-car garage, on 0.28 acres. in the Riverside section. Megan Sullivan, 203-979-7413, Kim McConnell, 631-988-1510, Sotheby’s International Realty-Greenwich, 203-979-7413; sothebysrealty.com

headline: A New Plant-Focused Film Series Examines Our Entanglement with Nature
abstract: Plus: a resort on the Indonesian island of Lombok, clothes made from reclaimed quilts and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: Lombok, the island just to the east of Bali, has lately become an attractive destination on its own with an influx of compelling new boutique beach resorts including Somewhere Lombok and Siwa. On the remote Ekas Bay, just over an hour drive from the island’s international airport, is the latest opening: Innit. Designed by two Indonesian architects, Andra Matin and Gregorius Supie Yolodi (who normally work separately but came together for this project), the property currently consists of seven two-story villas partly built of local Rajumas wood, typically used for boats. The structures blend with the surrounding landscape, particularly on the ground floor, which is essentially an extension of the beach: A concrete foundation has been overlaid with soft sand, atop which sit a rattan sofa, reading chairs and a dining table. Upstairs, the primary bedrooms’ floor-to-ceiling windows overlook the bay. Shared amenities include an Indonesian, seafood-focused restaurant (don’t miss the locally farmed lobster prepared over coconut husks) and a black-tiled infinity pool. When guests aren’t lounging by the water, they can opt for more vigorous activities, from paddleboarding to hiking, with or without a guide. Innit opens March 27; villas from $400 per night, including breakfast, innithotels.com/beach-house.

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and the Bronx
abstract: This week’s homes are in Greenwich Village, Lenox Hill and on the Grand Concourse.
lead_paragraph: A three-bedroom, one-and-a-half-bath duplex co-op apartment with 11-foot ceilings and crown molding; a living room with an original mantel and fireplace; a windowed kitchen with a dishwasher; a fireplace in the primary and second bedroom; a lower-level den with exposed brick and a fourth fireplace; and a separate 850-square-foot space with a washer/dryer, on the ground floor of the Portsmouth, an 1883 building with a doorman and a laundry room. Michael Fabbri and Ryan Bourque, Nest Seekers International, 917-226-6132; nestseekers.com

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Noah Smith
abstract: The Mar. 16, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Noah Smith. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: U.S. Releases Video Footage of Drone Incident
abstract: A Russian fighter jet collided with an unarmed U.S. reconnaissance drone before it crashed into the Black Sea.
lead_paragraph: A Russian fighter jet collided with an unarmed U.S. reconnaissance drone before it crashed into the Black Sea.

headline: 7 Ways to Kick-Start Your Asia Week Art Tour
abstract: New York’s annual festival of Asian art has returned to full strength. Our critic selects seven of the most eye-catching works to anchor your itinerary.
lead_paragraph: The annual convergence of Asia-themed auctions, gallery shows and museum exhibitions known as Asia Week New York is back, and it has returned to full strength. It may be a little smaller, but it still boasts a fantastic range of Mughal miniatures, shell necklaces, painted screens and contemporary works on canvas and paper from China, India, Korea and Japan — much of it being shown by out-of-town dealers here only for the week. These seven distinctive art works, listed by gallery or museum location from north to south, will get you started, but don’t forget to browse the website for details to see what else catches your eye.

headline: ‘Lucky Hank’ Review: Better Call Solecism
abstract: Bob Odenkirk returns to TV as an academic with a knack for talking himself into trouble.
lead_paragraph: William Henry (Hank) Devereaux Jr., played by Bob Odenkirk, is a talker. But that’s redundant. Talkers are what Odenkirk does, whether he is playing a huckster on “Mr. Show,” a sleazy agent on “The Larry Sanders Show,” a sad sack on “I Think You Should Leave” or, memorably, the motor-mouthed Saul Goodman on “Breaking Bad” and “Better Call Saul.”

headline: Wall Street’s Biggest Banks Rescue Teetering First Republic
abstract: A plan led by Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and JPMorgan Chase’s chief executive led to a $30 billion infusion by 11 of the largest U.S. banks.
lead_paragraph: In an extraordinary effort to stave off financial contagion and reassure the world that the American financial system was stable, 11 of the largest U.S. banks came together on Thursday to inject $30 billion into First Republic Bank, a smaller peer on the brink of collapse after the implosion of Silicon Valley Bank last week.

headline: What Is Article 49.3 of the French Constitution?
abstract: A move used before by President Emmanuel Macron’s government can push bills through the lower house of Parliament without a vote. But detractors view it as an undemocratic tool to strong-arm lawmakers.
lead_paragraph: Article 49.3 of the French Constitution enables a government to push a bill through the National Assembly, France’s lower house of Parliament, without a vote.

headline: Poland says it foiled a Russian spy ring seeking to sabotage arms shipments to Ukraine.
abstract: The sabotage, the Polish interior minister said, was planned “at the request of Russian intelligence” and “aimed at paralyzing the supply of equipment, weapons and aid to Ukraine.”
lead_paragraph: WARSAW ⁠ — Poland on Thursday said it had detained nine foreigners accused of spying for Russia and preparing sabotage operations to disrupt the flow of Western arms into neighboring Ukraine.

headline: ‘Money Shot: The Pornhub Story’ Review: A Clear Eye on an Industry
abstract: This documentary looks at the offenses of the pornography industry through interviews with performers and activists.
lead_paragraph: In December 2020, the journalist Nicholas Kristof wrote a column in the Opinion section of The New York Times detailing the stories of young survivors whose sexual abuse was posted on the website Pornhub. The piece, which urged the site to make changes, led to Pornhub’s banning of uploads from unverified users, and to Visa and Mastercard’s prohibiting the use of their cards on the website. Kristof’s article plays a complicated role in “Money Shot: The Pornhub Story,” a documentary on Netflix that shrewdly puts center stage some of the professional porn performers seeking autonomy in the industry.

headline: U.K. Bans TikTok on Government Devices
abstract: The move reflects fears in Britain and elsewhere in the West that the popular app’s Chinese ownership could share user information with Beijing.
lead_paragraph: Britain on Thursday became the latest Western country to prohibit the use of TikTok on “government devices,” citing security fears linked to the video-sharing app’s ownership by a Chinese company.

headline: Final Sondheim Musical Will Be Staged in New York This Fall
abstract: His long-gestating final show, now titled “Here We Are,” is coming to the Shed; it is inspired by two Luis Buñuel films.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Sondheim’s long-in-the-works Luis Buñuel musical, which he described as unfinished just days before his death, will be staged in New York this fall, giving audiences the chance to see the final show by one of the most important artists in musical theater history.

headline: 10 Drums of Nuclear Material Are Missing From Libya Site, U.N. Agency Says
abstract: The U.N. nuclear watchdog said that 2.5 tons of natural uranium concentrate was unaccounted for, but that the ore itself posed little radiation hazard.
lead_paragraph: More than 2.5 tons of natural uranium are missing from a site in war-torn Libya, the director general of the U.N. nuclear watchdog said on Wednesday, telling member states that the agency was searching for the material.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | The Anthropocene
abstract: Describe the growth of the human population over the past 11,700 years.
lead_paragraph: Geology is the history of Earth, especially as recorded in rocks. Some scientists believe that we are in a new period of geologic time — the Anthropocene or “the age of humans” — characterized by human-induced, planetary-scale changes that are unfinished but very much underway.

headline: Broadway’s ‘Room,’ Starring Adrienne Warren, Postpones Run Indefinitely
abstract: The show, scheduled to open in April at the James Earl Jones Theater, was adapted from Emma Donoghue’s best-selling 2010 novel.
lead_paragraph: In a surprise move, a new Broadway show that had already begun rehearsals announced on Thursday morning that its run this spring has been scuttled because of a money shortfall.

headline: Dominique Fishback Knows You Think She’s Sweet. ‘Swarm’ May Confuse That
abstract: In a new Amazon series cocreated by Donald Glover, Fishback plays the crazed fan of a Beyoncé-like pop star. Who knew she could be so terrifying?
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As soon as she scooched into the cramped booth of a no-frills Thai restaurant in Westwood here last week, the actress Dominique Fishback did that thing she does with her eyes.

headline: ‘Shazam! Fury of the Gods’ Review: Yells Like Teen Spirit
abstract: The problem with this sequel is that the character used up his best ideas in the first movie.
lead_paragraph: Over the next three months, Warner Brothers will release two separate blockbusters starring super-dudes who zip around in red suits emblazoned with lightning bolts. “Shazam! Fury of the Gods,” a sequel that trips over its desperation to amuse, needs the running start over “The Flash.”

headline: HelloFresh to Stop Buying Coconut Milk From Thailand Amid Claims of Monkey Labor
abstract: The meal kit company’s decision follows an advocacy group’s report claiming that some monkeys in Thailand are forced to climb trees and pick the fruit.
lead_paragraph: HelloFresh, the German meal kit company, announced it would stop using coconut milk from Thailand this year, after allegations by the animal rights advocacy group PETA of the use of forced monkey labor in the coconut industry there.

headline: The Best Cuts of Chicken Hold the Most Flavor. It’s in Their Bones.
abstract: Savor the richness of drumsticks, wings and thighs in a satisfying phở gà and a Cantonese-style clay pot rice from Genevieve Ko.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, the chef Jimmy Tu opened Bunker, a restaurant in an industrial stretch of Ridgewood, Queens, far from public transportation. And eager diners were always willing to make the trek. Among his remarkable dishes, inspired by street food vendors in Vietnam, where his family is from, his phở gà stood out for its broth. Even though Bunker closed, the phở’s chicken broth lives on in my mind.

headline: 3 Dogs Die After Eating Poisoned Meatballs at a Race in France
abstract: The poisonings took place at the French canicross championships, in which people run or cycle while attached to their dogs.
lead_paragraph: Three dogs died last weekend after eating poisoned meatballs during a canine cross-country race in southern France, prompting an investigation by the local police.

headline: Protesters Clash With Police Over Retirement Change
abstract: A protest at Place de la Concorde in Paris began as a jovial scene, but devolved as night fell and violent protesters clashed with the police.
lead_paragraph: Angry protesters lit small fires and clashed with police officers clad in riot gear at the Place de la Concorde in central Paris on Thursday after President Emmanuel Macron pushed his pension bill through Parliament without a vote.

headline: Three and a Half Myths About the Bank Bailouts
abstract: There were good reasons to act, despite uncertainty.
lead_paragraph: Last weekend, U.S. policymakers went all in on bailing out two medium-size banks: Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank.

headline: Stocks rally as First Republic receives a rescue.
abstract: The S&P 500 jumped, along with shares of First Republic Bank and other regional lenders.
lead_paragraph: The week’s dizzying swings in financial markets continued on Thursday, as investors welcomed a group of big banks stepping in to support their smaller peer First Republic Bank, helping ease some of the turmoil emanating from regional lenders.

headline: How Big of a Climate Betrayal Is the Willow Oil Project?
abstract: The world wants to have it both ways on fossil fuels.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, when President Biden approved ConocoPhillips’s $8 billion plan to extract 600 million barrels of oil from federal lands in Alaska, the announcement landed simultaneously with the thud of betrayal and the air of inevitability. On the campaign trail, Biden had promised “no more drilling on federal lands, period. Period, period, period.” But for all the talk about the renewables boom and the green transition, and all the money pouring into them as well, there has been little concerted effort, in the United States at least, to really draw down our profligate use of the stuff that is actually poisoning the climate: fossil fuels.

headline: Low Rates Were Meant to Last. Without Them, Finance Is In for a Rough Ride.
abstract: Economists expected inflation and rates to stay low for years. With Silicon Valley Bank’s implosion, Wall Street is starting to reckon with how wrong that prediction has proved.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If a number defined the 2010s, it was 2 percent. Inflation, annual economic growth, and interest rates at their highest all hovered around that level — so persistently that economists, the Federal Reserve and Wall Street began to bet that the era of low-everything would last.

headline: On Italy’s Coast, Empathy Mixes With Frustration After Migrant Tragedy
abstract: As bodies continue washing up in a poverty-stricken part of Calabria, some local residents wonder whether a hard-line government understands what drives migration.
lead_paragraph: In the weeks since Vincenzo Luciano pulled a dozen bodies from the rough sea in southern Italy, he has kept a careful eye on the beach, now strewn with jackets and sneakers, for the missing son of a shipwreck survivor he promised to help find.

headline: What to Know About the Recent Eye Drop Recalls
abstract: Global Pharma recalled eye drops in February after they were tied to a drug-resistant bacteria strain linked to at least three deaths. Two more companies have since recalled eye drops.
lead_paragraph: Two brands of eye drops have been pulled from shelves in January and February after they were linked to a drug-resistant bacteria strain that has caused at least three deaths and serious health issues in several others. Weeks later, two other types of eye drops were recalled because they posed a different kind of contamination risk.

headline: Review: Parsons Dance Is an Enjoyable Ride, as Usual
abstract: The company’s run at the Joyce Theater in Manhattan, featuring a premiere set to the soulful music of Bill Withers, is fun and clever in spots.
lead_paragraph: The singer-songwriter Bill Withers grew up in Slab Fork, a coal-mining camp in West Virginia. He struggled with a stutter and served as a mechanic in the Navy. These biographical facts help illuminate some of the sources of his idiosyncratic songs, homespun and soulful, simple and often profound.

headline: Favorite Athletes, Group Work and Optimism: Recent Teen Creative and Personal Writing
abstract: Some favorite student responses to three of our Picture Prompts.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s roundup, we’re sharing student comments on three recent Picture Prompts.

headline: The Cynical Reason College Applications Are Surging
abstract: For colleges, admissions is a business, and business is booming.
lead_paragraph: Frank is on leave this month and will return on Thursday, April 6. In the meantime, this newsletter is being written by a series of guest authors with some personal connection to him or a thematic connection to his work. Today’s contributor is Jeffrey Selingo, a former editor of the Chronicle of Higher Education and the author of “Who Gets In and Why: A Year Inside College Admissions.”

headline: Mushroom Week Returns
abstract: Set any HBO-induced fungal fears aside: It’s time for crispy tacos and saucy stews.
lead_paragraph: Now that the first season of a certain hit HBO show has concluded, I think this is, finally, a safe space for the return of a beloved topic: the mushroom!

headline: Public Health vs. Economic Growth: Toxic Chemical Rules Pose Test for Biden
abstract: Key industries — including some that the White House is backing through other policies — are lobbying to water down the first major new rules in a generation on chemicals that pose risks to humans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration is preparing to impose some of the first new rules in a generation to restrict or ban an array of toxic chemicals that are widely used in manufacturing, presenting the White House with tough choices between its economic agenda and public health.

headline: ‘The Spirit of ’45’ Review: Here Comes Nationalization
abstract: A documentary from Ken Loach sees the end of World War II as a brief moment of possibility for socialism in Britain.
lead_paragraph: “The Spirit of ’45” is, atypically, a documentary from Ken Loach, whose tireless chronicles of Britain’s working class (“Kes,” “Sorry We Missed You”) have generally been dramas.

headline: ‘Inside’ Review: Tortured Artist, Meet Tortured Man
abstract: Willem Dafoe stars as an art thief who gets trapped in a penthouse in this drama.
lead_paragraph: The art thief (a brutish Willem Dafoe) trapped in a megamillionaire’s extravagant loft knows the value of the bronze wedge he’s damaging in a desperate attempt to pry open the door. It’s one of the few pieces he intended to steal from the smart home before its security pad failed and the exits locked shut. But Vasilis Katsoupis, the director of the stark survival thriller “Inside,” deliberately withholds that the makeshift crowbar is meant to be the Lynn Chadwick piece “Paper Hat,” last auctioned at 2.5 million pounds. Katsoupis prefers his moral challenge incalculable: Do we want the art to endure or the criminal?

headline: Yellen Defends Efforts to Stabilize Banking System
abstract: The Treasury secretary said U.S. banks are “sound” but that regulators feared the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank could have led to other runs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen defended the federal government’s actions to stabilize the U.S. financial system, saying recent moves to protect depositors at two banks were aimed at preventing problems from spreading through the banking system.

headline: ‘Moving On’ Review: Cracking Jokes and Settling Scores
abstract: Lily Tomlin and Jane Fonda team up in an awkward comedy about two women contemplating the murder of a predatory man.
lead_paragraph: Let me say right up front that I would happily watch Lily Tomlin and Jane Fonda in anything — except for maybe that one about the football player. Their comic partnership, inaugurated back in 1980 with “Nine To Five” and honed during the seasons of “Grace and Frankie,” is one of the blessings of modern pop culture. It is certainly the main pleasure of “Moving On,” an otherwise thin and muddled new film directed by Paul Weitz.

headline: Gerhard Richter Rides Again
abstract: The German artist says the 14 paintings here are among his last. Even so, their freshness and spontaneity feels like a new beginning.
lead_paragraph: Over the past several years the prolific, celebrated German painter Gerhard Richter has twice figured prominently in art world news. In 2017, he announced that he had made his last paintings, a series of 47 abstractions. He was 85 and said he found painting tiring; forthwith, he would devote his energies to drawing.

headline: Twitch’s Chief Executive Says He Is Resigning
abstract: Emmett Shear was a co-founder of the Amazon-owned streaming service and managed it for 16 years.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Emmett Shear, the chief executive of the livestreaming site Twitch, said on Thursday that he was resigning, ending a 16-year tenure for the co-founder of the platform favored by video game enthusiasts.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, I heard a report on NPR’s “Weekend Edition” about efforts to bring more books into the Los Angeles County Jail. It was an interesting story in its own right, but the tidbit that has stuck with me was a detail at the very end, about the kinds of books that donors aren’t allowed to give: no hardbacks (presumably they could be used as weapons), no porn (to avoid inflaming the passions, I guess?) and — the real kicker — no romance novels for the male inmates, although they’re fine for the women.

headline: A Tenor’s Secrets to ‘Lohengrin’: Golf and a Blunt Spouse
abstract: Piotr Beczala, known as a charismatic singer of Italian operas, is challenging notions of what a Wagner voice should sound like.
lead_paragraph: Piotr Beczala, tan from a recent trip to Mexico and hungry for a roast beef sandwich, walked offstage after the first act of Wagner’s “Lohengrin” at the Metropolitan Opera on Tuesday night and bounded for his dressing room.

headline: Georgia’s Jalen Carter Avoids Jail Time for Role in Fatal Crash
abstract: Carter, projected as a top-five pick in the N.F.L. draft, pleaded no contest to two misdemeanor charges and will serve 12 months of probation.
lead_paragraph: Jalen Carter, a 21-year-old defensive tackle for the University of Georgia, pleaded no contest on Thursday to two misdemeanor charges of reckless driving and racing that stemmed from a car crash in January that killed two people, his lawyer Kim Stephens said in a statement.

headline: Biden Plans to Name Nevada’s Spirit Mountain Area a National Monument
abstract: The biologically diverse land is central to the creation story of the Mojave and other tribes. Energy companies have also identified it as a prime location for wind or solar installations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden plans next week to designate nearly a half-million acres of the Spirit Mountain area in southern Nevada as a national monument, according to two people familiar with the matter,  protecting some of the most biologically diverse and culturally significant lands in the Mojave Desert.

headline: An Effort to Resolve Israel’s Impasse Stalls on How to Pick Judges
abstract: Mediators say the government and its opponents agree on some changes to a judiciary overhaul plan that has divided the country. But the process of appointing new judges remains a major obstacle.
lead_paragraph: On the streets of Israel and in the corridors of power, a standoff over the government’s plan to take greater control over the country’s courts was as heated as ever on Thursday.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: What to do in Taiwan’s capital. Also: An interview with the actor who plays Roy Kent, and high intensity interval training for beginners.
lead_paragraph: What to do in Taiwan’s capital. Also: An interview with the actor who plays Roy Kent, and high intensity interval training for beginners.

headline: ‘Rimini’ Review: Just an Austrian Gigolo
abstract: The director Ulrich Seidl’s unsettling drama tracks the exploitative behaviors of an aging lounge singer, his fans and family members.
lead_paragraph: With his stringy blond locks, his face puffy from the effects of routine boozing, Richie Bravo (Michael Thomas), the lounge-singer protagonist of Ulrich Seidl’s “Rimini,” recalls Mickey Rourke’s aging brawler in “The Wrestler,” Darren Aronofsky’s 2008 drama. Richie is also miserable, clutching the memory of his past glory as an Austrian celebrity; now, he’s stuck in the gloomy Italian resort town of Rimini, where he performs power ballads for his geriatric fans, all German tourists, in tacky hotel conference rooms. Broke, he sleeps with some of these same adoring fans for extra dough.

headline: Lyme Isn’t the Only Tick Disease to Worry About in the Northeast, C.D.C Says
abstract: Babesiosis, which can cause flulike symptoms, could be spreading because of rising temperatures and the growing deer population.
lead_paragraph: Cases of a tick-borne disease, called babesiosis, more than doubled in some Northeastern states between 2011 and 2019, researchers from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported on Thursday.

headline: The Battle Over a Professor’s Speech
abstract: Reaction to the case of Amy Wax of the University of Pennsylvania Law School. Also: The Pledge of Allegiance; Ron DeSantis; Marjorie Taylor Greene; young and old.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Taylor Swift Fans Needed a Miracle. Here’s How They Got Tickets.
abstract: After “historic demand” led to a Ticketmaster debacle, the singer’s most devoted online fans sprang into action to get each other into the Eras Tour at fair prices.
lead_paragraph: When tickets for Taylor Swift’s first tour in nearly five years went on sale last November, Tina Studts, the mother of two young girls, thought she was well prepared.

headline: There Was Ronald Reagan, Calling Out Russia. And Now We Have … Ron DeSantis.
abstract: DeSantis and Trump project weakness and moral ambiguity in the face of a weaker power.
lead_paragraph: On March 8, 1983, Ronald Reagan gave one of the most famous speeches of his presidency, an address that would go down in history as the “evil empire speech.” If you watch it today — and you remember the Reagan presidency — you can see that it was vintage Reagan, full of confidence in the American nation and the American people, replete with references to the necessity of both liberty and morality to the success of the United States.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Our TV critic recommends an Australian apocalyptic comedy, an expansive climate-crisis drama and a new dance competition series.
lead_paragraph: ‘Class of ’07’When to watch: Now, on Amazon.

headline: The Return of Morgan Wallen (Who Never Went Away)
abstract: As the country star’s new album earns the biggest debut of the year, a conversation about the nature of his fame and the scope of his reprimand for using a racial slur.
lead_paragraph: The third album by the country music superstar Morgan Wallen, the 36-song “One Thing at a Time,” just debuted at the top of the Billboard album chart, with the equivalent of 501,000 units. It is the fifth biggest streaming debut, behind only releases by Taylor Swift and Drake. Its success is an extension of the dominance of his earlier work, especially the 2021 release “Dangerous: The Double Album,” which has been the emblematic and most popular country album of the 2020s.

headline: Review: In ‘Dear World,’ Donna Murphy Leads a Righteous March
abstract: Jerry Herman’s rarely seen 1969 musical is revived in an Encores! production at New York City Center.
lead_paragraph: If the composer-lyricist Jerry Herman loved one thing, it was a brassy dame who bulldozes past all obstacles in her quest for the best possible life for herself. The women at the center of his best-known shows, “Hello, Dolly!” and “Mame,” are pathologically positive, speaking directly to our vanities and vulnerabilities — and are celebrated for it.

headline: Madison Square Garden Owner Feuds With Part-Time Liquor Inspector
abstract: The cloak-and-dagger antics in Queens signal an escalation in the battle between a state agency and James Dolan, the owner of the arena, with millions at stake.
lead_paragraph: Charles Stravalle, a New York State Liquor Authority investigator and retired police captain, knows when he’s being followed. And the black Chevrolet had been on his tail all day.

headline: Two Hikers Swept to Their Deaths by Floods in a Utah Canyon
abstract: Two men were found dead and another was rescued after bad weather triggered a flash flood in Buckskin Gulch, a narrow gorge.
lead_paragraph: Two hikers were found dead and one was rescued by helicopter earlier this week after storms and heavy rainfall triggered floods that surged through a narrow canyon in southern Utah, the authorities said on Thursday.

headline: An Artist Whose Work Might (Possibly) Have Its Own Free Will
abstract: Tauba Auerbach’s brilliant, mathematical paintings and sculptures are as playful as they are conceptual.
lead_paragraph: Every morning when the artist Tauba Auerbach arrives at their ground-floor studio, housed in an old metal-stamping factory on New York’s Lower East Side, they race down to the basement to check on the contents of their glass kiln. On a recent afternoon, Auerbach, wearing a mismatched paint-spattered sweatsuit and clogs and a black apron, guided me down the steep stairs to show me some of the work they will unveil on March 18 at their first show in five years at Paula Cooper Gallery in Chelsea. “I’m newly in love,” Auerbach declared of the kiln, inspecting its recent issue: wafer-thin lattices made from granulated colored glass called frit; sprinkled and baked, the grains fuse together, leaving gaps as they contract to form distinctive, delicate architectures. “This might sound silly, but I just understand how profound it is, the oven as a technology to change the state of this material.”

headline: Your Friday Briefing: Macron Pushes Through Pension Bill
abstract: Also, Poland says it will give Ukraine warplanes and Japan extends a hand to South Korea.
lead_paragraph: President Emmanuel Macron pushed through contentious legislation to raise France’s retirement age — without a full vote in parliament. The decision inflamed tensions and set the stage for a no-confidence vote against his government.

headline: As a Possible Indictment Looms, Trump’s Team Plans to Attack
abstract: If the former president faces criminal charges, his campaign plans to begin a broad offensive against Alvin Bragg, the Manhattan district attorney and a Democrat, accusing him of political bias.
lead_paragraph: As former President Donald J. Trump faces likely criminal charges, his campaign is preparing to wage a political war.

headline: Macron, Risking Backlash, Pushes Through Law Raising Retirement Age
abstract: Lacking parliamentary support, the French president used a special measure to circumvent a vote, a step likely to further enrage opponents.
lead_paragraph: President Emmanuel Macron, worried that France’s Parliament would not approve a fiercely contested bill raising the retirement age to 64 from 62, opted to ram the legislation through on Thursday without a full parliamentary vote, a decision certain to inflame an already tense confrontation over the measure.

headline: N.Y. Lawmaker Pressured to Resign After Sexual Misconduct Allegations
abstract: Assemblyman Juan Ardila did not deny the allegations. He said that his actions were inexcusable and that he would not “debate the facts.”
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, N.Y. — A New York state lawmaker is facing pressure to resign following accusations from two women of sexual misconduct at a college party in 2015.

headline: F.D.A. Advisers Endorse Paxlovid’s Benefits as a Covid Treatment
abstract: While an agency analysis did find signs of Covid “rebound,” the drug significantly reduces hospitalizations and deaths, researchers said.
lead_paragraph: A panel of expert advisers to the Food and Drug Administration on Thursday endorsed Paxlovid as a treatment for adults with Covid who are at high risk for progression to severe illness. The move is likely to lead to full approval of the drug, which has been available under emergency use authorization.

headline: The Sports to Watch This Weekend
abstract: This is it: the weekend you suddenly care about Kennesaw State and Florida Atlantic. (But don't forget about baseball, rugby and Formula 1.)
lead_paragraph: This is it: the weekend you suddenly care about Kennesaw State and Florida Atlantic. (But don't forget about baseball, rugby and Formula 1.)

headline: N. Dakota Supreme Court Blocks Abortion Ban; Says Constitution Protects Procedure
abstract: The court’s opinion is not the final word on the case, but it upheld a lower court’s decision to suspend the state’s abortion ban.
lead_paragraph: North Dakota’s Supreme Court upheld a lower court’s decision to block a ban on abortions in the state, and said the state Constitution protects abortion rights in some situations.

headline: For This Classical Piano Star, a Detour Is Business as Usual
abstract: Jean-Yves Thibaudet is playing Messiaen’s “Turangalîla-Symphonie” this week. But before, he debuted a night of jazz standards with Michael Feinstein.
lead_paragraph: PALM DESERT, Calif. — “Jean-Yves, when did you start playing the piano?” Michael Feinstein asked from the stage of the McCallum Theater here on a recent Friday night.

headline: Florida Faces Federal Lawsuit Over Signature Rules for New Voters
abstract: The state does not accept digital signatures on voter registration applications. There are similar rules in Texas, Georgia and Oklahoma.
lead_paragraph: A national get-out-the-vote group and the N.A.A.C.P. on Thursday challenged a Florida law that bars the use of digital signatures on voter registration forms, bringing a federal lawsuit against the state similar to ones pending in Texas and Georgia.

headline: Singing and Banging, French Lawmakers Vow to Stop Pension Change
abstract: Parties from the left and right erupted in anger after learning of the government’s plans to adopt the measure without a vote.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Lawmakers filled the grand chamber of the National Assembly, climbing into the crimson-colored seats that curl in a semicircle around a room that has been the crucible of democratic debate in France since the French Revolution. The tension was palpable.

headline: Microsoft and Google Unveil A.I. Tools for Businesses
abstract: New artificial intelligence technology is roiling Silicon Valley. For now, the most obvious ways to use it are in software like Microsoft’s suite of products.
lead_paragraph: For all the talk about the transformative nature of new technology called generative artificial intelligence, some of the earlier commercial uses may be far more prosaic: formatting a PowerPoint slide, summarizing a call or writing to-do lists.

headline: Where to Eat Near Lincoln Center
abstract: A few standout restaurants have opened near the arts complex in recent months.
lead_paragraph: A few standout restaurants have opened near the arts complex in recent months.

headline: The Designer Whose Swoops, Whorls and Waves Ruled the Red Carpet
abstract: The Indian couturier Gaurav Gupta was inescapable during awards season, dressing Cardi B and Quinta Brunson after his brand’s Paris couture debut.
lead_paragraph: Awards season, as we all know, is actually gown season. Save for the perennial winners and losers lists, most people are simply keeping an eye out for who wore what.

headline: In Iowa, Kamala Harris Says Republicans Won’t Stop at Abortion
abstract: “If politicians start using the court to undo doctors’ decisions, imagine where that can lead,” Ms. Harris said at a discussion on abortion with local lawmakers and medical officials.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Vice President Kamala Harris said on Thursday that a lawsuit seeking to overturn federal approval of a widely used abortion pill amounted to an attack on “our public health system as a whole.”

headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Finding a Buyer for TikTok May Not Be So Easy
abstract: The Biden administration is pushing TikTok’s Chinese owners to sell the app or face a possible ban. But there are many complications to finding a suitor.
lead_paragraph: TikTok has what many Silicon Valley companies lust after: A culture-making machine beloved by 100 million Americans and deep-pocketed advertisers.

headline: Pentagon Releases Video of U.S. Drone’s Encounter With Russian Jets
abstract: The 42-second clip shows two Russian fighters spraying the American aircraft with a substance the Pentagon says is jet fuel.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon’s European Command on Thursday released the first declassified video images of the events leading up to a Russian fighter jet colliding with an unarmed U.S. reconnaissance drone on Tuesday, forcing the American aircraft down into the Black Sea.

headline: Sanofi Plans to Cut the Price of Insulin
abstract: The company is the third of the three major insulin manufacturers that dominate the U.S. market to announce such a move this month.
lead_paragraph: Facing pressure to follow a wave of industry price cuts, the drug maker Sanofi said on Thursday that it would reduce the sticker price of its most commonly used insulin by 78 percent.

headline: How to Watch the New York City St. Patrick’s Day Parade
abstract: The 262nd edition of the event will start at Fifth Avenue and 44th Street and will include elected officials and a variety of bands and other groups.
lead_paragraph: The New York City St. Patrick’s Day Parade returns on Friday for the 262nd time since the tradition began in 1762. It is the parade’s second year back after a two-year hiatus caused by the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Election Watchdog Accuses Gov. Murphy of Trying to Force Him From Job
abstract: The leader of New Jersey’s election enforcement commission claims in a lawsuit that Gov. Philip D. Murphy and his aides engaged in “extortion” in a bid to oust him.
lead_paragraph: New Jersey’s top election-enforcement official sued Gov. Philip D. Murphy and three of Mr. Murphy’s top aides on Thursday for what the official said was their attempt to oust him in retaliation for comments he made ridiculing the state’s rules governing political fund-raising.

headline: Lewis Spratlan, 82, Is Dead; Took Winding Route to Music Pulitzer
abstract: His opera sat unproduced for decades. Then a piece of it garnered one of the field’s top prizes. Then it sat some more.
lead_paragraph: Lewis Spratlan won the 2000 Pulitzer Prize in music for a chunk of an opera that he had completed in 1978 and that no one had ever staged.

headline: Trump and DeSantis Could Both Lose
abstract: The Post-Tucker conservatives have arrived.
lead_paragraph: There are two different narratives running through the Republican Party right now. The first is the Trumpian populist narrative we’re all familiar with: American carnage … the elites have betrayed us … the left is destroying us … I am your retribution.

headline: Dutch Pro-Farmer Party Sweeps Elections, Upsetting the Status Quo
abstract: The surprise victory is widely seen as a protest vote against Prime Minister Mark Rutte’s government and some of his policies, including a goal to slash nitrogen emissions, which many say will imperil farming operations.
lead_paragraph: A small pro-farmers party has swept provincial elections in the Netherlands to become the biggest in the Senate by channeling wide dissatisfaction with the Dutch government, in a sharp challenge to Prime Minister Mark Rutte’s administration.

headline: House G.O.P. Hunts for Evidence That Biden Family Deals Were Improper
abstract: The chairman of the House Oversight Committee released a memorandum asserting that President Biden’s relatives received payments from a business deal with a Chinese firm.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Republicans on Thursday released financial records showing that Hunter Biden and other relatives of President Biden received more than $1 million in 2017 from an associate who had entered into a business deal with a Chinese energy company, as they hunted for evidence that the president and his family have profited improperly from his position.

headline: Poland Says It Will Arm Ukraine With Warplanes, Raising Stakes
abstract: The Polish leader said he would send jets designed by the Soviet Union to help Ukraine fend off Russian forces. It was unclear if other allies might follow suit.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Poland’s president said on Thursday that his country would transfer four Soviet-designed MIG fighters to Ukraine “literally in the next few days,” potentially pushing Western military aid to the embattled country over a significant threshold.

headline: Corrections: March 17, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, March 17, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about a 1,600-year-old coffin discovered in northern England referred imprecisely to English Heritage. The organization manages prehistoric sites, medieval castles and Roman forts in England, not in the rest of Britain. (Other groups manage such sites in Northern Ireland, Scotland and Wales.)

headline: Princeton Commemorates Long-Ago Upset With a New One, of Arizona
abstract: In 1996, Princeton dropped U.C.L.A. in one of the most stirring N.C.A.A. tournament upsets. This year, it downed No. 2 seed Arizona.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — To hear the Princeton Tigers tell it, they sensed an upset at least 20 minutes before the basketball world saw what was coming.

headline: Fed Blocked Mention of Regulatory Flaws in Silicon Valley Bank Rescue
abstract: Federal government officials wanted a joint statement to include a reference to regulatory shortcomings that they believe helped lead to the bank’s demise.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As U.S. regulators prepared to announce an extraordinary government rescue of depositors at Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank on Sunday, officials from the Biden administration pushed to formally spotlight shortcomings in financial regulation that they blamed for the banks’ rapid descent to insolvency, according to several people involved in or close to the discussions.

headline: Rare Ice Sheet Forms on a Lake Tahoe Bay
abstract: It appears to be the first time in three decades that Emerald Bay, Calif., an inlet on Lake Tahoe, has frozen over, leaving some locals in awe.
lead_paragraph: In March, the birds usually begin appearing in Emerald Bay, Calif., as the days get longer and the temperature creeps up, melting the snow that feeds the creeks — the first tantalizing signs of spring. But this month, the bay, on the western shores of Lake Tahoe, has instead been frigid, stark and silent.

headline: Join a Boxer Rebellion
abstract: Carter Cobb opens our solving weekend.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Review: A Pageant of Love and Antisemitism, in ‘Parade’
abstract: Ben Platt and Micaela Diamond star in a timely and gorgeously sung Broadway revival of the 1998 musical about the Leo Frank case.
lead_paragraph: You do not expect the star of a musical about a man lynched by an antisemitic mob to be his wife. Especially when that man, Leo Frank, who was murdered in Georgia in 1915, is played, with his usual intensity and vocal drama, by Ben Platt.

headline: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
abstract: Christina Iverson tests the variety waters with a winsome debut.
lead_paragraph: PUNS AND ANAGRAMS — This was such a pleasant surprise! Christina Iverson is a puzzle editor at The Times and a familiar name to weekend solvers, mainly as a frequent constructor or co-constructor of bang-up Sunday crossword puzzles. Those big grids always come with a sprinkle of clever wordplay to bring a smile, and now we get to take a crack at a smaller grid with nothing but those offbeat gems.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Tribes Weigh the Future of Plundered Trophies
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, March 17, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “I think it’s finally sinking in that people are starting to identify us as human beings and not as scientific specimens in need of study.”

headline: New Data Links Pandemic’s Origins to Raccoon Dogs at Wuhan Market
abstract: Genetic samples from the market were recently uploaded to an international database and then removed after scientists asked China about them.
lead_paragraph: An international team of virus experts said on Thursday that they had found genetic data from a market in Wuhan, China, linking the coronavirus with raccoon dogs for sale there, adding evidence to the case that the worst pandemic in a century could have been ignited by an infected animal that was being dealt through the illegal wildlife trade.

headline: Search Crew Rescues Sole Survivor of Utah Hiking Group
abstract: A helicopter airlifted the hiker from deep within the canyons of Buckskin Gulch, which was flooded after heavy rainfall.
lead_paragraph: A helicopter airlifted the hiker from deep within the canyons of Buckskin Gulch, which was flooded after heavy rainfall.

headline: Theater Brought Them Together, but a Dead Rat Sealed the Deal
abstract: Katie Travis, an actress, suspected David Ruttura, a director, had a crush. One hint: He named a character in “School of Rock” after her.
lead_paragraph: David Brendan Ruttura and Katherine Julia Travis met in October 2014 in New York while working on the national tour of “The Phantom of the Opera.” Ms. Travis, who goes by Katie, was playing the role of Christine Daaé and Mr. Ruttura was the resident director.

headline: In Sickness and In Health, and Then, a Wedding
abstract: Marc VanSchaick and Nika Beamon found a new spark in their friendship after going to a Red Sox game, which eventually led them to support one another through personal challenges.
lead_paragraph: When Mtamanika Colisse Beamon and Marc Anthony VanSchaick were both working at WABC-TV in New York — she as a producer and he as a photojournalist — in 2007, neither was interested in meeting the other, despite the encouragement from a colleague.

headline: A ‘Flawless’ Proposal That Took a Few Tries — and the Fire Department
abstract: Michael Greene showed up to his first date with Tomika Anderson in a Bentley and fur coat. The journey to engagement was a little less smooth.
lead_paragraph: Michael Earl Greene’s four children had encouraged him to make a profile on a dating app, but he’s “old fashioned,” he said. It took some convincing before he joined Bumble and made his first and last swipe ever — on Tomika Lee Anderson.

headline: Here Lie the Bickersons, Side-by-Side for All Eternity
abstract: When I bought a burial plot for my almost-ex-husband’s girlfriend, I never guessed who might end up there instead.
lead_paragraph: Recently I came across the deed to two cemetery plots I own on Long Island. One is the final resting place of my late husband, Mark. The other, next to it, is vacant but was never meant for me. I bought it for his grieving girlfriend.

headline: Three Dates, and Then a Commitment
abstract: Grace Fooden and Michael Correy met on Bumble and quickly bonded over similar family backgrounds and a Phish cover band.
lead_paragraph: Grace Fooden and Michael Nicholas Correy make a practice of not dismissing the opinions of younger people in their lives.

headline: What We Learned From Friday’s Madness: One Upset to Rule Them All
abstract: Fairleigh Dickinson stunned Purdue in only the second upset of a No. 1 seed by a No. 16 seed in men’s college basketball.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Fairleigh Dickinson, a No. 16 seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament, defeated top-seeded Purdue on Friday, 63-58, in the most shocking upset in men’s college basketball in half a decade.

headline: Turning the ‘Music of Daily Life’ Into All Kinds of Anthems
abstract: Steve Barakatt never planned to become the composer of official songs for his native Quebec and other entities. It just worked out that way.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll meet the Francis Scott Key of Quebec. And of a South Korean development project. And of UNICEF. He makes his Carnegie Hall debut tomorrow. We’ll also look at two sides of the Republican Party in New York. One is combative and Trump-friendly.

headline: Purdue Favors Old Basketball Ideas. Will It Keep Working?
abstract: Led by center Zach Edey, the Boilermakers, who play on Friday, have earned a No. 1 seed in the N.C.A.A. men’s tournament.
lead_paragraph: WEST LAFAYETTE, Ind. — Zach Edey, the Big Ten men’s basketball player of the year, has grown exhausted, sometimes demoralized, by the focus on his body, which, at 7-foot-4 and 305 pounds, towers cartoonishly over students at Purdue University.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Private-sector bailout for First Republic Bank.
lead_paragraph: Eleven U.S. banks came together yesterday to inject $30 billion into First Republic Bank, a smaller peer on the brink of collapse after the implosion of Silicon Valley Bank last week. The arrangement, in which each will deposit at least $1 billion into First Republic, is meant as a show of support and a signal that the San Francisco lender’s woes do not reflect deeper trouble.

headline: You Don’t Have to Be a Doctor to Know How Much Trouble the N.H.S. Is In
abstract: But it’s not too late to save it.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 15, nurses walked out and began the largest nurses’ strike in the history of Britain’s National Health Service. They were protesting working conditions that have left them burned out and stretched thin — and compromised patient safety — and wages that fell in the last decade in real terms. Ambulance workers joined them. This week, thousands of junior doctors went on strike for three consecutive days.

headline: Jimmy Kimmel Mocks Trump’s New Lawyer
abstract: Kimmel joked that Joe Tacopina “seems to have been born in the ashtray of Rudy Giuliani’s Lincoln Continental.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Slovakia follows Poland in pledging warplanes for Ukraine, but most of its jets are in disrepair.
abstract: The news came after Poland’s president said that his country would send MIG-29 jets, a move that appeared intended to open the door to more advanced warplanes from NATO allies.
lead_paragraph: The government of Slovakia said on Friday that it would send 13 Soviet-designed fighter jets to Ukraine, a day after a similar announcement by Poland’s president, marking a possibly significant shift from NATO allies in increasing arms supplies for Kyiv.

headline: Word of the Day: callous
abstract: This word has appeared in 96 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word callous has appeared in 96 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Dec. 19 in “A Culture in the Cross Hairs” by Jason Farago, Sarah Kerr, Ainara Tiefenthäler and Haley Willis:

headline: Banking
abstract: What do you think this image is communicating?
lead_paragraph: What do you think this illustration is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: To Tyre Nichols, Memphis Was a City of Light
abstract: After Mr. Nichols’s death at the hands of police officers, his photographs of Memphis took on more meaning. The Times published several of them.
lead_paragraph: Tyre Nichols explored Memphis, the city he had moved to in 2020 from Sacramento, through the lens of a camera.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of the Broadway revival of "Parade," starring Ben Platt.
lead_paragraph: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of the Broadway revival of "Parade," starring Ben Platt.

headline: A Very Wet Winter Has Eased California’s Drought, but Water Woes Remain
abstract: Storms have brought heavy rain and snow to the state, but its ‘water issues haven’t gone away.’
lead_paragraph: Storms have brought heavy rain and snow to the state, but its ‘water issues haven’t gone away.’

headline: GPT-4 Is Here, and the Group Chat Bank Run
abstract: Then, Mark Zuckerberg rethinks Meta’s strategy.
lead_paragraph: It’s acing standardized tests, building websites and hiring TaskRabbits — GPT-4 is “equal parts fascinating and terrifying.” OpenAI has released its latest model, alongside A.I. announcements from Meta, Google and other industry players. The A.I. arms race is only accelerating.

headline: Should More Sports Be Coed?
abstract: In korfball, men and women play together with equal respect and responsibility. Could games like this have benefits for players on and off the court?
lead_paragraph: Do you play any sports? Are the teams you play on separated by gender? If so, do you like playing on single-gender teams? Or do you ever wish they were mixed?

headline: If You Want to Know What Republicans Think About How Americans Feel, Ask Walgreens
abstract: The abortion pill decision by Walgreens reflects the right’s success in using corporations to affect public policy.
lead_paragraph: The corporate culture wars have reached a turning point: A number of companies that once championed social justice and equity seem to be beating a hasty retreat.

headline: These Painters Regret Their Dealings With Scam Artists
abstract: Young artists say they often receive offers by email to purchase their paintings, but many are part of schemes to defraud them by using fake checks and phony shipping companies.
lead_paragraph: Many young artists survive their early careers with commissions from friends and family. Zachary Ginsberg was no different, participating in local fairs and selling his portraits to relatives for a couple of hundred dollars.

headline: DeSantis, on Defense, Shows Signs of Slipping in Polls
abstract: For now, the Florida governor isn’t firing back at Trump.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a tough few months for Ron DeSantis.

headline: What’s Wrong With Getting a Little Free Legal Advice?
abstract: State laws prohibiting the “unauthorized practice of law” hurt those who cannot afford a lawyer.
lead_paragraph: When the United States was founded, friends and neighbors could freely advise one another how to deal with legal problems. Anyone could give advice about the law or draft legal documents for others. One had to be a lawyer to advocate before certain courts, but that was all that lawyers had an exclusive right to do.

headline: Set It and Actually Forget It
abstract: Millions of workers open retirement accounts, then ignore or forget about them, leaving thousands of dollars unattended. Are you one of them?
lead_paragraph: Raquel Charles was in her mid-20s when she signed up — begrudgingly — for her first retirement account. Wading through paperwork to start her job at the Administration for Children’s Services in New York City, she would have skipped over the retirement option if not for an older colleague’s intervention.

headline: A Pianist Who Changes Key From Liberace to Cardi B
abstract: Chloe Flower has performed at the Grammys, and went viral during the Golden Globes. Naturally, a Christmas album is on the way.
lead_paragraph: Name: Chloe Flower

headline: CNN’s Prime-Time Experiment Is Off to a Slow Start
abstract: Viewership is down in the early going of CNN’s new 9 p.m. programming strategy, as the network tries to reinvent itself.
lead_paragraph: CNN’s new chairman, Chris Licht, debuted a novel experiment last month to revive his network’s flagging prime-time ratings, betting that viewers would tune in for a mix of exclusive interviews and specials dedicated to hot-button topics like fentanyl abuse and the war in Ukraine.

headline: Why We Want to Live (and Work) in That Vermeer Light
abstract: A quick scan of real estate listings shows the instinctive hold that sunlight has over us.
lead_paragraph: Sunlight wields enormous power in our interior spaces. It can drive up the value of real estate and alter the mood of a room. It can clarify the work on your desktop and create warmth on a cool day. No light bulb can do all that.

headline: Pam Shriver’s Tennis Juggling Act
abstract: The 21-time Grand Slam doubles champion is doing four-way duty as a television commentator, a coach, an ally to sexual abuse survivors and an agitator for changing the game’s culture.
lead_paragraph: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — It was late in the afternoon of an early round at the BNP Paribas Open in the California desert, and Pam Shriver was having a day.

headline: And Now Let’s Review …
abstract: A.O. Scott conducts his own exit interview as he moves to a new post after more than two decades of reviewing films.
lead_paragraph: Who the heck are you, anyway?

headline: A Little Motivation to Take a Walk
abstract: It’s one of the best forms of preventive medicine, experts say.
lead_paragraph: I, like so many of us, spend too much time hunched over a computer — and it’s alarming me a little. So throughout my day, I ask myself: Can this activity be done while walking? I’ve recently taken meetings and made eight-minute phone calls on foot, and I turned one coffee date with a friend into a ramble through the park.

headline: Will the Fed Keep Tightening as Banks Fail?
abstract: By quietly shedding billions in assets, the Fed is making conditions tighter for banks, home buyers and investors, our columnist says.
lead_paragraph: Quantitative tightening is supposed to be boring. That’s by design.

headline: After a Wild Week, What Are Markets Saying About the World?
abstract: Stocks, bonds and commodities markets are all sending different signals. Although the S&P 500 rose this week, oil prices fell along with bond yields, signaling that investors are worried about the economy.
lead_paragraph: It was a week of market turmoil that began with the collapse of a small bank in the United States, spiraled into a panic about the global financial system and ended with a bold effort to stanch the cascading crisis that ultimately fell short.

headline: What Happened to the Woman in the Hotel Room Next Door?
abstract: With their closed doors and transient nature, hotels can provide an environment for crimes like sex trafficking. An incident in the middle of the night prompts a writer to ask what is being done to prevent them.
lead_paragraph: The sound of rage woke me just before midnight. A man’s voice in the adjacent hotel room screamed, “Get out of my room!” with an obscenity added. His staccato fury was interspersed with heavy slamming noises and pleas of mercy from a woman’s voice.

headline: American Directors Bring Fresh Visions to Europe’s Opera Stages
abstract: Young music theater makers are benefiting from the continent’s huge operatic resources while developing their own distinctive voices.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, American directors headlined three of Europe’s most prestigious opera festivals.

headline: Banned From Russian Airspace, U.S. Airlines Look to Restrict Competitors
abstract: Because of the war in Ukraine, U.S. carriers have to take the long way on flights to and from Asia, giving an advantage to foreign rivals flying the same routes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Unable to fly through Russian airspace because of the war in Ukraine, U.S. airlines are stepping up a lobbying campaign on Capitol Hill and at the White House to address what they say is a growing problem: They are losing business to foreign competitors who can take passengers between the United States and Asia faster and more cheaply.

headline: Chicago’s New Manager Has a Clear Message: Details Matter
abstract: The star-laden White Sox underperformed last year. Pedro Grifol plans to wake up the A.L. Central’s “sleeping horse.”
lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Ariz. — Ask Pedro Grifol about his mentors, the folks who put him on the path to managing the Chicago White Sox, and he starts with his grandfather. Pedro Antonio Grifol, who emigrated from Cuba, delivered newspapers in the early mornings and worked all day as a high school janitor in Miami. But his day really began, he would tell young Pedro, when he picked him up from school.

headline: The Second Life of a Christian College in Manhattan Nears Its End
abstract: The King’s College, which draws students from around the country to Manhattan, has not been able to recover from enrollment and financial losses.
lead_paragraph: Administrators at the King’s College, a small Christian liberal arts college in Manhattan, have been meeting with students in recent weeks to deliver a grim message: All of you should find someplace else to go to school.

headline: Residents’ Right to Be Rude Upheld by Massachusetts Supreme Court
abstract: In an age of division, the court ruled that towns could not mandate polite discourse at public meetings. One official called the decision “very dispiriting.”
lead_paragraph: In a decision that jangled the nerves of some elected officials, the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court last week reaffirmed a basic liberty established by the founding fathers: the right to be rude at public meetings.

headline: An Artist for the End of the World
abstract: What’s so funny about our dystopian future? Just ask Josh Kline.
lead_paragraph: WHEN “SURROUND AUDIENCE,” the New Museum’s third triennial of contemporary art, opened in downtown New York in 2015, one piece quickly emerged as the standout. The mixed-media artist Josh Kline had created a full-room installation that deftly captured the daily indignities and collective angst of life in a sputtering democracy. The piece’s actual title is “Freedom,” but most viewers referred to it by another name: the Teletubbies.

headline: What Do Clothes Look Like in a Climate-Changed Future?
abstract: The costume designers behind the new Apple TV+ show “Extrapolations” offer a glimpse into the future of clothing in a warming world.
lead_paragraph: For decades, costumes meant to depict the future have taken inspiration from the streamlined silhouettes of the space age, and designers like André Courrèges and Paco Rabanne. But the way we dress in the coming years could be shaped more by climate change than life on the moon.

headline: Recyclable? Try Refillable. The Quest For a Greener Cleaner
abstract: As more consumers try to cut down on plastic waste, both start-ups and big brands like Clorox are hoping to usher in a new age of refillable cleaners.
lead_paragraph: Every week, Angela Espinoza Pierson looked at her recycling bin — filled with detergent jugs, shampoo bottles and clamshell containers that once held strawberries — with mixed feelings. Sure, it was a lot of plastic. But it was going to be recycled.

headline: As Dreams of Peace Wither, Nightmares Flourish in Ukraine’s Sleep
abstract: A survey asked hundreds of wartime Ukrainians what they dreamed about. Many replied: the war.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — The Russian tanks roll up to the house of 4-year-old Taras and open fire, burying his mother in debris. Taras tries, as hard as he can, to pull her from the rubble, but she is too heavy, and so he just pulls uselessly on her arm.

headline: When Helpless Fish Need a Hero, She Answers the Call
abstract: Three hundred goldfish in a hospital basement, a suckermouth at the airport: When fish are in crisis, a Bronx beautician and a partner in Pennsylvania ride to the rescue.
lead_paragraph: Construction workers have been at work demolishing an abandoned tuberculosis hospital in Queens over the past several months, dismantling the long-empty wards and carting off the bricks. But first, they had to figure out what to do with a school of goldfish which for unknown reasons had come to call the flooded basement home. Three hundred of them.

headline: Mortgages, Wine and Renovations: Silicon Valley Bank’s Deep Tech Ties
abstract: More than many other banks, SVB catered to how risky tech start-ups and their backers do not adhere to normal business practices.
lead_paragraph: When Kleiner Perkins, one of Silicon Valley’s highest-profile venture capital firms, wanted to build a bridge between two of its office buildings around 2005, it decided to take out a loan. It turned to Silicon Valley Bank, just 43 feet away on Sand Hill Road in the heart of the venture industry in Menlo Park, Calif.

headline: Jailed in Egypt at 17, He Wrote to Survive and to Share His Long Ordeal
abstract: Sentenced as a teenager to 15 years for “unlawful assembly,” Abdelrahman ElGendy started recording the abuses of prison life. The idea of someday publishing his memoir gave him a reason to live.
lead_paragraph: Abdelrahman ElGendy envisioned the ending of his book would be inspiring, despite all the horrors he would have to recount.

headline: Mass Protests in Israel Often Start on a Neighborhood Street, or an App
abstract: A movement against the government’s judicial overhaul plan is a grass-roots affair spread by word of mouth and WhatsApp messaging groups.
lead_paragraph: The four activists arrived stealthily just after dawn at the well-guarded home of the Israeli minister in a leafy residential street in Jerusalem. Dropping to the sidewalk, they handcuffed themselves to one another through sections of pipe, and to a nearby lamppost, for a “lock-on” protest in front of the front gate.

headline: Americans Head to Europe for the Good Life on the Cheap
abstract: Home sales to Americans have increased significantly, giving them a chance to enjoy a lifestyle they could not afford in major U.S. cities, but the influx risks upsetting local residents.
lead_paragraph: Ben Mitas sipped Vinho Verde from a stemmed wineglass while he watched his daughter play on a swing one afternoon in January. He had bought the wine from a quiosque, the ubiquitous park kiosks, a luxury of living in Lisbon.

headline: Meet Radio Man: Autograph King, Friend of George Clooney, ‘Bum’
abstract: In the billion-dollar industry of professional “graphing” — collecting celebrity signatures for resale — nobody does it like Radio Man.
lead_paragraph: On a blustery February evening in Midtown Manhattan, opposite an unmarked side entrance to the Ed Sullivan Theater, a crowd of more than 60 people stood crushed against a row of steel barricades. They all knew that at any moment, Harrison Ford would arrive for an appearance on “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert.” They elbowed and cursed one another, jockeying for position, each clutching a sheaf of photographs for Mr. Ford to sign.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, March 17, 2023
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: In Myanmar, Atrocities Rise as Army Comes Under Pressure
abstract: The rebellion against military rule is gaining strength, and analysts say soldiers are responding with increased brutality.
lead_paragraph: When the soldiers from Myanmar’s notorious army reached the village of Nanneint, the residents fled. Some took refuge in the basement of a nearby Buddhist monastery.

headline: Xi, Cast as Peacemaker, Wades Into Russia’s War in Ukraine
abstract: China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, is expected to meet with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia next week and speak with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, has cast himself as a global statesman, helping Saudi Arabia and Iran broker a deal to restore diplomatic ties while extolling the virtues of “Chinese solutions and wisdom” in solving the world’s biggest security challenges.

headline: Turkey’s Erdogan endorses Finland’s NATO bid.
abstract: Finland joining the alliance after decades of military nonalignment would be a major shift and represents a significant diplomatic and strategic defeat for Russia.
lead_paragraph: Turkey announced on Friday that it would move to ratify Finland’s application to join NATO, clearing a significant hurdle for the Nordic nation’s bid to join the alliance but leaving neighboring Sweden on the sidelines for now.

headline: Why the Banking Crisis Isn’t Over Yet
abstract: The sudden collapse of Silicon Valley Bank is fueling concern that the industry’s problems have only just begun.
lead_paragraph: In the past week, as spooked customers frantically withdrew $42 billion from Silicon Valley Bank, the U.S. government stepped in to craft a rescue operation for the failed lender.

headline: Japan and South Korea Make Nice, but Can It Last?
abstract: Both sides face potential political snags, as well as a delicate balancing act in a region where the United States and China are competing for influence.
lead_paragraph: To underscore the celebratory atmosphere surrounding the long-awaited visit by South Korea’s president this week, Japan’s prime minister hosted not just one, but two, dinners on Thursday night in Tokyo.

headline: Going Hungry in America
abstract: The country’s neediest are dealing with food stamp cuts and rising prices at the same time.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, millions of Americans got a notice: Your food budget is about to be cut, potentially by hundreds of dollars a month. Here are some tips on how you can manage. You can’t appeal.

headline: Bank Stocks Resume Slide as Relief Over Rescue Fades
abstract: Despite the rescue of First Republic, investors continue to sell off shares in the ailing bank and some other regional lenders, dragging the market lower.
lead_paragraph: Stocks dropped on Friday, signaling that investors had little confidence that the banking crisis had run its course despite moves to shore up flailing lenders with injections of tens of billions of dollars.

headline: What Happens on Page 76 in This Season’s New Books?
abstract: The artist Didier William envisions new releases by Victor LaValle, Mona Simpson and more.
lead_paragraph: “The men climbed up and got the horses trotting. With so much weight on the animals, they took the journey slow.

headline: Search Intensifies for Radioactive Canister Missing for Weeks in Thailand
abstract: It’s not clear exactly when the 55-pound cylinder containing cesium-137 vanished from the power plant where it was in use.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — In Thailand, a steel canister with dangerously radioactive contents has vanished from a coal power plant and may have been missing for three weeks — or possibly longer. The search for it, which began a week ago, has expanded repeatedly but so far yielded nothing.

headline: Submarine Deal With U.S. and U.K. Sparks Debate in Australia
abstract: The agreement has raised concerns about the need for the costly plan and whether it could tether Australia to the United States.
lead_paragraph: When Prime Minister Anthony Albanese formally unveiled plans with the U.S. and U.K. on Monday to develop and deploy nuclear-powered attack submarines, it set off a chain reaction of questions and criticism at home, and notably within his own party.

headline: Are America’s Banks Safe Yet?
abstract: The nation’s top lenders banded together to rescue First Republic Bank. But markets worry that regional institutions remain under pressure.
lead_paragraph: America’s biggest banks unveiled an impressive show of force on Thursday, injecting $30 billion into First Republic Bank as it teetered on the brink of collapse.

headline: Anger and No-Confidence Motions Follow Pension Action in France
abstract: After President Emmanuel Macron pushed his unpopular pension bill through Parliament without a vote, demonstrations about the changes broke out again — including a violent standoff in Paris.
lead_paragraph: Opposition parties filed two no-confidence motions against President Emmanuel Macron’s government on Friday after his decision to push a widely unpopular pension bill through Parliament without a full vote, escalating a showdown with protesters and labor unions, who have vowed more strikes.

headline: Parent Company of Silicon Valley Bank Files for Bankruptcy
abstract: The move would place SVB Financial Group, which owns other businesses aside from the collapsed Silicon Valley Bank, into a court-led process as creditors looked to recover funds.
lead_paragraph: SVB Financial Group, the former parent company of Silicon Valley Bank, the lender that regulators seized last week after a devastating run on deposits, filed for bankruptcy on Friday.

headline: More MIG fighters will help Ukraine, but what Kyiv really wants are F-16s.
abstract: Ukrainian officials and military analysts do not expect the MIG jets pledged so far by Poland and Slovakia to fundamentally alter the battle in the skies.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Ukraine’s fighter pilots have helped to keep Russia from controlling the skies above the battlefield in the yearlong war. But the fact remains that Russia’s air force dwarfs Ukraine’s and its pilots have far superior technology.

headline: Hundreds of L.A. Schools May Close Next Week as Workers Plan to Strike
abstract: A three-day strike at Los Angeles Unified School District is scheduled to start Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: It’s Friday. A three-day strike planned for next week may shut down the Los Angeles Unified School District. Plus, a powerful new exhibit at the de Young Museum in San Francisco.

headline: A Life-Changing Phone Call and More: The Week in Reporter Reads
abstract: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: Disco Night at Mar-a-Lago (and Other Tales From Palm Beach’s Private Clubs)
abstract: Inside the exclusive dinner clubs in South Florida, where money talks and Donald Trump sometimes plays D.J.
lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH, Fla. — If you plan to dine at a hot spot in Palm Beach this season, pack clothing so bright that it might be radioactive. Why? Sartorial armor is practically required in any exclusive enclave. And Palm Beach is all about fitting in and showing you belong.

headline: How Boston Left the Rest of the N.H.L. Behind. Far Behind.
abstract: The Bruins, who won 50 games faster than any N.H.L. team in history, have sputtered of late, but with a lead that big, there is room to focus on the larger goal.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — From the moment the Boston Bruins gathered for training camp in September, the players were under a mandate. Almost every team strives to win the Stanley Cup, of course, but the Bruins were driven by a deeper purpose.

headline: U2 Revisits Its Past, in the Name of … What, Exactly?
abstract: With “Songs of Surrender,” an album of 40 reimagined songs, and “A Sort of Homecoming,” a documentary on Disney+, the Irish band pauses to reflect.
lead_paragraph: For decades, U2 refused to rest on its catalog. A rarity among bands for having kept the same lineup since its formation in 1976 — Bono on lead vocals, the Edge on guitar and keyboards, Adam Clayton on bass and Larry Mullen Jr. on drums — U2 has headlined arenas since the early 1980s.
