abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:

headline: Bill Gates: ‘I Worry We’re Making the Same Mistakes Again’
abstract: “We can’t afford to get caught flat-footed again.”
lead_paragraph: Imagine there’s a small fire in your kitchen. Your fire alarm goes off, warning everyone nearby about the danger. Someone calls 911. You try to put the fire out yourself — maybe you even have a fire extinguisher under the sink. If that doesn’t work, you know how to safely evacuate. By the time you get outside, a fire truck is already pulling up. Firefighters use the hydrant in front of your house to extinguish the flames before any of your neighbors’ homes are ever at risk of catching fire.

headline: On Pets, Moral Logic and Love
abstract: I didn’t think I was a dog person. Then Herbie showed up and taught me a lesson about love.
lead_paragraph: In January, I fell in love with someone. It was the last thing I’d expect and caught me completely off guard.

headline: Assad’s 2nd Diplomatic Trip in Days Speeds Easing of Isolation
abstract: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, welcomed in the Emirati capital with a 21-gun salute, is gradually re-emerging after the global shunning that followed his violent crushing of his country’s 2011 uprising.
lead_paragraph: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria traveled to the United Arab Emirates on Sunday for an official visit, a sign of the growing momentum with which he is returning to the international stage after a decade-long isolation.

headline: UBS Agrees to Buy Rival Credit Suisse
abstract: In a deal brokered by the Swiss government, Switzerland’s largest bank will buy its smaller rival for about $3.2 billion.
lead_paragraph: Switzerland’s largest bank, UBS, agreed on Sunday to buy its beleaguered and longtime rival Credit Suisse for about $3.2 billion, the most drastic bid yet to arrest the financial panic that has swept the globe over the past week.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Kid-friendly recipes, chicken ragù and more.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I don’t know that my father made fried chicken every Sunday afternoon when I was small, but that’s how I remember it: the slice of bacon floating in the spattery oil, flour everywhere, golden crusty chicken laid out on a wire rack, then kept warm in the oven before supper. Mashed potatoes to go with, gravy, greens I rarely ate, everything washed down with a tall glass of milk and the New Lost City Ramblers on the turntable. It was among my favorite meals as a child.

headline: Review: Jaap van Zweden Returns to a Changed Philharmonic
abstract: Since the orchestra’s music director was last on the podium in November, his successor has been announced. He came back blaring with Messiaen.
lead_paragraph: “What have I missed?” you could imagine Jaap van Zweden thinking as he stood on the podium at David Geffen Hall and looked out at the audience on Friday evening. It’s been months since van Zweden, the music director of the New York Philharmonic, led this orchestra in a furious burst of activity as it opened the renovated Geffen Hall.

headline: Before Collapse of Silicon Valley Bank, the Fed Spotted Big Problems
abstract: The bank was using an incorrect model as it assessed its own risks amid rising interest rates, and spent much of 2022 under a supervisory review.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Silicon Valley Bank’s risky practices were on the Federal Reserve’s radar for more than a year — an awareness that proved insufficient to stop the bank’s demise.

headline: Amid Violence, Israeli and Palestinian Officials Meet to Promote Calm
abstract: Fearing that an already-bloody year could worsen during Ramadan, Palestinians and Israelis met for the second time in a month.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israeli and Palestinian officials met in Egypt on Sunday, along with other Middle Eastern and United States representatives, in an effort to lower tensions and the potential for violent conflict during the Muslim holy month of Ramadan, which starts this week.

headline: A ‘New Cold War’ Looms in Africa as U.S. Pushes Against Russian Gains
abstract: The U.S. is reprising its playbook in Ukraine, where it has used classified information to expose plans by Russia. Next target: Chad.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Fueled by guns, gold and social media, the rivalry between Russia and the West in Africa is rapidly escalating. The latest flashpoint is Chad, a sprawling desert nation at the crossroads of the continent, now a plum target for Russia’s expanding effort.

headline: The Happiness (or Sadness) of Progressives
abstract: Readers respond to David Brooks’s column about sadness among progressives. Also: Fleeing Oklahoma; Swiss neutrality and Ukraine; homeless in America.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: 5 Young People Are Killed in Car Crash in Westchester County
abstract: A 9-year-old boy was the sole survivor after a teenage driver veered off the road. The victims ranged in age from 8 to 17, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A fiery crash on the Hutchinson River Parkway took the lives of five young people in the early hours of Sunday morning, according to the Westchester County police.

headline: Trump Grand Jury Could Hear From Critic of Prosecution’s Star Witness
abstract: The grand jury considering the hush-money case against Mr. Trump might hear the testimony of lawyer Robert J. Costello, a critic of the ex-president’s fixer.
lead_paragraph: A Manhattan grand jury that is expected to vote soon on whether to indict Donald J. Trump may hear testimony Monday attacking the prosecution’s star witness, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: The Exquisite Darkness of Depeche Mode
abstract: Dave Gahan and Martin Gore are back with the group’s 15th album. But after losing the bandmate Andy Fletcher last year, their return was anything but certain.
lead_paragraph: SANTA BARBARA, Calif. — Martin Gore, who is now 50 percent of Depeche Mode, works in a studio on a low hill near Santa Barbara, hidden behind jungle-green foliage and fragrant flowering shrubs.

headline: Houston and Alabama Size Each Other Up From the Same Arena
abstract: The Cougars and Crimson Tide, the remaining No. 1s in the N.C.A.A. men’s tournament, both played this weekend in Birmingham, Ala. They will headline a wide-open round of 16.
lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — When the Houston Cougars trudged to the locker room at halftime of their second-round game in the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament, their shoulders weren’t the only things sagging. So were their national championship hopes.

headline: Leader of International Seabed Mining Agency Admonished by Diplomats
abstract: The United Nations-affiliated agency faces pressure from some member nations to greenlight ocean mining — and from others to slow it down.
lead_paragraph: Michael Lodge, the head of the United Nations-affiliated agency with jurisdiction over international ocean waters, has pushed diplomats to accelerate the start of industrial-scale mining at the bottom of the Pacific Ocean, members of the International Seabed Authority’s governing council said in interviews.

headline: Review: Protecting and Defending Ukraine’s Cultural Identity
abstract: A festival responds to the assaults and insults of war by celebrating the composer who shaped the nation’s contemporary music, Borys Liatoshynsky.
lead_paragraph: The shadow of the war in Ukraine once again hovered over the Ukrainian Contemporary Music Festival on Friday when it began its three-day tribute to the 20th-century composer Borys Liatoshynsky at Merkin Hall.

headline: Space Debris Spotted Over Northern California
abstract: Observers in Sacramento were mesmerized by streaks of light that brightened the night sky on Friday. The flaming debris was retired communications equipment that the International Space Station discarded in February 2020.
lead_paragraph: Observers in Sacramento were mesmerized by streaks of light that brightened the night sky on Friday. The flaming debris was retired communications equipment that the International Space Station discarded in February 2020.

headline: Flaming Space Debris Re-entering Atmosphere Lights Up California Sky
abstract: Chunks of communications equipment, which were jettisoned from the International Space Station, moved at 17,000 miles per hour, making for a nighttime spectacle.
lead_paragraph: A mesmerizing display of lights streaking in the night sky over Northern California on Friday was caused by the re-entry of flaming space debris into Earth’s atmosphere, experts said.

headline: Lab Leak or Not? How Politics Shaped the Battle Over Covid’s Origin
abstract: A lab leak was once dismissed by many as a conspiracy theory. But the idea is gaining traction, even as evidence builds that the virus emerged from a market.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the spring of 2021, with studies of the coronavirus pandemic’s origins going nowhere and the issue embroiled in bitter partisan politics, David Relman, a microbiologist at Stanford, quietly made a request of his congresswoman.

headline: Your Monday Briefing: Putin and Xi to Meet in Moscow
abstract: Also, Donald Trump says his arrest is imminent and UBS agrees to buy Credit Suisse.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir Putin made surprise visits to two Russian-occupied parts of Ukraine over the weekend: Crimea and the city of Mariupol. The defiant gesture came after the International Criminal Court issued a warrant for his arrest on Friday.

headline: Dissecting Charges That Could Arise From the Trump Investigations
abstract: Prosecutors in New York, Georgia and the Justice Department face complex choices about what crimes to charge if they decide to indict Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Prosecutors like to say that they investigate crimes, not people. The looming decision by the Manhattan district attorney about whether to indict former President Donald J. Trump on charges related to an alleged hush money payment to a porn actress is highlighting the complexity of the legal calculations being made by prosecutors in New York, Georgia and the Justice Department as they examine Mr. Trump’s conduct on a number of fronts.

headline: Federal Reserve and Global Central Banks Act to Shore Up Dollar Access
abstract: America’s central bank and its counterparts around the world are rushing to cushion markets against the impact of bank problems.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve and other major global central banks on Sunday announced that they would work to make sure dollars remain readily available across the global financial system as bank blowups in America and banking issues in Europe create a strain.

headline: What the Fish Said
abstract: Adam Vincent wants you to solve and then run for your life.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Trump Allies Pressure DeSantis to Weigh In on Expected Indictment
abstract: The effort previews how an indictment would jolt the still-nascent race for the Republican presidential nomination — and perhaps already has.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s political operation is trying to use the news of his expected indictment by a Manhattan grand jury to turn the strident base of the Republican Party against his expected rival for the 2024 presidential nomination, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida.

headline: Review: A Dance Gushes With an Outpouring of the Inner Self
abstract: Bobbi Jene Smith and Or Schraiber seem to have had a thousand ideas for “Pit.” All of them appear to have been included.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — “Angels empty the pockets of a violinist. / A woman in red. A mound of filth.” So read lines written by Bobbi Jene Smith in a poetic evocation of her new work, “Pit,” for the Paris Opera Ballet.

headline: Hedge Funds That Bet on Credit Suisse Rescue Face Uneven Results
abstract: Among the funds to bet on the rescue deal were two that specialize in buying the bonds of companies on the brink of bankruptcy.
lead_paragraph: As the value of Credit Suisse stocks and bonds plummeted last week, some investors viewed the sell-off as an opportunity to buy, anticipating that regulators would step in and prevent Credit Suisse from total collapse. They were right.

headline: Review: In Fosse’s ‘Dancin’,’ a Wiggle Is Worth a Thousand Words
abstract: A revival of the 1978 dancical has been substantially revamped to argue for Bob Fosse’s pure dance cred. It’s a joy anyway.
lead_paragraph: Right from the start, we’re advised that “Bob Fosse’s Dancin’,” which opened on Sunday at the Music Box Theater, will be “almost plotless” and include “no messages.”

headline: Cruz Miguel Ortíz Cuadra, ‌67, Face of Puerto Rican Culinary History, Dies
abstract: The island’s leading expert on its cuisine and its roots, he sought to educate the world about it through books, podcasts and teaching.
lead_paragraph: Cruz Miguel Ortíz Cuadra, a food historian who as Puerto Rico’s leading gastronomy expert sought to define the island’s cuisine and educate the world about it, died on March 8 in San Juan, P.R. He was 67.

headline: Two People Are Killed in Separate Colorado Avalanches
abstract: A skier was caught in an avalanche in the Maroon Bowl area of Highland Peak, near Aspen, on Sunday, two days after a man was buried in snow debris near Marble, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Two people were killed and four others were caught in two separate avalanches in Colorado since Friday, the authorities said.

headline: How Does Carbon Capture Work?
abstract: The idea of removing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere to turn back the clock on climate change is an appealing one. Can these technologies deliver on their promise?
lead_paragraph: The idea of removing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere to turn back the clock on climate change is an appealing one. Can these technologies deliver on their promise?

headline: Adam Sandler Is Awarded the Mark Twain Prize for American Humor
abstract: The comedy star was celebrated at the Kennedy Center in Washington for his prolific three-decade career as an actor, writer, producer and stand-up comic.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Adam Sandler brought his trademark loopy but charming sense of humor to the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts on Sunday night, as he was recognized for three decades of writing, acting and directing with the Mark Twain Prize for American Humor.

headline: Another No. 1 Gone, as Indiana Loses to Miami
abstract: The Hoosiers joined Stanford as top seeds to lose on their home courts. With the loss to Miami, Indiana is just the sixth No. 1 to miss the round of 16 since 1994.
lead_paragraph: For the first time since 1998, the round of 16 in the N.C.A.A. women’s tournament will be played without two of its No. 1 seeds.

headline: The Hoosiers’ Secret Weapon? He’s an 88-Year-Old They Call Pops.
abstract: Dick Moren, the father of Teri Moren, the Indiana women’s basketball coach, is the team’s No. 1 fan. He has a stringent game-day routine.
lead_paragraph: Dick Moren isn’t in the Hoosiers’ starting lineup, but he might as well be.

headline: Quotation of the Day: For TV News, Prime Time Comes Early
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, March 20, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “There’s so much more choice than there used to be. You can watch ‘Top Gun: Maverick’ on streaming. It’s hard for the news to compete with Maverick.”

headline: No Corrections: March 20, 2023
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, March 20, 2023.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Dr. Tony Fauci’ and the Mark Twain Prize
abstract: An ‘American Masters’ documentary follows Dr. Fauci, and Adam Sandler receives the Kennedy Center’s annual comedy award.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Mar. 20-26. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Will Trump be arrested this week?
lead_paragraph: Over the weekend, Donald Trump said that he expected to be arrested tomorrow. In a post on his social network, Truth Social, he sought to rally supporters and called for protests. Within hours, Speaker Kevin McCarthy said he wanted House committees to investigate whether federal funds were being used for “politically motivated prosecutions.”

headline: U.S. Breezes Past Cuba and Into World Baseball Classic Final
abstract: Trea Turner and a stacked U.S. lineup won in a rout, with protests inside and outside the stadium marking Cuba’s first game in Miami since at least 1959.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — It was a historic night, with the Cuban national baseball team playing in the city with the largest Cuban population in the United States, but the game itself was unable to match the intensity of the moment. Behind its star-studded offense, the United States dismantled Cuba, 14-2, at loanDepot Park on Sunday and advanced to the World Baseball Classic final.

headline: Stocks Bounce as Investors Welcome Bank Rescue Deals
abstract: The S&P 500 rose on Monday, but fears about the health of some banks, particularly First Republic, lingered.
lead_paragraph: Stocks nudged higher in choppy trading on Monday, as investors cautiously welcomed moves to shore up the global financial system after the collapse of four banks set off turmoil in financial markets this month.

headline: A Campaign to Remind Us That We Love New York (City)
abstract: A marketing alliance will introduce a logo that recalls a famous one from the 1970s, used to promote New York during tough times.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll get a preview of a new campaign to boost New York that has a back-to-the-future ring.

headline: Trump’s Team Braces for an Indictment
abstract: The former president's team is preparing for potential charges in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: The former president's team is preparing for potential charges in Manhattan.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Which Is the Better Buy? The Washington Commanders or Manchester United?
abstract: A struggling N.F.L. franchise is for sale. So is a Premier League club that is a storied name in a global sport. The markets for the two teams say a lot about sports economics.
lead_paragraph: Washington’s football team hasn’t won a championship in three decades, struggles to sell out its stadium and was recently ranked the least desirable team in the league by players. Manchester United is a perennial contender in the Premier League and is one of the most sought-after sports brands with about a billion fans around the globe.

headline: Out of Power, Trump Still Exerts It
abstract: An early-morning social media post amounted to a starter’s gun for Republican officials: Many raced to the former president’s side, denouncing a Democratic prosecutor investigating him.
lead_paragraph: Since he left office, Democrats and a smaller number of Republicans have vowed to ensure that former President Donald J. Trump never recaptures the White House, where he would regain enormous power over the nation and around the globe.

headline: Trial of 2016 Twitter Troll to Test Limits of Online Speech
abstract: Douglass Mackey tried to trick Black people into thinking they could vote by text in the Clinton-Trump presidential election, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: The images appeared on Twitter in late 2016 just as the presidential campaign was entering its final stretch. Some featured the message “vote for Hillary” and the phrases “avoid the line” and “vote from home.”

headline: For Years She Said a Coach Abused Her. Now She Has Named a Legend.
abstract: Jennifer Fox has long discussed what happened when she was 13 and her coach was 40. She even based a film on it. Now she has revealed the final detail: his identity.
lead_paragraph: In 2018, Jennifer Fox made an Emmy-nominated film called “The Tale” about her pieced-together memories of what she now describes as childhood sexual abuse.

headline: Iraq, 20 Years Later: A Changed Washington and a Terrible Toll on America
abstract: The White House, Congress, the military and the intelligence agencies see the war as a lesson in failed policymaking, one deeply absorbed if not thoroughly learned.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A month before President George W. Bush first sent American troops into Iraq, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld was warned that the war might end up costing the United States billions of dollars.

headline: The Children of the Iraq War Have Grown Up, but Some Wounds Don’t Heal
abstract: Twenty years after the U.S. invaded Iraq, a veteran Times correspondent and photographer asked Iraqis about growing up in wartime, and about their hopes now.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The thump of a car bomb explosion, then a whoosh of flame interrupting homework; the low boom of a roadside bomb and seconds later the shattering of glass jolting families awake; an apartment door being kicked open in the middle of the night and someone shouting in a foreign language; the pop, pop, pop of bullets whizzing past in a firefight and the bang of doors slamming as grown-ups drag children inside.

headline: Some Details on the Agenda for Xi Jinping’s Visit to Russia
abstract: The Chinese leader is expected to talk to Vladimir V. Putin about Ukraine and other issues.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news of the Putin-Xi summit in Russia.

headline: Why China and Russia Are Closer Than Ever
abstract: This week’s meeting between the leaders of China and Russia marks another key moment in the deepening relationship between the two powers.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news of the Putin-Xi summit in Russia.

headline: Your Data Is Diminishing Your Freedom
abstract: “We’re loading our lives into these systems and feeling we have no control of how these systems work,” warns the political theorist Colin Koopman.
lead_paragraph: “We’re loading our lives into these systems and feeling we have no control of how these systems work,” warns the political theorist Colin Koopman.

headline: How Can I Avoid Looking Like a Tourist in New York?
abstract: Hint: It’s less about what you wear, and more about how you wear it.
lead_paragraph: A better question may be what would make you not fit in? There are so many different versions of New York, so many layers of history and psycho-geographies — uptown and downtown; literary New York and financial New York; the hipster havens of Bushwick and Greenpoint — that almost anything goes, as long as it comes with the right attitude.

headline: ‘Biography of X’ Rewrites a Life Story and an American Century
abstract: Catherine Lacey’s new novel follows a polarizing artist through a fractured country.
lead_paragraph: The narrator of “Biography of X,” the new Catherine Lacey novel, is a journalist named C.M. Lucca who worked for a Village Voice-like newspaper in New York City during the 1980s. C.M. has a cool tone and a lonely intelligence; she’s a solitary spirit. Her voice is clear but worn, like beach glass. There’s some early Renata Adler in it, and some Janet Malcolm.

headline: Should Old TV Shows Be Brought Back?
abstract: Which series would you like to see return with their original casts to continue the story? Which do you think should stay gone?
lead_paragraph: What are your favorite television shows? Are any of them old shows that no longer have new seasons in the works? Were any of them created long ago, maybe even before you were born? Would you like any of these shows to be revived, meaning that the original actors return as the same characters, only in the present day?

headline: The Chaotic, Dispiriting Work of Liquidating Harmon Stores
abstract: Employees of the beauty and health chain said Bed Bath & Beyond’s decision to shut it down had caught them by surprise. Communication never got better.
lead_paragraph: It had been a busy but successful holiday season at the Harmon Face Values store in Morris Plains, N.J.

headline: Fed Meets as Bank Chaos Collides With Inflation
abstract: The Federal Reserve will decide whether and by how much to raise interest rates this week at a moment when its path ahead is newly fraught.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve entered 2023 focused on a central goal: wrestling down the rapid inflation that has plagued American consumers since 2021. But over the past two weeks, that job has become a lot more complicated.

headline: I Fantasized About Multiple Timelines, and It Nearly Ruined My Life
abstract: The multiverse has become a favorite pop cosmology. But there’s a danger in getting fixated on the fantasy that there are other, better versions of our world.
lead_paragraph: The patient was elderly and lived alone. She was showing signs of depression, but it was clear that something more was amiss. She insisted she was trapped in the wrong timeline.

headline: Crypto Wants Its Shine Back
abstract: After a miserable year, cryptocurrency companies are looking for ways to rebrand products that many consumers no longer trust.
lead_paragraph: At a cryptocurrency conference in Denver this month, a group of singers clad in bright orange onesies took the stage to perform what one industry website later described as an anthem for the crypto faithful, a “blockchain ‘Blowin’ in the Wind.’”

headline: Video Testimony in the Covid Era Faces a Constitutional Test
abstract: Two criminal defendants have asked the Supreme Court to decide whether remote testimony against them violated the Sixth Amendment’s confrontation clause.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In March 2021, a year into the coronavirus pandemic, a key witness in a criminal case in a federal court in New York was allowed to testify remotely, from his lawyer’s office in California. The cross-examination was marred by technical glitches and the stilted awkwardness familiar to anyone who has participated in a Zoom call.

headline: Lauren Ambrose Just Wants to Go to French Clown School
abstract: The actress, who is joining the cast of “Yellowjackets,” talks about British sitcoms, the “On Being” podcast and gardening at night.
lead_paragraph: “What creature is that?” Lauren Ambrose asked, craning her neck during a video interview from her home in the Berkshires. “I see this, like, crazy hawk sitting on a tree outside my window. It just caught my eye.”

headline: Before His Death, I Asked the Manhattan D.A. What His Greatest Fear Was. He Answered: ‘Trump.’
abstract: The history behind the unlikely friendship between Robert Morgenthau and Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: IN THE SUMMER OF 2019, when Robert M. Morgenthau, who reigned over New York law enforcement for six decades, died, 10 days short of his 100th birthday, eulogies filled the newspapers, the governor ordered flags to half-staff, and the man in the White House weighed in. “I was saddened to learn of the recent passing of Bob Morgenthau, a truly great man!” Donald Trump wrote on Twitter.

headline: How to Fix the TikTok Problem
abstract: If only Big Tech were getting the same scrutiny and enforced accountability that TikTok is enduring.
lead_paragraph: Banning TikTok won’t keep us safe.

headline: I Went on a Package Trip for Millennials Who Travel Alone. Help Me.
abstract: On visiting Morocco with a group-travel company that promised to build “meaningful friendships” among its youngish clientele.
lead_paragraph: Imagine walking into a party where you know almost no one (pathetic) — a party at which I, a stranger to you (probably), have arrived well before you (sorry). Should this occur in real life, it is inevitable that shortly after your entrance, as you are tentatively probing the scene in search of safe ingress into social traffic, I will yank you, abruptly, into the middle of a conversation. I will turn to you and start talking as if you’d been involved in the discussion for an hour. I will lob questions at you that are tailored so that any answer you give can be right. Soon, you will forget I dragged you into this interaction; your easy popularity will seem, in retrospect, inevitable. You will most likely feel at least vaguely friendly toward me, because I so clearly want to be your friend. And the whole time I am doing this — because, despite your rewritten recollections, I am the one doing all of this — I will be thinking: Oh, my God, I’m doing it again. I hate this. I hate this. Why can’t I stop doing this to people?

headline: N.Y. Authorities Prepare for Unprecedented Arrest of an Ex-President
abstract: Ahead of a likely indictment, law enforcement officials are making security plans as some of Donald J. Trump’s supporters signal that they intend to protest.
lead_paragraph: He would be fingerprinted. He would be photographed. He could even be handcuffed.

headline: A Sumptuous Historical, a Sweet Paranormal, a Gorgeous Bit of Horror
abstract: New romance novels brim with shining, seductive, beautifully crafted sentences.
lead_paragraph: There is nothing like the power of a well-set sentence, where every shining word is thoughtfully placed. I offer some of my favorites from this month’s romances, the better to tempt you with.

headline: Falling Lithium Prices Are Making Electric Cars More Affordable
abstract: An unexpected decline in the price of an essential battery material, along with those of other commodities, is good news for buyers. But experts disagree on how long low prices will last.
lead_paragraph: Lithium, the common ingredient in almost all electric-car batteries, has become so precious that it is often called white gold. But something surprising has happened recently: The metal’s price has fallen, helping to make electric vehicles more affordable.

headline: Never Mind About Ron DeSantis
abstract: The governor of Florida has the national interest all wrong.
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. I guess we have to talk about Donald Trump’s potential indictment and arrest, right? But before we go there: You know how I told you that I’d vote for Ron DeSantis over Joe Biden?

headline: Exploring a Malaysian Jewel Box Packed With Color and Spice
abstract: George Town, a colonial port on the island of Penang, dazzles visitors with its winding alleys, pastel-painted storefronts, sumptuously restored hotels and mouthwatering food.
lead_paragraph: “Try this way,” says Zainal Abidin, an affable manager at the Prestige in George Town, Malaysia, cocking his head to one side. Mr. Zainal is showing me around the hotel, which is named after the 2006 Christopher Nolan film about two rival magicians. I’m supposed to see an illusion in which the corridor entrance transforms into a mirror, but it’s not coming.

headline: Americans’ Old Car Batteries Are Making Mexican Workers Sick
abstract: The removal of lead from car batteries, many from the United States, at recycling plants in northern Mexico has led to high levels of lead contamination, a new report found.
lead_paragraph: After returning home from his job at a car battery recycling plant in northern Mexico one evening in 2019, Azael Mateo González Ramírez said he felt dizzy, his bones ‌ach‌ed and his throat was raspy. Then came ‌stomach pain, he said, followed by bouts of diarrhea.

headline: The Colorado River Is Running Dry, but Nobody Wants to Talk About the Mud
abstract: It’s time to drill holes in Glen Canyon Dam on the Colorado River and empty Lake Powell.
lead_paragraph: It’s difficult to fathom how the Colorado River could possibly carve the mile-deep chasm that is the Grand Canyon. But if one thinks of the river as a flume of liquid sandpaper rubbing the land over millions of years, it begins to make sense. “The finest workers in stone are not copper or steel tools,” Henry David Thoreau wrote, “but the gentle touches of air and water working at their leisure with a liberal allowance of time.”

headline: A Tiny Town Was Dying, but Reba McEntire Came to the Rescue
abstract: The country-music star is trying to revive her childhood home in Oklahoma with a restaurant, concert stage and lots of Reba memorabilia.
lead_paragraph: ATOKA, Okla. — Year after year, eight million vehicles drove through this sleepy town just off U.S. Highway 75, which stretches from Texas to Canada. Almost none of them stopped.

headline: House Tour | Ramdane Touhami & Victoire de Taillac-Touhami
abstract: The husband-and-wife creatives invite T into their 5,400-square-foot home, a former brothel in Paris.
lead_paragraph: The husband-and-wife creatives invite T into their 5,400-square-foot home, a former brothel in Paris.

headline: A Parisian Designer Builds His Dream House in a Former Brothel
abstract: Ramdane Touhami has turned a haute bohemian landmark into an audacious showcase for his inimitable, fearless creativity.
lead_paragraph: THE POLYMATHIC PARIS-based designer and entrepreneur Ramdane Touhami considers thinking overrated. “For me, it’s mostly a waste of time; instead I just do,” he says midway through a breakneck monologue — in which he describes his recent logo work for Moynat and Christofle, a hotel he’s just acquired in Switzerland, the challenges of reviving the nearly 400-year-old candle maker Cire Trudon and his collection of works by the German industrial designer Dieter Rams — as we drink takeout espresso in the late winter drizzle outside a coffee bar near his 10th Arrondissement studio. Most of the city has ceased masking, but not Touhami, and he stays outside when he can, no matter the weather, terrified of missing even a day of work because of illness. “I have so many things going on that there’s no room for that in my life,” he says.

headline: How TikTok Became a Matter of National Security
abstract: The U.S. government has expressed concerns that the app may endanger sensitive user data.
lead_paragraph: TikTok, the app known for short videos of lip syncing, dancing and bread baking, is one of the most popular platforms in the country, used by one out of every three Americans.

headline: A World War II Pilot Saved His Crew. It Took Almost 80 Years to Find His Remains.
abstract: Lt. William B. Montgomery flew a B-24 Liberator toward the British coast after it was hit in June 1944. Historians credit him for saving the lives of seven crew members.
lead_paragraph: The American pilot felt his aircraft wobble in the sky near the coast of West Sussex, England, where the beach gleamed below him, and the emerald meadow pastures lay ahead on June 22, 1944.

headline: Indictment Week?
abstract: If Trump is indicted, this week will be unlike any other in American politics.
lead_paragraph: Shortly before a grand jury in New York State indicts somebody, the person typically gets a chance to testify to the jury. The opportunity is a sign that the investigation is wrapping up and that prosecutors are giving the target a chance to tell his or her side of the story. Typically, the target declines to do so and waits to mount a defense until later.

headline: Spring Sweaters for Every Mood
abstract: Knits that range from quiet neutrals to high-contrast brights.

headline: How Do People Released From Prison Find Housing?
abstract: Thousands of people released from prison in New York go directly to homeless shelters.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Brooks hopes he won’t have to go to a homeless shelter. In 1999, Mr. Brooks and four others were arrested and charged with murder, and he was eventually sentenced to 25 years to life in prison.

headline: Why More Deals Are Likely After the Fall of Credit Suisse
abstract: Investors are still spooked after UBS bought its Swiss peer, with confidence in the banking sector in short supply.
lead_paragraph: Andrew here. After Credit Suisse’s historic shotgun sale to UBS over the weekend, the question now is whether the 166-year-old bank is the last domino to fall — or the first.

headline: $5 Million Homes in California
abstract: A Spanish-style home in Los Angeles, a renovated 1905 bungalow in Palo Alto and a Cape Cod-style retreat in Laguna Beach.
lead_paragraph: The first owner of this Los Feliz home was John Anson Ford, a longtime member of the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors and the namesake of the John Anson Ford Theatre, a music and performing arts venue in the Hollywood Hills.

headline: 6 Podcasts About Cults and Their Enduring Sinister Attraction
abstract: These shows explore the psychology of cult leaders and their victims, as well as how cultish thinking can bleed into our everyday lives.
lead_paragraph: Cults are ideal podcast fodder: psychologically rich human stories that combine elements of true crime, mystery and social history, and are often best told in long-form style. It’s been theorized that cults tend to proliferate during times of significant uncertainty and flux, which might explain why the public appetite for these stories remains so robust.

headline: Think You Have Red Flags? Marie Faustin Would Be Happy to Let You Know.
abstract: As the host of “Why Are You Single?,” a new live game show, the comedian will help determine whether you are the problem.
lead_paragraph: On a Wednesday night in Brooklyn, onstage in front of about 250 people, a woman who has been single for two and a half years recalled the last time she dated someone she actually liked.

headline: Internet Blocked in Indian State as Security Forces Pursue Separatist
abstract: The rise of Amritpal Singh, a self-styled preacher, has raised fears of violence in Punjab, where thousands died in the 1980s during a Sikh insurgency.
lead_paragraph: The authorities on Monday restricted communications across the Indian state of Punjab for a third day as a manhunt continued for a Sikh separatist leader, whose rapid rise in the public eye has stirred fears of violence in a state with vivid memories of a bloody separatist insurgency.

headline: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
abstract: Entries for the week of Mar. 13, 2022.
lead_paragraph: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes. It is probably also worth mentioning that the Diary is a work of fiction.

headline: California Marks Three Years Since Covid Stay-at-Home Orders
abstract: The nation’s first statewide stay-at-home order was announced on March 19, 2020.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a long three years.

headline: Climate Change Is Speeding Toward Catastrophe. The Next Decade Is Crucial, U.N. Panel Says.
abstract: A new report says it is still possible to hold global warming to relatively safe levels, but doing so will require global cooperation, billions of dollars and big changes.
lead_paragraph: Earth is likely to cross a critical threshold for global warming within the next decade, and nations will need to make an immediate and drastic shift away from fossil fuels to prevent the planet from overheating dangerously beyond that level, according to a major new report released on Monday.

headline: A Different Kind of Pipeline Project Scrambles Midwest Politics
abstract: Plans that would bury carbon underground rather than release it in the air have stoked debate over climate and property rights, creating unlikely alliances and stirring memories of fierce battles over oil.
lead_paragraph: HARTFORD, S.D. — For more than a decade, the Midwest was the site of bitter clashes over plans for thousand-mile pipelines meant to carry crude oil beneath cornfields and cattle ranches.

headline: Besides China, Russia Maintains Warm Relations With These Countries
abstract: India and South Africa are among the nations that have not criticized Russia for invading Ukraine. Some others have supplied military aid.
lead_paragraph: The state visit by China’s leader, Xi Jinping, to Russia highlights the close ties between the nations, a relationship that is increasingly crucial for Moscow as it is cut off from most of the West.

headline: Australian State Moves to Ban Nazi Salute After Clashes at Rally
abstract: After neo-Nazis appeared at a protest against transgender rights in Melbourne, a local politician was facing expulsion from her party for taking part in the demonstration.
lead_paragraph: It was a startling sight on the stone steps of Parliament House, the grand seat of state government in Melbourne, Australia: more than two dozen people dressed in black, many with their faces covered, each extending an arm in an unmistakable Nazi salute.

headline: 1948: Egypt Starts Power Project
abstract: Laying the foundation stone of a hydroelectric project that would have ambitious successors.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO, March 19 (U.P.).—King Farouk today laid the foundation stone of a new hydro-electric scheme at the Aswan Dam, in upper Egypt. The work which is expected to begin at Aswan shortly will be continued at Esna Nag Hamadi and Assiout, where other hydro-electric stations will be built. The whole scheme is to be completed by 1953. — The New York Herald, European Edition, March 20, 1948

headline: Americans Have Mostly Forgotten the Iraq War. I Haven’t.
abstract: For some, even 20 years later, the war hasn’t ended.
lead_paragraph: It was supposed to be a farewell party.

headline: American Held Hostage in Africa Is Freed
abstract: Jeffery Woodke, an aid worker abducted in Niger by militants, was released after more than six years in captivity. A second hostage was also released: Olivier Dubois, a French journalist who disappeared in April 2021.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An American aid worker abducted by militants more than six years ago in West Africa has been freed, his wife and U.S. officials said on Monday, but the circumstances of his release were not immediately clear.

headline: French government and Macron’s retirement overhaul survive a no-confidence vote. Here’s the latest.
abstract: President Emmanuel Macron’s government survived a crucial no-confidence vote in France’s lower house of Parliament on Monday after his decision to force through a change in the national retirement age set off the most intense political turmoil since his re-election last year.
lead_paragraph: President Emmanuel Macron’s government survived a crucial no-confidence vote in France’s lower house of Parliament on Monday after his decision to force through a change in the national retirement age set off the most intense political turmoil since his re-election last year.

headline: Here’s what to expect in Monday’s no-confidence vote in France.
abstract: Lawmakers in the National Assembly will debate two motions to oust President Emmanuel Macron’s cabinet and defeat his plan to raise the national retirement age.
lead_paragraph: By pushing through its plan to overhaul pensions and raise the national retirement age by two years to 64, the French government has exposed itself to no-confidence motions that could bring down President Emmanuel Macron’s cabinet — an outcome not seen in half a century of French politics.

headline: Trump’s Georgia Lawyers Seek to Quash Special Grand Jury Report
abstract: In a new motion, the lawyers asked that the Fulton County district attorney’s office be disqualified from the investigation into election interference in the state in 2020.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — As former President Donald J. Trump awaits a possible indictment in New York, his lawyers pushed back on Monday at another criminal investigation swirling around him in Georgia, filing a motion to quash the final report of a special grand jury that considered whether Mr. Trump and some of his allies interfered in the 2020 election results in the state.

headline: Israeli Leaders Advance Key Part of Judicial Overhaul but Delay Rest
abstract: The government vowed to press on with a plan to take more control over appointing judges. But other changes were postponed in a move that was presented as a concession.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s government announced on Monday that it would attempt to enact by early April the most contentious part of its effort to overhaul the country’s judiciary — a change to the way that judges are appointed — while postponing the implementation of other parts of the plan by at least a month.

headline: First Official Estimate of Somalia’s Drought Shows 43,000 Dead
abstract: At least half of the deaths were children under the age of 5, according to the report by health researchers, the United Nations and the Somali government.
lead_paragraph: About 43,000 people died last year from the drought in Somalia, according to international agencies and the government, which on Monday released the first official death toll about the record drought devastating the Horn of Africa nation.

headline: Fate of First Republic Hangs in Balance as Shares Plummet Again
abstract: A $30 billion cash infusion and a frantic effort to sell a stake in the bank have done little to calm investors.
lead_paragraph: The most imperiled bank on Wall Street, First Republic, slid closer to the precipice on Monday as its shares fell 47 percent, down nearly 90 percent since its close on March 8, the day Silicon Valley Bank’s woes incited a financial panic.

headline: A Clear Message From Science
abstract: An international panel offers a warning about the dangers of fossil fuels, and also a blueprint to change course.
lead_paragraph: “There is a rapidly closing window of opportunity to secure a livable and sustainable future for all (very high confidence).”

headline: E.U. Officials Agree to Supply More Artillery Shells to Ukraine
abstract: European leaders adopted a plan to provide Ukraine with badly needed shells, while replenishing their own national stocks.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European Union foreign and defense ministers agreed on Monday to spend up to 2 billion euros, or $2.14 billion, to supply Ukraine with badly needed artillery shells, replenish their own national stocks and ramp up Europe’s ammunition production.

headline: Meta Manager Was Hacked With Spyware and Wiretapped in Greece
abstract: Artemis Seaford, a dual U.S.-Greek national, was targeted with a cyberespionage tool while also under a wiretap by the Greek spy agency in a case that shows the spread of illicit snooping in Europe.
lead_paragraph: A U.S. and Greek national who worked on Meta’s security and trust team while based in Greece was placed under a yearlong wiretap by the Greek national intelligence service and hacked with a powerful cyberespionage tool, according to documents obtained by The New York Times and officials with knowledge of the case.

headline: Review: ‘The Good John Proctor’ Imagines Girlhood BFFs
abstract: The play, directed by Caitlin Sullivan at the Connelly Theater, focuses on two girls in the year leading up to the action depicted in “The Crucible.”
lead_paragraph: Abigail Williams is described by Arthur Miller in “The Crucible” as a “strikingly beautiful girl” of 17 with “an endless capacity for dissembling.” Lusty and conniving, Miller’s Abigail has an affair with her former boss, John Proctor, and after she gets fired, tries to hex his wife out of jealousy by drinking blood and dancing naked with other girls in the woods. Her lies about that night serve as the catalyst for Miller’s 1953 dramatization of the Salem witch trials, which casts John as its tragic hero.

headline: An Asparagus Tart for Spring
abstract: Make an adaptable tart with puff pastry, sabzi polo for Nowruz and more recipes.
lead_paragraph: It’s the first day of spring, which means you’re officially allowed to start daydreaming about asparagus and artichokes, green garlic and peas. So what if all those vegetables aren’t available locally, spring is here! And this creamy asparagus and goat cheese tart (above) is calling your name.

headline: Zoë Chao Identified With ‘Party Down’ a Little Too Well for a While
abstract: Starz’s beloved cater-waiter comedy hit awfully close to home when Chao was still hustling to make ends meet at a bar. She’s less worried about that now.
lead_paragraph: “To center myself this morning, I wrote a list of things I love and things I hate,” the actor Zoë Chao said on a drizzly afternoon last month at the sumptuous Russian Tea Room, in Manhattan. As she talked, she plucked a miniature blini from a silver tower in the middle of our table.

headline: War Crimes Charges Against Putin
abstract: Reaction to an international court’s arrest warrant for the Russian leader. Also: Labor in Qatar; working in the office; family policy; public housing.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: DeSantis, Breaking Silence on Trump, Criticizes Manhattan Prosecutor
abstract: The Florida governor, who had refrained for days from weighing in on the potential indictment of his likely 2024 rival, accused the Manhattan district attorney of political motivations.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida on Monday broke his silence about the potential indictment of his state’s most famous resident, former President Donald J. Trump, attacking the Manhattan district attorney pursuing the case but also pointedly noting the personal conduct over which Mr. Trump is being investigated.

headline: Colon Cancer Is Rising Among Younger Adults. Here’s What to Know.
abstract: With cases projected to continue climbing through 2023, scientists are racing to understand why.
lead_paragraph: In a study published by the American Cancer Society in March, researchers estimated that in 2023, 153,000 people in the United States would be diagnosed with colorectal cancer. Of those cases, about 13 percent would be among people under 50 — representing a 9 percent increase in cases in this age group since 2020.

headline: Morgan Wallen Holds at No. 1 With Strong Streaming Numbers
abstract: “One Thing at a Time” had the second-biggest streaming total for a country album, after its debut last week. The nine-woman K-pop group Twice opens at No. 2.
lead_paragraph: After a big opening last week, the country star Morgan Wallen easily takes No. 1 again with his latest album, “One Thing at a Time,” holding off new releases from Miley Cyrus and the K-pop group Twice.

headline: Amazon Plans to Lay Off Another 9,000 Employees
abstract: The cuts follow a round of layoffs announced several months ago that affected more than 18,000 jobs.
lead_paragraph: Amazon plans to lay off 9,000 corporate and tech workers by the end of April, adding to the 18,000 roles it already cut late last year and this January, Andy Jassy, the company’s chief executive, said in a note to employees on Monday.

headline: Here Comes Carlos Alcaraz Again. Next Stop: Miami.
abstract: Alcaraz, who won the men’s singles title at Indian Wells, reclaims the world No. 1 ranking from Novak Djokovic. But can he keep it?
lead_paragraph: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — The sun was setting in the desert, and dark clouds were gathering, but Carlos Alcaraz was walking jauntily down a hallway in Stadium 1 at the BNP Paribas Open.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: When Cherry Blossom Heads Know It’s ‘Game Time’
abstract: The interactive maps that track the progress of cherry blossom buds each spring have attracted an enthusiastic fan base.
lead_paragraph: Weeks before the Brooklyn Botanic Garden updated CherryWatch, the online tracker that documents the progress of a majority of the garden’s 220 cherry blossom trees, staff members noticed that some people had already begun to check the website for the first signs of spring.

headline: A Behind-the-Mask Tour of a Generation of Pitchers
abstract: Stephen Vogt, Seattle’s new bullpen coach, caught 6,000 innings in pro ball and came away with keen insights on the colorful pitchers he worked with along the way.
lead_paragraph: TEMPE, Ariz. — When last we saw Crash Davis, the protagonist of Ron Shelton’s film “Bull Durham,” he had swatted one final homer and was on to his next life, considering a managerial opening in Visalia, Calif.

headline: The Ski Season That Just Won’t Quit
abstract: What do you do with 55 feet of snow? Across the country, record snowfall has resorts pushing back closing dates and skiers and snowboarders making plans into June.
lead_paragraph: It was snowing steadily when I arrived at Stowe Mountain Resort last Tuesday. I was surprised by the absence of lift lines as I walked onto the bright red gondola. I was even more surprised when I dropped into a favorite ski run and snow boiled up around my thighs and a cold spray of snow hit my face.

headline: Three Convicted in 2018 Murder of Rapper XXXTentacion
abstract: After more than 27 hours of deliberation, a Florida jury found three men guilty of killing the rising rapper during a robbery in the parking lot of a motorcycle shop.
lead_paragraph: Nearly five years after the killing of the rising rap star XXXTentacion, who was fatally shot in broad daylight during a 2018 robbery just as his polarizing career was exploding, a jury in Florida on Monday ended more than a week of deliberations when it found three men guilty of first-degree murder in the case.

headline: How to Fight Climate Change for a Bargain
abstract: A new study argues that ramping up renewable energy production would bring down costs more quickly.
lead_paragraph: Conventional economic wisdom says that it’s costly and inefficient to spend a lot of money fixing a problem before the necessary technology has matured. By that logic, the environmental pluses from quickly stopping climate change have to be weighed against the economic minus of higher costs.

headline: Review: A Contemporary Music Group’s Next Era Begins
abstract: George E. Lewis’s tenure with the International Contemporary Ensemble began with a tribute to the multitalented artist Douglas R. Ewart.
lead_paragraph: Some artists earn the “multi-hyphenate” label by doing two or three things. But Douglas R. Ewart works on a whole other level.

headline: What We Know About the Los Angeles Schools Strike
abstract: The nation’s second-largest school district canceled classes for a third straight day, while thousands of employees continued to press demands for higher wages.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Tens of thousands of Los Angeles school employees continued to strike on Thursday, forcing hundreds of campuses to remain closed and canceling classes for 422,000 students.

headline: House G.O.P., Defending Trump, Targets Bragg Ahead of Expected Indictment
abstract: Three Republican committee chairmen sought to use their investigative power to involve themselves in the Manhattan district attorney’s criminal inquiry into the former president.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — House Republicans rallied around former President Donald J. Trump on Monday ahead of his expected indictment by a Manhattan grand jury, using their investigative power to scrutinize active criminal inquiries targeting him as at least one other G.O.P. lawmaker endorsed his 2024 presidential campaign.

headline: DeCamp to End Commuter Bus Service to New York City From New Jersey
abstract: The bus line, which serves northern New Jersey, has struggled to retain ridership since the start of the pandemic. Its last day of service into the city will be April 7.
lead_paragraph: DeCamp Bus Lines, which serves riders in Passaic and Essex Counties in northern New Jersey, announced on Monday that it would end its commuter service to and from New York City on April 7.

headline: Obsidian Cliff: Humanity’s Tool Shed for the Last 11,500 Years
abstract: X-ray technology has allowed researchers a glimpse at the reaches of the Yellowstone landmark’s prized stone and its importance to Indigenous people.
lead_paragraph: YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK, Wyo. — Near the north entrance, an imposing mountain of black glass rises against the blue sky.

headline: Who’s Behind the Judicial Overhaul Now Dividing Israel? Two New Yorkers.
abstract: Kohelet, the once-obscure think tank that conceived and now champions a revamped court system, is an American import.
lead_paragraph: As part of a recent “national day of resistance,” a group of army reservists wearing masks converged at the Jerusalem office of a think tank and blocked its front door with sandbags and coils of barbed wire. Outside, protesters led a noisy rally on the street, waving dozens of placards and sharing a microphone for a series of furious speeches.

headline: Blinken Says Xi’s Visit to Moscow Offers ‘Diplomatic Cover’ for Putin’s War Crimes
abstract: The U.S. secretary of state said the Chinese leader’s visit indicated that Beijing felt “no responsibility” to hold Russia accountable for atrocities in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken on Monday said that the visit to Moscow by China’s president days after the International Criminal Court issued an arrest warrant for Russian President Vladimir V. Putin, amounts to Beijing providing “diplomatic cover for Russia to continue to commit” war crimes.

headline: Four Convicted of Obstruction on Jan. 6 in Final Oath Keepers Trial
abstract: The verdicts came after earlier trials in which other members of the far-right pro-Trump militia were convicted of seditious conspiracy for their roles in the Capitol attack.
lead_paragraph: Four people who marched with the Oath Keepers militia into the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, were convicted on Monday of conspiracy to obstruct the work of Congress, bringing an end to the third and final trial examining the role that members of the far-right group played in the attack.

headline: No Joke: Jeremy Scott Is Leaving Moschino
abstract: In a fashion world surprise, the designer is leaving the Italian label he has helmed for 10 years.
lead_paragraph: Fashion is about to get a little less funny. In yet another major industry surprise, Jeremy Scott is leaving his post as the creative director of Moschino, the brand’s parent company said in a statement on Monday. His departure ends a 10-year tenure that rejuvenated the brand by using it as a vehicle to poke fun at consumerism while simultaneously celebrating it in visual stunts tailor-made for the Instagram era. No successor has been named.

headline: The White House Authorizes $350 Million in Military Aid for Ukraine
abstract: The latest infusion of aid is aimed at giving Ukraine much needed ammunition ahead of a planned spring offensive.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration on Monday approved a new $350 million package of military aid for Ukraine, U.S. officials said, a critical injection as Ukraine grapples with ammunition shortages and gears up for a spring offensive.

headline: The Debate Over a Trump Indictment Won’t Wait Till He’s Charged
abstract: Republicans are condemning the possible indictment, and Democrats, generally, are treading carefully. Here’s what else is being said.
lead_paragraph: With the Manhattan district attorney expected to indict former President Donald J. Trump soon (though there is no clear public indication of when), Republicans and conservative news outlets have already dug in against the move, while Democrats push back tepidly.

headline: Biden Warns That Climate Change Could Upend Federal Spending Programs
abstract: A chapter in the new Economic Report of the President focuses on the growing risks to people and businesses from rising temperatures, and the government’s role in adapting to them.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration warned on Monday that a warming planet posed severe economic challenges for the United States, which would require the federal government to reassess its spending priorities and how it influenced behavior.

headline: Trump’s Call for Protests of Pending Arrest Splits G.O.P.
abstract: After Donald Trump urged supporters to protest his looming indictment, some Republicans have heeded the call, while many others have publicly lobbied against it.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s call over the weekend for his supporters to protest his expected indictment has divided his allies on the right, as some fear mass gatherings could devolve into violence and lead to the prosecution of his supporters just as the Jan. 6 riot at the Capitol did two years ago.

headline: Kelsea Ballerini Is Ready for Lift Off
abstract: The country singer and songwriter has long tested Nashville’s boundaries while revealing herself to her listeners. Touring behind a recent album and a surprise EP, she’s finding new heights.
lead_paragraph: Ever since Kelsea Ballerini saw Shania Twain soar into a theater on a flying motorcycle wearing a catsuit and closer-to-God hair, the rising country star has known she wanted to be a boundary-breaking daredevil. But, like Kelly Clarkson, she also wanted to be a bare-it-all open book — hitting the big notes and still cracking self-effacing jokes onstage in jeans and a T-shirt.

headline: Biden Issues First Veto to Protect Socially Conscious Investing
abstract: The veto came amid a flurry of other presidential signings that illustrated how Mr. Biden is again positioning himself as a centrist in an era of divided government ahead of an election year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden issued the first veto of his presidency on Monday, turning back a Republican effort to bar investment managers from incorporating climate and social considerations into their decisions.

headline: Philadelphia to Pay $9.25 Million to Settle Suit by George Floyd Protesters
abstract: The protesters said they sustained “physical and emotional injuries” in the response by city police to civil unrest after his murder in Minneapolis in 2020.
lead_paragraph: Philadelphia has agreed to pay $9.25 million to more than 300 people who said they were injured in the police response to racial justice protests that erupted after the murder of George Floyd in 2020, the city said on Monday.

headline: Catching Up With Hillary Clinton at “Bob Fosse’s Dancin’”
abstract: The former secretary of state celebrated the opening on Broadway and shared her thoughts on those drag show bans.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday night, Hillary Clinton, fresh from attending the opening night of “Bob Fosse’s Dancin’” on Broadway at the Music Box Theater, swept into the Rosevale Cocktail Room at the Civilian Hotel on West 48th Street.

headline: Rick Pitino Hired by St. John’s, Returning to His Big East Roots
abstract: Pitino reached the N.C.A.A. men’s tournament with Iona this season. He will take over at St. John’s after being ousted from Louisville in 2017.
lead_paragraph: Rick Pitino, the Hall of Fame coach who was fired from Louisville in 2017 after a string of scandals, has agreed to a six-year deal to become the new men’s basketball coach at St. John’s, the university said on Monday.

headline: Xi Condemns Killings in African Nation Where Russian and Chinese Interests Compete
abstract: Nine Chinese nationals were killed in the Central African Republic, where the Kremlin-aligned Wagner group controls a gold mine and Chinese companies have built their own operations.
lead_paragraph: Shortly before landing in Moscow on Monday, China’s leader, Xi Jinping, condemned the killing of nine Chinese nationals a day earlier at a gold mine in the Central African Republic, where tensions have flared between Chinese and Russian interests.

headline: BONUS: Hard Fork Live! Big Tech’s Arch Nemesis + Bot or Not?
abstract: Live from the South by Southwest festival in Austin, a conversation with the assistant attorney general Jonathan Kanter.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Kanter, who heads up the Justice Department’s antitrust division, believes that antitrust laws are critical for innovation — from ad tech to A.I. The assistant attorney general is bringing a new philosophy to enforcing those laws. So, how is his new approach to protecting competition playing out?

headline: Three Novels Where Love Takes Center Stage
abstract: Romance — nostalgic, obsessive or consuming — is at the heart of Madelaine Lucas’s “Thirst for Salt,” Keiran Goddard’s “Hourglass” and Alison Mills Newman’s “Francisco.”
lead_paragraph: Madelaine Lucas’s debut novel, THIRST FOR SALT (Tin House, 262 pp., paperback, $16.95), opens by describing a photograph that shows a man and a child. The narrator sees, for the first time, a picture of her former lover Jude with what she presumes to be his daughter. Confronting bad news about her fertility and nearing the same age Jude had been during their relationship, the unnamed protagonist is ripe for reminiscence, and the photograph sends her deep into the act of remembering.

headline: Countdown to Change in Women’s College Basketball: One Mississippi …
abstract: Eighth-seeded Ole Miss’s upset win over Stanford, a No. 1 seed, seemed to open the door to a new era of competitive parity in the women’s game.
lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif. — Wait, hold on a minute. Upsets like this aren’t supposed to happen, especially during the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament on the women’s side.

headline: Sri Lanka, Its Economy Reeling, Is Approved for $3 Billion Rescue Loan
abstract: The nation, having weathered negotiations with Japan, India and China, hopes the emergency funds from the International Monetary Fund will see it through its debt crisis.
lead_paragraph: The executive board of the International Monetary Fund approved a loan worth $3 billion to help Sri Lanka through the financial crisis that has had the nation in a rolling economic and political crisis for more than a year.

headline: A Newcomer in the Mushrooming Field of ‘Animal-Free’ Meats
abstract: Cutlets and “steaks” without the meat, a few Easter treats and more.
lead_paragraph: Meati, a self-described “animal-free” food company that makes its products almost entirely from mushrooms, has entered the crowded market for meat alternatives. They don’t use portobello caps and the like, but mycelium, the fungal threads in mushroom roots. With smidgens of oat fiber and chick pea flour, plus vegetable and fruit extracts for color, the Boulder, Colo., company has created white meat cutlets — with and without breading — that easily pass for boneless chicken breast. I’m no fan of faux anything, but the “chicken” is suitable for making Parm, dressed in sauce or diced for chicken salad. The “steak” rendition, a disk that’s ready to sear and comes pre-seasoned, is an adequate mimic but could benefit from the addition of some fat. The protein content is around 15 grams per serving, the fiber around eight. The products are used at several Momofuku restaurants: in New York at Noodle Bar as a crispy cutlet with hot honey and chili crunch, at Ssam Bar in pieces with gochujang glaze, and in Los Angeles at Majordomo in a larb salad.

headline: Peanut Butter Stirs an Old Debate: To the T.S.A., What’s a Liquid?
abstract: A podcaster’s complaint about surrendering his jar of Jif inspired sympathy and a wave of comments, and a bit of cheek from the T.S.A.
lead_paragraph: The Transportation Security Administration thought it had settled a dispute over peanut butter some time ago: unless it is 3.4 fluid ounces or less, it has to be checked.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing: Xi Meets Putin in Moscow
abstract: Also, a major U.N. climate report and a manhunt in the Indian state of Punjab.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir Putin welcomed Xi Jinping at the Kremlin yesterday and pledged that Russia would study China’s peace proposals for Ukraine “with respect.” But Xi did not mention Ukraine at all in his public remarks.

headline: Deadly Fungus Spread Rapidly During the Pandemic, C.D.C. Says
abstract: Candida auris, a drug-resistant fungus that health officials hoped to contain is now in more than half the 50 states, according to a new research paper.
lead_paragraph: A deadly fungus that is considered an urgent public health threat by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention spread at an “alarming rate” during the pandemic, the C.D.C. said on Monday.

headline: Woman, 29, Who Pretended to Be a High School Teen Pleads Not Guilty
abstract: Lawyers for Hyejeong Shin said she longed for the sense of safety she felt as a teenager at a Massachusetts boarding school.
lead_paragraph: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. — The mystery of the 29-year-old woman who pretended to be a teenager to enroll in a New Jersey high school seemed to capture the imagination of the country, drawing millions of viewers to news articles, TikTok and YouTube.

headline: Ryan McGinness Reimagines The ‘We ❤️ NYC’ Logo
abstract: A reimagining of the ‘We ♥️ NYC’ logo by the artist Ryan McGinness.
lead_paragraph: A reimagining of the ‘We ♥️ NYC’ logo by the artist Ryan McGinness.

headline: Trump Grand Jury Hears From Lawyer Who Assails Cohen’s Credibility
abstract: Robert J. Costello, a former legal adviser to Michael Cohen, said after testifying, “I told the grand jury that this guy couldn’t tell the truth if you put a gun to his head.”
lead_paragraph: In a last-ditch effort to stave off the indictment of Donald J. Trump, a witness on Monday appeared before a Manhattan grand jury at the request of the former president’s lawyers, providing testimony aimed at attacking the credibility of the prosecution’s star witness.

headline: U.S. Players Enjoy the ‘World Series’ Atmosphere at W.B.C.
abstract: Jeff McNeil of the Mets and other prominent players from the United States are sacrificing playing time in hopes of securing a title. They will face Japan in the W.B.C. final.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Jeff McNeil, a star second baseman and outfielder for the Mets, is an exceptional hitter with a standout ability to make contact. He won the 2022 National League batting title with a .326 average over 148 games. His average over his five major-league seasons is .307. Over the winter, the Mets rewarded the 30-year-old McNeil with a four-year, $50 million contract extension.

headline: Stuart Hodes, Who Danced With Martha Graham, Is Dead at 98
abstract: Devoting his long life to dance, he was also a choreographer, an educator and an author, and was still onstage in his 90s.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Hodes, who danced with Martha Graham in the 1940s and ’50s and who for the rest of his life served the field of dance as a performer, choreographer, educator, administrator and author, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 98.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Macron’s Government Survives but Faces Wrath of France Over Pension Overhaul
abstract: Two no-confidence votes failed to oust the cabinet of President Emmanuel Macron over a new law raising the retirement age to 64 from 62.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French National Assembly rejected a no-confidence motion against the government of President Emmanuel Macron on Monday, ensuring that a fiercely contested bill raising the retirement age to 64 from 62 becomes the law of the land.

headline: Tracking the Chinese Balloon From Space
abstract: A new analysis of satellite imagery traces the path of the Chinese balloon from its launch in China to the United States.
lead_paragraph: A new analysis of satellite imagery traces the path of the Chinese balloon from its launch in China to the United States.

headline: Putin and Xi Celebrate Ties Unbroken by Russia’s War in Ukraine
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin welcomed Xi Jinping, China’s top leader, to Russia, briefly noting Beijing’s peace plan for Ukraine but stressing Moscow and Beijing’s enduring partnership.
lead_paragraph: Standing side by side in a show of partnership unshaken by Russia’s yearlong war in Ukraine, President Vladimir V. Putin and China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, began talks in Moscow on Monday with boasts of their close ties and only understated mention of the conflict itself.

headline: The prosecutor in the Trump case waded into treacherous political waters.
abstract: Alvin L. Bragg, the Manhattan district attorney, has indicted former President Donald J. Trump. The political firestorm has already begun.
lead_paragraph: Alvin L. Bragg, the Manhattan district attorney, has insisted that he does not pay attention to politics when deciding whether to charge someone with a crime.

headline: An explosion in Crimea destroyed Russian cruise missiles, Ukrainian officials say.
abstract: Kremlin-appointed authorities in Crimea denied the claim saying that all the drones had been “aimed at civilian objects.”
lead_paragraph: An explosion hit the town of Dzhankoi in Russian-occupied Crimea on Monday, and Ukraine’s Defense Ministry said the blast had destroyed Russian Kalibr cruise missiles that were being transported by rail.

headline: Bush Doesn’t Second-Guess Himself on Iraq. Even if Everyone Else Does.
abstract: George W. Bush has told advisers that the world is better off without Saddam Hussein — and he has not changed his mind about that.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Twenty years later, veterans are reflecting on their service and remembering fallen comrades. Iraqis are talking about how their country has changed and how it has not. American lawmakers are debating whether to finally repeal the legislation authorizing the invasion.

headline: Inside the 3 Months That Could Cost Fox $1.6 Billion
abstract: The decision by Fox News executives in November 2020 to treat the more hard-right Newsmax as a mortal threat spawned a possibly more serious danger.
lead_paragraph: Since 2002, when Fox News first overtook CNN as the most-watched cable news channel, one thing has been as certain and predictable as its dominance: Every time a Democrat wins the White House, the right-leaning network’s ratings take a momentary dip.

headline: Savory and Sweet Ramadan Recipes to Break the Fast
abstract: These dishes from Somalia are ideal before sunrise and after sundown.
lead_paragraph: Ramadan is a time to examine oneself and be in community with others. It also centers on food, yet calls for fasting from sunrise until sundown. During this holy month for Muslims, families and friends worldwide gather before light and after dark to share sustaining meals.

headline: ‘Drinking in America’ Review: Men in a Cracked Mirror
abstract: After 15 years away from the stage, Andre Royo of ‘The Wire’ goes all in with an evening of Eric Bogosian monologues at the Minetta Lane Theater.
lead_paragraph: Andre Royo practically glows with pleasure as he walks onstage at the Minetta Lane Theater in Greenwich Village. That’s the first surprise at “Drinking in America,” an evening of Eric Bogosian monologues peopled with misfits, screwups and creeps.

headline: Teen Driver in Crash That Killed 5 Didn’t Have License, Officials Say
abstract: Malik Smith, 16, may have been distracted or asleep when the rented vehicle he was driving veered off a New York parkway, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A 16-year-old driving a car that crashed on a New York highway, killing him and four young passengers, did not have a driver’s license or learner’s permit and may have been distracted or asleep when he drove off the road, officials said on Monday.

headline: For the G.O.P., a Looming Trump Indictment Takes Center Stage
abstract: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida spoke on Monday about Donald Trump’s expected indictment, as Republicans weighed whether to heed the former president’s call to protest.
lead_paragraph: Republicans on Monday braced for the impact of the impending indictment of former President Donald J. Trump, with his allies on Capitol Hill flexing their investigative powers to target the prosecutor pursuing Mr. Trump while the leading rival for the 2024 G.O.P. presidential nomination, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, took his first swipe at Mr. Trump’s personal conduct.

headline: 2 Charged With Murdering Dog Breeder and Taking His French Bulldog
abstract: Lonnie A. Ray, 76, of South Carolina, was shot and killed last month at a site where he had arranged to sell a dog. The authorities expect more arrests.
lead_paragraph: Two South Carolina men have been charged with murdering a dog breeder last month and stealing a French bulldog that he had arranged to sell to them, the authorities said Monday.

headline: Fox Producer Says She Was Set Up in Dominion Case
abstract: The producer, Abby Grossberg, said in a pair of lawsuits that the effort to place blame on her and Maria Bartiromo, the Fox Business host, was rooted in rampant misogyny and discrimination at the company.
lead_paragraph: A Fox News producer who has worked with the hosts Maria Bartiromo and Tucker Carlson filed lawsuits against the company in New York and Delaware on Monday, accusing Fox lawyers of coercing her into giving misleading testimony in the continuing legal battle around the network’s coverage of unfounded claims about election fraud.

headline: Something to Reflect on
abstract: Michael Lieberman’s puzzle asks you to repeat yourself.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: ‘Perry Mason’ Season 2, Episode 3 Recap: ‘King Kong’ Ding-Dong
abstract: Perry tries to be a better dad. Della tries a Turkish cigarette. Paul runs an interesting and inconvenient ballistics experiment.
lead_paragraph: Della Street has Perry Mason’s number. She has just learned of the suicide of their former client Emily Dodson, by way of a stack of desperate postcards and letters Perry that dumps on Della after keeping them secret for months. She realizes that this is the reason they switched to civil cases from criminal law — a major career shift, the rationale for which she ought to have been told.

headline: Where High Interest Rates Have Sent Home Prices Sliding
abstract: In Sweden, the central bank’s fight against inflation is crimping economic growth and has contributed to a 15 percent drop in home prices.
lead_paragraph: When Madeleine Eiswohld decided to move in with her boyfriend last year, she never expected to find it so difficult to sell her apartment. It’s a cozy studio, with lots of natural light, in Huddinge, an increasingly desirable suburb of Stockholm.

headline: Who’s Using Facial Recognition Technology?
abstract: Madison Square Garden Entertainment is employing the technology against lawyers who have sued the company. Not many other businesses nearby seem to be using it.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Facial recognition technology is increasingly being used to scan customers entering stores or, in the case of Madison Square Garden Entertainment, to scan ticket holders for basketball or hockey games or shows. We’ll look at where this is happening in New York City.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Xi Jinping’s visit to Moscow.
lead_paragraph: Vladimir Putin, the Russian president, and China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, began talks in Moscow yesterday with boasts of their close ties and only understated mention of the conflict in Ukraine. The leaders went to great lengths to flatter each other and project unity in a series of meticulously choreographed events.

headline: ‘Listen to Us.’ What These 12 Kids Want Adults to Know.
abstract: The group discusses social media, the return to in-person schooling and their hopes and fears for the future.
