lead_paragraph: The group discusses social media, the return to in-person schooling and their hopes and fears for the future.

headline: Quotation of the Day: World Has Less Than a Decade to Stop Catastrophic Warming, U.N. Panel Says
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, March 21, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “The pace and scale of what has been done so far and current plans are insufficient to tackle climate change. We are walking when we should be sprinting.”

headline: Corrections: March 21, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, March 21, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about expert advisers to the Food and Drug Administration endorsing Paxlovid as a Covid treatment misstated the reason that European Union regulators recommended against approval of molnupiravir. They were concerned about its lack of efficacy, not about its safety.

headline: Word of the Day: embodiment
abstract: This word has appeared in 177 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word embodiment has appeared in 177 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 2 in “In Big Sur, Living With Nature’s Beauty but Trapped by Its Fury” by Victoria Kim:

headline: Jimmy Kimmel Celebrates ‘the Calm Before the Stormy’
abstract: Kimmel joked that indictments were “in the air” after former President Donald Trump said he expected to be arrested on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Japan’s Prime Minister Becomes Latest G7 Leader to Visit Ukraine
abstract: Fumio Kishida, who has been seeking a more active role for his country in international affairs, made an unannounced trip to meet with Ukraine’s president.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Fumio Kishida of Japan arrived in Kyiv on Tuesday to meet with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, becoming the latest leader of the Group of 7 nations to travel to the country as he seeks a more active role for Japan in international affairs.

headline: Spring Books
abstract: What are you reading for fun right now?
lead_paragraph: Do you like to read in your spare time? Do you prefer fiction or nonfiction? What kinds of stories do you like best? Is there something you’ve read recently that you’d recommend to others your age?

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: A Music Newsletter Offers an ‘Alternative to the Algorithm’
abstract: Lindsay Zoladz, a pop music critic for The Times, cuts through the noise with The Amplifier, a newsletter that harks back to the days of mixtapes.
lead_paragraph: “What should I listen to?”

headline: ‘We Were Helpless’: Despair at the C.D.C. as the Pandemic Erupted
abstract: Current and former employees recall rising desperation as Trump administration officials squelched research into the new coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: In early March 2020, as the nation succumbed to a pandemic, a group of young scientists walked out of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta. They left quietly, one or two at a time, through the building’s front doors, flashing their badges at guards, instead of through side exits where their departures would be recorded.

headline: Comer, Republicans’ Investigative Chief, Embraces Role of Biden Antagonist
abstract: The fourth-term Kentuckian and chairman of the House Oversight and Accountability Committee has become an aggressive promoter of sinister-sounding claims about the president and his family.
lead_paragraph: DANVILLE, Ky. — Steering his S.U.V. through pounding rain on his way to the state capital on a recent Thursday, Representative James R. Comer, the chairman of the Oversight and Accountability Committee, reflected on the pressure he often faced from constituents to investigate unhinged claims about President Biden and Democrats.

headline: Damning Report Finds London Police Force Is Sexist and Racist
abstract: The report, ordered up after the murder of Sarah Everard by a London police officer in 2021, denounced the culture within Britain’s largest police force and called for change.
lead_paragraph: London’s police force is institutionally sexist, misogynistic, racist and homophobic, according to an independent report released on Tuesday, the strongest condemnation yet of a department plagued by systemic problems and a severe erosion of public trust.

headline: In This Story, George W. Bush Is The Hero
abstract: Twenty years ago, Bush did something amazing. Hint: It wasn’t the Iraq war.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago, Bush did something amazing. Hint: It wasn’t the Iraq war.

headline: Why Look at Planes?
abstract: At Los Angeles International Airport, plane spotters gather to watch the sky.
lead_paragraph: At Los Angeles International Airport, plane spotters gather to watch the sky.

headline: Break the Chain Between Russian Oligarchs and Managers, and You Break Everything
abstract: Impose sanctions on the wealth managers who create these complex offshore shell games.
lead_paragraph: Russian oligarchs were hit with sanctions last year in an effort to cut off Vladimir Putin’s overseas lieutenants from their vast offshore wealth — an estimated 60 percent of their net worth. Mega-yachts, private jets and luxury villas were seized, sometimes with news cameras rolling. Yet for all that drama, much of the oligarchs’ money was quietly moved to safer havens.

headline: What Role Does Your Family’s Native Tongue Play in Your Life?
abstract: A guest writer says that immigrants, and the many languages they bring, enrich American English. What do you think?
lead_paragraph: Do you speak any languages besides English at home? Did your parents, grandparents or great-grandparents when they were growing up? Do you or anyone else in your family have what might be considered an accent?

headline: A.I. Is About to Get Much Weirder. Here’s What to Watch For.
abstract: The Vox writer Kelsey Piper talks about the increasing pace of A.I. development, how it’s changing the world and what to do about it.
lead_paragraph: OpenAI last week released its most powerful language model yet: GPT-4, which vastly outperforms its predecessor GPT-3.5 on a variety of tasks.

headline: These Police Chiefs Are Working to Change Perceptions
abstract: In “Walk the Walk,” Neil Gross profiles three departments around the country experimenting with genuine reform.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to policing, this is no country for optimists: Few Americans seem to believe in the promise of reform.

headline: In This Story, George W. Bush Is the Hero
abstract: Twenty years ago, Bush did something amazing. Hint: It wasn’t the Iraq war.
lead_paragraph: When President George W. Bush invaded Iraq 20 years ago this week, I was in the middle of the smoke and chaos of that cataclysmic war that became his best-known legacy. I wrote countless columns opposing an invasion, then I was scathing as I covered the war, and I still see it as a practical and moral catastrophe.

headline: A Rough Guide of the Electoral Fallout if Trump Is Indicted
abstract: It would be uncharted territory, but the F.B.I. search of Mar-a-Lago offers at least some precedent.
lead_paragraph: A lot of people believe I make political predictions, but that’s not really true. Instead, I try to marshal history, data, polling, reporting and more to help make sense of the political landscape. It usually amounts to one of those old, yellowish, distorted maps from the age of exploration. It offers only a rough guide of what lies ahead.

headline: Matthew Macfadyen Has Mixed Feelings About the End of ‘Succession’
abstract: “It’s sort of awful and heartbreaking, but at the same time, there’s a slight relief,” said the actor, whose unbearably awkward Tom has gone from punching bag to power player.
lead_paragraph: Could there be a more excruciatingly awkward TV character than Tom Wambsgans in “Succession”? Played with understated comic glee by the British actor Matthew Macfadyen, Tom manages to simultaneously exist on all points of the show’s power spectrum: bullied, bullying and wafting helplessly in between.

headline: ‘The Circus Continues’: For Trump, Legal Woes Resurrect Old Habits
abstract: The former president strengthened his political position in recent weeks, but an impetuous response to his potential indictment could alienate voters he will need to win back the White House.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump, the former prime-time reality TV star known for his love of big stages and vast crowds, has embraced a more humbling and traditional style on the campaign trail in recent months.

headline: Make No Mistake, the Investigation of Donald Trump and the Stormy Daniels Scheme Is Serious
abstract: Trump’s former job does not, and should not, immunize him from the accountability that would be sought for anyone else.
lead_paragraph: Though it may be tempting to do so, it is a mistake to assess the Manhattan district attorney’s investigation of Donald Trump by comparing its relative severity with those of myriad other crimes possibly committed by him. That is not how state and federal prosecutors will — or should — be thinking about the issue of charging Mr. Trump or, for that matter, any other defendant.

headline: These New Yorkers Don’t ❤️ the ‘We ❤️NYC’ Logo
abstract: Promoters said the campaign, which draws on a successful tourism slogan from the 1970s, was aimed at cutting through pandemic-era negativity. So far, it’s getting rough reviews.
lead_paragraph: “It’s bad!” one person wrote.

headline: A Time-Travel Novel Whose Thrills Go Beyond the Speculative
abstract: In Jinwoo Chong’s debut novel, “Flux,” a time-warping discovery impacts the lives of three people coping with personal and systemic traumas.
lead_paragraph: Given the plethora of recent cultural productions that center extreme ontological uncertainty (think of TV series like “Westworld,” “Russian Doll” and “Peripheral”), it’s a pleasure to encounter a work like Jinwoo Chong’s debut novel, “Flux,” that offers a healthy dose of brain-bending pleasure without making it the whole point. Chong (who is a sales planner for The New York Times) strikes the balance by attending as much, or more, to his central characters and to the textures of the world around them as he does to his dizzy-making tech. “Flux” happily offers a moving appraisal of lives buffeted by personal and systemic traumas; a deep dive into the good, the bad and the ugly of self-serving corporate culture; and no shortage of “wait, what the heck just happened?” thrills.

headline: A Family Tree as Racially Mixed as the America It Sprang From
abstract: In “Benjamin Banneker and Us,” Rachel Jamison Webster uncovers Black ancestors she never knew about, and with the help of far-flung relatives assembles her family’s story.
lead_paragraph: In 1753, Benjamin Banneker, a free Black farmer in Baltimore County, Md., carved a clock almost entirely out of wood. According to most sources, he based his design on a pocket watch he had borrowed from a family friend and disassembled; he had never seen a larger clock up close. Decades later, after Banneker had become famous for his best-selling almanacs, visitors reported the clock still hung in his family’s cabin, faithfully striking the hour.

headline: The Robots Can’t Take Taxi-Whistling Away From Me
abstract: A relic of a pleasure in the face of relentless modernity.
lead_paragraph: When I was a kid, I spent my summers at a sleep-away camp in the Berkshires. The activities on offer included baseball, basketball, football, soccer, tennis, swimming, sailing, fishing, water polo, archery, arts and crafts (my 92-year-old mother still has a faux-opal necklace I made for her), photo lab (I took a lot of bad pictures of elm trees) and electronics shop (I have Proustian memories of the smell of solder: gross yet intoxicating!). We staged plays with our sister camp, sang corny songs around campfires and competed in color wars.

headline: At House Republican Retreat, the Focus, Once Again, Is on Trump
abstract: For the third year since he left office, former President Donald J. Trump continued to dominate an annual G.O.P. gathering in Florida, underscoring his grip on the party.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Speaker Kevin McCarthy arrived at an upscale resort here this week eager to use a Republican retreat to promote the party’s policy agenda and achievements so far, working to paper over the divisions that nearly sank his bid for his job and talk about anything but former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: The Problem With Celebrity Travel Shows? The Celebrities.
abstract: What used to be meaningfully informative programming, delivered by personable but only tangentially notable hosts, is gradually being swallowed up.
lead_paragraph: In the resplendent green of Costa Rica, a peak reaches toward the clouds. Eugene Levy gazes up at it in awe. “That’s a volcano,” his host explains, adding that it last erupted about 10 years ago. Levy looks unsettled. “I was hoping it would be more dormant,” he says. The understated delivery is classic Levy, but it feels different, less endearing, in this context. The premise of Apple TV+’s “The Reluctant Traveler” is that the celebrity actor hasn’t liked to travel in the past, but is now pushing himself out of his comfort zone with televised trips to places like Finland, Italy and Japan. With that, he joins an increasingly established subgenre: the celebrity travel show. Netflix has “Down to Earth With Zac Efron.” TBS had Conan O’Brien’s “Conan Without Borders.” CNN had “Stanley Tucci: Searching for Italy,” which was both a celebrity travel show and a celebrity food show — another thriving subgenre, with entries from Selena Gomez, Amy Schumer, Jon Favreau and Paris Hilton.

headline: One Man’s Foray Into the Heartland of the Far Right
abstract: Alarmed by the country’s political divisions, Jeff Sharlet embarked on an anguished quest to understand the rise of antidemocratic extremism. In “The Undertow,” he documents his findings.
lead_paragraph: The premise of “The Undertow,” Jeff Sharlet’s anguished new book of reportage, is that the United States is “coming apart.” The disintegration is political. It involves the rise of the autocratically inclined Donald Trump; the attempt by members of the Republican Party to overthrow the election of Joe Biden in January 2021; and, during the Biden presidency, the overturning by the Supreme Court of Roe v Wade.

headline: Biden Creates Two National Monuments in the Southwest
abstract: The Spirit Mountain area in Nevada and Castner Range in Texas will be off limits to development.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Tuesday designated two new national monuments in the Southwest, insulating from development a half-million acres in Nevada that are revered by Native Americans and 6,600 acres in Texas that were once admired by the writer Jack Kerouac.

headline: Why Are These Italians Massacring Each Other With Oranges?
abstract: Every winter, Ivrea erupts into a ferocious three-day festival where its citizens pelt one another with 900 tons of oranges. (Yes, oranges.)
lead_paragraph: It looked as if a war was coming. It was. One Sunday last month, in a northern Italian town called Ivrea, the facades of historic buildings were covered with plastic sheeting and nets. Storefront windows had been fortified with plywood and tarps. And in several different piazzas, hundreds of wooden crates had appeared, walls of them stacked eight feet high and even farther across. The crates looked like barricades but were actually arms depots. Inside them were oranges. Oranges, the fruit.

headline: Unlikely Allies, They Spread the Gospel of Tree-Hugging
abstract: In “Guardians of the Valley,” Dean King chronicles the friendship between the naturalist John Muir and the journalist Robert Underwood Johnson.
lead_paragraph: It’s a brave thing, to write about John Muir.

headline: Even the Supreme Court Can’t Save the N.C.A.A. From Itself
abstract: A Supreme Court ruling paved the way for college athletes to earn financial payments. But a governing body’s neglect means the players are still powerless pawns.
lead_paragraph: The N.C.A.A. is the easiest target in sports, and that’s entirely its own fault. Decades of defending a system premised on the unpaid labor of its athletes — a system that Walter Byers, one of its architects, later regretfully compared to a “neo-plantation” — has whittled the N.C.A.A.’s credibility to near nonexistence.

headline: In T’s Spring Design Issue, Three Maximalist Homes Filled With Collections
abstract: It’s the objects in each of these spaces — as well as those in her own, T’s editor in chief writes — that bring the place to life.
lead_paragraph: By the time I turned 17, my family had moved nine times. Every few years, our possessions would be packed into moving vans or U-Hauls and driven cross-country — south to north, east to west — or loaded onto a boat for Hawaii, where we returned again and again.

headline: Trump Could Stand in the Middle of Fifth Avenue and Not Lose Mike Pence
abstract: Pence is still afraid of the former president, and he is not alone.
lead_paragraph: Mike Pence wants to have it both ways.

headline: Strains Emerge Inside the Union That Beat Amazon
abstract: Nearly a year after its victory on Staten Island, the Amazon Labor Union is grappling with election losses and internal conflict.
lead_paragraph: One year after its surprise victory at a Staten Island warehouse, the only union in the country representing Amazon workers has endured a series of setbacks and conflicts that have caused longtime supporters to question if it will survive.

headline: Following a Folk Tale Through the Himalayas
abstract: On a trip through northern India, a writer was guided by the age-old epic story of “Rajula Malushahi,” which led him to a series of unexpected places.
lead_paragraph: In a high hamlet, a two-hour trek up a verdant slope beneath ice-clad Himalayan peaks, an argument erupted over a folk tale. Two brothers, Pralad Singh Dariyal, 60, and Hira Singh Dariyal, 77, heatedly debated which nearby village in the Johar Valley was once the home of the story’s heroine. Eventually agreeing on a few possible locations, Hira said that the story, which is sung as a ballad and which he remembered from childhood, was virtually unknown today among the area’s young people. “They’re the YouTube generation,” he explained with a shrug.

headline: As War in Ukraine Grinds On, China Helps Refill Russian Drone Supplies
abstract: China has shipped more than $12 million in drones to Russia since it invaded Ukraine, in an indication of quiet collaboration between the two.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration vowed last month to crack down on companies that sell critical technologies to Russia as part of its efforts to curtail the country’s war against Ukraine. But the continued flow of Chinese drones to the country explains why that will be hard.

headline: In Seattle, a Grocery Store Becomes a Live-Work Space
abstract: When two artists bought the vacant building, it was ‘grim and creepy.’ Now it’s not only a home — it’s a communal arts space.
lead_paragraph: When two artists bought the vacant building, it was ‘grim and creepy.’ Now it’s not only a home — it’s a communal arts space.

headline: What’s It Like to Live in a Grocery Store? Surprisingly Comfortable.
abstract: When two artists bought the vacant building, it was ‘grim and creepy.’ Now it’s not only a home — it’s a communal arts space.
lead_paragraph: A few years after Demi Raven and Janet Galore were introduced by a mutual friend and fell in love, they started looking for a home where they could live together. But for artists with careers in technology, it was clear that a cookie-cutter house would not suffice.

headline: Ferraris and Hungry Children: Venezuela’s Socialist Vision in Shambles
abstract: After years of extreme scarcity, some Venezuelans lead lives of luxury as others scrape by. The nation of grinding hardship has increasingly become one of haves and have-nots.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — In the capital, a store sells Prada purses and a 110-inch television for $115,000. Not far away, a Ferrari dealership has opened, while a new restaurant allows well-off diners to enjoy a meal seated atop a giant crane overlooking the city.

headline: An Italian Villa That Houses 30,000 Beetles and a Flock of Porcelain Birds
abstract: Giorgio Taroni’s home overlooking Lake Como has become a cabinet of curiosities, filled with collections of oil paintings, books, ancient coins and vintage postcards.
lead_paragraph: FOR MANY PEOPLE, the mention of Lake Como, an hour’s drive north of Milan at the foot of the Alps, conjures sun-bleached summer vacations and hotels with striped canvas umbrellas. The palatial villas that stand on the shore, perfect in their icy elegance and glimpsed, perhaps, on a boat tour of the area’s towns, can seem like part of a stage set erected to enhance a visitor’s experience.

headline: America Already Loves Spritzes. Now It Just Needs Its Own Aperol.
abstract: Producers across the United States are working to create a uniquely American aperitif and digestif tradition using local ingredients and less sugar.
lead_paragraph: Depending on region and personal preference, you might order a vermouth on the rocks in Barcelona before lunch or amaro neat in Sicily after dessert. Aperitifs and digestifs — alcoholic drinks traditionally served before and after a meal — are rituals inextricably woven into the social fabric of many countries.

headline: China, Russia and the Risk of a New Cold War
abstract: Xi Jinping, China’s leader, is visiting Moscow. It may not simply be a mission of peace.
lead_paragraph: As Xi Jinping, China’s leader, meets with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Moscow this week, Chinese officials have been presenting his trip as a mission of peace. But American and European officials are watching for something else altogether — whether Mr. Xi will add fuel to the full-scale war that Mr. Putin began more than a year ago.

headline: Fanatics Adds N.H.L. Player Jerseys to Its Growing Pro Sports Roster
abstract: The sporting apparel company will replace Adidas, which last year said it would not extend its contract as the league’s uniform supplier beyond the 2023-24 season.
lead_paragraph: Fanatics, the world’s leading licensed sporting apparel supplier, will begin making and designing jerseys for N.H.L. players starting in the 2024-25 season, the latest expansion of its growing uniform business.

headline: Jam or Cream First? Notes From One Woman’s Decade of Eating Scones.
abstract: A Londoner spent 10 years sampling scones at hundreds of historic sites across the U.K. Here’s why her story made headlines — and which essential topping she says should come before the other.
lead_paragraph: When Sarah Merker sat down one day in 2013 to snack on a scone at one of Britain’s many, many historic sites, she had no idea that she was embarking upon a quest that would take her a decade to complete and transform her into a kind of national celebrity.

headline: A Translation Problem
abstract: A small change to climate science could make a big difference for Americans.
lead_paragraph: The world’s top scientists released their latest report yesterday warning that the Earth is on pace for severe damage from climate change. But many Americans might have a hard time understanding the report because the analysis, like those before it, talks about temperatures exclusively in Celsius.

headline: U.S. Is Ready to Protect Smaller Banks if Necessary, Yellen Says
abstract: The Treasury secretary pledged that the Biden administration would take additional steps as needed to support the banking system.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen expressed confidence in the nation’s banks on Tuesday but said she was prepared to take additional action to safeguard smaller financial institutions as the Biden administration and federal regulators worked to contain fallout from fears over the stability of the banking system.

headline: With Japan-U.S. Final at the W.B.C., the World Has Already Won
abstract: A dramatic semifinal set up a World Baseball Classic final for the ages: Shohei Ohtani and Japan against Mike Trout and the United States.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The games in this World Baseball Classic, collectively, have been like the very best postseason series, with the mayhem unspooling so fast that you cannot possibly keep it all together. It is a grand mosaic, each little piece its own story, all of them essential to the whole.

headline: The Surgeon General’s New Mission: Adolescent Mental Health
abstract: In an interview with The Times, Dr. Vivek Murthy ascribed the mental health challenges among young people in part to “hustle culture” values.
lead_paragraph: In December 2021, Surgeon General Vivek Murthy issued a rare warning: Mental health challenges were leading to “devastating effects” among young people. His statement came as the suicide rate for young Americans ages 10 to 19 jumped by 40 percent from 2001 to 2019, while emergency room visits for self-harm rose by 88 percent.

headline: Thinking Made Visible: The Winners of Our One-Pager Contest
abstract: We challenged teenagers to respond to the Times piece of their choice by creating an illustrated guide to what they gleaned. Here are our favorites.
lead_paragraph: Back in December, we invited teenagers around the world to respond to any recent Times article, video, podcast, graph or photo essay by creating an illustrated one-pager.  (If you’re unfamiliar with the format, a one-pager is an “image-heavy, idea-driven assessment which prompts students to select the most meaningful ideas in a text, make connections to their own lives, and display the ideas creatively with color, drawings, and quotes.”)

headline: Macron Presses Ahead After Bitter Victory in Pensions Dispute
abstract: The future of President Emmanuel Macron’s second term was unclear after a no-confidence vote triggered by his effort to raise France’s retirement age fell short by only nine votes.
lead_paragraph: President Emmanuel Macron vowed to stay the course on Tuesday after his government barely survived a no-confidence vote in Parliament that ensured the passage of his unpopular pension overhaul but did little to quell the swirling political uncertainty about the future of his second term.

headline: The Real Story of ‘Cocaine Bear’
Our Best Spring Recipes
Recipes for Observing Ramadan
In ‘You’ Season 4, Joe Goldberg Is No Longer in Control
The Colorado River Is Shrinking: What to Know
What is Pickleball?
Who Is Jennifer Lawrence Now?
Markets Extend Gains as Focus Turns to Fed Meeting
abstract: Relief over recent financial rescue measures pushed stocks up for a second day, as investors prepared for a pivotal decision from the Federal Reserve on interest rates.
lead_paragraph: Stocks rose for a second day on Tuesday, with shares of regional lenders sharply higher, as investors awaited a decision from the Federal Reserve on whether it will hold off on further interest rate increases that have already shaken the financial system.

headline: The Fed’s Dilemma: Raise Rates During a Banking Crisis?
abstract: The central bank’s decision on interest rates on Wednesday is shaping up to be the most consequential of the Jerome Powell era.
lead_paragraph: The failures of Silicon Valley Bank and three other lenders over the past 11 days has put the Fed in a difficult position as it prepares to deliver on Wednesday one of the most consequential decisions on interest rates of the Jay Powell era.

headline: Saudi Arabia Releases U.S. Dual Citizen Jailed in Crackdown on Dissent
abstract: Saad Almadi, 72, a Florida resident, was one of several Americans and hundreds of Saudis caught up in the crackdown under Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman. He still cannot fly home, his son said.
lead_paragraph: A Saudi-American dual citizen who spent more than a year in a Saudi prison over Twitter posts critical of the kingdom’s government was released from detention on Tuesday, but will not be able to leave the country, according to his son.

headline: We’re Adding New Songs to Our California Soundtrack
abstract: The playlist includes 20 new tracks recommended by readers.
lead_paragraph: Joni Mitchell’s classic tune in which she warbles, “California, I’m coming home.” Or Otis Redding’s hit song inspired by the rolling tides of the San Francisco Bay, as seen from a houseboat in Sausalito. Or Tupac Shakur’s ode to the West Coast, the quintessential “California Love.”

headline: Designing Their Own Studios to Meet Demand for Content
abstract: Businesses are spending hundreds of thousands of dollars to add in-house production and broadcast facilities to their offices.
lead_paragraph: Ann Duskus and Vicky Vuong, sneaker artists in San Francisco, met on Instagram early in the pandemic, a time when Ms. Duskus was giving Zoom classes on topics like how to take apart a Nike Air Force 1 basketball shoe and Ms. Vuong was gaining a following for embellishing footwear with paint, embroidery and fake pearls.

headline: Video Shows Virginia Man’s Death in Custody
abstract: Irvo Otieno’s death was a devastating ending to a journey that began when his family immigrated from Kenya when he was a young boy, “compelled by the American dream.”
lead_paragraph: HENRICO, Va. — Surveillance video from a state psychiatric hospital in Virginia shows a group of sheriff’s deputies and medical staff members piling on a handcuffed man, Irvo Otieno, and pinning him on the floor for around 11 minutes, until his death on March 6.

headline: Los Angeles Schools Shut Down After Workers Launch Three-Day Strike
abstract: The work stoppage began early Tuesday morning with a picket line at a district bus yard.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As rain pummeled the sidewalks and wind bent back umbrellas on Tuesday morning, Bartui Merchain, a pool clerk, arrived at her job at a recreation center, her children in tow.

headline: Rare Tornadoes Touch Down in Southern California
abstract: At least five people were killed by falling trees as a new round of storms swept the state.
lead_paragraph: At least five people were killed and several others were injured by falling trees in California, where heavy rain and snow have repeatedly walloped weather-fatigued residents, officials said.

headline: Google Releases Bard, Its Competitor in the Race to Create A.I. Chatbots
abstract: The internet giant will grant users access to a chatbot after years of cautious development, chasing splashy debuts from rivals OpenAI and Microsoft.
lead_paragraph: For more than three months, Google executives have watched as projects at Microsoft and a San Francisco start-up called OpenAI have stoked the public’s imagination with the potential for artificial intelligence.

headline: What Is a Song That Explains You?
abstract: We’re asking readers for the music that defines them.
lead_paragraph: In a time when people have millions of songs at their fingertips, The Amplifier, a new newsletter from The New York Times, aims to cut through the noise with a must-listen playlist.

headline: Danny and Lucy DeVito Head to Broadway With Roundabout Theater Company’s New Season
abstract: The actors will play a father and daughter in “I Need That,” a comedy written by Theresa Rebeck.
lead_paragraph: Danny DeVito and his daughter, Lucy, will co-star in a new Theresa Rebeck play on Broadway this fall, presented by the nonprofit Roundabout Theater Company, which announced its 2023-2024 season on Tuesday.

headline: The Philharmonic’s New Season: What We Want to Hear
abstract: Jaap van Zweden’s final season as the New York Philharmonic’s music director will feature belated debuts and premieres, and a grand farewell.
lead_paragraph: In his final season as music director of the New York Philharmonic, Jaap van Zweden will lead a host of premieres, performances of Mozart’s Requiem and Mahler’s Second Symphony, and a residency in China, the orchestra announced on Tuesday.

headline: Yes, They Are Tall. No, They Do Not Play Basketball.
abstract: For the vertically gifted, every day of the year means standing out. But March can be particularly maddening.
lead_paragraph: Dave Rasmussen has learned to deal with the small inconveniences that life lobs at him.

headline: Justice Dept. Embraces Supporting Role in Pursuing War Crimes in Ukraine
abstract: Prosecutors are investigating war crimes against Americans but are mainly focused on helping Ukraine to hold Russians accountable for atrocities.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Merrick B. Garland makes a point of refusing to discuss active investigations, but during a recent trip to Ukraine he broke form, revealing that U.S. prosecutors had identified “several specific” Russians suspected of war crimes against one or more Americans.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Kelsey Piper
abstract: The Mar. 21, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Kelsey Piper. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: You Don’t Need to Disinfect So Much
abstract: Our use of antimicrobial cleaners spiked during the pandemic. Given the potential long-term health risks, it might be worth cutting back again.
lead_paragraph: The cleaning industry experienced a boom during the first years of the pandemic. Covid-19 cleaning protocols in schools, stores and other public spaces ratcheted up, with a spray and a wipe-down becoming de rigueur on every surface after every use. Fear of the coronavirus also prompted people to use more disinfectant wipes and sprays in their homes, and consumer spending on cleaning products increased 12 percent between 2019 and 2021. (The New York Times admittedly contributed to this disinfecting frenzy.)

headline: Johnson Admits Misleading Parliament Over Lockdown Parties
abstract: Former Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain, who will testify before a committee investigating whether he lied to lawmakers, said any misinformation was not intentional.
lead_paragraph: A day before he was to face a potentially make-or-break hearing, Boris Johnson conceded that he had misled the British Parliament about lockdown-breaking parties at 10 Downing Street while he was prime minister. But he insisted that he did not do so “intentionally or recklessly.”

headline: The Iran Hostages, and a Plot to Thwart Carter
abstract: Responses to an article about an effort to delay release of the hostages until after the 1980 election. Also: The Iraq war; hate groups; end-of-life care.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Push to Insure Big Deposits Percolates on Capitol Hill
abstract: The government insures only deposits of less than $250,000, but there is precedent for lifting that cap amid turmoil. It could happen again.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Lawmakers are looking for ways to resolve a major concern that threatens to keep the banking industry in turmoil: The federal government insures bank deposits only up to $250,000.

headline: Overlooked No More: Lilian Lindsay, Britain’s First Female Dentist
abstract: The profession was considered unladylike in 1890s England, where she was refused admission to dental school. But she found one in Scotland, and became a notable figure in dentistry.
lead_paragraph: When the headmistress at the North London Collegiate School told Lilian Lindsay that she should become a teacher, and that she would block her from finding any other type of work, Lindsay shot back: “You cannot prevent me from being a dentist.”

headline: Scenes From Recent Atmospheric Rivers in California
abstract: A relentless stretch of winter storms has flooded communities, trapped residents in snow, caused mudslides and shut down major roadways.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — California residents piled sandbags outside their homes and anxiously watched stream levels as the season’s 12th atmospheric river arrived on Tuesday morning, threatening to bring another round of flooding and chaos to the beleaguered state.

headline: Bracket Busted? Try Round 2 of Our Tournament Prediction Game Instead.
abstract: So, your N.C.A.A. tournament bracket is in shambles. How about playing a game that requires no brackets?
lead_paragraph: So, your N.C.A.A. tournament bracket is in shambles. How about playing a game that requires no brackets?

headline: A Massive Trump Painting Has Mysteriously Gone Missing
abstract: A portrait of former President Donald J. Trump by a Salvadoran painter is one of several gifts to the presidential family that is now unaccounted for.
lead_paragraph: It was the commission of a lifetime for this artist, who grew up poor in El Salvador with no formal training: Paint a portrait of the 45th president of the United States, Donald J. Trump.

headline: Virginia’s, a Neighborhood Bistro, Gets a Second Act in the East Village
abstract: Turkish doner kebab by way of Germany on 14th Street, a New York steakhouse with a Peter Luger alumnus cooking, and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: Reed Adelson opened the original Virginia’s, named for his mother, in 2015 and found he had the very definition of a neighborhood bistro on his hands. But it was a trifle too compact. So, in 2021, with the pandemic and a new baby, he decided to close it, seeking to reopen in a larger space when the lease ended. He has taken over the former Root & Bone nearby, and now has 60 seats indoors, with another 50 outside in front of the expansive storefront. As at the original, the walls are decorated with framed menus from great restaurants. The executive chef, Justin Lee, who worked at Barbuto, Fat Choy and Lafayette, among others, is here working with the chef Isamar Checo at his side to produce a combination of bistro favorites and steakhouse items like raw bar specialties, crab cake rémoulade, roasted carrot salad, steak frites, clams casino, trout roe dip with potato chips, steak tartare and a burger. Cocktails by Evan Hawkins include a martini garnished with an olive stuffed with blue cheese. (Opens Thursday)

headline: Reconstructing Kyiv, One Synth Wave at a Time
abstract: “Kyiv Eternal,” by the composer and sound artist Heinali (real name Oleh Shpudeiko), submerges listeners in the sounds of the prewar Ukrainian capital.
lead_paragraph: It’s disorienting: Again and again these past few weeks, I’ve been walking through New York and thinking I’m somewhere else. I’ll be strolling through Central Park, but the sounds I hear come from a park nine time zones away. In line at my local Whole Foods I’ll hear the cash registers of an Eastern European grocery store. Last week I was riding the subway to Harlem and the announcer called out the wrong line. “Next stop, Maidan Nezalezhnosti …”

headline: Patrick French, Unsparing Biographer of V.S. Naipaul, Dies at 56
abstract: He was a historian of India and Tibet, but best known for his biography of Naipaul, which one reviewer described as “a portrait of the artist as a monster.”
lead_paragraph: Patrick French, a historian and biographer whose books include acclaimed accounts of India’s march toward independence and the life of the writer V.S. Naipaul, “The World Is What It Is,” died on Thursday in London. He was 56.

headline: How an Indictment and Arrest of Donald Trump Could Unfold
abstract: An indictment could be handed up in the days ahead, but much about how the process might play out remains unknown.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates on Donald Trump’s indictment.

headline: How Do Volcanic Smoke Rings Form? New Clues in the Vapor.
abstract: Some scientists think we can better understand volcanoes by learning how the gaseous vortexes emerge.
lead_paragraph: Some volcanoes perform a rather subtle trick: blowing rings of vapor that waft near their craters. The short-lived rings have been observed occasionally at volcanoes like Etna in Italy and Eyjafjallajökull in Iceland. Now researchers have found new clues about how bursting gas bubbles create these curiosities in some volcanoes.

headline: Once a Detective, Always a Detective
abstract: In his novel “Old God’s Time,” Sebastian Barry puts a retired policeman on a case that dredges up painful memories.
lead_paragraph: The opening of Sebastian Barry’s new novel, “Old God’s Time,” invites us to imagine we are at the start of a detective story. One detective, Tom Kettle, on the first page; three detectives by Page 5. And not just any old detective story but that darling of the genre, the cold-case review.

headline: Israel Votes to Scrap Law Barring Settlers at Four Evacuated West Bank Sites
abstract: In a highly symbolic action for Israel’s settler movement, lawmakers approved a first step toward resettling evacuated areas amid spiraling Israeli-Palestinian tensions.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s Parliament on Tuesday repealed legislation that barred settlers from four Jewish communities in the occupied West Bank that were evacuated in 2005, a preliminary move for now, but one that comes as tensions rise over government efforts to assert greater control over Palestinian territories.

headline: Michael Bloomberg Has Found a New $5 Million Cause: Helping Hochul
abstract: Mr. Bloomberg, the billionaire former mayor of New York City, has quietly bankrolled a group that is flooding the airwaves with ads to support Gov. Kathy Hochul’s budget plans.
lead_paragraph: The slick campaign-style ads have been running on repeat during telecasts of “Jeopardy!” and March Madness basketball. They trumpet, at great expense, the agenda of New York’s governor, Kathy Hochul. And at the end of each, a tiny message says they are paid for by a vanilla-sounding group, American Opportunity.

headline: 10 (or, Actually, 11) Songs That Explain Me
abstract: Introducing a new newsletter dedicated to music discovery, and your host, Lindsay Zoladz.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the first installment of The Amplifier — a twice-weekly note about songs (new and old) worth hearing. I want The Amplifier to bring that mixtape-from-your-friend feeling back to musical discovery. Too often, in the streaming era, our choices are at the mercy of a shadowy, impersonal algorithm. The Amplifier will be a return to something more intimate and human.

headline: ‘Shucked’: A Broadway Musical That Doubles Down on the Corn
abstract: For their debut, the country-music songwriting team Shane McAnally and Brandy Clark embraced puns, heartfelt songs and campy performances. Here’s their story.
lead_paragraph: Shane McAnally’s boffo songwriting career got off to a slow start, but by 2013 he and his frequent writing partner Brandy Clark were finally having success. The Band Perry’s “Better Dig Two” and Miranda Lambert’s “Mama’s Broken Heart,” both co-written by McAnally and Clark, reached No. 1 and No. 2 on the Billboard country chart.

headline: Judge Dismisses Lawsuit Over Ownership of $1.47 Million NFT
abstract: The legal battle over “Quantum” is part of a larger effort to define rules of ownership for digital artworks.
lead_paragraph: A federal court last Friday dismissed a lawsuit that questioned the ownership rules around an NFT called “Quantum,” which Sotheby’s sold for $1.47 million in 2021 as the first of its kind. The legal battle had become part of a larger effort to define rules of ownership for digital artworks.

headline: Film Club: ‘The Army We Had’
abstract: Nearly 20 years after their deployment to Iraq, veterans struggle to make sense of the war. What can we learn from their stories?
lead_paragraph: Note to Teachers: The film includes profanity and disturbing images and themes. Please preview it to make sure it is appropriate for your students.

headline: Six Ways to Learn About the Iraq War
abstract: On the 20th anniversary of the American-led invasion, we provide resources to help students understand the war’s causes and effects, along with its legacy and lessons.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago, the United States invaded Iraq as part of the “war on terror” announced by President George W. Bush after the attacks by Al Qaeda on Sept. 11, 2001. Mr. Bush and members of his administration said that Saddam Hussein, Iraq’s leader, was manufacturing and concealing weapons of mass destruction, though no evidence was ever found to back up those accusations. The Americans quickly toppled Mr. Hussein’s brutal authoritarian government but also unleashed a sectarian civil war and a violent insurgency against occupying U.S. forces.

headline: How Big a Deal Is the Banking Mess?
abstract: A murky economic outlook just got even murkier.
lead_paragraph: I’m on vacation and trying to spend a few weeks not thinking about the usual stuff. But it turns out that I can’t stay completely out of the debate over the sudden wave of banking crises and their effect on the economic outlook.

headline: Teacher Shot by 6-Year-Old Will ‘Never Forget’ the Look on His Face
abstract: In an interview with NBC’s “Today” show, the teacher, Abigail Zwerner, said she was recovering after a bullet struck her hand and chest at a Virginia elementary school in January.
lead_paragraph: The Virginia teacher who was shot by a 6-year-old student in her classroom in January said in a television interview broadcast on Tuesday that she would “never forget the look on his face that he gave me while he pointed the gun directly at me.”

headline: Have You Moved to a New City in the Last 10 Years? Tell Us Your Story.
abstract: Help us understand patterns of American migration.
lead_paragraph: The Upshot is working on a project about migration within the United States, exploring the patterns of where people move when they leave for another region or state.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Her Gifts Drove Me Crazy’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: Every birthday, my Filipino grandmother gave me pearls: necklaces, earrings, bracelets, rings. Always tissue-wrapped and labeled with her fine handwriting. Pearls are what she believed a woman should be: polished, elegant. When I was in my punk-rock teens, her gifts drove me crazy — then guilty. “Please, grandma, save your money!” She didn’t listen. She lived to 95. When she lost the ability to walk, shop or remember, I’d sneak previous pearls into her jewelry box. By my early 30s, I’d learned that it’s the giving that matters. She’d find them, delighted to have the perfect present for me, again. — Gendy Alimurung

headline: Its Forces Under Siege, Ukraine Hits Distant, Russian-Held Crimea
abstract: The Crimean Peninsula, which Russia seized in 2014, has been a staging ground for other attacks and an increasingly attractive target for Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — As swarms of Russian soldiers stormed Ukrainian lines in furious assaults around two cities in the east on Tuesday, Ukraine set the stage for its own advance by making strikes deep behind Russian lines, including what appeared to be a drone attack on a vital logistical hub in the occupied Crimean Peninsula.

headline: Ex-Prosecutor in ‘Rust’ Case Suggested Role ‘Might Help’ Her Campaign
abstract: Andrea Reeb, part of the team that charged Alec Baldwin with manslaughter, wrote in an email in June that the case could help her campaign for the state legislature.
lead_paragraph: When Andrea Reeb was hired last June as a prosecutor investigating the fatal shooting of a cinematographer on the set of the film “Rust,” she emailed the district attorney in charge of the case that an announcement of her role “might help” her campaign for a seat in the state legislature.

headline: Willis Reed, Hall of Fame Center for Champion Knicks, Dies at 80
abstract: He was beloved by New York fans for his willingness to play hurt, as memorably exemplified in the decisive Game 7 of the 1970 N.B.A. finals at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: Willis Reed, the brawny and inspirational hub of two Knicks championship teams that captivated New York in the early 1970s with a canny, team-oriented style of play, died on Tuesday. He was 80.

headline: Restaurant Review: Kebabs From India, in So Many Shapes and Forms
abstract: Kebab aur Sharab, on the Upper West Side, celebrates flat yogurt kebabs, lamb chops on a long pole, and more.
lead_paragraph: New York City is large and full of kebabs. There are self-basting kebabs of marinated lamb threaded with chunks of fat from a lamb’s tail at Uzbek grills; fried saucer-shaped patties of ground meat kneaded with flour at Afghan restaurants; skinless sausages of cevapi piled into freshly baked and opened loaves of lepinja at Balkan joints; bullet-shaped doner kebabs orbiting slowly beside a vertical flame at Turkish pit stops.

headline: Why There Is Talk of a Writers’ Strike in Hollywood
abstract: TV and movie writers want more money, but Hollywood companies say the demands ignore economic realities. The deadline to sort out those differences is approaching.
lead_paragraph: Television and movie writers want raises, saying that Hollywood companies have taken unfair advantage of the shift to streaming to devalue their work and create worsening working conditions.

headline: Virginia Zeani, Versatile and Durable Soprano, Dies at 97
abstract: A noted Violetta in Verdi’s “La Traviata,” she was “a woman blessed with beauty both physical and vocal,” Plácido Domingo said.
lead_paragraph: Virginia Zeani, a Romanian soprano with a brilliant, powerful voice and striking looks who overcame childhood poverty and the perils of war to become a fixture on the opera stage, died on Monday in West Palm Beach, Fla. She was 97.

headline: Did You Hear About Rupert Murdoch’s Engagement?
abstract: The cast of “Succession” reacted to the news at a party celebrating Season 4.
lead_paragraph: Hours before the cast of the HBO drama “Succession” gathered for the premiere of its fourth and final season, the news broke: Rupert Murdoch, 92, the chairman of the conservative media empire that owns Fox News, announced in his own tabloid that he was engaged to Ann Lesley Smith, 66, a former police chaplain of San Francisco.

headline: The Pentagon plans to send older, refurbished Abrams tanks to Ukraine by fall, far sooner than expected.
abstract: Excess M1A1 tank “hulls” are to be refitted and refurbished to make them ready on a quicker timeline for Ukraine than new tanks could be delivered.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States will send M1 Abrams tanks to Ukraine far more quickly than expected, with a number of them now scheduled to arrive later this year, the Pentagon said in a briefing to reporters.

headline: How to Read a Menu Like a Food Critic
abstract: It’s harder than it seems. So Pete Wells and Tejal Rao have tips.
lead_paragraph: This week marks one year of Where to Eat. What I hoped would be a digestible, funny and useful weekly guide to eating out in New York City is now a community of readers with thoughtful questions and strong opinions.

headline: What Google Bard Can Do (and What It Can’t)
abstract: Google has released a new chatbot to a limited number of people in the U.S. and Britain. How does it compare with what is already out there?
lead_paragraph: Google has released a new chatbot, Bard, and has shared the experimental technology with a limited number of people in the United States and Britain.

headline: Review: In ‘Hang Time,’ Lynched Men Tell Finely Tuned Tales
abstract: Zora Howard’s new play at the Flea catches three men during a few moments of their breathless eternity.
lead_paragraph: Walking into the Flea for Zora Howard’s “Hang Time” is like stepping into a horror film. Darkness pervades the black box theater, and cicadas carry on conversations in some unseen woods. A large obstruction — perhaps a statue? or installation? — interrupts the space. Then it becomes clear: Three Black men seemingly hanging from invisible ropes above an elevated round platform. Lights faintly illuminate their slumped heads and shoulders; their shadows are cast on the right wall, evoking Kara Walker’s silhouettes. You have to pass by them to get to your seat.

headline: ‘Kubrick by Kubrick’ Review: Stanley Plays Himself
abstract: A primer on the filmmaker’s career and interests won’t offer much that will surprise even mild obsessives, but it does pierce some of the mystique.
lead_paragraph: The director Stanley Kubrick gave so few interviews that hearing his voice is always a little jarring. It’s less deep than you might imagine from late-career photographs, which make him look like a woolly elder statesman of the cinema, or from seeing his movies, which raise dark questions about human nature. Kubrick’s accent contains traces of his Bronx upbringing, even though he lived in Britain for more than 30 years. And his conversational manner is much more casual, more affable, than his reputation as a hermetic perfectionist would suggest.

headline: Unbowed, Macron Appears Ready to Tough Out Pension Crisis
abstract: Amid protests in the streets and in Parliament, the French leader shows no sign of scrapping a law that raises the retirement age.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — President Emmanuel Macron’s re-election program last year was short on detail. His mind seemed elsewhere, chiefly on the war in Ukraine. But on one thing he was clear: He would raise the retirement age in France to 65 from 62.

headline: A Big Question for the Fed: What Went Wrong With Bank Oversight?
abstract: As the Federal Reserve reviews the failure of Silicon Valley Bank, and Congress prepares for hearings, bank oversight is getting a closer look.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jerome H. Powell is likely to face more than the typical questions about the Federal Reserve’s latest interest rate decision on Wednesday. The central bank chair will almost certainly be grilled about how and why his institution failed to stop problems at Silicon Valley Bank before it was too late.

headline: Rejection of AirTrain Leaves La Guardia With a Familiar Fallback: Buses
abstract: New York transportation authorities appear poised to improve bus service to La Guardia after a plan for a rail link was scrapped last week.
lead_paragraph: In the pecking order of mass transit projects, trains always seem to trump buses — even if the trains are designed to go in the wrong direction.

headline: Ukrainian Soldiers Speed Through U.S. Training on Patriot Missiles
abstract: At the end of a 10-week crash course at a U.S. Army base in Oklahoma, the Ukrainians are essentially running their own training in preparation for the front lines.
lead_paragraph: FORT SILL, Okla. — Several dozen Ukrainian soldiers are wrapping up their training on the Patriot missile system and within a few weeks will deploy to the war’s front lines, armed with America’s most advanced ground-based air defense to help protect against Russian missile attacks.

headline: Here is what Putin and Xi agreed to in Moscow.
abstract: The two leaders did not reveal any progress toward achieving peace in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, sought to project a sense of unity and normalcy on Tuesday, during the second day of Mr. Xi’s grand state visit, which included the signing of 14 agreements.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing: China, Japan Divided on Ukraine
abstract: Also, an I.M.F. loan to Sri Lanka and the Japan-U.S. final in the World Baseball Classic.
lead_paragraph: Separate visits by the leaders of the two largest economies in Asia — China and Japan — are highlighting the geopolitical fault lines created by Russia’s invasion.

headline: Puppetry So Lifelike, Even Their Deaths Look Real
abstract: Members of the puppetry team for “Life of Pi” discuss making the show’s animals seem all-too-real on a very crowded lifeboat.
lead_paragraph: Fair warning: This article is riddled with spoilers about puppet deaths in “Life of Pi,” the stage adaptation of Yann Martel’s best-selling novel about a shipwrecked teenager adrift on the Pacific Ocean. He shares his lifeboat first with a menagerie of animals from his family’s zoo in India — large-scale puppets all, requiring a gaggle of puppeteers — and eventually just with a magnificent, ravenous Royal Bengal tiger named Richard Parker that takes three puppeteers to operate.

headline: Gwyneth Paltrow to Testify in Trial Over Utah Ski Accident
abstract: A retired optometrist accused the actress in a lawsuit of violently crashing into him in a skiing accident in Park City in 2016. He is seeking $300,000 in damages.
lead_paragraph: Gwyneth Paltrow, the actress and lifestyle entrepreneur, is expected to testify in a civil trial in the coming weeks after a retired optometrist accused her of violently crashing into him while skiing in Park City, Utah, in 2016.

headline: Wisconsin Court Candidates Clash Over Abortion and Democracy
abstract: In their lone debate, Janet Protasiewicz, a liberal, and Daniel Kelly, a conservative, unleashed searing attacks on each other. At stake is a crucial seat on the battleground state’s Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — The dueling contenders in Wisconsin’s consequential and costly Supreme Court race collided on Tuesday in their lone debate, a hostile affair that illustrated their stark disagreements over cultural issues and the role of a justice on the state’s high court.

headline: Fox and Dominion Urge Judge to Rule on Case
abstract: At the start of a pretrial hearing for the $1.6 billion defamation trial, the judge said he was still weighing whether to issue a summary judgment.
lead_paragraph: A Delaware judge overseeing Dominion Voting Systems’ $1.6 billion defamation lawsuit against Fox News said in a pretrial hearing on Tuesday that he was still weighing whether to issue a summary judgment for either side in the case.

headline: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: A ‘Rocking Chair Rebellion’: Seniors Call On Banks to Dump Big Oil
abstract: Older climate activists gathered in cities around the country for a day of action targeting banks that finance fossil fuel projects.
lead_paragraph: They were parents, grandparents, great-aunts and great-uncles, ranging in age from their 50s to their 80s and beyond, and together they braved frigid temperatures to protest all through the night, and to rock.

headline: Possible Trump Indictment Puts Attention on Prosecutorial Discretion
abstract: The Manhattan district attorney has considerable leeway in deciding whether to bring charges against the former president using what could be an untested legal theory.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Manhattan district attorney’s looming decision about whether to seek an indictment of former President Donald J. Trump for a hush money payment to a porn actress has ignited debate over the strength of the case and how prosecutors should decide when it is appropriate to pursue charges — and when not to do so.

headline: Trump at Mar-a-Lago: Magical Thinking and a Perp-Walk Fixation
abstract: Those who have spent time with Donald Trump in recent days say he has often appeared significantly disconnected from the severity of his potential legal woes.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump claims he is ready for his perp walk.

headline: UConn’s Freshman Center Stands Out Off the Bench
abstract: At 7-foot-2, Donovan Clingan is proving himself a natural, but he dedicated himself to basketball only after his mother, a Connecticut high school star who played at Maine, died when he was 14.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, N.Y. — Like a lot of boys, Donovan Clingan competed in many activities while growing up in Bristol, Conn.: baseball, basketball, fishing and soccer.

headline: Warren Boroson, Who Surveyed Psychiatrists on Goldwater, Dies at 88
abstract: The defeated Republican presidential candidate sued Mr. Boroson and the magazine he worked for, saying it had libeled him for suggesting that he was mentally unfit for the presidency.
lead_paragraph: Warren Boroson, a journalist who conducted a survey of psychiatrists that declared the 1964 Republican presidential nominee, Barry M. Goldwater, mentally unfit to be president — provoking a libel suit from the candidate and prompting a psychiatric association to muzzle its members from ever diagnosing a public figure from afar — died on March 12 at his home in Woodstock, N.Y. He was 88.

headline: Wuhan Market Samples Contained Covid and Animal Mixtures, Report Says
abstract: In a much-anticipated study, experts described a swab that was positive for the coronavirus and contained loads of genetic material from raccoon dogs.
lead_paragraph: On Jan. 12, 2020, Chinese investigators combing a market for clues about the outbreak of a mysterious new illness in the city of Wuhan swabbed a cart. It was the kind typically used for transporting animal cages, and it came back positive for the coronavirus.

headline: Biden Brings the Stars to the White House
abstract: The president bestowed National Medals of Arts and National Humanities Medals to a host of celebrated musicians, actors, writers and other figures.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Call it Celebrity Week at the White House.

headline: Gwyneth Paltrow’s Utah Ski Crash Trial Begins
abstract: Lawyers delivered opening statements in a civil trial involving the actress Gwyneth Paltrow and Terry Sanderson, a retired optometrist, who accused her of violently crashing into him while skiing in 2016.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers delivered opening statements in a civil trial involving the actress Gwyneth Paltrow and Terry Sanderson, a retired optometrist, who accused her of violently crashing into him while skiing in 2016.

headline: Pulling the Plug on TikTok Will Be Harder Than It Looks
abstract: The tensions over the Chinese-owned social media app will come to a head on Thursday, when the company’s chief executive testifies on Capitol Hill.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2020, in full re-election mode and looking for new ways to punish China, President Donald J. Trump threatened to cut off TikTok from the phones of millions of Americans unless its parent company agreed to sell all of its U.S. operations to American owners. The effort collapsed.

headline: 20 Years On, I Don’t Regret Supporting the Iraq War
abstract: The rationale was wrong, and the execution was lousy. But getting rid of Saddam Hussein was the right call.
lead_paragraph: Of those who supported the U.S. invasion of Iraq 20 years ago — not just warmongering neocons like yours truly but also plenty of liberals, such as the current president of the United States — most have disavowed it.

headline: Our New Promethean Moment
abstract: I just saw magic, and it’s the future.
lead_paragraph: I had a most remarkable but unsettling experience last week. Craig Mundie, the former chief research and strategy officer for Microsoft, was giving me a demonstration of GPT-4, the most advanced version of the artificial intelligence chatbot ChatGPT, developed by OpenAI and launched in November. Craig was preparing to brief the board of my wife’s museum, Planet Word, of which he is a member, about the effect ChatGPT will have on words, language and innovation.

headline: Xi and Putin Bind China and Russia’s Economies Further, Despite War in Ukraine
abstract: On the second day of the Chinese leader’s state visit in Moscow, Xi Jinping and Vladimir V. Putin declared an enduring economic partnership, in an effort to insulate their countries from punitive Western measures.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, declared an enduring economic partnership on Tuesday, promising to bring more Russian energy to China and more Chinese companies to Russia as the two leaders sought to insulate their countries from Western sanctions and other consequences of the war in Ukraine.

headline: John Jenrette Jr., Congressman Nabbed in Abscam Sting, Dies at 86
abstract: Once a rising star of the Democratic Party, he served 13 months in prison for bribery after being targeted in an F.B.I. scam involving a phony sheikh.
lead_paragraph: John Jenrette Jr., a charismatic Democratic Representative from South Carolina who became ensnared in the Abscam investigation of political corruption that also brought down six other members of Congress, died on Friday in Conway, S.C. He was 86.

headline: Here are the legal intricacies that could make or break the case against Trump.
abstract: To try to convict the former president of a felony, prosecutors might attempt to connect state election law to a federal election.
lead_paragraph: It is the kind of case that emboldens prosecutors and mesmerizes juries: a celebrity defendant authorizing a secret payoff to cover up a tryst with a porn star.

headline: Today’s Woke Excesses Were Born in the ’60s
abstract: When rhetoric overtakes action in the fight for equality.
lead_paragraph: Various books I’ve been reading lately have me thinking about 1966. I have often said that the history of Black America could be divided between what happened before and after that year.

headline: DeSantis, Doubling Down, Presses Questions About Trump’s Character
abstract: In an interview with Piers Morgan, the Florida governor sought to strike a clear contrast with Donald Trump, calling himself a low-drama “winner.”
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, the closest prospective rival to Donald J. Trump in early polls of the 2024 Republican presidential primary, pressed forward with questions about the former president’s character and pointed to himself as a low-drama “winner” in an interview this week with the British media personality Piers Morgan.

headline: Jeremy Scott Speaks for the First Time Since His Split From Moschino
abstract: The former creative director of the Italian label shared what his future holds, what brought him to Seoul and the celebrity Oscar gown that was his “cherry on top.”
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — When the news emerged on Tuesday that Jeremy Scott had stepped down as the creative director of the Italian designer label Moschino after 10 years, he was busy settling into his latest destination: South Korea.

headline: Regional Banks and Regulators Try to Soothe Depositors’ Fears
abstract: While some executives said money wasn’t being pulled from their small and midsize banks, the “too big to fail” giants attracted business customers.
lead_paragraph: In the panic after Silicon Valley Bank collapsed in early March, some small and medium-size businesses yanked their money from regional banks and deposited it with the biggest ones, seeking the security of their gigantic balance sheets and the government’s implicit backstop of lenders deemed too big to fail.

headline: Driver Kills 2 on Street That Had Been Focus of Traffic Safety Campaign
abstract: Brooklyn’s 18th Avenue was removed from a list of New York’s deadliest roads after fatalities dropped. Then, a car jumped the curb.
lead_paragraph: A man who investigators said sped through a red light at a Brooklyn intersection was charged on Tuesday with killing a driver and a pedestrian, according to the New York Police Department.

headline: Corrections: March 22, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, March 22, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about the Black Sea as a flashpoint between Russia and the West referred incorrectly to Sevastopol. Russia tried to cement control over the Crimean port city in 2014, but it is not Russia’s only warm-water port. The error was repeated in a picture caption.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Yes, They Are Tall. No, They Do Not Play Basketball.
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, March 22, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “No. Did you play miniature golf?”

headline: Falls by the Wheyside
abstract: You might want a big screen for Madeline Kaplan’s debut puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Ohtani Shines as Japan Beats U.S. to Win World Baseball Classic
abstract: A thrilling tournament ended emphatically with Shohei Ohtani striking out Mike Trout to give Japan its third W.B.C. crown.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The matchup that many had dreamed about all along — between two of the world’s baseball powerhouses and two of its very best players in Shohei Ohtani and Mike Trout — is exactly what it came down to.

headline: Biden Presents Awards for the Arts and Humanities
abstract: The president honored several stars, including Julia Louis-Dreyfus, Bruce Springsteen, Mindy Kaling and Amy Tan during a ceremony at the White House.
lead_paragraph: The president honored several stars, including Julia Louis-Dreyfus, Bruce Springsteen, Mindy Kaling and Amy Tan during a ceremony at the White House.

headline: Who Was Buried at Green-Wood, 1840-1937? Now It’s Easier to Find Out.
abstract: The ledgers of the famous Brooklyn cemetery are online and include some famous names, like Boss Tweed and F.A.O. Schwarz.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll look at how a cemetery in Brooklyn is using 21st-century technology to take a closer look at 19th- and 20th-century records.

headline: Pacific Storm System Batters California
abstract: The latest atmospheric river flooded neighborhoods and created dangerous driving conditions.
lead_paragraph: The latest atmospheric river flooded neighborhoods and created dangerous driving conditions.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Closer ties between Russia and China.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir Putin of Russia and China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, declared an enduring economic partnership yesterday, promising to bring more Russian energy to China and more Chinese companies to Russia as the two leaders sought to insulate their countries from Western sanctions and other consequences of the war in Ukraine.

headline: China Approves an mRNA Covid Vaccine, Its First
abstract: The homegrown shot is a crucial tool that China has been lacking — a vaccine based on a technology considered among the most effective the world has to offer.
lead_paragraph: China has for the first time approved a Covid-19 vaccine based on mRNA technology, greenlighting a homegrown shot months after the ruling Communist Party eliminated its strict pandemic restrictions.

headline: Word of the Day: flail
abstract: This word has appeared in 15 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word flail has appeared in 15 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 24 in “Bedlam on the Ice, Torn Loyalties Off It, Define Battle of Alberta” by David Waldstein:

headline: Late Night Is Getting Antsy for a Trump Indictment
abstract: The former president was not charged Tuesday, as he predicted. “Right now in Times Square, Anderson Cooper and Andy Cohen are hosting the indictment countdown,” Jimmy Fallon said.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Spring’s Arrival
abstract: What do you like and dislike about the season?
lead_paragraph: Spring has arrived. How do you feel about the season?

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: In Duluth, Real Estate Collides With Climate
abstract: More Americans are uprooting their lives for safer climates. That sent one Times real estate reporter to the Upper Midwest.
lead_paragraph: In January, I flew to Duluth, Minn., to find people who had moved across the country seeking refuge from climate change.

headline: U.K. Inflation Swings Upward, in a U-Turn
abstract: Prices in Britain reversed a recent downward trend, rising 10.4 percent over the year through February.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s inflation rate unexpectedly rose last month, reversing its recent downward trend and potentially undermining expectations that the Bank of England was close to halting interest rate increases.

headline: The Fed, Still Inflation-Focused, Raised Rates Amid Bank Uncertainty
abstract: Federal Reserve officials raised interest rates by a quarter-point while they noted that bank turmoil could help slow the economy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal Reserve officials raised interest rates by a quarter-point on Wednesday as they tried to balance two conflicting problems: the risk that inflation could remain rapid and the threat that turmoil in the banking system could slow the economy drastically.

headline: The Politics of a Trump Indictment
abstract: It could hurt him at the polls and still be a very bad long-term idea.
lead_paragraph: If you intend to indict and try a former president of the United States, especially a former president of the United States whose career has benefited from the collapse of public trust in the neutrality of all our institutions, you had better have clear evidence, all-but-obvious guilt and loads of legal precedent behind your case.

headline: What Is the Best Thing About Being Your Age?
abstract: Do you like being a kid? If you could wave a magic wand and turn into an adult, would you?
lead_paragraph: How old are you? How do you feel about your age? Do you like being a teenager? Or do you ever wish you could skip ahead to adulthood, or go back to being a little kid?

headline: ‘Ted Lasso,’ Season 3, Episode 2 Recap: Origin Stories
abstract: Also: Can AFC Richmond acquire one of the greatest footballers alive?
lead_paragraph: “Trent Crimm! Are you kidding me?”

headline: ‘Scorpion Girl’ Found Dead on Staten Island Is Identified After 31 Years
abstract: Police said a woman with a distinctive tattoo was Christine Belusko, who was beaten to death and strangled. No one knows where her daughter is.
lead_paragraph: For almost 30 years, detectives knew her only as the Scorpion Girl.

headline: Stocks Drop After Fed Raises Rates Despite Banking Turmoil
abstract: There had been widespread uncertainty about whether the Federal Reserve would continue raising rates after turmoil in the banking industry.
lead_paragraph: Stocks on Wall Street skidded lower in late trading on Wednesday, as investors balked at the Federal Reserve’s decision to raise interest rates, by a quarter of a percentage point, amid a banking crisis.

headline: Baseball’s Unicorn Made the W.B.C. ‘Real’
abstract: Shohei Ohtani’s ability to dominate as a hitter and as a pitcher delivered a championship for Japan while establishing the World Baseball Classic as a must-watch tournament.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — He strode to the mound with purpose, 6-foot-4 and full of muscle, a relief pitcher unlike any other. Fresh from the bullpen, his uniform was already caked in dirt. Shohei Ohtani had put in a full day’s work by the ninth inning of the World Baseball Classic final on Tuesday, coming to bat four times, and now he was going to pitch.

headline: ‘It Is Our Fate to Live in the Age of the Indelible’
abstract: In “Bottoms Up and the Devil Laughs,” Kerry Howley explores how the erosion of privacy has fueled conspiracy theories and the national security state.
lead_paragraph: The people in Kerry Howley’s new book include fabulists, truth tellers, combatants, whistle-blowers. Like many of us, they have left traces of themselves in the digital ether by making a phone call, texting a friend, looking up something online. Certain conveniences have become so frictionless that we reflexively entrust devices with mundane yet intimate secrets: group-chat gossip, numbers of steps taken, dumb selfies.

headline: The Unsettling Truth About Trump’s First Great Victory
abstract: His electoral triumph in 2016 continues to confound election experts. But it’s hardly just an academic question.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s 2016 election victory continues to confound election experts. How could American voters put such a fractious figure into the White House?

headline: The Best Biscuits Outside of the South
abstract: These uniquely layered, pillowy biscuits get a caramelized crust from a bit of extra sugar.
lead_paragraph: Whenever Briana Holt is baking at home, her rescue dog, Gravy, is usually close by waiting for a treat. She named him after Wavy Gravy, the Woodstock-era peace activist and the former official clown of the Grateful Dead, one of Holt’s favorite bands. Her dog’s name, she says, has nothing to do with the fact that she happens to make the best biscuits I’ve ever tasted outside the South. Holt is an owner and the head baker at Tandem Coffee + Bakery in Portland, Maine, which has a line out the door more often than not. I met her for the first time at the front of that line. As I was ordering my third biscuit of the week, I felt a gentle tap on my shoulder. “Eric?”

headline: Is Working From Home Really Working?
abstract: The attitude of many Americans toward their jobs appears to have changed during the long pandemic — and not for the better.
lead_paragraph: Quiet quitting. Working from home. The Great Resignation.

headline: New York Birders Reject Audubon Name Over Slavery Past
abstract: The association with the naturalist John James Audubon is “problematic” for a local group seeking to be more inclusive.
lead_paragraph: NYC Audubon will drop Audubon from its name over concerns that the racist legacy of the 19th-century naturalist and illustrator John James Audubon has become a barrier to its efforts to become more inclusive.

headline: Want to Love Your Body? Try Swimming Naked.
abstract: Searching for myself at a queer nude beach in Mexico.
lead_paragraph: I heard about the gay beach the way I hear about all the good gay things: Through a lover, an ex-lover, my ex-lover’s new love. A warm mouth pressed against my ear on the dance floor, a dropped pin, an Instagram D.M. The murmurs were about a queer nude beach nestled along the coast of Oaxaca. It took a full day and a half to get there, flying first into Mexico City and then catching a shorter flight toward the Pacific.

headline: Inside a Brooklyn School Teaching the Course That Florida Banned
abstract: Students taking the African American studies class have learned about ancient kingdoms, 20th-century movements and modern issues.
