lead_paragraph: Halfway through a yearlong high school course in African American studies, Shannah Henderson-Amare asked her students to think about college — but with a question that many had never heard posed in a classroom before: Could they name the “Divine Nine,” the popular nickname for a group of the nation’s Black fraternities and sororities?

headline: Why the Fed’s Decision Matters for Biden
abstract: The president is counting on the central bank to strike the right balance on jobs and inflation — and to prevent a spiraling financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve’s decision on Wednesday to raise interest rates at a precarious moment carries risks not just for the central bank, but also for President Biden.

headline: Why Are Public Restrooms Still So Rare?
abstract: Cities in the U.S. and elsewhere have made strides, but challenges remain.
lead_paragraph: When a visiting friend asked if I wanted to go on a run in Philadelphia, I did a lot of planning. Not just our route, but where to go to the bathroom. It did not go well.

headline: NIMBYs Threaten a Plan to Build More Suburban Housing
abstract: Whether they like it or not, New York officials fighting to maintain exclusionary housing policies are on the wrong side of history.
lead_paragraph: In an insult to New Yorkers suffering from spiraling rents and home prices, both houses of New York’s Democratic-controlled Legislature rejected an ambitious set of proposals from Gov. Kathy Hochul last week that would begin to address the crisis in available housing.

headline: Michael Cohen’s Long Arc From Trump Ally to Chief Antagonist
abstract: He once said he would take a bullet for Donald Trump. Now, he’s hoping to help prosecutors put him away.
lead_paragraph: When Michael D. Cohen stood before a federal judge to ask for leniency, he attributed much of his behavior to the influence of one man: Donald J. Trump.

headline: The Agony and Ecstasy of Ballet Flats
abstract: Six ideal pairs of one of the season’s trendiest (but hardest to get right) shoes.
lead_paragraph: While there’s no doubt that ballet flats are everywhere right now, the definition of what constitutes a ballet flat is somewhat elastic. Here are some helpful parameters to keep in mind when looking for a pair of your own:

headline: Questlove Has a New Creative Pursuit: Publishing
abstract: The musician and producer Ahmir Thompson, better known as Questlove, is starting his own imprint, with eye toward a mix of memoir, history and more.
lead_paragraph: On top of being a D.J., producer, filmmaker, drummer, Academy Award-winning director, culinary entrepreneur, member of the hip-hop band the Roots and scholar of Black musical history, Ahmir Thompson, also known as Questlove, is a prolific author. He’s written and co-authored seven books, including best sellers like “Mo’ Meta Blues,” “Creative Quest” and “Music is History,” and a forthcoming children’s book about time travel.

headline: An Independent Barbados
abstract: The country recently declared itself a republic and there’s a new energy on the Caribbean island. Rum shops, farmers’ markets and surf breaks are there to be found if you venture beyond the resorts of the island’s west coast.
lead_paragraph: One sunny Saturday in the middle of the island of Barbados, in the eastern Caribbean, among former sugar cane plantations, I found myself eating fried sea cat in the yard of a rum shop called De Thirsty Lizard in the village of Bridgefield.

headline: As Haiti’s Police Retreat, Gangs Take Over Much of the Capital
abstract: Even wealthier areas in the capital, Port-au-Prince, are no longer immune to violence as gangs attack police officers and destroy police stations.
lead_paragraph: One by one, schools and hospitals have closed. Kidnappings are an everyday risk and gang warfare rages openly on the streets. But now, the chaos that has long consumed many parts of Port-au-Prince, the capital of Haiti, has spread: The national police, outgunned, outnumbered, underpaid and demoralized, have ceded control of most of the city to gangs.

headline: Bank Crisis Could Cast Pall Over Commercial Real Estate Market
abstract: The market hadn’t fully rebounded from the pandemic. Some worry that another slowdown could add to fears of a recession.
lead_paragraph: The fallout from the recent banking crisis spurred by the collapse of two banks — and concerns about the health of a third — is bubbling up in the market for commercial real estate lending, as borrowers fear that banks will pull back. That could slow down construction activity and increase the likelihood of a recession, analysts and real estate experts said.

headline: I’m Lost All the Time. So I Went on a Labyrinth Vacation.
abstract: The dizzying joys of maze tourism, in Barcelona, Paris and Chenonceaux.
lead_paragraph: Who’s to say when exactly we started to walk twisting paths — to think of them as sites for enjoyment, for the holy, and for the surreal? Labyrinths and mazes have appeared across cultures and time, made by digging ruts into the soil, laying out rock or mosaic or enclosing paths within hedges, walls, bamboo, corn and mirrors. The first recorded labyrinth dates to the 19th century B.C., built by Egyptians near the ancient city Arsinoe to hold the sepulcher of kings and crocodiles. In the desert of Peru, the Nazca dug winding geoglyphs in the shape of birds, flora and monkeys; some of them were thought to be traversed by gods and spirits, by priests and pilgrims during ceremonies. Rock-lined labyrinths along the coasts of the Baltic Sea may have been created in the Bronze Age. Surviving lore suggests they were used in spring pagan dances and light exorcisms, trapping malevolent spirits in their confounding geometry. And of course, one of the most enduring myths of ancient Greece is that of the Minotaur lying in wait at the center of the maze.

headline: Turing Award Won by Co-Inventor of Ethernet Technology
abstract: In the 1970s, Bob Metcalfe helped develop the primary technology that lets you send email or connect with a printer over an office network.
lead_paragraph: In June 1972, Bob Metcalfe, a 26-year-old engineer fresh out of graduate school, joined a new research lab in Palo Alto, Calif., as it set out to build something that few people could even imagine: a personal computer.

headline: This 835-Year-Old English Manor Needs Some Modern Love
abstract: Tim and Sue Soar have toiled for decades to maintain their medieval estate and not go broke. They can’t take it much longer. But will it sell?
lead_paragraph: Tim Soar stood in the oak-paneled drawing room of his 12th-century English manor house, known as Long Crendon Manor, fretting as the heat from the crackling fire escaped out of a door left ajar.

headline: Conservatives Aim to Build a Chatbot of Their Own
abstract: After criticizing A.I. companies for liberal bias, programmers started envisioning right-wing alternatives, making chatbots a new front in the culture wars.
lead_paragraph: When ChatGPT exploded in popularity as a tool using artificial intelligence to draft complex texts, David Rozado decided to test its potential for bias. A data scientist in New Zealand, he subjected the chatbot to a series of quizzes, searching for signs of political orientation.

headline: At Al Aqsa Mosque, Shards of Stained Glass Tell a Story of Conflict
abstract: Artisans at the contested Jerusalem holy site, known to Jews as the Temple Mount, complain of Israeli interference with their work and face a constant struggle to keep up with repairs after violence flares.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — At a workshop on the edge of the Aqsa Mosque compound, Muhammad Rowidy spends hours hunched over panes of stained glass, painstakingly carving through white plaster to reveal geometric designs. While he works, there is a thought he can’t shake.

headline: Aaron Sorkin Revamps ‘Camelot,’ With Challenges Classic and New
abstract: The screenwriter overcame a stroke as he worked to revise the beloved but befuddling Golden Age musical for a Broadway revival.
lead_paragraph: “Camelot” opened on Broadway 63 years ago, an eagerly anticipated new musical from the makers of “My Fair Lady.” But happily-ever-aftering took a while.

headline: The U.S. Is Not an Indispensable Peacemaker
abstract: America needs to accept more peacemakers in the world.
lead_paragraph: There was a time when all roads to peace went through Washington. From the 1978 Camp David Accords between Israel and Egypt brokered by President Jimmy Carter to the 1993 Oslo Accords signed on the White House lawn to Senator George Mitchell’s Good Friday Agreement that ended the fighting in Northern Ireland in 1998, America was the indispensable nation for peacemaking. To Paul Nitze, a longtime diplomat and Washington insider, “making evident its qualifications as an honest broker” was central to America’s influence after the end of the Cold War.

headline: She Posted Online About the War in Ukraine. Then She Faced a Prison Term.
abstract: The case of Olesya Krivtsova, a Russian student who ended up on the Kremlin’s official terrorist list, has underscored the perils of using social media to criticize the Kremlin’s war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Sitting in a small courtroom flanked by her two lawyers last month, Olesya Krivtsova was facing a stiff penalty for her fondness for posting on social media. Barely 20 and until this year a university student in northern Russia, she was accused of “justifying terrorism” and “discrediting the Russian armed forces,” and was facing up to a decade in prison.

headline: Barney Frank on His Role in the Banking Crisis
abstract: Looser financial requirements contributed to the failure of Signature and Silicon Valley banks. And one of the rules’ creators supported loosening them.
lead_paragraph: Barney Frank was one of the people most responsible for overhauling financial regulation after the 2008 economic crisis. After retiring from Congress, he supported a change to his own law that would benefit midsize banks, and joined the board of such a bank.

headline: 8 Dolphins Dead After Washing Ashore in New Jersey
abstract: It was the latest instance of marine mammals being found dead on the state’s beaches, raising concerns among residents over what might be the cause.
lead_paragraph: Eight dolphins were dead after a pod of the marine mammals washed ashore in a mass stranding in Sea Isle City, N.J., on Tuesday, the authorities said, prompting questions over what caused their deaths.

headline: The Fed’s Unpleasant Choice
abstract: What’s worse: More inflation or more turmoil?
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve faces a difficult decision at its meeting that ends this afternoon: Should Fed officials raise interest rates in response to worrisome recent inflation data — and accept the risk of causing further problems for banks? Or should officials pause their rate increases — and accept the risk that inflation will remain high?

headline: Abel Prize Goes to Mathematician Who Studied Equations That Describe Nature
abstract: The honor, like a Nobel Prize for mathematics, was given this year to Luis Caffarelli for his work on partial differential equations.
lead_paragraph: As a mathematician, Luis A. Caffarelli of the University of Texas at Austin tries to answer questions that sound simple, even potentially useful:

headline: The Designer Marco De Vincenzo’s Inspirations, and Obsessions, in Pictures
abstract: The new creative director of Etro shares his favorite flea-market finds, and a few creations of his own.
lead_paragraph: As a child in Messina, Italy, a port city in the northeastern corner of Sicily, Marco De Vincenzo, whose parents owned a vehicle registration agency, assumed that a career in fashion was, if not impossible, at least ambitious. And yet, “I remember hearing the story of Gianni Versace,” who grew up just across the sea in Reggio Calabria, says the 44-year-old designer, Etro’s creative director since last June. “I thought, ‘If he started from here and succeeded, so can I.’”

headline: Love in Three Dimensions
abstract: Alice Oseman on bringing her viral webcomic, “Heartstopper,” to life.
lead_paragraph: Alice Oseman on bringing her viral webcomic, “Heartstopper,” to life.

headline: The Monks in the Middle of Russia’s War in Ukraine
abstract: A war-fueled rift between the living clerics loyal to Moscow and those loyal to Kyiv is coming to a head.
lead_paragraph: A war-fueled rift between the living clerics loyal to Moscow and those loyal to Kyiv is coming to a head.

headline: Credit Suisse’s Investment Bank Is Slowly Disappearing
abstract: UBS is weighing whether and how to end a deal that would have preserved most of its rival’s investment bank, as part of its takeover of the ailing Swiss lender.
lead_paragraph: When UBS agreed to buy Credit Suisse at a fire-sale price over the weekend, a big question was what would happen to the ailing firm’s investment bank. Months before the chaos that felled Credit Suisse, the firm had unveiled an ambitious plan to spin out the division, under the leadership of the veteran deal maker Michael Klein, as part of its now-failed turnaround effort.

headline: $250,000 Homes in Wisconsin, Pennsylvania and Alabama
abstract: A Craftsman bungalow in Kaukauna, a rowhouse in Philadelphia and a midcentury ranch house in Florence.
lead_paragraph: Kaukauna is a city about 100 miles north of Milwaukee, straddling the Fox River. This home, which the sellers restored using period-appropriate materials, is within half a mile of several parks, including La Follette Park and Hydro Park, which sits on the river. The Thousand Island State Conservancy Area, also on the river, is less than five minutes away by car.

headline: John Wick Sure Has a Lot of Friends for a Lone Assassin
abstract: How does a taciturn solo killer have so many pals? The films’ creators can’t really explain, but each character has a raison d’être in this world.
lead_paragraph: Over a run of three stunt-laden films, John Wick has dispatched his enemies with rifles, pistols, swords and knives, as well as an assortment of things that just happen to be nearby. On one occasion, he took out several foes by slamming into them with his ’69 Ford Mustang; on another, he beat a man to death with a library book. And then there was that time Wick slaughtered three men in a bar with a pencil, a feat that his fellow killers can’t seem to stop talking about. Wherever Wick goes, folks die.

headline: Not Your Daddy’s Freud
abstract: A new generation of analysts and patients is embracing the father of psychoanalysis – in magazines and memes and many hours on the couch.
lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2020, Ilan Zechory stepped down as president of Genius, the annotation site he founded with two friends from Yale. After more than a decade at the start-up, he could have been forgiven for taking a break.

headline: In a Brother Act With Putin, Xi Reveals China’s Fear of Containment
abstract: Instead of focusing on a solution to the war in Ukraine, the Chinese leader’s visit to Moscow reinforced China and Russia’s shared opposition to American dominance.
lead_paragraph: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, flew into Moscow this week cast by Beijing as its emissary for peace in Ukraine. His summit with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, however, demonstrated that his priority remains shoring up ties with Moscow to gird against what he sees as a long campaign by the United States to hobble China’s ascent.

headline: Los Angeles schools remain closed on Wednesday for a labor strike.
abstract: Classrooms in Los Angeles sat vacant again on Wednesday morning, as tens of thousands of teachers and employees in the nation’s second-largest school district continued a three-day strike that has left some families blindsided and scrambling for child care.
lead_paragraph: Classrooms in Los Angeles sat vacant again on Wednesday morning, as tens of thousands of teachers and employees in the nation’s second-largest school district continued a three-day strike that has left some families blindsided and scrambling for child care.

headline: Los Angeles School Workers Are on Strike, and Parents Say They Get It
abstract: Both parents and the striking school district employees are on the same side of the economic divide in one of the nation’s most expensive cities.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Since Tuesday, Diana Cruz has juggled her stay-at-home job as an executive assistant with the care of her children after the Los Angeles school strike forced their classes to be canceled for three days.

headline: A 90-Year-Old Tortoise Named Mr. Pickles Is a New Dad of Three
abstract: The radiated tortoise is the oldest animal at the Houston Zoo. He has been with his partner, Mrs. Pickles, since she arrived in 1996. The mom and hatchlings are doing fine.
lead_paragraph: The oldest animal at the Houston Zoo, a radiated tortoise born nearly a century ago, is finally a father.

headline: The A.I. Chatbots Have Arrived. Time to Talk to Your Kids.
abstract: Artificial intelligence can make adults nervous, but experts say exploring it as a family is the best way to understand its pros and cons.
lead_paragraph: The race is on. Companies are pouring billions of dollars into powerful online chatbots and finding new ways to integrate them into our daily lives.

headline: My New Boyfriend Offered to Pay Off My Credit Card Debt. Help!
abstract: A reader doing battle with 25 percent annual interest is tempted by her boyfriend’s offer of an interest-free loan, but she worries it may be inappropriate to accept.
lead_paragraph: I started dating a new guy two months ago. Things have been going very well. I also have $5,000 in credit card debt that I am working hard to pay down. The subject came up when he asked me why I always use a debit card. (I don’t want to add a penny to my credit card balance.) He comes from a very wealthy family; I do not. Out of the blue, he offered to pay off my entire balance in exchange for a zero-interest loan that I could repay to him over time. This is obviously attractive compared with the 25 percent interest I now pay. But yikes! This is huge. Is it wildly inappropriate that I am entertaining his offer?

headline: A Stage Adaptation of ‘Smash’ Is Setting Its Sights on Broadway
abstract: Producers including Steven Spielberg have been exploring several possible incarnations of the decade-old TV series. Now they have a plan.
lead_paragraph: A long-discussed stage musical version of the television series “Smash” is finally coming to Broadway … but fans are going to have to wait a bit more.

headline: Behind the Story: Can U.F.W. Make a Comeback?
abstract: The United Farm Workers union hopes a California law can help it regain lost influence.
lead_paragraph: Decades after Cesar Chavez made the United Farm Workers a powerhouse in California’s fields, the union has lost much of its clout.

headline: A Pouf for Every Living Room
abstract: The eternally useful furniture piece is available in new, unusually pleasing forms.

headline: Uganda Passes Strict Anti-Gay Bill That Imposes Death Penalty for Some
abstract: The legislation, which now goes to the president, also calls for life in prison for anyone engaging in gay sex. Policies to stifle L.G.B.T.Q. rights have been on the rise in several African nations.
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers in Uganda have passed a sweeping anti-gay law that can bring punishments as severe as the death penalty — the culmination of a long-running campaign to criminalize homosexuality and target L.G.B.T.Q. people in the conservative nation in East Africa.

headline: In Chicago Mayor’s Race, a Former Teacher Rises With Union Support
abstract: Brandon Johnson, a county commissioner who once taught in struggling neighborhoods, soared in the polls after an endorsement and donations from the Chicago Teachers Union.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Brandon Johnson had a problem. In a crowded Chicago mayoral race full of established liberal politicians — a sitting congressman, the incumbent mayor, two City Council members — many voters had never heard of Mr. Johnson, a county commissioner from the West Side.

headline: Appeals Court Orders Trump Lawyer to Hand Over Records in Documents Inquiry
abstract: The ruling compelling the lawyer, M. Evan Corcoran, to turn over documents came after a lightning round of appeals court filings overnight.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court ruled on Wednesday that a lawyer representing former President Donald J. Trump in the investigation into his handling of classified material had to answer a grand jury’s questions and give prosecutors documents related to his legal work.

headline: U.S. Organ Transplant System, Troubled by Long Wait Times, Faces an Overhaul
abstract: The Biden administration announced a plan to modernize how patients are matched to organs, seeking to shorten wait times, address racial inequities and reduce deaths.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration announced on Wednesday that it would seek to break up the network that has long run the nation’s organ transplant system, as part of a broader modernization effort intended to shorten wait times, address racial inequities and reduce the number of patients who die while waiting.

headline: What if ‘The Daily Show’ Used Guest Hosts Permanently?
abstract: Fill-ins for Trevor Noah have shown how exciting the lack of a permanent replacement could be. It’s an option with an illustrious history in television.
lead_paragraph: For two months, Comedy Central has conducted something of a public audition. Nine different guest hosts have each taken over “The Daily Show” for a week, including Chelsea Handler, Wanda Sykes, Leslie Jones, Hasan Minhaj, Sarah Silverman and, currently, the former Democratic Senator Al Franken. Who should get the job?

headline: The Making of ‘Daisy Jones & the Six’
The I.C.C.’s Arrest Warrant for Putin is More Than ‘Just Symbolic’
abstract: A different way to think about justice & accountability
lead_paragraph: The International Criminal Court issued an arrest warrant last Friday that accused Russia’s president, Vladimir Putin, and its commissioner of children’s rights, Maria Lvova-Belova, of unlawfully deporting Ukrainian children to Russia.

headline: ‘Ted Lasso,’ Season 3
Crisp Beef Sambuus, Honeycomb Bread and More Ramadan Recipes
abstract: Ifrah F. Ahmed brought us new recipes for the holiday, and we have lots more for suhoor and iftar.
lead_paragraph: Hello all, New York Times Food reporter Julia Moskin here filling in for the vacationing Melissa Clark this week. (Next week will bring Tejal Rao to the dance floor, and then Melissa will be back.)

headline: The Truth About the Internet’s Favorite Stress Hormone
abstract: Cortisol gets a bad rap, but it’s not so clear-cut.
lead_paragraph: Maybe you can’t sleep. Or you sleep too much. Maybe you keep breaking out, or getting sick. Perhaps your stomach bloats, your skin sags, you feel shaky. Maybe you can’t focus, eat or get rid of the tension in your spine.

headline: Oumuamua Was a Comet After All, a Study Suggests
abstract: Astronomers offer “a surprisingly simple explanation” for the curious behavior of the interstellar visitor in 2017.
lead_paragraph: Was it alien space junk? A wandering interstellar asteroid? Or a weird comet from another sun?

headline: DNA From Beethoven’s Hair Unlocks Medical and Family Secrets
abstract: By analyzing seven samples of hair said to have come from Ludwig van Beethoven, researchers debunked myths about the revered composer while raising new questions about his life and death.
lead_paragraph: It was March 1827 and Ludwig van Beethoven was dying. As he lay in bed, wracked with abdominal pain and jaundiced, grieving friends and acquaintances came to visit. And some asked a favor: Could they clip a lock of his hair for remembrance?

headline: PacWest Bank Taps Credit Lines After 20% Drop in Deposits
abstract: The Los Angeles lender, which has come under scrutiny amid worries about midsize banks, said withdrawals had “stabilized.” It also expressed confidence in its ability to raise cash.
lead_paragraph: Pacific Western Bank said on Wednesday that customers had withdrawn 20 percent of their deposits since the start of the year, providing one of the first official accounts of the unease that has engulfed smaller lenders after Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank collapsed nearly two weeks ago.

headline: How Colleen Hoover Rose to Rule the Best-Seller List
What Fed Rate Increases Mean for Mortgages, Credit Cards and More
abstract: Savers will benefit and borrowers can expect to pay more on credit cards, student loans and other forms of debt.
lead_paragraph: As the Federal Reserve has consistently lifted its key interest rate over the past year, Americans have seen the effects on both sides of the household ledger: Savers benefit from higher yields, but borrowers pay more.

headline: How the Banking Crisis Has Had the Same Effect as a Fed Rate Increase
abstract: Some analysts say that the banking industry tumult has slowed the economy as banks pull back on lending.
lead_paragraph: As the Federal Reserve on Wednesday raised interest rates by a quarter-point, Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, noted that the recent turmoil in the banking industry is likely to have a similar effect as a rate increase, namely by slowing the economy.

headline: In Testy Exchanges, Johnson Vows He Didn’t Intend to Mislead Parliament
abstract: Boris Johnson told a powerful committee that his statements over parties at his office were “made in good faith.” His political future may be at stake.
lead_paragraph: Facing a hearing that could curtail his political career, Britain’s former prime minister Boris Johnson denied lying to Parliament on Wednesday, but under sharp questions from lawmakers struggled to justify some of the misleading statements he made about lockdown-busting parties held in Downing Street.

headline: Macron Denounces Violent Protests, Warning Against ‘Excesses’
abstract: President Emmanuel Macron of France, in his first remarks since pushing through a rise in the retirement age, was firm and unapologetic.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — President Emmanuel Macron, addressing the French people for the first time since the tumultuous passing of a law that raises the retirement age to 64 from 62, denounced violent protests and said he would not tolerate their threat to the republic.

headline: My Son Is in Prison Again. What Do I Owe Him?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the obligations parents have to their adult children.
lead_paragraph: I am 72 and retired, and have an 81-year-old husband who has health challenges. My youngest child, now 33, was recently incarcerated for the third time. I have four older children who are all thriving — one, ironically, works for a nonprofit law center seeking to reform the criminal-(in)justice system. My incarcerated son is an addict, has lied to me consistently since childhood and offended against a family member as a teenager. During a previous incarceration, he gave my phone number to a fellow inmate, who tried to extort money from me through his wife.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned, this article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Scroll no further if you haven’t solved it yet.

headline: The Times Switches to C.D.C. Covid Data, Ending Daily Collection
abstract: As local data sources become less reliable, The Times will instead report information collected by the C.D.C. on its virus tracking pages.
lead_paragraph: After more than three years of daily reporting on the number of Covid-19 cases and deaths in every county in the United States, The New York Times is ending its Covid data-gathering operation. The Times will continue to publish its Covid tracking pages for the United States, only now they will be based on the latest information available from the federal government, not the Times’s data set.

headline: Geothermal Power, Cheap and Clean, Could Help Run Japan. So Why Doesn’t It?
abstract: For decades, new plants have been blocked by powerful local interests, the owners of hot spring resorts, that say the sites threaten a centuries-old tradition.
lead_paragraph: A treasured getaway for travelers in Japan is a retreat to one of thousands of hot spring resorts nestled in the mountains or perched on scenic coasts, some of which have been frequented for centuries.

headline: Grand Jury Hearing Trump Evidence Did Not Meet Wednesday
abstract: While prosecutors have signaled that an indictment of the former president is likely, its specific timing remains unclear, and grand juries conduct their work in secret.
lead_paragraph: The Manhattan grand jury that has been hearing evidence about Donald J. Trump’s involvement with a hush-money payment to a porn star did not meet on Wednesday, according to two people with knowledge of the matter, meaning that any indictment of the former president would come Thursday at the earliest.

headline: U.K. Lawmakers Approve Key Measure of Northern Ireland Trade Deal
abstract: An important element of the agreement known as the Windsor Framework, a Brexit provision negotiated with the European Union, was roundly endorsed in the British Parliament.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — British lawmakers on Wednesday voted overwhelmingly in favor of a key component of a long-awaited deal on Northern Ireland trade rules, an emphatic victory for Prime Minister Rishi Sunak as he tries to resolve one of the most vexing legacies of Britain’s exit from the European Union.

headline: On Paris Streets, Anti-Macron Protests Take On a Hint of Menace
abstract: Peaceful solidarity alternates with the threat of violence, and all of France waits to see which way the standoff will turn.
lead_paragraph: During the French Revolution, the Place de la Concorde, the sprawling cobblestone square across the Seine from the National Assembly, was known as Revolutionary Square — the place where the newfound power of the street paraded on full display, in all its glory and horror.

headline: Track Covid-19 in the U.S.
abstract: Track the virus in your area, and get the latest state and county data on hospitalizations, cases, deaths, tests and vaccinations.
lead_paragraph: Track the virus in your area, and get the latest state and county data on hospitalizations, cases, deaths, tests and vaccinations.

headline: Track Covid-19 in Places Important to You
abstract: Build your own dashboard to track the virus in places across the United States.
lead_paragraph: Build your own dashboard to track the virus in places across the United States.

headline: ‘The Mandalorian’ Season 3, Episode 4 Recap: Out of the Nest
abstract: This week filled in some of Baby Yoda’s back story and offered yet another thrilling aerial chase. Then another.
lead_paragraph: One aspect of the Baby Yoda special effect that has been hard to get used to is how weightless the character often seems. Granted, the little guy is … well, a little guy. But whenever Grogu jumps around or Din picks him up, it feels a bit like one of those TV scenes where someone pretends to drink out of an empty coffee cup. It disrupts the suspension of disbelief, if only for a moment.

headline: Political leaders are keeping a low profile on the school labor dispute.
abstract: The mayor of Los Angeles, Karen Bass, has avoided taking sides over the three-day Los Angeles Unified School District strike, and California’s governor, Gavin Newsom, has not intervened.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles is an outlier among the nation’s biggest cities: Unlike the District of Columbia, Chicago and New York, its mayor does not control the schools.

headline: Britain defends supplying Ukraine with weapons containing depleted uranium.
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia falsely claimed the material had a “nuclear component.” Many armies, including Russia’s, use it in weapons.
lead_paragraph: Britain on Wednesday defended its decision to supply Ukraine with weapons made with depleted uranium, a day after President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia falsely claimed the material had a “nuclear component.”

headline: Biden Plan to Cut Billions in Medicare Fraud Ignites Lobbying Frenzy
abstract: The Biden administration has proposed changes to how it would pay private Medicare Advantage plans.
lead_paragraph: “How’s the knee?” one bowler asked another across the lanes. Their conversation in a Super Bowl ad focused on a Biden administration proposal that one bowler warned another would “cut Medicare Advantage.”

headline: How Best to Protect Bank Customers?
abstract: Readers discuss the recent bank failures and how banks are regulated. Also: Prosecuting Donald Trump; gawking like a tourist; funding public libraries.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: With Films Like ‘Inside,’ One Actor Does the Heavy Lifting
abstract: Filmmakers behind movies that place one character in one location discuss the challenges this type of project brings.
lead_paragraph: By reducing their cinematic tool kit to only a few essentials, the directors of movies where one character is confined to a single interior space can stretch the audience’s imagination.

headline: Ship Owned by U.S. Navy Tips Over at Edinburgh Port, Injuring Dozens
abstract: A research vessel once owned by the Microsoft co-founder Paul G. Allen and now by the U.S. Navy became dislodged while docked. The cause of the accident was under investigation.
lead_paragraph: A research ship owned by the U.S. Navy toppled onto its side while at dock in Edinburgh on Wednesday, leaving dozens of people injured.

headline: For This Experimental Festival, Bring Your Swimsuit and Dancing Shoes
abstract: The Borealis experimental music festival in Norway has become a space for lively exploration in a famously self-serious field.
lead_paragraph: BERGEN, Norway — Little could be predicted about a premiere by the young experimental Norwegian-Tamil composer Mira Thiruchelvam. But it was held at a fjord-facing heated pool, so the presenter had a suggestion: Bring a swimsuit.

headline: Germany Pushes for Exception in Law Banning Combustion Engines
abstract: Berlin and Brussels are scrambling for a solution after Germany calls for allowing cars to run on synthetic fuels. The move could endanger the E.U.’s climate goals.
lead_paragraph: Germany is negotiating with the European Union to win an exception to the proposed 2035 ban on internal combustion engines to permit cars to run on carbon-neutral synthetic fuels, the country’s Transportation Ministry said on Wednesday.

headline: F.A.A. Issues Safety Alert After Runway Near Misses
abstract: After a series of high-profile episodes at major airports, the Federal Aviation Administration has taken steps in recent months to address airport safety.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Aviation Administration on Wednesday called on airlines to exercise “continued vigilance” after a string of high-profile near misses on runways, including at Kennedy International Airport in New York in January.

headline: Seven Ideas to Prevent the Next Bank Crisis
abstract: It’s time for some fresh thinking.
lead_paragraph: If there’s ever been a topic about which fresh thinking is sorely needed, it’s how to fix the banks so they stop doing what they’ve been doing lately. It’s worth casting the net wide to include even ideas that aren’t fully developed or that are politically unrealistic.

headline: A Wine Vintage Takes a Break From Climate Change
abstract: After years of higher temperatures, kabinett riesling producers have a vintage that seems like a throwback to the time when growers battled to ripen grapes. Kabinett lovers rejoice.
lead_paragraph: Discussions of recent vintages often center on the challenges posed by the climate crisis. Wine has been a leading indicator of how the world is changing, whether you measure by intense heat, drought or once-rare disasters that now seem to occur regularly, like spring frosts, summer hail and forest fires.

headline: Denver Student Shoots 2 School Administrators, Police Say
abstract: The 17-year-old student, who was later found dead, had been under a safety plan that required he be searched before entering the school.
lead_paragraph: Update: High school shooting puts focus on safety plans.

headline: William A. Wulf, Pioneering Computer Scientist, Dies at 83
abstract: One of the first people to receive a graduate degree in the field, Dr. Wulf helped to adapt an early Pentagon communications web into the network that eventually grew into the internet.
lead_paragraph: William A. Wulf, a pioneering researcher, entrepreneur and policymaker in computer science, who helped adapt an early Pentagon communications web into the network that grew into the internet, died on March 10 in Charlottesville, Va. He was 83.

headline: The Inevitability of Ice Spice
abstract: A conversation about the ubiquitous Bronx rapper’s rise, and her boosts from the meme universe.
lead_paragraph: It was only last August — seven months ago! — that Ice Spice became seemingly ubiquitous with “Munch (Feelin’ U),” a casually devastating burn of a would-be suitor. Then an emerging rapper from, or more accurately adjacent to, the Bronx drill scene, she’s had a rapid ascent to a contemporary version of pop stardom. She’s now in the Top 5 of the Billboard Hot 100 with “Boy’s a Liar Pt. 2,” a collaboration with the equally TikTok-friendly PinkPantheress. And she recently released her debut EP, “Like..?”

headline: Seven takeaways from a big day for the Fed.
abstract: By raising interest rates a quarter-point, the Federal Reserve signaled that it was continuing to fight inflation, but it was holding off an aggressive move that might spook investors.
lead_paragraph: Here are a few of the key points from the Federal Reserve’s latest interest rate decision and comments from Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, at his post-meeting news conference:

headline: Raphael Mechoulam, ‘Father of Cannabis Research,’ Dies at 92
abstract: His work helped break down the chemical structures of THC, the psychoactive compound in marijuana, to figure out how cannabis makes users high.
lead_paragraph: Raphael Mechoulam, a pioneering Israeli chemist who is credited with opening the field of cannabis science after identifying the structure and function of the key compounds of cannabis, died on March 9 at his home in Jerusalem. He was 92.

headline: How a $100 Bet Saved Our Relationship
abstract: At 40, he was desperately embarrassed by his overprotective mother. Until a playful deal paved the way for a healthy set of boundaries.
lead_paragraph: Mark Jason Williams and his mom often butted heads on two issues: She was uncomfortable when he brought up anything about being gay, and he was tired of her incessantly talking about how he survived childhood cancer.

headline: Fed Raises Interest Rates a Quarter of a Point
abstract: Jerome H. Powell said that the Federal Reserve raised interest rates to combat inflation amid turmoil in the banking system.
lead_paragraph: Jerome H. Powell said that the Federal Reserve raised interest rates to combat inflation amid turmoil in the banking system.

headline: 14 Easy Breakfast Ideas to Jump-Start Your Mornings
abstract: You’re just one recipe away from a better day.
lead_paragraph: It can be difficult, if not impossible, to come up with rousing breakfast options when you’ve just been, well, roused from sleep. And while buttered toast, yogurt with an artfully arranged serving of berries or cereal haphazardly poured into a bowl can get you out the door, they’re not exactly the most exciting fare. We here at New York Times Cooking hope the following recipes can help invigorate your routine, making those early morning hours something to look forward to as you drift to sleep. Who knows? Maybe they’ll even make you a morning person.

headline: Rising Rate of Drug Shortages Is Framed as a National Security Threat
abstract: A Senate homeland security committee examined growing health care shortages amid reports of rationing within hospitals.
lead_paragraph: An increase in shortages of inexpensive yet critical medications is forcing hospitals to make “horrible” choices and is amounting to a national security threat, according to a report and testimony at a Senate homeland security hearing on Wednesday.

headline: Forged After a Tumultuous Era, World Golf Championships Fade in Another
abstract: A match play event in Texas may be the last W.G.C. event, ending an international competition that preceded golf’s high-rolling present.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Texas — It was not all that long ago — Tom Kim, after all, is only 20 years old — but before Kim emerged as one of the PGA Tour’s wunderkinds-in-progress, he would watch the World Golf Championships.

headline: N.B.A. ‘Bad Boy’ Wants Players to Do as He Says, Not as His Teams Did
abstract: Joe Dumars was on the 1980s Detroit Pistons teams known for their hard fouls. But players and coaches who step out of line today can expect fines and suspensions — from him.
lead_paragraph: Joe Dumars chuckled at his desk in Midtown Manhattan as framed portraits of links to the N.B.A.’s past — Bill Russell, Wilt Chamberlain and Gus Williams — loomed behind him.

headline: Britain’s Prince William thanks Poland’s president for supporting Ukraine.
abstract: He met with President Andrzej Duda on the second day of his visit to Poland.
lead_paragraph: Prince William of Britain met with President Andrzej Duda of Poland on Thursday during a two-day visit to Poland intended to highlight Britain’s support for Ukraine.

headline: Michigan Democrats Set to Repeal Law That Hampered Unions
abstract: A state is rolling back a so-called right-to-work law for the first time in decades, as depleted unions must now relearn how to bolster their ranks.
lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, Western Michigan’s food and commercial workers union has been in a defensive crouch after Republicans made union membership optional in a state once synonymous with organized labor. The union shifted from expansion and organizing to just trying to hold down attrition as workers opted out of paying their dues.

headline: Tyger Campbell Is the Calm as U.C.L.A. Storms Into the Sweet 16
abstract: The senior guard, whom the Hall of Famer Bill Walton called “one of my favorite all-time Bruins,” has become one of the most recognizable faces in college basketball.
lead_paragraph: A season was on the line. The N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament was at full throttle and Northwestern had melted a 14-point deficit to 3 when Tyger Campbell, the 5-foot-11 U.C.L.A. senior point guard, drove the lane and was knocked to the floor by a hard foul.

headline: A Chew Toy for Dogs Provokes a Spirited Supreme Court Argument
abstract: The justices differed about whether the toy, shaped like a bottle of Jack Daniel’s, violated the distiller’s trademark rights or was protected by the First Amendment.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a lively and lighthearted argument on Wednesday, the Supreme Court considered the fate of the Bad Spaniels Silly Squeaker, a chew toy for dogs that looks a lot like a bottle of Jack Daniel’s, with the addition of some potty humor.

headline: Former Iran Hostages Are Divided on Jimmy Carter and a Sabotage Claim
abstract: A report about a covert effort to delay their release until after the 1980 presidential election drew anger, resignation and disbelief from the survivors of the crisis.
lead_paragraph: They are the last survivors of an international crisis that hobbled Jimmy Carter’s presidency and may have cost him re-election. Many are now in their 80s.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing: U.S. Raises Interest Rates
abstract: Also, China and Russia grow closer and the U.S. waits for news of a possible Donald Trump indictment.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Federal Reserve raised interest rates by a quarter-point as officials tried to balance the risk of runaway inflation with the threat of turmoil in the banking system.

headline: Meet the Lonely New York Progressive Defending TikTok
abstract: Representative Jamaal Bowman of New York says the drive to ban TikTok stems from anti-China “hysteria.” His Democratic colleagues disagree.
lead_paragraph: Of TikTok’s 150 million American users, there may be none more valuable to the embattled platform right now than Representative Jamaal Bowman of New York.

headline: Rare Coin, Minted by Brutus to Mark Caesar’s Death, Is Returned to Greece
abstract: The gold coin, which dates from 42 B.C. and is valued at $4.2 million, is thought to have been looted from a field near where an army loyal to Brutus camped during the struggle for control of Rome.
lead_paragraph: A rare and ancient gold coin that morbidly celebrates the stabbing death of Julius Caesar was returned this week to Greek officials by investigators in New York who had determined it was looted and fraudulently put up for sale at auction in 2020.

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The DeSantis Foreign Policy: Hard Power, but With a High Bar
abstract: The Florida governor has never been the internationalist that some old-guard Republicans wanted or imagined him to be. A close reading of his record reveals how he might lead the U.S. abroad.
lead_paragraph: When Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida made headlines recently by undercutting U.S. support for Ukraine, Republican hawks, many of whom cling to him as their only hope to defeat former President Donald J. Trump, wondered if they had misread him as an ideological ally.

headline: Fox Argues Top Executives Weren’t Involved in Voter Fraud Broadcasts
abstract: Lawyers for the company, which faces a $1.6 billion defamation lawsuit, are pushing for a judge to rule in their favor before a trial.
lead_paragraph: WILMINGTON, Del. — Fox Corporation executives, including Rupert and Lachlan Murdoch, had no direct involvement in what aired on the company’s cable news channels, and therefore their company should not be found liable in a $1.6 billion defamation case, lawyers for Fox argued Wednesday in a Delaware court.

headline: Norfolk Southern to Provide Financial Support After Derailment, C.E.O. Says
abstract: Alan Shaw told Congress his rail company would create a medical compensation fund and a property assurance program to help residents of East Palestine, Ohio, the site of last month’s accident.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The chief executive of Norfolk Southern told Congress on Wednesday that his company would create programs to provide long-term financial support to residents of East Palestine, Ohio, where one of its trains carrying hazardous materials careened off the tracks seven weeks ago and ignited a fire.

headline: Online Troll Named Microchip Tells of Sowing ‘Chaos’ in 2016 Election
abstract: The defendant in the unusual trial, Douglass Mackey, and the pseudonymous witness collaborated to beat Hillary Clinton. They met for the first time in a Brooklyn courtroom.
lead_paragraph: The two social media influencers teamed up online years ago.

headline: Powell and Yellen Suggest Need to Review Regulations After Bank Failures
abstract: Proposals for more scrutiny of the financial sector are meeting resistance from industry and Congress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two of the nation’s top economic policymakers on Wednesday said they were focused on determining how the failure of Silicon Valley Bank had happened and suggested changes to federal regulation and oversight might be needed to prevent future runs on American banks.

headline: Can’t Read? Here’s a ‘Barefoot College’ for You.
abstract: This is a campus that trains even illiterate people in job skills, while messing with people’s heads.
lead_paragraph: TILONIA, India — It’s the Harvard of rural India, minus wingtips or heels: a 50-year-old institution called Barefoot College that offers lessons for empowering people worldwide. Maybe even in America.

headline: Zelensky Makes Morale-Boosting Trip to Bakhmut
abstract: The Ukrainian leader also condemned a deadly Russian missile attack against an apartment building in Zaporizhzhia.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, made a rare and defiant trip near the front line on Wednesday, personally thanking soldiers who have been fighting in the devastated eastern city of Bakhmut, which has become a potent symbol of Ukrainian resistance.

headline: Centuries of Stargazing Leave Jesuit Names Written in the Heavens
abstract: The latest list of approved labels for asteroids includes nods to three more scholars of the order, as well as a pope, challenging the idea that science and religion make awkward partners.
lead_paragraph: Centuries after the Holy See muzzled Roman Catholic stargazers for questioning the centrality of the Earth in the cosmos, Jesuit astronomers from the Vatican’s in-house observatory are increasingly writing their names in the heavens.

headline: Trump May Face Prosecution. America Faces a Test.
abstract: We are called to endure what I call the inconvenience of the necessary, a point at which something is morally right but the political timing is problematic.
lead_paragraph: Of course, Donald Trump went to social media to speculate that he’d be arrested on Tuesday of this week and — big surprise — that turned out not to be true.

headline: ‘The Hunting Gun’ Review: Letters to Burn After Reading
abstract: Miki Nakatani and Mikhail Baryshnikov star in this meticulously handsome stage adaptation of Yasushi Inoue’s 1949 novella.
lead_paragraph: In a corner of a shallow pond, its dimly lit surface dotted with lily pads, a barefoot young woman crouches to light a stick of incense. It’s an elegant bit of stagecraft: The wisps of smoke waft low across the water as the woman meanders through it, splish-splashing softly, ankle-deep.

headline: Crypto Entrepreneur and Celebrity Promoters Face S.E.C. Charges
abstract: The agency charged Justin Sun with violations of securities law in a scheme involving the actress Lindsay Lohan and other celebrities.
lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced charges on Wednesday against a prominent cryptocurrency entrepreneur and a group of celebrities who promoted his ventures, including the actress Lindsay Lohan.

headline: Prosecutors Drop Charges Against Former ‘Rick and Morty’ Actor
abstract: The animated show severed ties with Justin Roiland, one of its co-creators, in January after reports that he faced charges of domestic abuse.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors in California dismissed domestic abuse charges against Justin Roiland, a co-creator and former star of the animated comedy “Rick and Morty,” after determining that there was not enough evidence to prove them in court, the Orange County District Attorney’s Office said on Wednesday.

headline: Sex, Lies and … Trump. What More Can You Ask For?
abstract: Things are getting Stormy.
lead_paragraph: One thing we can be sure of: If this Stormy Daniels thing hurts Donald Trump politically, it will be for reasons having nothing whatsoever to do with sex.

headline: DeSantis Calls Putin a ‘War Criminal,’ Clarifying Earlier Comment on Ukraine
abstract: The Florida governor and presumed G.O.P. presidential candidate previously described the Russia-Ukraine conflict as a “territorial dispute” and did not mention the Russian president.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida this week clarified his description of the Russian invasion of Ukraine as a “territorial dispute” and said that Vladimir V. Putin, the Russian president, was a “war criminal” who should be “held accountable.”

headline: Wyoming Judge Temporarily Blocks the State’s New Abortion Ban
abstract: Wyoming’s Constitution guarantees a right to make individual health care decisions. The new ban attempts to circumvent that right by declaring that abortion is not health care.
lead_paragraph: Abortion will remain legal in Wyoming — at least temporarily — after a judge on Wednesday ordered that a newly enacted ban be blocked until further court proceedings in a lawsuit challenging it.

headline: Corrections: March 23, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, March 23, 2023.
lead_paragraph: A chart with an article on Wednesday about a rise in the stock market as investors awaited a decision on interest rates from the Federal Reserve  mislabeled the annual pace of single-family home sales in February. It was an increase of 14.5 percent, as the chart correctly showed, not a decrease.

headline: A Water System So Broken That One Pipe Leaks 5 Million Gallons a Day
abstract: As a water shortage ballooned into a crisis in Jackson, Miss., the leak grew bigger and bigger, gouging out a swimming pool-size crater in the earth.
lead_paragraph: On an abandoned golf course, overgrown with shrubs and saw grass, you can hear the rushing water from 100 yards away.

headline: Collective Opinion
abstract: David Kwong calls us third wheels. Are we going to put up with that?
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Quotation of the Day: Baring Beethoven’s Secrets With Snips of DNA
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, March 23, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “They didn’t know how to react. Every day they say their name and people say, ‘Are you related to Ludwig van Beethoven?’”

headline: See One Historic Turkish Street Before and After the Earthquakes
abstract: The Times flew a drone over a street in Antakya’s Old City to show the places that were lost — among them, a barber shop, a historic church and doner kebab shops.
lead_paragraph: The Times flew a drone over a street in Antakya’s Old City to show the places that were lost — among them, a barber shop, a historic church and doner kebab shops.

headline: Kansas State Tops Michigan State in an Overtime Thriller
abstract: Markquis Nowell led the Wildcats with 20 points and 19 assists, which set a record for an N.C.A.A. tournament game. In another exciting finish, Gonzaga beat U.C.L.A. in the final seconds.
lead_paragraph: Kansas State plays in a city called Manhattan and features four players from New York City, so it seemed fitting that they were cheered like the hometown favorites during a thrilling overtime win over Michigan State, 98-93, in the men’s round of 16 at Madison Square Garden.

headline: The N.C.A.A. Once Avoided Las Vegas. Times, and Prospects, Have Changed.
abstract: Las Vegas will host a men’s basketball regional this week, the men’s Final Four in 2028 and numerous other college championships — all prompted by changes in how the N.C.A.A. has viewed the city.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — There was a time when the N.C.A.A. would have played men’s basketball tournament games on the moon before placing its marquee event in Las Vegas.

headline: In Spring, New Yorkers’ Thoughts Turn to Pickleball
abstract: Now that skating season is over, Wollman Rink in Central Park will be home to 14 courts of the fast-growing sport.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll find out what’s going on at Wollman Rink now that the skating season is over.

headline: The First 3-D Printed Rocket Fails Shortly After Launch
abstract: Relativity Space, a private company with ambitions for sending people to Mars, made it off the launchpad, but the vehicle experienced problems during the second stage of its flight.
lead_paragraph: Terran 1, a rocket designed and built by the company Relativity Space, suffered a failure shortly after lifting off from a launchpad in Cape Canaveral, Fla., late on Wednesday night. A demonstration mission, the rocket was not carrying people or a customer payload, and no one was hurt.

headline: New Video Shows Virginia Officers Overpowering and Punching Irvo Otieno in Jail Cell
abstract: The video was recorded several hours before previously released footage, which showed seven sheriff’s deputies pinning Mr. Otieno down for more than 11 minutes.
lead_paragraph: New surveillance video released on Wednesday shows a group of sheriff’s deputies rushing into Irvo Otieno’s jail cell in Henrico County, Va., and physically overpowering him, with one of them appearing to punch down multiple times before the officers carry his limp body out to a transport van.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Legal cases involving Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court ruled that a lawyer representing Donald Trump in an inquiry into his handling of classified materials had to answer a grand jury’s questions and give prosecutors a trove of documents related to his legal work for Trump. The ruling came after Trump sought an order to stop the lawyer, Evan Corcoran, from handing over documents to investigators.

headline: Officers Tackle Irvo Otieno in His Jail Cell
abstract: Surveillance video shows a group of sheriff’s deputies rushing into Irvo Otieno’s jail cell and overpowering him hours before his death.
lead_paragraph: Surveillance video shows a group of sheriff’s deputies rushing into Irvo Otieno’s jail cell and overpowering him hours before his death.

headline: Word of the Day: effusive
abstract: This word has appeared in 65 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word effusive has appeared in 65 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on April 28 in “How the Spice Girls’ Manufactured Girl Power Became Real” by Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Jennifer Harlan:

headline: Late Night Awaits Donald Trump’s Perp Walk
abstract: Jimmy Kimmel joked that a grand jury “decided to push the hearing to tomorrow to give Trump supporters time to iron their Confederate flags.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: For Argentina’s Champions, Back to Work Means Back to Earth
abstract: Lionel Messi and his Argentina teammates have reunited for the first time. Most are finding a day job feels different after you’ve won the World Cup.
lead_paragraph: When Alexis Mac Allister returned to his day job, he was greeted by a standing ovation, an Argentine flag and a set of strategically placed cannons that showered him with blue, white and gold glitter. His Premier League team, Brighton, had even gone to the trouble of commissioning a scale-model replica of the World Cup trophy for him to lift.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Poverty
abstract: What do you think this image is communicating?
lead_paragraph: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: TikTok Claims It’s Limiting Teen Screen Time. Teens Say It Isn’t.
abstract: This month, the company announced a new 60-minute “daily screen time limit” for users under 18. But for most young users, staying on the app takes just a few taps.
lead_paragraph: At the end of 2021, Ruby McMahon and some of her high school classmates decided to go “TikTok sober.” Ms. McMahon had gotten hooked on TikTok during the Covid-19 pandemic and regularly spent five hours a day on the app.

headline: $20,000 Pants … and Other Adventures in Men’s Luxury Resale!
abstract: Late-night appointments with Offset and Cardi B! Trading Rick Owens for Balenciaga! The secondhand trade in upmarket men’s wear is booming.
lead_paragraph: In a floor-through loft in SoHo one Friday night in January, Vincent Ferraro was selling luxury clothing. Sort of.

headline: Bank of England Raises Rates Again as Inflation Persists
abstract: Policymakers approved a quarter-point increase, to 4.25 percent, while affirming that British banks were “resilient.”
lead_paragraph: The Bank of England raised interest rates a quarter-point on Thursday, its 11th consecutive rate increase, a day after data showed that Britain’s inflation rate unexpectedly increased last month, providing an unwelcome setback in the central bank’s struggle against rapidly rising prices.

headline: 36 Hours in Johannesburg
abstract: Take a turn, or as South Africans say, a “short left,” and be rewarded in this modern, contradictory city.
lead_paragraph: Take a turn, or as South Africans say, a “short left,” and be rewarded in this modern, contradictory city.

headline: The Joy of Letting Loose
abstract: For a kid watching TV in the 1980s and ’90s, seeing grown-ups get weird meant that adulthood might not have to be a drag.
lead_paragraph: For a kid watching TV in the 1980s and ’90s, seeing grown-ups get weird meant that adulthood might not have to be a drag.

headline: How an Allergist Gets Through Allergy Season
abstract: We asked Dr. Shradha Agarwal, an allergist immunologist at Mount Sinai in New York City, for her best tips for quelling spring allergy symptoms.
lead_paragraph: We asked Dr. Shradha Agarwal, an allergist immunologist at Mount Sinai in New York City, for her best tips for quelling spring allergy symptoms.

headline: Poem: 88 Days
abstract: An awe-struck, awful, careening sensation of loss is held in place by the weight of language itself.
lead_paragraph: The force of grief is sublime, scattering certainty, reorganizing the world around the fresh absence of the dead. Anthony Robinson’s “88 Days” is a powerful poem, executed with absolute fidelity to that eviscerating feeling. Its technique is gravity: staid couplets, considered lines, confident imagery. That awe-struck, awful, careening sensation of loss is held in place by the weight of language itself. Selected by Anne Boyer

headline: A Couple Decided to Swap Their Family Home in Pennsylvania for a California Rental. Which One Did They Choose?
abstract: Wanting to be closer to their adult children, they moved west, knowing they would have to make some compromises to live near Malibu. Here’s what they found.
lead_paragraph: Wanting to be closer to their adult children, they moved west, knowing they would have to make some compromises to live near Malibu. Here’s what they found.

headline: Judge John on Hodgman on What Really Counts as a Hobby
abstract: A Scattergories play opens up a debate on what’s a genuine way to pass the time.
lead_paragraph: Matt writes: 15 years ago, I was playing Scattergories with some co-workers. I was close to winning. The category was “hobbies,” and the letter was T. I submitted “typing.” I was shut down, and my arguments were met with laughter. But surely if the letter had been W, “writing” would qualify! Can “typing” be considered a hobby?

headline: What Makes a City Great?
abstract: What’s wonderful about the city you live in or know best? How could it reinvent itself to make life for residents even better?
lead_paragraph: Do you live in or near a city? What do you like about it? What do you not like? What changes, large or small, might make life in this area better for its residents?

headline: Banks Can’t Be Trusted. A ‘Golden Share’ Might Help.
abstract: Saule Omarova, who was forced to withdraw her nomination as comptroller of the currency because she opposed loosening bank regulations, offers a creative solution to the banking mess.
lead_paragraph: I had the honor of being nominated by President Biden in 2021 to head the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, the top regulator of federally chartered banks. If confirmed, I would have been the first minority woman — an immigrant — to lead the 160-year-old agency.

headline: A Swashbuckling Pirate Pulled Into One Last Job
abstract: In “The Adventures of Amina al-Sirafi,” the first book in a new series by Shannon Chakraborty, a retired pirate gets an offer she can’t refuse.
lead_paragraph: There is a reason “one last job” remains such a popular and powerful subgenre. Watchers of the “Fast & Furious” movies, “Ocean’s Eleven” and Michael Mann’s “Heat” know: There is a built-in tension. Our heroes want to change but their skills, what’s given them a measure of success, are often the very things they must give up in order to become their better selves. What’s a rogue to do? Shannon Chakraborty’s latest novel, “The Adventures of Amina al-Sirafi,” the first in a new fantasy trilogy, leans enchantingly into the moral and spiritual dimensions of this choice.

headline: The Shameful Secret at the Heart of My War Reporting
abstract: I won awards covering Iraq, but my Iraqi colleague lost everything.
lead_paragraph: I first met Ali Hamdani in Baghdad in 2003, just months after the U.S.-led invasion of Iraq. He’d recently finished his medical school training, but instead of becoming a doctor, he started working with me and other foreign journalists. We covered the conflict together for years, and he was my guide as Iraq descended into all-out civil war. Ali saved my life on more than one occasion, at great personal risk to himself — and he’s become a dear friend.

headline: Liberal Professors Can Rescue the G.O.P.
abstract: Professors have to do a better job of exposing students to a rich intellectual tradition that stretches back to Edmund Burke and Adam Smith.
lead_paragraph: When conservative undergraduates look around for mentors these days, who do they find? Not conservative professors, at least not very often. Our ranks have been slowly vanishing since the 1980s. Instead, those students find organizers from the MAGA-verse who teach them how to own the libs. That’s who is instructing the next generation of Republican leaders, modeling how to act and think like good conservatives. It’s a squalid education, one that deepens their alienation from the university and guarantees that the next generation of elected officials will make Ron DeSantis’s war against higher education look tame.

headline: Attention, Travelers: Now Is the Best Time to Switch to eSIM
abstract: The digital version of the SIM card, included on many newer phones, is set to become prevalent. It also offers affordable cellular data abroad.
lead_paragraph: As vacation season looms, now is as good a time as ever to bite the bullet and become familiar with a smartphone feature that many of us have ignored for years: the eSIM, the digital version of the SIM card that carries your phone number.

headline: Where It’s Cheaper to Build Than Buy
abstract: The states where buying land and hiring a contractor to build a new house beats buying an existing one.
lead_paragraph: The last few years have been among the most challenging for home buyers. The pandemic blew up prices as demand for single-family homes grew. Today, inflated prices, high interest rates and few active listings continue to make finding and buying a house extremely difficult.

headline: Is 70 M.P.H. the New 65? Legislators Say N.Y. Roads Are Just Too Slow.
abstract: Sponsor cites better cars, better roads — and drivers accustomed to zipping along. But the data suggests raising the speed limit has fatal consequences.
lead_paragraph: GUILDERLAND, N.Y. — Standing outside the Guilderland Travel Plaza and waiving his right against self-incrimination, Ryan Lynch said what many drivers on the New York State Thruway have signaled for years: They can’t drive 65.

headline: Everything, Everywhere, in One Big Book
abstract: In “All the Knowledge in the World,” Simon Garfield recounts the history of the encyclopedia — a tale of ambitious effort, numerous errors and lots of paper.
lead_paragraph: According to Denis Diderot, perhaps the most famous encyclopedist of the 18th century, the goal of an encyclopedia is “to assemble all the knowledge scattered on the surface of the earth.”  More than 270 years later, the size of that task grows still, as new knowledge continues to be created. In “All the Knowledge in the World,” Simon Garfield offers a delightful curated sampling of what seekers before and after Diderot have tried to actualize.

headline: Dr. Sticks and the Return of the Splitter
abstract: Among the American League’s most promising young pitchers, Cleveland’s Triston McKenzie and Seattle’s Logan Gilbert stand out as Cy Young Award candidates.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Triston McKenzie and Logan Gilbert both dress a few lockers down from a surprise American League Cy Young Award winner. In the Cleveland Guardians’ clubhouse in Goodyear, Ariz., it is Shane Bieber, who won in 2020; in the Seattle Mariners’, in Peoria, it is Robbie Ray, who won for Toronto the next season. Neither had finished in the top three in voting before they won.

headline: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
abstract: This week’s properties are in the South Street Seaport area, on the Upper East Side and in Brooklyn Heights.
lead_paragraph: A one-bedroom, one-bath apartment with a balcony, an open living and dining area, a galley kitchen with Caesarstone countertops and a glass backsplash, a bedroom with a double closet and a bathroom with a tub in a 27-story doorman building with a laundry room, a parking garage and a community room. Bridget A. Schuy, BOND New York, 646-541-3076; bondnewyork.com

headline: College Sports Are a Treasure. Don’t Turn Them Into the Minor Leagues.
abstract: The best way to support student-athletes is to ensure that they are students first.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH BEND, Ind. — In a teary locker room this month, after the Notre Dame men’s basketball team ended its season with a close loss in the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament, the coach spoke not about lost opportunities on the court, but rather about the six master’s degrees (in addition to undergraduate degrees) that members of the team had earned, the lifelong friendships they had formed, and the invaluable lessons they had learned about leadership, teamwork and growing through adversity. The locker room is a classroom where the lesson that athletics can and should be part of a university’s educational mission is lived every day. Even Knute Rockne said that college athletics should be secondary to academics.

headline: In Memphis, Car Seizures Are a Lucrative and Punishing Police Tactic
abstract: Vehicle seizures have been used to combat street racing and other crimes, but critics say that even people not convicted of a crime have been left for months without their cars.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — As he drove to work on a summer afternoon in Memphis last year, Ralph Jones saw a woman on the sidewalk flagging him down. Thinking she was in distress or needed a ride, Mr. Jones said, he pulled over.

headline: Chatbot Start-Up Character.AI Valued at $1 Billion in New Funding Round
abstract: Founded by ex-Google employees, the Silicon Valley company is among the few start-ups poised to compete with OpenAI, the creator of ChatGPT.
lead_paragraph: Character.AI, a 16-month-old start-up that builds online chatbots, said on Thursday that it had raised $150 million in a recent funding round that valued the company at $1 billion.

headline: Women Are Still Stuck in ‘A Doll’s House’
abstract: It’s shocking that Ibsen’s 1879 play remains so shocking.
lead_paragraph: When Henrik Ibsen’s play “A Doll’s House” opened in 1879 at the Royal Theater in Copenhagen, it was an instant success — and an outrage to many. The story of Nora, a woman who walks out on her husband and three children, was considered scandalous in a country in which marriage was held as a sacred bond, and one that held women to exacting strictures.

headline: A Scoreless Wonder and a Master of the Sinker
abstract: Among the National League’s most promising young pitchers, Arizona’s Zac Gallen and San Francisco’s Logan Webb stand out as Cy Young Award candidates.
lead_paragraph: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — Zac Gallen had just been promoted to Class AA, and his first assignment for the Springfield Cardinals was to chart the pitches of a teammate. It was a routine task and Gallen was tired, but a coach gave him a tip: “You might want to pay attention to this.”

headline: What to Know About Today’s Congressional Hearing on TikTok
abstract: The Chinese-owned video app has become a battleground as the U.S. and China duel for tech leadership.
lead_paragraph: Shou Chew, the chief executive of TikTok, will testify before Congress for the first time on Thursday, in an appearance that is expected to reflect U.S. lawmakers’ escalating distrust of the short-form video app’s Chinese ownership.

headline: Double-Barreled Economic Threat Puts Congress on Edge
abstract: Republicans and Democrats disagree over how recent bank closures should impact the debt limit stalemate, and have taken divergent lessons from past economic crises.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 2008, an imminent collapse of the banking system consumed Congress before lawmakers delivered a bailout. Three years later, a debt limit crisis enveloped Washington and led to a series of spending cuts after a dangerous brush with default and a first-ever downgrade in the nation’s credit rating.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
abstract: This week’s homes are a five-bedroom in Larchmont, and a six-bedroom in Cherry Hill once owned by Muhammad Ali.
lead_paragraph: A five-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bath, renovated, 3,409-square-foot home with a living room that has an original brick fireplace and a secret door to an office behind a bookshelf; a bright eat-in kitchen with custom cabinets, a wine fridge, a six-burner Thermador stove with a pot filler and a quartz island with seating; a family room with sliding doors to the outdoors; an en suite primary bedroom with a walk-in closet, a double vanity with fog-free mirrors, a soaking tub, and a glass-stall steam shower with six shower heads; a mudroom; a laundry room with storage; a fenced yard; and a detached one-car garage with an electric car charger, on 0.13 acres. Joan Capaldi, Julia B. Fee Sotheby’s International Realty, 914-806-9965; sothebysrealty.com

headline: ‘Give Me an Abrams!’ Ukrainian Tank Commanders Grow Impatient.
abstract: For now, they are holding on with inferior Soviet-era tanks, but relish the idea of taking on the Russians with modern Western battle tanks.
lead_paragraph: OUTSKIRTS OF BAKHMUT, Ukraine — Large snowflakes drifted silently through the trees as two Soviet-era tanks roared to life and churned through the mud up the hill. It was daybreak on one of the last days of winter, and the tank commander and his deputy tramped through the snow checking on the men as they readied for battle.

headline: The South Carolina Player Taking Basketball to Girls in West Africa
abstract: “I’ve never coached anybody that comes with that much determination,” Coach Dawn Staley said of Laeticia Amihere.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — In the first two rounds of the women’s N.C.A.A. basketball tournament, it became clear why Dawn Staley calls Laeticia Amihere the most versatile player she has ever coached at South Carolina.

headline: Along the Volta, African Commandos Train to Battle Terrorists by Land and Sea
abstract: As terrorists move south through the Sahel, the Pentagon’s annual Flintlock exercise reinforced the rule of law in a region roiled by coups.
lead_paragraph: SOGAKOPE, Ghana — Troops clad in black jumped out of motorboats near a riverside resort and made their way along a wood-slat fence to their objective: a building where terrorists had seized a high-level government official.

headline: N.F.L. Teams Are Bullish on Cornerbacks and Bearish on Running Backs
abstract: Recent off-season deals also show that trades are hot, free-agent signings are not, and “bridge quarterback” is one of the greatest jobs ever.
lead_paragraph: The trade talks/ransom negotiations over Aaron Rodgers between the Jets and the Green Bay Packers, coupled with the icy contractual staring contest between Lamar Jackson and the Baltimore Ravens, have so thoroughly dominated the N.F.L. news cycle that it is easy to lose track of the dozens of trades, signings and releases that have taken place since the official start of the league’s new year on March 15.

headline: An Interior Designer Creates a Sea of Tranquillity in Greenwich Village
abstract: In his compact walk-up, Nicholas Obeid combines objects of his own design and flea-market finds to create an escape from the city below.
lead_paragraph: FIVE YEARS AGO, at the San Telmo flea market in Buenos Aires, the New York-based interior designer Nicholas Obeid saw a midcentury chandelier in perforated red metal that he admired but didn’t want to carry home on the plane. A year later, he was still thinking about that chandelier and, on his next trip, he was surprised to find the $70 piece right where he’d last seen it. (Obeid’s mother was born in Argentina, and he visits the country whenever he can.) Now rewired, it hangs in the kitchen of his Greenwich Village apartment, above a stainless steel baker’s rack. “I saw something similar on 1stDibs for thousands of dollars,” Obeid says. “Almost identical.”

headline: Migration Tops Agenda as Biden Visits Canada
abstract: As migration has swelled at the U.S.-Canada border, the two countries plan to announce a deal to allow them both to turn back asylum seekers.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Nearly every day at Roxham Road, people cross over from the United States into the arms of the Canadian police and ask for asylum.

headline: China’s Rise Relied on Ties to the West, Which Xi Is Now Loosening
abstract: The Chinese leader has edged ever closer to Russia, while distancing China from countries that have helped it develop over the past four decades.
lead_paragraph: In late 1978, China’s paramount leader, Deng Xiaoping, set in motion two major policy shifts that would change China and the world order in the decades to come. At a Communist Party meeting that December, the leadership declared that China would turn its focus from political struggle to economic development. Within days, China and the United States announced that they would establish diplomatic relations.

headline: Vocabulary in Context: Invasive Pythons
abstract: Test your vocabulary and reading comprehension with this quiz based on the Times article “Pythons, Invasive and Hungry, Are Making Their Way North in Florida.”
lead_paragraph: Test your vocabulary and reading comprehension with this quiz based on the Times article “Pythons, Invasive and Hungry, Are Making Their Way North in Florida.”

headline: Our Film Critic on Why He’s Done With the Movies
abstract: A.O. Scott discusses how American cinema has evolved over his 23 years at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: A.O. Scott started as a film critic at The New York Times in January of 2000. Next month he will move to the Book Review as a critic at large.

headline: Leader of Indian Party Opposing Modi Is Sentenced in Defamation Case
abstract: Rahul Gandhi, who leads the main opposition party, received a two-year sentence for a comment in 2019 criticizing Prime Minister Narendra Modi.
