lead_paragraph: Follow for the latest news on the expulsion of Rahul Gandhi from India’s Parliament.

headline: The Threat of TikTok
abstract: U.S. officials say TikTok is a national security risk. They’re trying to turn it into their advantage.
lead_paragraph: The platforms are so powerful, their names are verbs: Google, Uber, Instagram, Netflix.

headline: ‘The Five Devils’ Review: The Scent of the Past
abstract: Part queer love story, part supernatural psychodrama, the uncanny second feature by Léa Mysius follows a young girl with a magical sense of smell.
lead_paragraph: Vicky (Sally Dramé), the creepy kid at the center of “The Five Devils,” has a strange power: her sense of smell is so strong, she can track her mother, Joanne (Adèle Exarchopoulos), from dozens of yards away with her eyes closed; can detect the scent of chlorinated swimming-pool water and spilled coffee in the pages of an old journal. Smell is perhaps the most opaque of the five human senses; the one that’s hardest to put into words. No wonder it’s key to the uncanny intrigues of the film, part queer love story, part supernatural psychodrama, by the French director Léa Mysius.

headline: ‘The Lost King’ Review: A Royal Obsession
abstract: Sally Hawkins lights a fire under this droll dramedy about the search for the final resting place of Richard III.
lead_paragraph: Sally Hawkins is a gift, to directors and audiences alike. When she smiles, it’s a face-splitting beam, so contagious that we would likely love her even if she were playing a murderer. And while her character in “The Lost King” is firmly tethered to a dead man, she didn’t kill him: She’s trying to dig him up.

headline: ‘What the Hell Happened to Blood, Sweat & Tears?’ Review: What Goes Up
abstract: The rise and fall of a classic-rock band is chronicled (shakily) in this documentary.
lead_paragraph: What happened to Blood, Sweat & Tears, judging by this spurious, somewhat cranky documentary by John Scheinfeld, is that the band faced the unforeseen consequences of its own bad decisions.

headline: ‘Walk Up’ Review: Good Friends Make Bad Neighbors
abstract: Hong Sang-soo’s latest film traces the relationships in a small Seoul apartment building as they evolve and grow heavier with complications.
lead_paragraph: Just five months after the theatrical release of “The Novelist’s Film,” the fantastically prolific filmmaker Hong Sang-soo offers “Walk Up,” an equally spare and melancholy study of the small moments that define a life. A conversation falters. Another bottle is opened. Three people share drinks and their universe is completely reordered.

headline: ‘Ithaka’ Review: In Julian Assange They Trust
abstract: A frustrating new advocacy documentary about the WikiLeaks founder, with appearances by his father and wife, loses its footing on weak assertions and reporting.
lead_paragraph: Julian Assange’s legal travails began in 2010, when Swedish prosecutors ordered his detention on suspicion of rape and sexual coercion. To avoid being extradited to Stockholm, Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, jumped bail and took refuge in the Ecuadorean Embassy in London; today he’s in London’s Belmarsh Prison, fighting extradition to the United States on 17 counts of violating the Espionage Act. Yet “Ithaka,” a frustrating advocacy documentary directed by Ben Lawrence and produced by Assange’s brother Gabriel Shipton, argues that Assange’s most crucial trial is in the court of public opinion.

headline: ‘A Good Person’ Review: Zach Braff’s New Chapter
abstract: The filmmaker behind “Garden State” has created a fully drawn female character in Florence Pugh’s grieving addict. But this recovery drama often has too heavy a hand.
lead_paragraph: An interesting litmus test of the shift in our zeitgeist’s consideration of female characters — or of female agency at large — exists in the space between the release of Zach Braff’s “Garden State” in 2004 and the reconstituted consensus around the film in the next decade.

headline: ‘Nam June Paik: Moon Is the Oldest TV’ Review: Art Onscreen
abstract: A new documentary follows the ceaseless innovations of a man who made art out of television sets and found inspiration in disruption.
lead_paragraph: Nam June Paik died in 2006, one year before the first iPhone was released. Now that hand-held glowing screens have become as dominant as television once was, one misses that influential artist’s subversive spirit. But it’s on ample display in Amanda Kim’s new film “Nam June Paik: Moon Is the Oldest TV,” which shows how Paik forged novel avenues of expression and communication in the televisual era.

headline: A New Trio of Watches That Honors Breitling’s Founding Family
abstract: Each timepiece is named after the brand’s patriarchs, spanning three generations of craftsmen.
lead_paragraph: In 1884, a 24-year-old Léon Breitling opened a workshop in the Swiss Jura town of Saint-Imier, where he began obtaining patents for chronometric instruments. His pioneering creations — which ranged from a pocket-watch tachymeter for measuring a vehicle’s speed to table clocks with weeklong power reserves — were coveted for their technical precision. Léon’s son, Gaston, later expanded the business, developing an early wrist-worn chronograph that became popular among athletes and aviators. In 1932, Gaston’s 19-year-old son, Willy, took over the company and, in 1943, he launched the brand’s Premier collection, with its distinctive Arabic numerals and polished square buttons.

headline: ‘Reggie’ Review: Reggie Jackson on Himself, Racism and, Yes, Baseball
abstract: Jackson, a.k.a. Mr. October, was called a lot of things during his storied career with the Yankees. A new documentary goes beyond the nicknames.
lead_paragraph: Star athletes in America are often expected to have brash personalities. This delights or alienates fans to different degrees, and for different reasons. A star athlete with a brash personality who also happens to be Black is apt to infuriate a large and vociferous corner of fandom.

headline: Strikes, Marches and Clashes in France Amid Anger Over Pension Law
abstract: The tensions started when President Emmanuel Macron raised the retirement age to 64, and the anger shows no sign of abating.
lead_paragraph: Huge street protests and widespread strikes rocked France on Thursday as demonstrators put on a fierce display of resistance to a new law raising the retirement age and expressed fury at President Emmanuel Macron, who bypassed a full vote in Parliament to force the measure through.

headline: Markets Struggle to Decide Where Banking Rules Go From Here
abstract: Jerome Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, and Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said that more must be done to rein in banks. What that looks like is unclear.
lead_paragraph: U.S. banking regulators gave investors a lot to chew on yesterday. The Federal Reserve went ahead with a quarter-point increase in interest rates, signaling that, for now, it remained more worried about inflation than banking stability.

headline: What Would Ben Franklin Say? Artists Weigh the Dream of Democracy
abstract: In Philadelphia, the sun rises on a bold collaboration between two museums.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — It’s just a few blocks on Arch Street between the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts, the oldest art school and museum in the United States, and the African American Museum in Philadelphia, founded in 1976 to celebrate the achievements of African Americans from pre-colonial times to the current day. Yet rarely have visitors at one museum made the walk to the other. “How do we create this corridor between us?” posed Dejay Duckett, vice president of curatorial services at AAMP.

headline: ‘Star Trek: Picard’ Season 3, Episode 6 Recap: Night at the Museum
abstract: Geordi La Forge gets to right some wrongs, but first he has to make up with his daughter in an episode that doubles as a Callback Museum.
lead_paragraph: Geordi La Forge, through much of “Next Generation,” on some level needed rehabilitation. He was brilliantly portrayed by LeVar Burton, but he was also sometimes treated like a stereotype: a nerdy engineer who couldn’t get the girl and wasn’t given much else to do. In fact, his main love interest was Dr. Leah Brahms (Susan Gibney), whom he initially met as a hologram.

headline: Stop Treating Adolescent Girls as Emotionally Abnormal
abstract: Let’s approach adolescent mental health with concern, not panic.
lead_paragraph: In February, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention released a report titled the “Youth Risk Behavior Survey Data Summary & Trends Report: 2011-2021,” or Y.R.B.S. According to the C.D.C., “nearly 3 in 5 (57 percent) U.S. teen girls felt persistently sad or hopeless in 2021 — double that of boys” and “the highest level reported over the past decade.”

headline: Ali Krieger Is Calling It a Career. She Wants Wins on Her Way Out.
abstract: Krieger, 38, will retire after one final season with Gotham F.C. in the N.W.S.L. She is confident it will go better than the last one.
lead_paragraph: Since it began almost two decades ago, Ali Krieger’s soccer career has taken her more places than she can remember: dozens of countries, three World Cups and at least two operating rooms.

headline: What Does All This Rain Mean for California’s Drought?
abstract: Despite all the rain, experts are hesitant to say the drought is over.
lead_paragraph: As you’re well aware, California has had an extremely wet winter, replete with severe flooding, snowed-in mountain communities and a massive snowpack accumulating in the Sierra Nevada.

headline: From the Musician Weyes Blood, a Moonstone Heart Necklace
abstract: Plus: an exhibition of Stanley Whitney’s grid paintings, sculptural meditation accessories and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: Ulum Moab, a new resort about an hour’s drive from the Arches and Canyonlands national parks, opens next week, promising visitors a chance to maximize their time in southern Utah’s red rock country. Fifty safari-inspired tents — each with a king-size bed and queen-size pullout sofa — are scattered across 200 acres, just paces from Looking Glass Rock, south of Moab. Inside, adornments and amenities include woven rugs, Pendleton blankets, Aesop bath products and West Elm furnishings, as well as a cooling fan and a wood stove. But the idea is not to spend too much time inside, particularly when there’s complimentary yoga, stargazing, on-site hiking and evening s’mores by shared fire pits, not to mention canyon-side cocktails incorporating local flora such as sage, juniper and prickly pear. For those wanting to go farther afield, the resort can arrange mountain biking, white-water rafting, rock climbing and guided national park tours. Ulum Moab’s season runs from March 30 through Oct. 23, tents from $549, ulumresorts.com.

headline: Attempts to Ban Books Doubled in 2022
abstract: A new report from the American Library Association showed a spike in censorship efforts, with 1,269 attempts.
lead_paragraph: Efforts to ban books nearly doubled in 2022 over the previous year, according to a report published Thursday by the American Library Association. The organization tracked 1,269 attempts to ban books and other resources in libraries and schools, the highest number of complaints since the association began studying censorship efforts more than 20 years ago.

headline: Who Is Shou Chew, TikTok’s Chief Executive?
abstract: Shou Zi Chew is testifying for
lead_paragraph: Shou Chew, TikTok’s chief executive, is appearing for the first time on Thursday before Congress, as the solo witness in a hearing about the dangers of the video app. TikTok is owned by the Chinese internet giant ByteDance, which has prompted concerns that the app could share sensitive data from American users with the Chinese government.

headline: China Says It Will ‘Firmly Oppose’ Forced Sale of TikTok
abstract: China’s commerce ministry publicly rebuked the Biden administration’s efforts to push TikTok’s Chinese ownership to sell the app or face a possible ban in the United States.
lead_paragraph: China said it would oppose efforts by the United States to force a sale of TikTok, in a public rebuke of the Biden administration that leaves the app’s Chinese ownership stuck between orders from governments of the world’s two largest economies.

headline: National security is the prevailing theme of lawmakers’ questions.
abstract: Lawmakers of the House Energy and Commerce Committee pursued accountability and transparency from TikTok’s chief executive, Shou Chew, in a five-hour hearing on Thursday, accusing the company of keeping ties to the Chinese government and having harmful effects on children and teenagers.
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers of the House Energy and Commerce Committee pursued accountability and transparency from TikTok’s chief executive, Shou Chew, in a five-hour hearing on Thursday, accusing the company of keeping ties to the Chinese government and having harmful effects on children and teenagers.

headline: Seeking the Spirited, Mystical Jamaica Tourists Don’t See
abstract: A photographer’s journey through her native spiritual landscape of Jamaica, where Christian and Afro-centric traditions blend.
lead_paragraph: A photographer’s journey through her native spiritual landscape of Jamaica, where Christian and Afro-centric traditions blend.

headline: Why Do People Care That Sofia Coppola’s Daughter Was Grounded?
abstract: The internet can’t get enough of nepo baby content.
lead_paragraph: “My parents’ biggest rule is, like, I’m not allowed to have any public social media accounts,” Romy Mars says in a video she posted to TikTok.

headline: ‘John Wick: Chapter 4’ Review: There Will Be Blood, Yeah
abstract: In the latest and longest movie set in Wick World, Keanu Reeves’s titular assassin visits Paris and paints the town red.
lead_paragraph: A vulgar pleasure of the “John Wick” series is that it aestheticizes violence without the usual blah-blah rationales and appeals to conscience. At once basic and off-the-charts nuts, each movie — the fourth opens this week — centers on a laconic assassin with a hazy back story and extraordinary skills. A virtuoso of death, Wick (Keanu Reeves) has his reasons, or so the series insists, but he kills because it is what he does. It’s his thing. “Deserves got nothing to do with it,” as Clint Eastwood says in “Unforgiven.”

headline: Ireland Asks: What if Artists Could Ditch Their Day Jobs?
abstract: A government pilot program is giving 2,000 artists $350 a week with no strings attached, allowing them to concentrate on creative pursuits.
lead_paragraph: Ian Fay had toiled for years to make it as a comic book artist and illustrator, and last fall, he was ready to call it a day.

headline: Suspect Dead After Hostages Rescued in Houston F.B.I. Operation
abstract: Several hostages were rescued during a multiday operation involving multiple law enforcement agencies, the F.B.I. said. One suspect died after “an agent-involved shooting” and a second was taken into custody.
lead_paragraph: A hostage rescue in Houston that lasted several days ended on Thursday with one suspect shot dead and a second suspect in custody, the F.B.I. said.

headline: With Beijing opposing a TikTok sale, the Biden administration’s options narrow.
abstract: If the White House can’t force a sale, that would effectively leave it with two options to resolve concerns about the company.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration recently told TikTok it wanted the app’s Chinese owners to sell their stakes or face a possible ban in the United States. But that plan hit a new roadblock on Thursday when the Chinese government said it would oppose a sale.

headline: Two Real Estate Agents Say Racism Was Part of the Culture at Brokerage
abstract: A real estate agent, who is white, is suing his former employer in part because he says he was fired for speaking up about the treatment of his colleague, who is Black.
lead_paragraph: Jarret Willis, a Black real estate agent at a luxury brokerage in the Hamptons, said his co-workers called him Jafar — a comparison to the brown-skinned, villainous sorcerer from “Aladdin.”

headline: Why Do I Feel More Anxious at Night?
abstract: The quiet hours can bring a lot of internal chatter. Here’s how to deal.
lead_paragraph: Q: Whenever I’m trying to fall asleep at night, a bunch of anxious thoughts and embarrassing memories come racing into my mind, preventing me from drifting off. Why does this happen and is there anything I can do about it?

headline: Scare Me Once? Great Game. Scare Me Twice? Great Remake.
abstract: New versions of Resident Evil 4 and Dead Space illustrate the challenges that video game developers face when immersing players in horrifying yet familiar worlds.
lead_paragraph: Die-hard fans wanted the floating spaceship of their nightmares, one stocked with mutilated zombies, improvised blowtorches and zero-gravity spectacles. The fictional engineer Isaac Clarke navigated this ramshackle vessel in Dead Space, the popular survival horror video game from 2008 that spawned two sequels.

headline: The Aspiring Cult Leader’s Missing Art and the Nephew Obsessed With His Legacy
abstract: The strange, twisting tale of Bradford Boobis and the nephew who has spent 50 years trying to make his painting public once again.
lead_paragraph: Lester Chanin was asleep the night that the paintings were taken. He was only 15 and, though it happened over 50 years ago, he still remembers waking the next day to a world that seemed irrevocably changed.

headline: Prosecutor in Trump Hush-Money Case Fires Back at House Republicans
abstract: The office of the Manhattan district attorney, Alvin L. Bragg, said the committee chairmen’s attempts to intervene in the investigation were “unlawful.”
lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump declared over the weekend that the Manhattan district attorney, Alvin L. Bragg, was about to have him arrested, he called for his supporters to “PROTEST.” Instead, it was Republican leaders who hurried to the former president’s defense.

headline: Netanyahu Digs In on Court Overhaul, in the Face of Mass Protests
abstract: Amid a national crisis over a planned judicial overhaul, Israel’s Parliament approved a bill making it much harder to remove a prime minister from office.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel defiantly vowed on Thursday to proceed with a divisive judicial overhaul, in a move that came just hours after his coalition passed a law making it harder to remove him from office.

headline: Man at Center of Jan. 6 Conspiracy Theory Demands Retraction From Fox
abstract: A lawyer for Ray Epps has demanded that the Fox host Tucker Carlson publicly apologize for “false and defamatory statements” that Mr. Epps served as a federal agent during the Capitol attack.
lead_paragraph: A lawyer for Ray Epps, the man at the center of a prominent conspiracy theory about the Capitol riot, sent a letter on Thursday to the Fox News host Tucker Carlson demanding that he publicly retract his “false and defamatory statements” that Mr. Epps had worked as a government provocateur on Jan. 6, 2021, and helped to instigate the mob attack.

headline: Climate Change: The Time to Act Is Now
abstract: Readers react to a new U.N. climate report. Also: Grandpa’s world; delayed reports of sexual abuse; the loss of insect life; the manuscript thief.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Petite Solange’ Review: Coming of Age as Your Parents Divorce
abstract: Axelle Ropert’s carefully calibrated film from France follows a girl experiencing the pain of having to accept her parents as people with faults.
lead_paragraph: Early in the French film “Petite Solange,” four family members make eye contact with one another in turn in a measured series of close-ups. It’s a quiet expression of intimacy, and the moment establishes their balance and bond as a group. It also illustrates the compassionate gaze of the writer-director, Axelle Ropert, who spins a conventional divorce story into a focused melodrama about the loneliness of youth.

headline: Victor LaValle Likes to Stare Directly at His Deepest Fears
abstract: “People sometimes ask why I want to read horror at all, let alone write it,” says the horror novelist, whose new book is “Lone Women.” “So much writing glances off the hardest and worst experiences, but horror confronts the worst that happens. ... A good horror novel doesn’t lie to you.”
lead_paragraph: “The Black Guy Dies First,” by Robin R. Means Coleman and Mark H. Harris; “The Survivalists,” by Kashana Cauley; “Mott Street,” by Ava Chin.

headline: Short Seller Accuses Jack Dorsey’s Block of Facilitating Fraud
abstract: Shares of the financial tech company plunged after Hindenburg Research said Block had failed to stamp out illegal activity on its platforms, including drug sales and sex trafficking.
lead_paragraph: Hindenburg Research, the small investment firm whose critical investigative reports pummeled shares in an Indian industrial conglomerate and an electric-vehicle start-up, has found its newest target: Jack Dorsey’s financial technology company, Block.

headline: Hoover Biographer Wins American History Book Prize
abstract: The New-York Historical Society award goes to Beverly Gage, whose “G-Man: J. Edgar Hoover and the Making of the American Century” puts a notorious character in context.
lead_paragraph: Beverly Gage, the author of “G-Man: J. Edgar Hoover and the Making of the American Century,” has been named the winner of the New-York Historical Society’s 2023 Barbara and David Zalaznick Book Prize, which is awarded annually for the best work of American history or biography.

headline: Amazon Union Gets Favorable Finding on Warehouse Access for Organizing
abstract: Federal labor regulators said that Amazon had illegally barred off-duty employees from work sites and that the policy was aimed at union backers.
lead_paragraph: Federal labor regulators have concluded that Amazon’s policy of restricting the warehouse access of off-duty employees is illegal, backing a contention of the union that has represented workers at a Staten Island warehouse since winning an election there last year.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? Wong Kar-wai and More
abstract: I’m a deputy editor and columnist for Food and Cooking. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.
lead_paragraph: I’m a deputy editor and columnist for Food and Cooking. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.

headline: For Two Los Angeles Artists, the Spiritual Is Political
abstract: Patrisse Cullors and noé olivas trade activism for spiritual reflection in a joint exhibition that emphasizes the Ifá religious tradition.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — At the Charlie James Gallery, in the Chinatown neighborhood here, a surprising exhibition of spiritually reflective and esoteric artwork opened recently. Surprising because the artists, Patrisse Cullors and noé olivas, are known for their activism and social engagement, and because the works in the show, “Freedom Portals,” reject the strident, declamatory tenor of much political art.

headline: Arizona Supreme Court Turns Down Kari Lake’s Appeal in Her Election Lawsuit
abstract: The justices refused to hear Ms. Lake’s claims disputing her loss in the governor’s race, but sent one part of her lawsuit back to a trial court for review.
lead_paragraph: Arizona’s Supreme Court on Wednesday denied a request from Kari Lake to hear her lawsuit disputing her loss last year in the governor’s race. The lawsuit was based on what the court said was a false claim by Ms. Lake, a Republican, that more than 35,000 unaccounted ballots were accepted.

headline: Here Comes the … Baby Bump
abstract: More couples are proudly announcing on their wedding day that they are expecting.
lead_paragraph: When Kelly Sullivan and Tommy Barkovic found out last July that she would be about 15 weeks pregnant for their September wedding, they knew they wanted to announce it in a big way.

headline: Stocks Are Turbulent as Wall St. Weighs Fed’s Future Moves
abstract: Investors remain preoccupied with the health of banks as interest rates rise, putting balance sheets under pressure.
lead_paragraph: Stocks rose on Thursday afternoon, after a second day of volatility in which the S&P 500 swung between gains and losses.

headline: Israeli Police Use Water Cannons on Protesters in Tel Aviv
abstract: Israelis demonstrated against the right-wing government’s plan to overhaul the country’s judicial system.
lead_paragraph: Israelis demonstrated against the right-wing government’s plan to overhaul the country’s judicial system.

headline: ‘The Worst Ones’ Review: The Gazes of Children
abstract: In their feature, the directors Lisa Akoka and Romane Gueret build a provocative critique of filmmaking practices.
lead_paragraph: A freckled girl, Maylis (Mélina Vanderplancke), sits in a classroom that has been turned into a casting venue. Her gaze could be described as apathetic were it not for the way she challenges Gabriel (Johan Heldenbergh), a fictional filmmaker, at the start of the keen drama “The Worst Ones,” from Lise Akoka and Romane Gueret. Those two real directors’ movie follows Gabriel as he films in an economically depressed neighborhood in Northern France. That Gabriel gives Maylis a nonspeaking role speaks volumes.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: National Poetry Month begins next week, but here at the Book Review we believe that you don’t need a ceremonial excuse to read poems — you just need a capacity for delight in language, and some good poems to read. We trust that you have the first part down already; to help with the second, can we recommend Karisma Price’s debut collection, “I’m Always So Serious”? To poetry lovers her title might seem to evoke Christian Wiman’s marvelous epic “Being Serious” (also worth reading!), but Price is very much staking her own ground here, on Southern soil blessed and haunted by the ghosts of forebears; her book summons everyone from James Baldwin to Gwendolyn Brooks to Beyoncé. I think you’ll like it.

headline: Ja Morant Moves Toward ‘Redemption’ After Gun Video
abstract: Back from an eight-game suspension, the Memphis Grizzlies guard said he had more work to do to improve himself. But there was also a hint of defiance in his approach.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — When Ja Morant checked into his first game in almost three weeks on Wednesday, Grizzlies fans at the FedEx Forum wrapped him in the warm embrace of a standing ovation and prolonged roars.

headline: Yes, Vegetables for Dessert
abstract: Carrots, beets and sweet potatoes make subtly sweet and vibrant treats.
lead_paragraph: Few phrases have the power to inspire a tantrum quite like the utterance of “vegetables for dessert.” While I’m sure this applies to toddlers, I’m referring to myself: an adult woman.

headline: Autism Prevalence Rises Again, Study Finds
abstract: The pandemic may have disrupted the detection of autism spectrum disorder in young children, researchers also reported.
lead_paragraph: The prevalence of autism spectrum disorder in American children rose between 2018 and 2020, continuing a long-running trend, according to a study released by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Thursday. In 2020, an estimated one in 36 8-year-olds had autism, up from one in 44 in 2018. The prevalence was roughly 4 percent in boys and 1 percent in girls.

headline: Who Is Most at Risk for Long Covid?
abstract: A new analysis summarizes the emerging picture of factors that make long-term post-Covid symptoms more likely.
lead_paragraph: Which coronavirus patients are most at risk for developing long Covid?

headline: What Fueled the U.K.’s Season of Strikes, and Why It May Be Ending
abstract: For months, labor disputes rattled Britain, disrupting transportation, the mail and even medical procedures. Now, tensions seem to have eased.
lead_paragraph: The strikes trickled in at first and then came like a flood. As labor disputes gained momentum in Britain last year, postal workers, train drivers, nurses, teachers and others walked out, some for the first time ever, as they demanded higher pay or better working conditions.

headline: Driver Strikes Highway Workers in Maryland, Killing 6
abstract: The six workers, including two brothers from El Salvador and a father and son, were pronounced dead after they were struck on Interstate 695 outside Baltimore, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Six highway workers, including two brothers from El Salvador and a father and son, were killed on a busy highway outside Baltimore on Wednesday when they were struck by a car that plowed into their work zone, the authorities said.

headline: On and Off ‘Ted Lasso,’ Toheeb Jimoh Has Stepped Out of the Background
abstract: Just as his character, Sam Obisanya, has grown over the hit series’ seasons, the actor’s career has also soared.
lead_paragraph: In the Season 2 finale of “Ted Lasso,” Toheeb Jimoh’s character, Sam Obisanya, stands in front of the vacant storefront he has just bought. “What’s it going to be?” asks the woman who has handed the soccer player his keys. “A Nigerian restaurant,” he says, a broad smile on his face. This moment is a turning point of sorts for Sam, a mark of his ambition and growth from the young man viewers met in the “Ted Lasso” pilot who had recently arrived in Britain.

headline: Canada Grew by a Record 1 Million People From Immigration
abstract: The country’s growth was fueled almost entirely by newcomers, as the federal government pushes more immigration to plug labor shortages.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — For the first time in its history, Canada grew by over one million people last year and most of them were newcomers, signaling that the federal government’s ambitious goal of boosting immigration to fill labor shortages is within reach.

headline: ‘Tori and Lokita’ Review: Precarious Lives in Exile
abstract: In the new movie from the Dardenne brothers, two underage African migrants struggle to make a home in an unkind land.
lead_paragraph: Like most of the films from the brothers Jean-Pierre and Luc Dardenne, their latest — the harrowing “Tori and Lokita” — is a story about outcasts. And like most their films, it too is a suspense thriller about moral conscience, one that takes place in and around a gray, Belgian city. There, two young African migrants are struggling to make a home in an unkind world in which nearly every human exchange is transactional and carries the threat of betrayal.

headline: Science Museums Take Stock of 1.1 Billion Objects From Around the World
abstract: Natural history museums have joined forces to produce a global digital inventory of their prized collections, from pinned butterflies to dinosaur skulls.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of the world’s largest natural history museums revealed on Thursday a survey of everything in their collections. The global inventory is made up of 1.1 billion objects that range from dinosaur skulls to pollen grains to mosquitoes.

headline: House Tour | Harry Nuriev
abstract: The Russian-born architect and furniture designer shows T around his Parisian home.
lead_paragraph: The Russian-born architect and furniture designer shows T around his Parisian home.

headline: A Paris Apartment With Boxer-Brief Bedding and Rugs Made From Socks
abstract: There wasn’t a style that reflected his approach to design. So Harry Nuriev made up his own.
lead_paragraph: IN 1900, about a month before dying, Oscar Wilde is rumored to have looked around his accommodations at the Hôtel d’Alsace, the derelict Parisian pension house where he spent his final days, and said, “My wallpaper and I are fighting a duel to the death. One or the other of us has to go.” More than 120 years later, another flamboyant expat found himself on rue des Beaux-Arts at an only slightly less dire impasse.

headline: What Students Are Saying About Coed Sports
abstract: Some teenagers said playing on a team with boys and girls had benefits for athletes on and off the court, but not all were convinced coed teams were fair — or fun.
lead_paragraph: “It is one of the world’s most obscure games but among the most progressive, a rare team sport devised expressly for women and men to play together in equal numbers, with equal respect and value and responsibility,” Jeré Longman writes in “‘8 Players 1 Heartbeat’: A Game Men and Women Play as Equals.”

headline: Trump Inquiries Present a Stress Test for Justice in a Polarized Nation
abstract: Attorney General Merrick Garland and other prosecutors have sought to demonstrate that politics should not infect the justice system. Those efforts face a steep challenge as the Trump investigations move ahead.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On the morning of Jan. 6, 2021, Merrick B. Garland was busy typing away in his upstairs office at home, finalizing remarks he planned to deliver the following day when he was to be introduced as Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s nominee to be attorney general.

headline: Jeremy O. Harris’s Writer’s Residency Under the Tuscan Sun
abstract: The finalists for the 2023 Yale Drama Series Prize suddenly find themselves in Italy, with plenty of time to write, reflect and make pasta.
lead_paragraph: CASTIGLIONCELLO DEL TRINORO, Italy — Just two weeks ago, the lives of four promising playwrights were upended: Not only did they receive an email announcing that their work had been shortlisted for the 2023 Yale Drama Series Prize, but they were also invited to participate in a monthlong residency in Tuscany, led by the American playwright Jeremy O. Harris.

headline: ‘It Needs You’: The Human Side to Boulez’s Demanding Music
abstract: Matthias Pintscher speaks about Boulez’s “Dérive 2,” which the composer’s old ensemble performs in New York this weekend.
lead_paragraph: Pierre Boulez, one of the most commanding musicians of the past century, must have been asked countless times, before his death in 2016, what he thought his legacy might be.

headline: For Sale: Mansions in Los Angeles at Bargain Prices
abstract: Millionaire homeowners are trying to sell their houses before the city’s “mansion tax” goes into effect on April 1.
lead_paragraph: Millionaire home sellers are slashing prices and sweetening deals this week in Los Angeles, eager to move their properties off the market before a new real estate tax aimed squarely at the rich goes into effect on April 1.

headline: This Passover Egg Dish Always Has a Place at the Table
abstract: But this recipe for egg and onion, from a founder of Australia’s Monday Morning Cooking Club, is delicious any time of year.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Lisa Goldberg takes her weekly gatherings very seriously.

headline: Trump Grand Jury Expected to Continue Hearing Hush-Money Case Monday
abstract: The panel that has been investigating the case involving the former president typically meets on a different matter on Thursdays and does not convene on Fridays.
lead_paragraph: It now appears that any indictment of former President Donald J. Trump will not come until next week at the earliest.

headline: The Danish Experience: Art That Marries Real and Ideal
abstract: ‘‘Beyond the Light’’ at the Met is a luminous, move-close exhibition whose paintings and drawings render a volatile world with purity of heart and line.
lead_paragraph: “Purity of heart is to will one thing,” wrote the early 19th-century Danish philosopher and poet Soren Kierkegaard, his one willed thing being knowledge of — meaning faith in — an absolute, sometimes called God. Certain Danish artists of his time espoused a will to purity too, purity of eye and hand, a way to see and know the world, factually or emotionally, as it really is.

headline: Woman Who Stormed Pelosi’s Office on Jan. 6 Is Sentenced to Three Years
abstract: Prosecutors said that Riley June Williams, 24, had acted as an “accelerant” in the Capitol attack, leading those around her past police lines and into the speaker’s office.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Pennsylvania woman who steered a group of rioters toward Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s office on Jan. 6, 2021, and directed others inside the Capitol to steal a laptop computer was sentenced in Federal District Court in Washington on Thursday to three years in prison.

headline: Slovakia Makes Its First Delivery of Pledged Soviet-Era Fighter Jets to Ukraine
abstract: The arrival of the aging MIG-29s is not expected to significantly change battlefield dynamics, and the planes will most likely be used for spare parts for Ukraine’s own Soviet-era jets.
lead_paragraph: The first four of the 13 Soviet-designed fighter jets Slovakia pledged to send to Ukraine have been delivered, and the remaining will arrive in the coming weeks, the Slovak defense ministry said on Thursday.

headline: I Love Coffee, but I Gave It Up for MudWtr. Don’t Make My Mistake.
Republicans Say Spending Is Fueling Inflation. The Fed Chair Disagrees.
abstract: Jerome H. Powell has said that snarled supply chains, an oil shock following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and shifts among American consumers are primarily behind rapid price growth.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The chair of the Federal Reserve, Jerome H. Powell, has repeatedly undercut a central claim Republicans make as they seek sharp cuts in federal spending: Government spending is driving the nation’s still-hot inflation rate.

headline: In Trump Rape Case, Jurors Will Be Kept Anonymous to Protect Them
abstract: A judge said that they could become victims of “harassment or worse” from supporters of the former president as he faces a lawsuit by the writer E. Jean Carroll.
lead_paragraph: A Manhattan judge ruled on Thursday that jurors hearing a trial next month involving a rape allegation against former President Donald J. Trump will be kept anonymous because of concern they could become victims of “harassment or worse” by Mr. Trump’s supporters.

headline: The Sports to Watch This Weekend
abstract: There's surely more madness in store in the N.C.A.A. tournament; soccer and golf is on deck as well.
lead_paragraph: There's surely more madness in store in the N.C.A.A. tournament; soccer and golf is on deck as well.

headline: How to Ease Your Back Pain
abstract: Five expert-backed ideas that can help you find some relief.
lead_paragraph: Five expert-backed ideas that can help you find some relief.

headline: Free Speech Doesn’t Mean Free Rein to Shout Down Others
abstract: When protests amount to mob censorship.
lead_paragraph: If you pay any attention to legal news at all, you’re familiar with the Stanford Law School shout-down. The story is simple and disturbing. The Federalist Society chapter at Stanford Law School invited Judge Kyle Duncan of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit to speak on a fascinating and important topic (for legal nerds, anyway): How do lower courts decide cases on legal issues in which Supreme Court case law is unsettled or changing?

headline: Lawmakers Blast TikTok’s C.E.O. for App’s Ties to China, Escalating Tensions
abstract: Lawmakers grilled Shou Chew, TikTok’s chief executive, over the app’s ties to its Chinese parent company and its effects on children, as Chinese officials said they opposed a sale of the platform.
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers lambasted TikTok’s chief executive about the platform’s ties to China in a roughly five-hour hearing on Thursday, punctuating how the viral video app has become a central battleground as the United States and China tussle for political, technological and economic primacy.

headline: Spain’s prime minister plans to visit Beijing for talks on China’s contentious peace proposal.
abstract: China has been trying to build support for its proposal to start peace talks, but Ukraine’s allies hold that its call for an immediate cease-fire would only help Russia consolidate territorial gains.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — The Spanish prime minister, Pedro Sánchez, will travel next week to China for talks with President Xi Jinping, and intends to discuss China’s framework for negotiating a peace agreement between Russia and Ukraine, he announced on Thursday.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Looking for something good? “Succession” and “Yellowjackets” are back. Or try a new musical series from a team of Broadway all-stars.
lead_paragraph: ‘Succession’When to watch: Sunday at 9 p.m., on HBO and HBOMax.

headline: Crypto Fugitive Do Kwon Is Charged With Fraud by U.S. Prosecutors
abstract: Mr. Kwon, the entrepreneur behind the failed TerraUSD and Luna cryptocurrencies, was arrested earlier in Montenegro.
lead_paragraph: The cryptocurrency entrepreneur Do Kwon — who designed a pair of digital currencies that failed spectacularly last year, triggering a market meltdown — was charged with fraud by federal prosecutors in New York on Thursday, hours after the authorities in Montenegro arrested him as he prepared to board a flight.

headline: Newly Published Visual Books, from Nan Goldin to NFTs
abstract: A selection of recently published books.
lead_paragraph: BE-SPOKE: Revelations From the World’s Most Important Fashion Designers, by Marylou Luther. Illustrated by Ruben Toledo. (Rizzoli, $57.50.) A fashion journalist collects memorable quotes from her 70-year career interviewing notable designers, including Coco Chanel and Virgil Abloh, presented alongside Toledo’s vibrant illustrations.

headline: No Prison Time for Book Thief
abstract: The former publishing employee who pleaded guilty to stealing unpublished book manuscripts was ordered to be deported and to pay $88,000 in restitution.
lead_paragraph: Filippo Bernardini, a former publishing employee who pleaded guilty in a fraud case in which the government accused him of stealing more than 1,000 manuscripts, avoided prison on Thursday but was ordered to be deported.

headline: How Manhattan Hotels Became Refuges for Thousands of Migrants
abstract: The city has spent millions to convert upscale hotels, humble motels and even office buildings into housing for an influx of migrants.
lead_paragraph: Just steps from Times Square and surrounded by Broadway theaters, the Row NYC hotel advertises itself as “more New York than New York,” bringing together “urban grit with grandeur.”

headline: Banks Are Borrowing More From the Fed: What to Know
abstract: As turmoil sweeps the United States financial system, banks are turning to the Federal Reserve for loans to get them through the squeeze.
lead_paragraph: Banks are turning to the Federal Reserve’s loan programs to access funding as turmoil sweeps the financial system in the wake several high-profile bank failures.

headline: Tennessee Moves to Decertify Officers Who Beat Tyre Nichols
abstract: Four of the Memphis police officers charged with second-degree murder in Mr. Nichols’s death should never again work in law enforcement in the state, an oversight agency says.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — At least four of the five Memphis police officers charged with second-degree murder in connection with the killing of Tyre Nichols should be barred from ever working in local law enforcement in Tennessee, an oversight agency said on Thursday.

headline: Your Friday Briefing: U.S. Lawmakers Blast TikTok’s C.E.O.
abstract: Also, a World Bank estimate on the cost to rebuild Ukraine and a prison sentence for India’s opposition leader.
lead_paragraph: TikTok has come to represent the growing divide between the U.S. and China over tech leadership and national security. The app, which has 150 million users in the U.S., has become a battleground in a technological cold war between the two countries, and yesterday U.S. lawmakers blasted Shou Chew, TikTok’s chief executive, for more than five hours.

headline: U.S. and Canada Reach an Agreement on Diverting Asylum Seekers
abstract: The deal, reached just before President Biden arrived in Canada for an official visit, allows both countries to reduce a surge in migration.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States and Canada have reached an agreement that will allow both countries to divert asylum seekers from their borders at a time when migration has surged across the hemisphere, a U.S. official familiar with the agreement said Thursday.

headline: Pineapple and Ham Belong Together
abstract: On the Easter table and, yes, on pizza, these smart, flavorful tweaks make the retro combination even better.
lead_paragraph: Hiwa Rosario is celebrating Easter a week early this year. The actual holiday weekend is one of the busiest times of the year for her business, Farm to Jar Hawaii. She’ll be setting up shop at Ward Centre in Honolulu to sell her coveted pineapple glazes, which her customers buy to deck out their holiday hams. The balanced combination of tangy, sweet fruit and salty, savory pork is, she said, “a perfect union.”

headline: Utah Law Could Curb Use of TikTok and Instagram by Children and Teens
abstract: The law, which prohibits social networks from allowing minors to have accounts without parental consent, may come as welcome news to many families even as it raises privacy concerns.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Spencer J. Cox of Utah signed a sweeping social media bill on Thursday afternoon that could dramatically limit youth access to apps like TikTok and Instagram, potentially upending how many minors in the state use the internet.

headline: Fuzzy Haskins, Who Helped Turn Doo-Wop Into P-Funk, Dies at 81
abstract: As a teenager, he joined forces with George Clinton. Their vocal group, the Parliaments, morphed into Parliament-Funkadelic, one of the wildest acts of the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: Fuzzy Haskins, a foundational member of the vocal group that morphed into Parliament-Funkadelic, the genre-blurring collective led by George Clinton that shook up the pop music world in the 1970s, died on March 16 in Grosse Pointe Woods, Mich. He was 81.

headline: Explaining the Ties Between Alvin Bragg and George Soros
abstract: Donald Trump’s allies have accused the district attorney bringing a case against him as having been “bought” by Mr. Soros, the philanthropist. That is misleading, though the men do have a financial connection.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As a potential indictment looms over former President Donald J. Trump, he and his allies have sought to tie the Manhattan district attorney bringing the case to a familiar Republican specter: George Soros, the financier and Democratic megadonor.

headline: What to Buy at the Restaurant Supply Store
abstract: Sheet pans, mixing bowls and more recommendations from Lesley Stockton of Wirecutter.
lead_paragraph: Home cooks are increasingly shopping with chefs and restaurateurs at restaurant supply stores, where they can find inexpensive but durable kitchen tools. Here are the tools that Lesley Stockton, a senior staff writer at Wirecutter, recommends looking for on the shelves.

headline: Home Cooks Find Bargains at the Restaurant Supply Store
abstract: These warehouses equip professionals with kitchen tools and food, but they’re also open to the public.
lead_paragraph: Somewhere in every major city in America, there’s a nondescript warehouse filled with enough sheet pans, bowls, knives, pots and pans to arm the kitchen brigade of the next new restaurant.

headline: TikTok Stars Go On a D.C. Field Trip
abstract: On the bus, off the bus and all over Capitol Hill with creators turned temporary lobbyists. Wait, does anybody need a bathroom break?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a hotel room on Wednesday morning, Janette Ok, a fashion and lifestyle TikTok creator from Los Angeles, was getting ready for a day of lobbying on Capitol Hill. She ripped off the tag hanging from a sleeve of her blazer and donned a pair of hot pink gloves, which matched her heels.

headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: American Hopes for Canadian Military Leadership in Haiti Likely to Be Dashed
abstract: The United States had hoped that its neighbor would lead a major intervention, but Canada lacks resources and is skeptical of its value.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — When President Biden and Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada meet on Friday, one thorny topic likely to be on the table will be a worsening humanitarian crisis in Haiti, where criminal gangs have unleashed waves of violence and now control much of the capital.

headline: ISIS Matchmaker Gets 18 Years in First Trial Under N.Y. Terrorism Law
abstract: Abdullah el-Faisal, a Jamaican cleric, was the first person to face a jury under state terrorism laws passed after Sept. 11. He was not in the city when he committed his crimes.
lead_paragraph: After ISIS promised in 2014 that the world would “hear and understand the meaning of terrorism,” fervent western support came from a Jamaican preacher once imprisoned in Britain for urging violence, and later expelled from Kenya by officials fearing he would encourage radicalism.

headline: Marisol Malaret, First Puerto Rican Miss Universe, Dies at 73
abstract: Edging out Miss USA, Ms. Malaret — who was also the first winner from the Caribbean — brokered her fame to become a television host and magazine editor back home.
lead_paragraph: Marisol Malaret, who in 1970 overcame a difficult childhood to become the first woman from Puerto Rico, and from the Caribbean, to win the Miss Universe pageant — and who then brokered her fame into a career as a television host, editor and entrepreneur — died on Sunday in a hospital in San Juan, P.R. She was 73.

headline: Court Action Underscores Peril for Trump in Documents Investigation
abstract: Federal prosecutors continue to build a case that the former president obstructed efforts by the government to reclaim classified material and that he may have misled his own lawyer.
lead_paragraph: The behind-the-scenes legal fight over obtaining evidence from a lawyer who represented former President Donald J. Trump in the investigation into his handling of classified documents has brought into sharper view where the Justice Department might be headed with the case.

headline: Next Stop for Andy Byford, Former New York Subway Chief: Amtrak
abstract: Mr. Byford, whom transit riders nicknamed “Train Daddy” and credited with improving an antiquated system, will run Amtrak’s new high-speed rail development program.
lead_paragraph: Train Daddy is back.

headline: The world organization for track and field keeps its ban on Russia and Belarus, adding to Olympic debate.
abstract: Another similar ban by the council that oversees ice hockey shows the issue has not waned.
lead_paragraph: World Athletics, the international governing body for track and field, voted Thursday to continue its ban on athletes from Russia and Belarus from participating in events.

headline: 4 People Accused of $13 Million in Pro Athlete Fraud Schemes
abstract: Prosecutors said the people, including a former N.B.A. agent, took money from professional basketball players and spent it on luxury goods and home renovations.
lead_paragraph: Four people were arrested Thursday and charged with collectively defrauding four professional men’s basketball players out of more than $13 million, according to Damian Williams, the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York.

headline: The Cold War With China Is Changing Everything
abstract: Both sides are spending lots of money on technological elites.
lead_paragraph: So I guess we’re in a new cold war. Leaders of both parties have become China hawks. There are rumblings of war over Taiwan. Xi Jinping vows to dominate the century.

headline: As Zelensky Visits Kherson, World Bank Says Ukraine Needs $411 Billion to Rebuild
abstract: The bank released a significantly higher figure as European Union leaders approved plans to provide Kyiv with one million artillery shells over the next 12 months.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine traveled to the southern region of Kherson on Thursday in his second trip near the front line in two straight days, visiting areas ravaged by Russia’s campaign to destroy energy infrastructure.

headline: Shooting at Denver High School Focuses Attention on School Safety Plans
abstract: A 17-year-old student who shot two administrators and later killed himself had to be patted down every day at East High School because of past behavior, the police said.
lead_paragraph: The shooting of two administrators at a Denver high school on Wednesday has focused attention on student safety plans, which are commonly used by schools across the country as a way to monitor troubled students and prevent violence.

headline: Another Mental Illness Tragedy Spurs Questions About Virginia’s Health System
abstract: Irvo Otieno’s death after sheriff’s deputies pinned him to the floor shows that changes in recent years have not solved deep problems, critics say.
lead_paragraph: One evening in May 2018, a 24-year-old high school biology teacher crashed his car at a highway exit in Richmond, Va. He got out of the car, naked and apparently in mental distress, and for several moments writhed on the ground. Then, with nothing in his hands, he stood, strode toward a police officer and lunged. The officer shot and killed him.

headline: Biden’s Options on TikTok Narrow After Beijing Pushes Back
abstract: China’s opposition to a sale of the app leaves the president to challenge that stand or consider seeking a ban, which would face its own obstacles.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration recently told TikTok that it wanted the app’s Chinese owners to sell the app or face a possible ban in the United States. But that plan hit a roadblock on Thursday, when Beijing said it would oppose a sale.

headline: Myke Towers Is Seizing His Moment
abstract: In just a few years, the rapper has become one of the most sought-after collaborators in Latin music. His new album, “La Vida Es Una,” surveys his many aesthetics.
lead_paragraph: Myke Towers could tell you that he never knew he would make it big, but that wouldn’t be true. Because back in 2014, six years before the rapper would put out his debut, he was preparing for a make-or-break show in his hometown, San Juan, Puerto Rico, and breaking wasn’t an option.

headline: Which Celebrities Are Facing Backlash for Crypto Promotion?
abstract: Lindsay Lohan and Jake Paul are just two names who have encountered legal trouble for pushing crypto on their social media accounts.
lead_paragraph: The most recent posts on Lindsay Lohan’s Twitter page are Christmas-themed advertisements from December for “Pilk,” a creamy, bubbly concoction of Pepsi and milk. The posts are clearly marked as promotions for Pepsi.

headline: Antisemitic Incidents Reach New High in U.S., Anti-Defamation League Says
abstract: The report from the advocacy group included online harassment and speech as well as physical attacks, and mirrored similar data from the federal government and another study.
lead_paragraph: The number of antisemitic incidents in the United States last year was the highest since the Anti-Defamation League began keeping track in 1979, the Jewish advocacy group announced on Thursday.

headline: A Paler Uranus Emerges in the Latest Hubble Telescope Image
abstract: A pair of images, taken eight years apart, show changes to the ice giant planet as spring arrives in the northern hemisphere.
lead_paragraph: With the passage of the vernal equinox a few days ago, we in the Northern Hemisphere can look forward to the warmer days of spring while those in the Southern Hemisphere will begin to feel the chill of autumn.

headline: Corrections: March 24, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, March 24, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An obituary on Wednesday about the former New York Knicks center Willis Reed misstated the number of consecutive games the Knicks won early in the 1969-70 season. It was 18, not 17. And a picture caption with the obituary misstated when a photograph of Reed attempting to block a shot by Bill Russell of the Boston Celtics was taken. It was the late 1960s, not the mid-1960s.

headline: Ukrainian Author Andrey Kurkov Among National Book Critics Circle Award Winners
abstract: A collection of fantastical short stories and a book of poems about escaping capitalist society were also among the 2022 winners.
lead_paragraph: The Ukrainian author Andrey Kurkov won a National Book Critics Circle Award for his novel “Grey Bees,” about a beekeeper living in the “gray zone” in the Donbas, a region torn by ongoing conflict between Russian proxies and the Ukrainian military.

headline: Things That Make Hay
abstract: Check out the grid in Blake Slonecker’s Friday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon wish us sweet dreams.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — It’s been a while since we have solved an acrostic and found a poem, although we often uncover lyrical passages. I didn’t recognize it as such, but the puzzle comprises a very slightly truncated version of the first two stanzas of a Billy Collins poem called “Night Golf.” I found that reading the whole poem after finishing the grid was really satisfying, as was learning that Collins, who served as U.S. poet laureate from 2001 to 2003, is a lover of golf.

headline: That Missing Trump Portrait? Found, Next to Some Old Yoga Mats.
abstract: After a tip, The Times located a portrait of Donald Trump given to him by El Salvador’s president and that Democrats were eager to account for. It was propped up in an obscure spot in a Trump hotel.
lead_paragraph: In the bowels of the Trump National Doral hotel in Miami, in a small space leading to electrical rooms, an enormous portrait of the 45th president of the United States rests on a piece of deteriorating purple-colored foam.

headline: Quotation of Day: Tank Crews Impatient for New Gear From West
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, March 24, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “We will beat them even with stones, but it will take longer. We will beat them with sticks.”

headline: American Contractor Killed in Drone Attack on Base in Syria
abstract: Five service members and another U.S. contractor were wounded. The Pentagon said the drone was of “Iranian origin” and ordered airstrikes on facilities in Syria used by Iran-linked groups.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A U.S. contractor was killed and another contractor and five U.S. service members were injured when a self-destructing drone struck a maintenance facility on a coalition base in northeast Syria on Thursday, the Pentagon said in a statement.

headline: Melbourne Art and Design, Past and Present
abstract: Two exhibitions in Melbourne — “Radical Utopia” and “Melbourne Now” — trace the city’s art and design from the 1980s to the present.
lead_paragraph: As a design student in Melbourne in the 1960s,  Mimmo Cozzolino, who in childhood had moved with his family to Australia from Italy, was struck by his lecturers’ preoccupation with design movements taking place on the other side of the earth.

headline: The Care Package That Revived Their Relationship
abstract: Jennifer Walters and Clark Palicka met as Air Force pilots. Eventually, the stresses of military life caused them to cut off contact for a while.
lead_paragraph: The first time Jennifer Nicole Walters spoke with John Clark Palicka was over the phone, it was in preparation for a training mission scheduled for the following day. Both were U.S. Air Force pilots stationed at Travis Air Force Base in Solano County, Calif.

headline: For These World Travelers, Home Base Is Wherever They Are Together
abstract: Anna Spelman and Peter Prix, who met in Cambodia, lived in several cities over the years before settling in Istanbul. They married in Arizona.
lead_paragraph: A heartfelt smile can be infectious, and for Anna Clare Spelman and Peter Prix, it commenced their love story.

headline: From Volunteers to High School Sweethearts
abstract: Hannah Sellinger and Basil Azim met while working for a mentorship program in Texas. He then asked for a number he already had.
lead_paragraph: Hannah Shea Sellinger often got on the mic during pep rallies at Byron Nelson High School in Trophy Club, Texas, with a nod to the girls’ varsity basketball team.

headline: Our Second Date Was Statistically Abnormal
abstract: And the ensuing beauty, tragedy and pain have been exquisite.
lead_paragraph: Years later, I still told the undergraduate students in my research methods class the story of my first date with Corey to help them remember the concept of regression to the mean — how something that is extreme on a first measurement will become less extreme, or regress to the mean, on a second measurement.

headline: Garden State’s Basketball Talent Blooms in N.C.A.A. Tournament
abstract: Whether it’s teams like Princeton and Fairleigh Dickinson pulling off upsets or standout performances from players, New Jersey’s imprint has been all over the Division I men’s basketball tournament.
lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, N.J. — By now, many members of the Princeton men’s basketball team just groan and shake their heads upon hearing the customary refrain. They will be watching a college basketball game on television, like on Sunday when Isaiah Wong, a Miami guard from South Brunswick, N.J., threw in 27 points against Indiana.

headline: For a Restaurateur, the Secret Desire for Romance Was Finally Sated
abstract: Ilson Goncalves, who runs a popular Brazilian restaurant in New Jersey, never thought he would have a meaningful relationship — until he met Yasar Sakman on a summer vacation in Turkey.
lead_paragraph: At the height of the pandemic, Ilson Leir Goncalves was winning a reputation around Montclair, N.J., as a restaurateur who refused to quit.

headline: The Lawmaker Who’s a Fan and Defender of TikTok
abstract: Jamaal Bowman, who represents parts of the Bronx and Westchester, thinks opposition to the platform is rooted in anti-China bias.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll meet the lonely New York congressman who has become the most prominent defender of the embattled platform TikTok. We’ll also look at city contracts that are turning hotels into temporary housing for some of the migrants who have arrived on buses from the southern border.

headline: They’re Desperation Heaves for Most Players. For Caitlin Clark, They’re Money.
abstract: Clark, the Iowa guard whose long-range shots have made a stir online, perfected her form in her driveway. But even when she abandons that form, she can hit game-winners from nearly halfcourt.
lead_paragraph: Lisa Bluder, the women’s basketball coach at Iowa, had developed a concrete definition of a good shot attempt during her four decades of coaching experience. A player needs to be in range, in rhythm and uncontested.

headline: 40 Years After Phi Slama Jama, There’s Hope in Houston for a Better Finish
abstract: The 1982-83 Houston Cougars, a sensation nicknamed Phi Slama Jama, lost the N.C.A.A. men’s title game to North Carolina State on a dunk in the final moments.
lead_paragraph: Forty years is too long to hold onto heartbreak. Members of the 1983 Houston men’s basketball team, which found itself on the wrong side of one of the most famous upsets in N.C.A.A. tournament history, have processed that moment, made peace with it and moved on with their lives.

headline: ‘Bad Cinderella’ Review: The Title Warned Us
abstract: Andrew Lloyd Webber hopes to extend an unbroken 43-year streak on Broadway. But his 13th new musical may not be the charm.
lead_paragraph: First: Bring earplugs.

headline: North Korea Says It Tested a Nuclear-Capable Underwater Attack Drone
abstract: Such a test would be a first for Kim Jong-un’s weapons program. But there was no independent confirmation that it had happened.
lead_paragraph: North Korea said on Friday that it had used an underwater drone to practice launching a nuclear attack on an enemy seaport, saying that threats from the United States and its allies were forcing it to develop diverse means of carrying out nuclear strikes.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Mass opposition to legislative changes in France and in Israel.
lead_paragraph: In a televised address, Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli prime minister, yesterday defiantly vowed to proceed with a divisive plan to overhaul the judiciary. Earlier, his coalition passed a law making it harder to remove him from office, and thousands of protesters demonstrated across Israel against the plan, leading to clashes and confrontations with right-wing supporters and the police.

headline: France Is Furious
abstract: The damage of the past weeks can’t be undone.
lead_paragraph: FOS-SUR-MER, France — “This government just does not listen to us,” said Renald, a 50-year-old electrical mechanic at the Port of Marseille, as his co-workers assembled a barricade this week on the route leading to a fuel depot. “There’s a deep anger here.”

headline: Word of the Day: boundless
abstract: This word has appeared in 103 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word boundless has appeared in 103 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 13 in “Webb Telescope Spots a Distant Spiral Galaxy Like Our Own” by Dennis Overbye:

headline: Long-Lost Letters
abstract: These letters went missing centuries ago. Use your imagination to write the story behind one of them.
lead_paragraph: These letters are some of more than 160,000 pieces of mail that were never delivered to their intended recipients. Known as the Prize Papers, they were snatched by British warships from aboard merchant ships during wars from the 1650s to the early 19th century.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: The Younger Brother Caught in the Middle of the FTX Investigation
abstract: The collapse of Sam Bankman-Fried’s business empire has led federal prosecutors to scrutinize his brother, Gabe, who ran a pandemic-prevention group.
lead_paragraph: The money flowed freely at a pandemic-prevention organization run by the younger brother of Sam Bankman-Fried, the disgraced cryptocurrency mogul.

headline: In Montana, It’s Youth vs. the State in a Landmark Climate Case
abstract: Sixteen young Montanans have sued their state, arguing that its support of fossil fuels violates the state Constitution.
lead_paragraph: KALISPELL, Mont. — Badge and Lander Busse tromped into the forest behind their house on a snowy Sunday in March, their three hunting dogs in tow. It was in these woods, just outside Glacier National Park, that the teenage boys learned to hunt, fish, dress a deer and pick birdshot from Hungarian partridges.

headline: Al Franken Talks Potential TikTok Ban on ‘The Daily Show’
abstract: “That’s right, we don’t need a Chinese company stealing our data and spying on us. That’s a job for American companies,” Franken said.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: U.S. Due Diligence Firm Says China Detained Its Employees
abstract: Five Chinese nationals were taken away Monday, and the company, which does corporate investigations, and its law firm have been unable to contact them.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in China have raided the Beijing office of the Mintz Group, an American corporate investigations firm, and detained all five of its Chinese employees, the company said on Friday.

headline: She Needed ‘Something, Anything, of Theirs to Go On Living.’ She Found Nothing.
abstract: A photographer revisits her homeland to document what has been lost.
lead_paragraph: A photographer revisits her homeland to document what has been lost.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, March 24, 2023
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: 6 Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: This week's picks include “Crying in H Mart” by Michelle Zauner, Rita Dove’s latest poetry collection and more.
lead_paragraph: This week's picks include “Crying in H Mart” by Michelle Zauner, Rita Dove’s latest poetry collection and more.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including a preview of Season 4 of HBO's "Succession."
lead_paragraph: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including a preview of Season 4 of HBO's "Succession."

headline: Sorry You Were Laid Off. ‘CFBR.’
abstract: Abbreviations like “LOL” and “ILY” are popular expressions used across the web, and these days chances are you have probably seen “CFBR,” which stands for “commenting for better reach” and appears regularly under posts on LinkedIn.
lead_paragraph: Abbreviations like “LOL” and “ILY” are popular expressions used across the web, and these days chances are you have probably seen “CFBR,” which stands for “commenting for better reach” and appears regularly under posts on LinkedIn.

headline: The One Where They Live Happily Ever After … or Not
abstract: In her new novel, “Romantic Comedy,” Curtis Sittenfeld pays homage to the beloved form.
lead_paragraph: All straight women of a certain age were sold a trio of lies by romantic comedies — that love conquers differences, that we can have it all (whatever “all” is) and that perfect men fall from the sky just as our emotional acidity starts to become permanent.

headline: A Radical Way of Thinking About Money
abstract: Morgan Ricks argues that stricter regulations on “private money” can help panic-proof our financial system.
lead_paragraph: It’s been two weeks since the Silicon Valley Bank run, and we’re still feeling the ripple effects — not just at banks like Signature, First Republic and Credit Suisse, which are definitely taking a beating. Across the industry, too, banks are on edge, and regulators are rushing to keep the system together.

headline: Do School Employees Deserve More Respect — and Pay?
abstract: Los Angeles school workers — teachers’ aides, bus drivers and other school employees — went on a three-day strike. How do these often “invisible” workers make your education possible?
lead_paragraph: Do you ever stop to consider — or thank — the many school workers who make your daily education possible? Not just your teachers, of course, but also the numerous teachers’ aides, special education assistants, custodians, cafeteria workers and bus drivers?

headline: What’s Behind the ‘Middle-Aged Groan’?
abstract: Experts weigh in on the sounds we make when we bend over, stand up and sit down.
lead_paragraph: When my daughter was a toddler, she often imitated the long groan I made when I bent down. It was both funny and mortifying. Judging by the large number of videos of toddlers doing this on the internet, I was not alone.

headline: Bard Fork, and How to Talk So Chatbots Will Listen
abstract: Google has unleashed its A.I. chatbot, Bard, to the world. And Spotify’s A.I. D.J. knows your taste — perhaps a little too well.
lead_paragraph: “It’s different because it’s Google.” Bard, Google’s answer to ChatGPT, could prove to be more consequential than any large language model to date — but it isn’t there yet.

headline: The Man Who Leaked the Pentagon Papers Is Scared
abstract: The whistle-blower Daniel Ellsberg has never run out of secrets.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Ellsberg, famous for leaking the Pentagon Papers and his activism against nuclear weapons, announced recently that he has been diagnosed with terminal cancer.

headline: There’s a Problem With Banning TikTok. It’s Called the First Amendment.
abstract: American users of the social media platform are indisputably exercising their constitutional rights when they post and consume content on the site.
lead_paragraph: The First Amendment has so far played only a bit part in the debate about banning TikTok. This may change. If the U.S. government tries to shut down this major communications platform, the First Amendment will certainly have something to say about it.

headline: Nature and Nurture: Picture Books About Grandparents Who Garden
abstract: For two different young boys, beloved grandparents who fled war-torn lands embody the new gardens they’ve cultivated.
lead_paragraph: Every picture book has three stories. The first is how the book came to be, which is interesting in its own right but may be unknown to us. The second is the one told in the book. The third is what lingers in the reader’s mind after it ends.

headline: The Fed Has Targeted 2% Inflation. Should It Aim Higher?
abstract: After raising interest rates again, the Federal Reserve will soon have to consider how much pain it is willing to inflict in its fight against inflation, our columnist says.
lead_paragraph: There’s rarely a convenient time for the Federal Reserve to openly debate whether its 2 percent inflation target makes sense. This isn’t that time, but the Fed better get ready.

headline: Meet the Editor Behind a Slew of Best Sellers
abstract: Jennifer Hershey is the guiding hand who helped shape “Daisy Jones & the Six,” “Mad Honey” and many other chart-topping regulars.
lead_paragraph: Do your eyes glaze over when you reach the acknowledgments page at the end of a book? If so, you’re missing a delightful window into the village that came together for the barn raising of its publication. Let’s say, for instance, that Amazon Prime’s rendition of “Daisy Jones & the Six” has inspired you to delve into the novel that inspired the show. Flip to Page 353 of the paperback and you’ll find Taylor Jenkins Reid’s homage to her squad, including her agent, book designer, publicists and marketing team.

headline: What’s ‘Woke’ and Why It Matters
abstract: A marker of just how much American politics has changed over the last eight years.
lead_paragraph: Believe it or not, the term woke wasn’t uttered even once in the Republican debates back in 2015 and 2016.

headline: How to Talk to Teens About Cannabis (So They Won’t Ignore You)
abstract: Keep it brief, do your homework … and maybe don’t share your own teenage pot stories.
lead_paragraph: It’s sold as gummies and cookies. It can be dabbed or vaped. And, depending on where you live, it may be available in dispensaries, inside products much more potent than anything that came before.

headline: Galloping Through a ‘Horse Crazy’ Middle Grade Novel
abstract: In Sarah Maslin Nir’s “The Flying Horse,” a young equestrian and her trusty steed jump back in time.
lead_paragraph: Many girls grow up reading a book (for me it was “Silver Birch,” by Dorothy Lyons) in which the heroine longs for a horse, finds one, tames it and makes a connection that is much more solid and fun than those she has with her schoolmates. Such a book is often the start of a lifelong infatuation with horses.

headline: Say Goodbye to Daily Hotel Room Cleaning
abstract: The pandemic put a pause on many hotels’ guaranteed once-a-day cleanings. Now many of them are making the change permanent, even saying guests prefer it.
lead_paragraph: Stephanie VanDerSchie returned to her hotel room in Wausau, Wis., after a long day of skiing last month with her three young children to find their room disheveled.

headline: These Devices Sickened Hundreds. The New Models Have Risks, Too.
abstract: Duodenoscopes — tubular cameras threaded into the intestine — with disposable parts were supposed to be safer. But the parts can fall off in the body, the F.D.A. warned.
lead_paragraph: After medical instruments called duodenoscopes sickened hundreds of patients in hospital outbreaks a few years ago, the Food and Drug Administration urged health care facilities to switch to models with disposable components less likely to carry bacteria from one patient to another.

headline: ‘Yellowjackets’ Season 2 Premiere Recap: Best Friends Forever
abstract: The hit Showtime series returns to find the young and pregnant Shauna becoming a little kooky. And hungry.
lead_paragraph: In a 1994 interview with The Baltimore Sun about her album “Under the Pink,” Tori Amos explained: “Part of this record is dealing with the betrayal of women, by women.” She went on to say that “the history of woman has been very lonely, and when you think that we should support each other, understand each other, that makes sense to me.”

headline: A Cellist Breaks Music Into ‘Fragments,’ Then Connects Them
abstract: Alisa Weilerstein’s latest project is a series of staged solo recitals that weave Bach’s cello suites with newly commissioned works.
lead_paragraph: When the cellist Alisa Weilerstein found herself cooped up with her family at the start of the pandemic, her first instinct, like that of so many classical musicians, was to find some way — any way — to communicate.

headline: Everything but the Girl Breaks a 24-Year Silence With a Bang
abstract: Tracey Thorn and Ben Watt’s personal partnership has thrived since their duo’s last release. During the pandemic, they reconnected musically for “Fuse,” reclaiming the group’s modern melancholy.
lead_paragraph: At first, Tracey Thorn and Ben Watt didn’t want to admit to themselves that they were re-emerging — after 24 years — as Everything but the Girl.

headline: Who Is the Bad Art Boss?
abstract: Tom Sachs made an art career on casual shock value and relationships with luxury brands. Now he’s under attack for what employees say was an abusive studio environment.
lead_paragraph: Tom Sachs, the downtown artist who has recently come to broader public attention over accusations of epically mistreating his studio assistants, first emerged as a creature of interest to high-rolling, mid-cult New York in 1994, when he built a crèche for Barneys Christmas windows and cast Hello Kitty in the role of Jesus. Outraged, Catholic groups placed hundreds of calls to the store, and the display was quickly removed. Still, it was a time when a calculatedly offensive expression, a tasteless gesture, did not signal the midnight of a career so much as the bright early morning.

headline: ‘Bonkers’ Bond Trading May Be Sending a Grim Signal About the Economy
abstract: Wild swings in the Treasury market are unlike anything many investors today had seen. They’re also potentially warning of a recession.
lead_paragraph: In the typically tame market for government bonds, investors have been left reeling from some of the most chaotic trading conditions they have ever seen, entrenching concerns about the broader economy since the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank.

headline: ‘Succession’: Which Rat Could Win the Race?
