headline: Mississippi’s Season Is Done. Coach Yo Says the Rebels Are Just Warming Up.
abstract: Yolett McPhee-McCuin, buoyed by her confidence, represents a new wave of coaching in women’s college basketball. “We’re gliding now,” she said of her Rebels.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Becoming a college basketball contender, the kind of team with enough enduring quality that it regularly competes for national titles, involves a series of incremental steps.

headline: Israel’s Defense Minister Says Government Should Halt Contentious Judicial Plan
abstract: Yoav Gallant, who oversees Israel’s military, is the first minister in Benjamin Netanyahu’s government to criticize a plan to weaken the judiciary. His comments follow fears that weeks of unrest have undermined military capacity.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Israeli defense minister, Yoav Gallant, called on Saturday night for his government to suspend its contentious plan to overhaul the country’s judiciary, arguing that the turmoil it has unleashed within Israeli society and the military has become a threat to Israel’s national security.

headline: Before 12:01 A.M., Migrants on Foot Dashed Into Canada to Beat Deadline
abstract: A freer era of migration into Canada ended on Saturday when officials stopped accepting asylum petitions from people who walk in at unofficial crossings.
lead_paragraph: At precisely midnight, two officers pulled a black tarp and plastic sheet off a newly erected sign at what has been the most famous unofficial border crossing in Canada, Roxham Road. “STOP. DO NOT CROSS,” it told asylum seekers in French and English, warning that if they did come into Canada, they might be sent back to the United States.

headline: President Is Ousted in United Auto Workers Election
abstract: Shawn Fain, an insurgent, edged Ray Curry after calling for a harder line in contract talks. The union has been dogged by corruption scandals.
lead_paragraph: An insurgent candidate has won the presidency of the United Auto Workers union, potentially setting the organization on a more confrontational path as it heads into contract talks this year with the three Detroit automakers.

headline: Mitch McConnell Released From Inpatient Rehab After Concussion
abstract: The Senate minority leader left the rehabilitation facility on Saturday and said he would be working from home for the next few days. He had been injured in a fall earlier this month.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell, the Kentucky Republican and minority leader who suffered a concussion in a serious fall earlier this month, was released from inpatient rehabilitation on Saturday, according to a statement he released Saturday evening.

headline: I Do, I Do … Do!
abstract: David Karp’s Sunday puzzle challenges our chakras.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: NPR Cuts 10% of Staff and Halts Production of 4 Podcasts
abstract: Production will stop on “Invisibilia,” “Louder Than a Riot,” “Rough Translation” and “Everyone & Their Mom.”
lead_paragraph: NPR laid off 10 percent of its staff this week and announced that it would stop production of four podcasts — “Invisibilia,” “Louder Than a Riot,” “Rough Translation” and “Everyone & Their Mom” — to make up for a $30 million gap in its budget.

headline: Here’s How You Can Help the Victims of the Mississippi Tornadoes
abstract: These are a few charitable organizations involved in the relief effort.
lead_paragraph: Recovery efforts are only just beginning for the communities that were devastated by the tornadoes that swept across Mississippi and Alabama late Friday night.

headline: In the Mississippi County Where a Legend Was Born, Damaged Sculptures of ‘Teddy’s Bear’
abstract: More than a century after a storied hunting trip by Theodore Roosevelt, the storm destroyed artworks that were part of a county tradition.
lead_paragraph: In the hours after tornadoes ripped through the community of Rolling Fork, Fred Miller took stock of what needed to be rebuilt and repaired: the homes and businesses, the newly refurbished visitor’s center and its trove of artifacts, and the beloved restaurant, Chuck’s Dairy Bar.

headline: In Blow to Taiwan, Honduras Switches Relations to China
abstract: The decision by Honduras is also a setback in Washington’s efforts to use its influence in Central America to help prevent China from isolating Taiwan.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — China has persuaded Honduras to abandon formal ties with Taiwan and establish them with Beijing, a blow to Taipei’s international standing days before the Taiwanese president embarks on a Central American tour that will take her through the United States.

headline: Caitlin Clark Is Everywhere
abstract: The Iowa star scored 31 points on Friday, including one of her signature “logo” 3-pointers. Here’s a look at her dominating range.
lead_paragraph: The Iowa star scored 31 points on Friday, including one of her signature “logo” 3-pointers. Here’s a look at her dominating range.

headline: Trump Puts His Legal Peril at Center of First Big Rally for 2024
abstract: Facing a potential indictment, the former president devoted much of his speech in Waco, Texas, to criticizing the justice system, though his attacks were less personal and caustic than in recent days.
lead_paragraph: WACO, Texas — Former President Donald J. Trump spent much of his first major political rally of the 2024 campaign portraying his expected indictment by a New York grand jury as a result of what he claimed was a Democratic conspiracy to persecute him, arguing wildly that the United States was turning into a “banana republic.”

headline: Jonathan Majors Arrested in New York After Domestic Dispute
abstract: The actor, who recently co-starred in “Creed III” and is viewed as a rising star in Hollywood, was charged with assault and harassment.
lead_paragraph: The actor Jonathan Majors was arrested on Saturday in Manhattan and charged with assault and harassment after what the police in New York described as a “domestic dispute.”

headline: Brothers Renew a Rivalry When Creighton Plays San Diego State
abstract: Creighton’s Arthur Kaluma and San Diego State’s Adam Seiko have faced each other at the N.C.A.A. tournament, and plenty of other times, before.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Inevitably, there will be a moment on Sunday when Creighton’s Arthur Kaluma, a silky, skilled, 6-foot-7 sophomore, is isolated against San Diego State’s Adam Seiko, a compact, rugged, 6-foot-3 senior, each desperately intent on taking his team to the Final Four for the first time.

headline: Steve Cohen’s Amazin’, Maddening, Money-Losing Bid to Own New York
abstract: Once a symbol of Wall Street excess, Cohen has invested lavishly in the Mets, becoming the most beloved billionaire in Queens. Is that enough to reverse team history?
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Around early 2020, before the New York Mets were his, Steven A. Cohen received an unexpected request: Justin Verlander, then the Houston Astros’ ace, wanted to speak with him.

headline: Quotation of the Day: At Least 26 Die as Tornadoes Wreck Rural South
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 26, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “My city is gone.”

headline: Corrections: March 26, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, March 26, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Page 1 this weekend about an East Village building and the generations of its history being captured in a song cycle by David Hajdu misspells the surname of the owner of the Paradox, a macrobiotic restaurant once located in the building. He is David Puchkoff, not Pushkoff.

headline: Nominee for F.A.A. Post Withdraws From Consideration
abstract: Phillip A. Washington’s Republican critics had complained that he lacked aviation experience and raised questions about his connection to a corruption investigation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s nominee to lead the Federal Aviation Administration, Phillip A. Washington, has withdrawn from consideration for the job, according to the White House.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: The Word ‘Tattoo’ in New York Times Ink
abstract: It has referred to body art, repetitive sound and last call.
lead_paragraph: In Word Through The Times, we trace how one word or phrase has changed throughout the history of the newspaper.

headline: ‘The Driver Turned His Head Slowly to Look Directly at the Woman’
abstract: Riding an uptown bus, an easily identified flying object and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Esther Perel’s Business Is Your Business
abstract: She is podcasting-famous, considered a “crossover breakthrough artist” by other therapists — and still trying to both see patients and conquer new platforms.
lead_paragraph: The talk was about trauma and intimacy. But the presentation was vintage Esther Perel — warm and playful, erudite and provocative, enhanced by her rich soufflé of an accent (which sounds French but is in fact Belgian). Alluding to the Mexican poet Octavio Paz and the Argentine writer Jorge Luis Borges, she asked: “What if accessing the erotic is the catalyst that helps the recovery from the trauma?”

headline: How the Saw Lady Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Natalia Paruz, a musical saw player who is also a bell ringer for her church, tends to her garden, her six cats and the neighborhood birds.
lead_paragraph: “To most people, the concept of playing a musical saw is akin to chopping a log in half with a cello,” said Natalia Paruz, also known as the Saw Lady, who often plays a toothless saw in the subways and other public venues.

headline: Victor LaValle’s Latest Mixes Horror With a History of the West
abstract: His novel “Lone Women” follows a Black homesteader in Montana who is haunted by secrets and a dark past.
lead_paragraph: Victor LaValle’s enthralling fifth novel, “Lone Women,” opens like a true western, with a scene of dark, bloody upheaval and a hint of vengeance. But nothing in this genre-melding book is as it seems. When we meet Adelaide Henry, the grown daughter of Black farmers, she is in a daze, dumping gasoline all over her family’s farmhouse. We don’t know why she’s doing what she’s doing, what happened to her family or, most important, what else she has or hasn’t done.

headline: From a Suicide Expert, an Unflinching Guide to Saving Lives
abstract: After 10 attempts and years of suffering and addiction, Clancy Martin describes facing the darkness in his raw memoir “How Not to Kill Yourself.”
lead_paragraph: Some titles are blunt instruments, and “How Not to Kill Yourself” is the bluntest I’ve encountered yet in this job. The book it describes, by Clancy Martin, is a doozy: messy, confessional but ultimately beneficent. Casting a harsh high beam on a growing societal problem, swaddled in mental-health resources and caveats, it doesn’t so much illuminate as irradiate.

headline: In China, Marriage Rates Are Down and ‘Bride Prices’ Are Up
abstract: China’s one-child policy has led to too few women. Grooms are now paying more money for wives, in a tradition that has faced growing resistance.
lead_paragraph: The 30 women sat in wooden chairs, facing each other in a rectangular formation. At the front of the room was the ruling Communist Party’s hammer and sickle logo, with a sign declaring the meeting’s purpose: “Symposium of unmarried young women of the right age.”

headline: They Left Town as Convicts. Will They Be Buried as Heroes?
abstract: As thousands of ex-prisoners fight and die in Ukraine, honoring their memory is becoming a patriotic imperative in Russia. But some committed crimes their old neighbors cannot forget.
lead_paragraph: When the corpse of a Wagner mercenary fighter arrived in his small Russian village in late February after he was killed fighting in Ukraine, some residents wanted to give him a hero’s burial. Others could not forget that the former prisoner had stabbed his father to death.

headline: What Evan Mock Wore to His Kombucha Party
abstract: And the interior stylist Colin King hosted a book party at his TriBeCa loft.
lead_paragraph: Party at a magazine store? That was the story behind a cool-kid takeover of Iconic Magazine at the corner of Mulberry and Kenmare Streets in SoHo, hosted by the skateboarder-turned-actor Evan Mock for JuneShine, a hard kombucha brand. The March 16 event drew an overflow crowd of downtown scenesters including the rapper Asap Ferg, the actor Eli Brown and the music artist Austin Millz.

headline: Putin Says He Could Put Tactical Nuclear Weapons in Belarus by Summer
abstract: The proposal from President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, talked of since last year, would be provocative without changing the West’s battlefield calculus in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said he would be able to position nuclear weapons in Belarus by the summer, a claim that analysts said was likely bluster but which underscored the Kremlin’s determination to use its vast nuclear arsenal to pressure the West to back down from its support of Ukraine.

headline: The Potential Trump Indictment Is Unwise
abstract: Why I’m skeptical of the Manhattan district attorney’s case.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in American history, a hotly anticipated indictment of a former American president may actually be handed up. Manhattan’s district attorney, Alvin L. Bragg, seems set to bring charges related to Donald Trump’s allegedly paying off a porn star named Stormy Daniels to cover up their affair. There are, however, significant problems with the case.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘How Danhausen Became Professional Wrestling’s Strangest Star’
abstract: What’s the best way for a not particularly athletic barista-slash-wrestling geek to go pro? Act really weird.
lead_paragraph: Like a lot of people who get into professional wrestling, Donovan Danhausen had a vision of a different version of himself. Ten years ago, at age 21, he was living in Detroit, working as a nursing assistant at a hospital, watching a lot of “Adult Swim” and accumulating a collection of horror- and comedy-themed tattoos.

headline: When I Got Cancer, My Dreams Told Me What My Doctors Could Not
abstract: When all the rational decision-making options are bad, relying on dreams offers a different kind of logic that can be a lifesaver in its own way.
lead_paragraph: As soon as I woke up from the dream about two helicopters crashing onto a highway, I called my doctor’s office and asked for a mammogram.

headline: A.I. Can’t Write My Cat Story Because It Hasn’t Felt What I Feel
abstract: A.I. hasn’t suffered enough to write this essay.
lead_paragraph: For a few years, I’ve been trying to write a story about a cat. A.I. will not be able to write this, partly because the story is still inside my imagination and on a few rough pages that were originally drafted in Boston, on sheets of notebook paper, as I sat in my daughter’s apartment on a hot summer day.

headline: How China Keeps Putting Off Its Lehman Moment
abstract: Chinese regulators have proved the financial doomsayers wrong again and again. But their biggest test may yet lie ahead.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Remember the Evergrande crisis?

headline: The Week in Business: TikTok in the Hot Seat
abstract: The Fed raised interest rates, even as some banks continued to find themselves on shaky ground. The A.I. race is on. And a new inflation reading is coming.
lead_paragraph: Shou Chew, the chief executive of TikTok, did not meet a warm reception when he appeared before lawmakers in Congress for the first time last week. During more than five hours of testimony, Mr. Shou was barraged with questions about TikTok’s effects on teenagers’ mental health, limits to onscreen time, the relationship between the app and its Chinese parent company, ByteDance, and how it treats the data of its American users. The questions came from lawmakers on both sides of the aisle, an indication of how the viral social app had become part of the larger battle between the United States and China over technological and economic supremacy. Mr. Chew tried to convince lawmakers of TikTok’s distance from China’s government, at times by emphasizing his own biography: Mr. Chew lives in Singapore and attended business school in the United States. He also stated that ByteDance was a private company “not owned or controlled by the Chinese government.” But he failed to reassure lawmakers. “Your platform should be banned,” one House Republican told him.

headline: History in the Rubble
abstract: Documenting the damage of last month’s earthquakes in Turkey.
lead_paragraph: Times graphics reporters Anjali Singhvi and Bedel Saget recently traveled to Antakya, a Turkish city badly damaged by February’s earthquakes. Based on their reporting, they published an article this week that walks through the damage in Antakya’s Old City, a commercial and religious hub.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | March 27, 2023
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:

headline: Israel Boils as Netanyahu Ousts Minister Who Bucked Court Overhaul
abstract: Protests broke out shortly after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu fired the defense minister, who had called for a halt to efforts to weaken the judiciary.
lead_paragraph: Civil unrest broke out in parts of Israel Sunday night after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu fired his defense minister for criticizing the government’s divisive judicial overhaul, prompting protesters to surge into the streets, universities to shut their doors, and union leaders to hint of a looming general strike.

headline: The Global Transformation of Christianity Is Here
abstract: The influx of nonwhite believers will challenge white religious conservatives to choose between xenophobia and building alliances with immigrants who share their views on social issues.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, I went to a worship service that, in many ways, was like a thousand evangelical services I’d seen before. People raised their hands while singing and cried out “Glory to God!” and “Amen.” People stood and gave “testimony,” telling stories of finding hope or healing from pain. They read Bible verses and prayed prayers. There was a clear difference, however, from most worship services I’ve attended: Nearly everyone in the room was an immigrant and a person of color. We sang in English but also in Spanish, Portuguese, Igbo and Nepali.

headline: We Have Cutting-Edge Science to Make Vaccines, but Will Everyone Benefit?
abstract: A vaccine scientist on what needs to change.
lead_paragraph: As a physician-scientist who has spent nearly 40 years studying viruses and immunity, I can speak to the scientific advances that made rapid Covid-19 vaccine development possible. I oversaw the work at the National Institutes of Health’s Vaccine Research Center that provided the basis for designing and evaluating the initial Covid-19 vaccines and antibodies.

headline: George Washington University Is Moving on From ‘Colonials’
abstract: The move comes amid a reckoning of the fraught history of team names across American sports. Potential new names include: “Ambassadors,” “Blue Fog,” “Revolutionaries” and “Sentinels.”
lead_paragraph: George Washington University will soon choose a new nickname for its athletic teams, dropping “Colonials” after years of pressure from students who said the name was entangled with violence toward Native Americans and other colonized people.

headline: At Apple, Rare Dissent Over a New Product: Interactive Goggles
abstract: The company is expected to unveil an augmented reality headset in a few months. Some employees wonder if the device makes sense for Apple.
lead_paragraph: When Apple held a corporate retreat in California’s Carmel Valley about five years ago to discuss its next major product, Jony Ive, its longtime design chief, captivated a room of the company’s 100 top executives with a concept video as polished as an Apple commercial.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Stuffed peppers, carne asada and more recipes.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Lately I’ve been making a cherry tomato salsa to accompany my Sunday carne asada (above): the tomatoes (halved), a small red onion (sliced), a fistful of cilantro (chopped) and a couple of limes (juiced). I salt the mixture and allow it to sit while I sear the flap meat I buy instead of more expensive skirt or hanger steak. Then I serve the (rested) sliced meat with the salsa, warm flour tortillas, hot sauce and crema. This is an exceptional way to spend time on a Sunday evening, and I commend the experience to you unreservedly.

headline: A Conservative’s View of What ‘Woke’ Means
abstract: Readers react to a column by Ross Douthat. Also: Budget proposals and actual spending; the music scene on FM radio.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Ro Khanna Endorses Barbara Lee’s Senate Campaign as He Declines to Run
abstract: The race in California to succeed Senator Dianne Feinstein is likely to be one of the most expensive in the nation in 2024.
lead_paragraph: Representative Ro Khanna of California said on Sunday that he would not run in an already crowded Democratic field seeking to succeed his state’s senior senator, Dianne Feinstein, who is retiring at the end of her term.

headline: His ‘Soft White Cube’ Is Conquering TriBeCa
abstract: With more than a dozen projects, the architect Markus Dochantschi of studioMDA is reshaping the state of the art gallery, one historic building at a time.
lead_paragraph: Construction crews were roaming TriBeCa. All around, one could hear the omnipresent drills echoing from within historic cast-iron buildings. Inside 384 Broadway, standing before a junk heap quadruple his size, the architect Markus Dochantschi was explaining how a gallery might find its own identity when virtually everyone has the same white walls and concrete floors. God was in the details — and in the lighting fixtures and in the floorboards.

headline: Review: In Chicago, an Opera Triptych Reaches for Connection
abstract: Lyric Opera of Chicago follows a recent world premiere with yet another: “Proximity,” a set of works by three librettist-composer pairs.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Major opera companies used to put on new or recent works once in a blue moon. But, astonishingly, pieces by living composers make up about a third of the Metropolitan Opera’s coming season. And on Friday, Lyric Opera of Chicago, just a month after one world premiere, presented another.

headline: In pictures: Violent storms leave behind scenes of devastation and heartbreak.
abstract: Photographers on the ground captured scenes of storm’s aftermath.
lead_paragraph: The storm system that ripped through Mississippi and Alabama over the weekend, causing at least 26 deaths, and left residents and volunteers in the Mississippi town of Rolling Fork digging through rubble.

headline: Elon Musk Values Twitter at $20 Billion
abstract: The billionaire bought the social media company for $44 billion in October and took it private.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Elon Musk said Twitter is now worth about $20 billion, according to an email he sent the company’s employees on Friday, a significant drop from the $44 billion that he paid to buy the social network in October.

headline: Trump’s Rally Was Just What I Expected. He’s Stuck in a Rut.
abstract: Trump is still fighting old battles. But Republicans have moved on to their own war, a new war, a culture war.
lead_paragraph: WACO, Texas — In the first big rally of his 2024 presidential campaign, Donald Trump didn’t dwell on the symbolism of speaking in Waco amid the 30th anniversary of the deadly siege there that still serves as a right-wing cri de coeur against federal authority.

headline: Little Lionsgate Soars to the Top With John Wick Ticket Sales
abstract: “John Wick: Chapter 4” took in roughly $73.5 million on its opening weekend, a rare phenomenon this far into a series.
lead_paragraph: A small Hollywood studio, one that has struggled to remain relevant in a fast-changing film business, delivered a master class in movie franchise management over the weekend.

headline: MAGA, Not Trump, Controls the Movement Now
abstract: It’s clear who runs today’s G.O.P.
lead_paragraph: The most telling exchange in Donald Trump’s Waco, Texas, rally on Saturday didn’t come from Trump himself. It came at the beginning, when the aging rock star Ted Nugent was warming up the crowd. “I want my money back,” he yelled. “I didn’t authorize any money to Ukraine, to some homosexual weirdo.”

headline: Philadelphia Monitoring Water Supply After Chemical Spill
abstract: More than 8,000 gallons of an acrylic polymer solution leaked on Friday into a tributary of the Delaware River, a source of the city’s drinking water.
lead_paragraph: Philadelphia officials on Sunday evening stepped back from a suggestion earlier in the day that residents consider using bottled water rather than tap water for drinking and cooking after a chemical leaked into a tributary of the Delaware River, a source of drinking water for about 14 million people across four states.

headline: Scott Johnson, Playfully Inventive Composer, Is Dead at 70
abstract: In works like “John Somebody,” he mixed the structural rigor of classical composition with the ebullient sound and attitude of rock.
lead_paragraph: Scott Johnson, a composer and guitarist who forged an original style involving the rhythmic cadences of speech and the gestures and timbres of popular music, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 70.

headline: Your Monday Briefing: Arms Race in Asia
abstract: Also, Putin’s nuclear brinkmanship and a rift in the Israeli government.
lead_paragraph: Countries across Asia and the Pacific are bolstering their defense budgets, spooked by China’s military buildup, Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and doubts about U.S. resolve in the region. The current arms race is the most significant in Asia since World War II.

headline: U.N. Investigators Protest to U.S. Over Health Care at Guantánamo Bay
abstract: The rapporteurs filed the complaint with the United States on Jan. 11 but kept it confidential until this weekend. Washington has yet to respond.
lead_paragraph: Two months ago, seven United Nations human rights investigators sent the U.S. government a protest over health care for detainees at Guantánamo Bay that described troubling treatment of an Iraqi prisoner who is now disabled.

headline: Furious Finishes Set the Final Four: Miami and San Diego State Are In
abstract: Fifth-seeded Miami rallied from 13 points down to beat Texas, while a foul and a free throw gave another No. 5 seed, San Diego State, a win over Creighton. They join UConn and Florida Atlantic.
lead_paragraph: Miami, trailing and listless for much of the first 30 minutes of its round-of-8 game against Texas on Sunday, mounted a stunning, compact comeback in the men’s N.C.A.A. tournament to claim the last spot in the Final Four next weekend in Houston.

headline: Ready When You Are
abstract: Simon Marotte and Trenton Lee Stewart have some questions for you.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Twitter Says Parts of Its Source Code Were Leaked Online
abstract: The leak adds to the challenges facing the Elon Musk-owned company, which is trying to identify the person responsible and any other people who downloaded the code.
lead_paragraph: Parts of Twitter’s source code, the underlying computer code on which the social network runs, were leaked online, according to a legal filing, a rare and major exposure of intellectual property as the company struggles to reduce technical issues and reverse its business fortunes under Elon Musk.

headline: Protests Erupt in Israel After Netanyahu Fires Defense Minister
abstract: Israelis demonstrated after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu dismissed a member of his cabinet who had called for a halt to the government’s planned judicial overhaul.
lead_paragraph: Israelis demonstrated after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu dismissed a member of his cabinet who had called for a halt to the government’s planned judicial overhaul.

headline: ‘He’s Here’: The Anthony Volpe Era Begins for Yankees
abstract: Volpe, 21, grew up rooting for Derek Jeter. Making the Yankees’ opening day roster after a hot preseason, Volpe will try to pick up where his idol left off.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — He was somewhere downtown, Anthony Volpe remembers, though not near City Hall, because he didn’t hear the speeches. Wherever he started in that giddy crowd of Yankees fans, he ended up in front.

headline: Gun Violence Has Changed Us
abstract: Times readers share how rising gun deaths across the country have affected their outlook — and, in some cases, their life choices.
lead_paragraph: Times readers share how rising gun deaths across the country have affected their outlook — and, in some cases, their life choices.

headline: Review: The Many Thrilling Flavors of a Full-Scale ‘Sweeney Todd’
abstract: Sondheim’s masterpiece, restored to its proper size and sung to the hilt by Josh Groban, makes a welcome Broadway return.
lead_paragraph: How do you like your “Sweeney Todd” done?

headline: Caitlin Clark Leads Iowa to the Final Four, While L.S.U. Gets Past Its Cold Shooting
abstract: Clark delivered a 41-point triple-double against Louisville to take Iowa to its second Final Four; Angel Reese recorded her 32nd double-double of the season to propel L.S.U. over Miami.
lead_paragraph: Iowa is headed to the Final Four of the women’s N.C.A.A. tournament for the second time in program history after Caitlin Clark led an offensive assault on fifth-seeded Louisville in a 97-83 win.

headline: ‘Succession’ Season 4 Premiere Recap: Many Happy Returns
abstract: The Roy family is back for a fourth and final season, and everyone came out swinging. Let the humiliations begin.
lead_paragraph: Have you ever noticed that “Succession” is a show about deal-makers in which hardly any deals are ever completed? Every major acquisition or transfer of power always seems to be 48 hours away. Everyone always needs to iron out a few more details, get a few more stragglers from the board into the fold, toss in a few more sweeteners for the major shareholders, et cetera. How many times over the course of this series have the principals actually signed on the dotted line?

headline: Jet Shook, Killing Ex-White House Aide, After Pilots Shut Off Key System, Report Says
abstract: Dana Hyde sustained fatal injuries during the flight in New England after pilots turned off a switch that controls a stabilizer function in the aircraft, a preliminary report said.
lead_paragraph: A business jet carrying a former White House official this month pitched up and down in midair, causing her death, after pilots turned off a system that stabilizes the plane, the National Transportation Safety Board said in a preliminary report.

headline: ‘Nemesis’ Review: A Philip Roth Adaptation Resonates
abstract: The American writer’s last novel becomes surprisingly effective theater in the hands of Tiphaine Raffier at the Odéon-Théâtre de l’Europe.
lead_paragraph: You can imagine directors being warned away from adapting the work of Philip Roth. The film versions of his novels have been panned so consistently that a writer for The Atlantic in 2014 called for them to stop. Few playhouses have even attempted to translate them for the stage.

headline: Quotation of the Day: In the Amazon, a Tribe Is Being Poisoned
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, March 27, 2023
lead_paragraph: “In the last four years, we have seen apathy, perhaps intentional. They failed to act, aware that they were allowing a humanitarian crisis to happen.”

headline: As Banking Worries Swirl, Europe’s Policymakers Express Confidence, With Caution
abstract: Officials say eurozone lenders are strictly supervised and continue to be strong. But at a recent conference, wariness about the future remained.
lead_paragraph: For a bank, a loss of confidence is a fatal blow. After that occurred at several banks in the United States and Switzerland in the past few weeks, policymakers in the eurozone have been trying to shore up confidence in the region’s banking sector.

headline: In Africa, Kamala Harris Looks to Deepen Relations Amid China’s Influence
abstract: In a weeklong trip to Ghana, Tanzania and Zambia, the vice president will face a balancing act as she tries to foster a collaborative U.S. relationship.
lead_paragraph: In the neon lights of a recording studio, with skateboarders doing tricks a few feet away, Vice President Kamala Harris appeared alongside musicians  in the West African nation of Ghana and pledged to set the American relationship with Africa on a new path, focused on collaboration rather than crises.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Mass protests in Israel.
lead_paragraph: Chaotic protests broke out last night shortly after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu fired his defense minister for criticizing a divisive judicial overhaul. The dismissal intensified an already dramatic domestic crisis — one of the gravest in Israeli history.

headline: The Final Four That Nobody Could Have Expected
abstract: Connecticut has a pedigree but hasn’t made a deep run since 2014. Florida Atlantic plays in a small gym on a campus that’s an owl sanctuary. San Diego State got in on a free throw. And Miami’s coach likes his self-help advice.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — After San Diego State Coach Brian Dutcher snipped the last two strands of the net, he held it aloft like a trophy to admire for his players, coaches, staff and the hundreds of fans who let out a celebratory roar for the Aztecs’ first trip to a men’s Final Four.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Riverdale’ and ‘Royal Crackers’
abstract: Riverdale returns for a seventh season on the CW, and a new animated comedy series comes to Adult Swim.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, March 27- April 2. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Silicon Valley Bank Sold to First Citizens in Government-Backed Deal
abstract: Banking regulators, which announced the deal late Sunday, had been looking for a buyer since seizing control of the failed bank.
lead_paragraph: First Citizens BancShares, a family-run bank in North Carolina that traces its history to the late 1800s, said on Sunday that it would acquire Silicon Valley Bank, the California lender founded in the 1980s at the center of the technology industry, whose rapid growth and sudden collapse this month sent shock waves across the financial sector.

headline: Word of the Day: earnest
abstract: This word has appeared in 464 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word earnest has appeared in 464 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 22 in “Sacramento’s Latest Craze Is Like a Bat Signal” by Kellen Browning:

headline: No Corrections: March 27, 2023
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, March 27, 2023.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: The Mystery of Beethoven’s Skull Remains Unsolved
abstract: A researcher at Mount Sinai thought he was testing a piece of the composer’s skull. Later he learned he might have been mistaken.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll revisit the day I saw what was billed as a fragment from the composer Ludwig van Beethoven’s skull.

headline: Taiwan’s Ex-President Heads to China in Historic and Closely Watched Visit
abstract: Though his visit is not official, it is nonetheless significant and may offer clues to political calculations on both sides of the increasingly tense Taiwan Strait.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Taiwan’s former president, Ma Ying-jeou, landed in China on Monday in the first visit to the country by any sitting or former Taiwanese leader since China’s civil war ended with the Nationalist government retreating to the island from the mainland in 1949.

headline: A Trump-DeSantis War of Words
abstract: The two men have increasingly clashed lately. But while Trump has delivered his usual stream of insults, DeSantis has operated from a more old-school playbook.
lead_paragraph: The two men have increasingly clashed lately. But while Trump has delivered his usual stream of insults, DeSantis has operated from a more old-school playbook.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Finding Common Ground With the Commissioner
abstract: While interviewing Rob Manfred for his book about baseball, Joe Kelly, an outspoken reliever, realized their goals weren’t all that different.
lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Ariz. — When a middle reliever published a candid book in 1970, the commissioner of baseball ordered him to his office to formally express dismay. When a middle reliever was writing a book that was published this year, the commissioner granted an interview for it.

headline: A Whole New (Old) Ballgame
abstract: With three major rule changes this season, Major League Baseball will try to reinvent itself while looking to the game’s past for inspiration.
lead_paragraph: The commissioner of Major League Baseball is always in demand, which makes it hard, these days, to actually watch a game.

headline: ‘Catastrophe’ for Poor New Yorkers as Pandemic Food Aid Ends
abstract: The Met Council, a major nonprofit, is calling for nearly $13 million in emergency city funding for food pantries.
lead_paragraph: For nearly three years, New Yorkers have been able to take advantage of a pandemic-era lifeline that provided people like Jocelyne Grandu, a retired French teacher who lives in Harlem, with an extra $80 each month in food stamp benefits.

headline: Clash Over Building Atop Native Burial Sites Angers N.Y. Tribes
abstract: After battles with previous governors, New York’s Native American leaders were hopeful for a reset with Kathy Hochul’s administration. Instead, the tensions have increased.
lead_paragraph: MONTAUK, N.Y. — New York’s Native American tribes fought bitterly with former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo over his efforts to tax their tobacco sales and seize a sizable share of their gambling proceeds, and they blamed him for the deterioration of a stretch of interstate that slices through tribal lands.

headline: How Big Law and Black Brooklyn Fueled Hakeem Jeffries’s Rise
abstract: The House Democrats’ new leader, whose path was shaped as much by the Black Baptist church and hip-hop as it was by Manhattan’s legal elite, is hard to pigeonhole.
lead_paragraph: The campus at Binghamton University was in uproar. Whispers of outside agitators swirled among the mostly white student body. Security was heightened.

headline: The Israeli Government’s Plan to Overhaul the Judiciary: What to Know
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s right-wing government contends the Supreme Court has unchecked power, but critics of the proposal say it goes too far.
lead_paragraph: Israel is in the throes of a grave political crisis that ballooned in recent days to envelop crucial components of society — the military, universities and trade unions — and has caused strains with Israel’s foreign allies, chief among them the United States.

headline: The Ukrainians hold on with old tanks, but relish the idea of advancing with modern Western battle tanks.
abstract: OUTSKIRTS OF BAKHMUT, Ukraine — Large snowflakes drifted silently through the trees as two Soviet-era tanks roared to life and churned through the mud up the hill. It was daybreak on one of the last days of winter, and the tank commander and his deputy tramped through the snow checking on the men as they readied for battle.
lead_paragraph: OUTSKIRTS OF BAKHMUT, Ukraine — Large snowflakes drifted silently through the trees as two Soviet-era tanks roared to life and churned through the mud up the hill. It was daybreak on one of the last days of winter, and the tank commander and his deputy tramped through the snow checking on the men as they readied for battle.

headline: Build Your Own College Rankings
abstract: The values that you care about most should inform your top college choices.
lead_paragraph: The values that you care about most should inform your top college choices.

headline: Can the U.S. See the Truth About China?
abstract: The economist Keyu Jin argues that if it can’t, “peaceful coexistence may not be possible.”
lead_paragraph: The economist Keyu Jin argues that if it can’t, “peaceful coexistence may not be possible.”

headline: How ‘Build Your Own College Rankings’ Was Built
abstract: A guide to Times Opinion’s college ranking tool.
lead_paragraph: Times Opinion has built a tool that we hope will help students, parents and other readers think anew about the high-stress process of choosing the right college or university — and whether one “right” school ever really exists. This tool allows you to design your own college rankings: You tell us what matters to you and we’ll give you a list of schools that best matches your priorities.

headline: How Do I Find a New Style Identity?
abstract: A reader is seeking a wardrobe fit for a fresh start.
lead_paragraph: First, it is truly impressive that you had the strength to escape a bad situation, and second, congratulations on rebuilding your life.

headline: We Talked to 10 Graduates About Their College Regrets
abstract: Here’s what they’d tell their high school selves.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what they’d tell their high school selves.

headline: How Often Do You Just ‘Hang Out’ With Others?
abstract: Spending time together doing nothing: When, where and with whom do you chill? Do you wish you did more of it?
lead_paragraph: When is the last time you hung out with one or more friends — not to study or work on a project for school, not as part of an extracurricular activity, not while earning money at a job or volunteering at an event — but just plain old chilling out together?

headline: And You Thought Your Family Had Problems
abstract: In “The New Earth,” Jess Row introduces us to the Wilcoxes, who are buffeted by racial and sexual secrets, Middle East hatreds — and literary trickery.
lead_paragraph: Officially, there is no hall of fame for unhappy families. But even the staunchest Russian novelist might be hard pressed to match the particular gift for dysfunction that the Wilcoxes, subjects of Jess Row’s sprawling metafiction “The New Earth,” display with such impressive esprit de corps across nearly 600 dense and often wildly discursive pages. Death and divorce are a given; immigration, climate change and crises of faith crowd the margins, clambering to compete with a thousand-year conflict in the Middle East. Incest eventually enters the chat, an assiduous but uninvited guest, and race hovers over it all, a quivering question mark. (The impetus for everything, naturally, is a wedding.)

headline: Mayor Proposes First Composting Mandate in New York City
abstract: The city would require New Yorkers with yards to separate their leaf and yard waste from trash. The program is expected to start in Queens in June.
lead_paragraph: The Adams administration will propose New York City’s first composting mandate on Monday — requiring that residents who have yards separate their leaves, flowers, twigs and grass clippings for compost.

headline: There’s Only One College Rankings List That Matters
abstract: My advice to the many anxious college applicants and their parents is to think about what you really want.
lead_paragraph: DURHAM, N.C. — Within a few months of joining the faculty at Duke University in 2021, I could spot them: the high school seniors, juniors and even sophomores on their pilgrimages to our verdant and coveted wonderland, with its Gothic Revival spires, ecstatic basketball fans and acceptance rate of 6 percent.

headline: The Slow-Motion Tidal Wave Consuming Our Economy
abstract: Economic models are failing us because they don’t reflect large forces that are starting to affect our economy: climate change, demographics, deglobalization and artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: Our economy today has been described variously as “weird,” “really weird” and “very, very weird.”

headline: Welcome to Immortality. Your Body Can’t Come With You.
abstract: Jaroslav Kalfar’s novel “A Brief History of Living Forever” is set in a future America where dead is the new old.
lead_paragraph: Jaroslav Kalfar’s first novel, “Spaceman of Bohemia” (2017), was about a vaguely bewildered Czech professor of astrophysics who blasts into space on an urgent mission. Once up there, his wife back on Earth leaves him and (worse?) a giant, hairy spider latches onto his spaceship. The spider, unlike his wife, can read his mind.

headline: Kristin Chenoweth Lives for 3 A.M. FaceTime Calls and ‘Funny Girl’
abstract: The actress is returning for the second season of “Schmigadoon!” Reality TV and occasional shopping sprees have kept her going in the meantime.
lead_paragraph: If you are Kristin Chenoweth’s friend, she will call you in the middle of the night, and it will be a FaceTime.

headline: Are We Actually Arguing About Whether 14-Year-Olds Should Work in Meatpacking Plants?
abstract: Rollbacks on child labor protections are happening amid a surge of child labor violations.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Sarah Huckabee Sanders of Arkansas signed a bill this month rolling back the state’s child labor protections, making it easier for employers to hire children under 16. Elsewhere, bills to allow 14- and 15-year-olds to work in meatpacking plants and other dangerous jobs in Iowa as part of training programs and 16- and 17-year-olds to take jobs at construction sites in Minnesota are under consideration.

headline: The Romance Went Nice and Slow. So, Too, Did the Apartment Hunt.
abstract: A couple was waiting for the right time to move in together. After a long search and a surprising twist, the perfect apartment found them.
lead_paragraph: When Scott Warfel met Luccas Israel in 2019 through friends, neither thought romance was in their future. But during the pandemic, their friendship moved slowly, thoughtfully, into a deeper connection.

headline: Trump Would Like a Word
abstract: Or maybe more than a word.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: Bret, I have to admit that when the subject of Donald Trump comes up these days, I tend to start telling sex-scandal stories. My bad.

headline: Meet the Xi Jinping Loyalist Now Overseeing China’s Economy
abstract: He Lifeng’s long career in government has spanned the extremes of China’s approach, from the early embrace of small business in the 1980s to today’s tighter state control.
lead_paragraph: In 1984, when China was in its early embrace of capitalism, 29-year-old He Lifeng was near the center of the action. A Communist Party member with two degrees in government finance, he got a municipal job in Xiamen, a coastal city that had just been freed by Deng Xiaoping from central planning dictates to test free markets.

headline: Germany Wants More Chip Makers, but They Won’t Come Cheap
abstract: The global competition to attract semiconductor companies is expected to cost Berlin billions. Some wonder if it’s a good use of money.
lead_paragraph: Intel, the Silicon Valley chip-making giant, paved the way last year when it picked the eastern German city of Magdeburg as the site for its first semiconductor factory in Europe, pledging to invest 17 billion euros (about $18.3 billion) — provided that Berlin throw in nearly €7 billion in subsidies.

headline: 8 Places to Dazzle the Grandkids in Florida
abstract: Arm yourself with this list of child-friendly activities in the Palm Beach area and never hear the dreaded words “I’m so bored” again.
lead_paragraph: What could be bad about visiting your grandparents in Florida when it’s gray and chilly elsewhere?

headline: Why Tiny Ponds and Singing Frogs Matter So Much
abstract: When we work to preserve frogs and salamanders — when we work to preserve any species — we are working to preserve life on earth as we know it.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — I wish you could hear what it sounds like to sleep near an ephemeral pond in early springtime on the Cumberland Plateau, especially on a rainy night. As darkness begins to fall, the small frogs called spring peepers begin to sing. At first their song is the sonic equivalent of the way popcorn pops: each peep a single sound, each sound buffered on either side by silence.

headline: A Lighthouse to Call Your Own
abstract: A weekend at a family hostel in a light station on the California coast is filled with tide-pooling, stargazing and marking time by the beacon’s flash.
lead_paragraph: It turns out that Pigeon Point was Whale Point until the Carrier Pigeon ran into it.

headline: Reckoning with an Upbringing in a ‘Noah’s Ark’ of a Family, With ‘Two of Every Race’
abstract: Matthew Pratt Guterl’s parents wanted a family that embodied an integrated American future. The “experiment” — his father’s word — had painfully mixed results.
lead_paragraph: It’s early morning in a classroom at Brown University. Six students settle into their seats and consider the cardboard box in front of them: doughnuts. Their teacher, Matthew Pratt Guterl, brings them every Tuesday and Thursday, when he leads the freshman seminar on the history of Black resistance. Today, the class is discussing the book “In My Place,” by Charlayne Hunter-Gault, who was the first Black student to attend the University of Georgia in 1961. Guterl’s students analyze a photograph of Gault taken when she was about their age, a first-year student at an all-white university. Her expression is resolutely composed — a kind of armor, they decide — despite the fact that she has faced down protesters since arriving at school.

headline: In the Basque Region of Spain: Art, Culture and a Puppy That Blooms
abstract: Does a culture-centric family trip have to be boring for the kids? Our writer finds the perfect balance of contemporary art, scary medieval weapons, Gothic cloisters and wide-open space.
lead_paragraph: It’s not every beach stroll that leads to a modernist masterpiece, let alone one set in the sea amid crashing waves.

headline: Restoring a Giant Plane: Ukrainian Resilience or Folly?
abstract: Ukraine, with far more pressing needs, plans to rebuild the colossal Mriya cargo plane, a symbol of pride that was destroyed last year in a battle for its airfield.
lead_paragraph: HOSTOMEL, Ukraine — The gigantic twin tail fins, once stretching as high as a six-story building, are gone.

headline: Save the Gowns!
abstract: What’s the best way to preserve fashion? For some brands, it’s a white-glove storage service.
lead_paragraph: The concept of museum-worthy clothes is arguably as old as museums themselves. But only in modern history did blockbuster fashion exhibits really take off.

headline: People Started Buying Crocs During the Pandemic. They Can’t Stop.
abstract: While other brands that thrived with customers in quarantine have dropped off, sales of the easily slipped-on clogs are up nearly 200 percent since 2019.
lead_paragraph: Like Peloton, Etsy and Zoom, Crocs saw its business boom during the early days of the coronavirus pandemic. The company’s aesthetically questionable but easily slipped-on clogs were the perfect footwear for Americans puttering around their homes, gardens and kitchens during quarantine.

headline: A Sweeping Plan to Protect Kids From Social Media
abstract: A new law in Utah bans any account held by minors without parental consent.
lead_paragraph: A few days ago, Utah became the first state to pass a law prohibiting social media services from allowing users under 18 to have accounts without the explicit consent of a parent or guardian. The move, by Republican officials, is intended to address what they describe as a mental health crisis among American teenagers as well as to protect younger users from bullying and child sexual exploitation.The technology reporter Natasha Singer explains the measure, and why it could be a sign of where the country is headed.

headline: The World Bank estimated the cost of rebuilding Ukraine at $411 billion. Support is growing to use Russian funds for it.
abstract: LONDON — When the World Bank released its latest damage assessment of war-torn Ukraine last week, it announced that the price of recovery and rebuilding had grown to $411 billion. What it didn’t say, though, was who would pay for it.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When the World Bank released its latest damage assessment of war-torn Ukraine last week, it announced that the price of recovery and rebuilding had grown to $411 billion. What it didn’t say, though, was who would pay for it.

headline: A Republican Spending Problem
abstract: Will the House be willing to cut programs that benefit G.O.P. voters?
lead_paragraph: As congressional Republicans prepare for a budget showdown later this year with President Biden, they say that they will insist on large cuts to federal spending. So far, though, they have left out some pretty important details: what those cuts might be.

headline: Markets Climb as Silicon Valley Bank Finally Finds a Buyer
abstract: First Citizens agreed on Sunday to acquire the failed lender’s retail operations. Will the move convince investors that recent turmoil in the sector is over?
lead_paragraph: First Citizens agreed on Sunday night to buy most of Silicon Valley Bank at a discount, clearing the way for the U.S. banking industry to potentially move on from the turmoil set off by the collapse of the tech-focused lender.

headline: $1.6 Million Homes in California
abstract: A midcentury-modern home designed by Cliff May in Long Beach, a 1918 Craftsman house in Oakland and a three-bedroom bungalow in Sierra Madre.
lead_paragraph: Homes in the Rancho Estates tract, designed by the prolific architect Cliff May, are highly sought after by aficionados of his work, which elevated the suburban ranch house with elements of midcentury-modern design. This house is on one of the larger lots in the neighborhood, and like many of Mr. May’s homes, it is configured to facilitate indoor-outdoor living, with many of the main spaces having direct outdoor access.

headline: The Moment They Knew: A ‘Last First Date,’ and Not a Moment Too Soon
abstract: Four years after a first date at a food hall, a Denver couple talked about what drew them to each other at the tail end of a “season” of online dating.
lead_paragraph: Kyle Long and Skylar Simpson matched on Tinder in March 2019, during a period when both were reaching their limits on dating apps and hoping to find someone serious.

headline: Silicon Valley Bank’s Collapse Chills Start-Up Funding
abstract: Two weeks after the bank failed, the fallout has hit the start-up market as investors pull back further and fear has risen.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Nelson had lined up commitments for $2 million in new funding for his financial technology start-up, HF.Capital, from two investors last month. He was aiming for $2.5 million and thought securing the rest would be “perfunctory.”

headline: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
abstract: Entries for the week of March 20, 2023.
lead_paragraph: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes. It is probably also worth mentioning that the Diary is a work of fiction.

headline: Newsom Rolls Back Water Restrictions After Winter Deluge in California
abstract: The state is “mostly but not completely” out of a drought, Gov. Gavin Newsom says.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — After being soaked by an onslaught of storms that have flooded towns, saturated fields and heaped the Sierra Nevada with a near-record snowpack, Californians are getting relief from a host of drought restrictions that were imposed last year during a historic dry spell.

headline: How the ‘Yellowjackets’ ‘Weirdos’ Fell in Love and Wrote a Hit Show
abstract: The married creators of “Yellowjackets” always had big screenwriting dreams. Their idea about witchy teen cannibals struck the right alchemy.
lead_paragraph: Ashley Lyle and Bart Nickerson share a marriage, a house in Los Angeles and a hit TV series that they created together. But not a computer screen, at least not when it comes to doing interviews.

headline: Unrest Surges in Israel: Videos and Photos
abstract: Major protests continued into a second day as Netanyahu announced he would delay a plan to overhaul Israel’s judiciary.
lead_paragraph: Major protests continued into a second day as Netanyahu announced he would delay a plan to overhaul Israel’s judiciary.

headline: Chicago’s Mayoral Race Pits the Teachers Union Against the Police Union
abstract: In a city known for its unions, two loom over the Paul Vallas-Brandon Johnson race, and no labor leader is as significant as the incendiary president of the Fraternal Order of Police.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — When Bobby L. Rush, the Black Panther turned congressman turned elder statesman of this city’s South Side, stood last week to endorse Paul Vallas for mayor, the first question he confronted featured his own words.

headline: Morgan Wallen’s ‘One Thing at a Time’ Is No. 1 for a Third Week
abstract: The country star’s hit-stuffed streaming blockbuster is just shy of one million equivalent sales. U2 opens at No. 5 with an album of acoustic rerecordings.
lead_paragraph: Morgan Wallen is not budging from No. 1 on the Billboard album chart, with the country star’s latest hit-stuffed double album holding the top spot for a third week in a row.

headline: Spring Means Lemon Everything
abstract: Pasta with creamy Meyer lemon sauce, a lemon cheesecake tart and more recipes.
lead_paragraph: Hi, Julia Moskin here in your inbox today, filling in for the irreplaceable Melissa Clark once more.

headline: 3 Ways to Measure How Fit You Are, Without Focusing on Weight
abstract: Exercise tests, heart rate and physical ability can tell you more about your health than the scale ever could.
lead_paragraph: Exercise is one of the best things you can do for your mental and physical health. But too often, the only measurement people use to evaluate their progress is their weight, which is not the most accurate metric to assess fitness and can be emotionally fraught.

headline: A Sting Operation to Save Elephants, With No Stings
abstract: While live bees can be used as a deterrent to keep elephants away from farms, a new technology fills in for cases where a buzz without the sting is preferable.
lead_paragraph: It’s a familiar, dreaded scenario in many parts of Africa and Asia: An elephant shows up, wanders into farmers’ fields, and tramples and eats crops. Sometimes farmers fight back, and elephants are killed.

headline: Can a Machine Know That We Know What It Knows?
abstract: Some researchers claim that chatbots have developed theory of mind. But is that just our own theory of mind gone wild?
lead_paragraph: Mind reading is common among us humans. Not in the ways that psychics claim to do it, by gaining access to the warm streams of consciousness that fill every individual’s experience, or in the ways that mentalists claim to do it, by pulling a thought out of your head at will. Everyday mind reading is more subtle: We take in people’s faces and movements, listen to their words and then decide or intuit what might be going on in their heads.

headline: The Scramble to Save California’s Heartland
abstract: Recent storms have walloped the Central Valley’s system of reservoirs, dams and levees, leaving no place for excess water to go. Farmers and emergency crews are racing to save the region’s farms.
lead_paragraph: Recent storms have walloped the Central Valley’s system of reservoirs, dams and levees, leaving no place for excess water to go. Farmers and emergency crews are racing to save the region’s farms.

headline: Artificial Intelligence Glossary: Neural Networks and Other Terms Explained
abstract: The concepts and jargon you need to understand ChatGPT.
lead_paragraph: We’ve compiled a list of phrases and concepts useful to understanding artificial intelligence, in particular the new breed of A.I.-enabled chatbots like ChatGPT, Bing and Bard.

headline: Quiz: Become an Expert on A.I.
abstract: You read Part 1 of our weeklong series on artificial intelligence. Now test your knowledge.
lead_paragraph: You read Part 1 of our weeklong series on artificial intelligence. Now test your knowledge.

headline: Gwyneth Paltrow Says Skier ‘Struck Me’ on a Utah Slope
abstract: Ms. Paltrow, 50, denied a man’s accusation that she crashed into him on a run at the Deer Valley Resort in Park City in 2016.
lead_paragraph: Gwyneth Paltrow’s civil trial over a collision with another skier in a Utah slope entered its second week on Monday after she denied in testimony late Friday the man’s accusation that she had crashed into him while skiing in 2016.

headline: Heavily Armed Assailant Kills 6 at Christian School
abstract: The shooter was also killed after police officers responded on Monday morning at the Covenant School, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — A 28-year-old from Nashville fatally shot three children and three adults on Monday at a private Christian elementary school, officials said, leaving behind writings and detailed maps of the school and its security protocols.

headline: How to Become an Expert on A.I.
abstract: Part 1 of our weeklong series.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to On Tech: A.I., a pop-up newsletter that will teach you about artificial intelligence, especially the new breed of chatbots like ChatGPT — all in only five days.

headline: Commutes Come to a Halt in Germany as Transport Workers Strike
abstract: One of the largest public transportation walkouts in decades was intended to give unions leverage as they seek raises to keep pace with rising inflation.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Travel for millions of people in Germany was upended on Monday when transportation workers went on a 24-hour strike, the largest transit walkout in decades, bringing most train, tram, bus and ferry services to a halt and forcing the cancellation of a majority of flights.

headline: Binance Is Hiding U.S. Crypto Trading Activity, Regulator Says
abstract: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission wants to permanently bar the cryptocurrency exchange and its founder from commodities markets.
lead_paragraph: Federal regulators sued Binance, the world’s largest cryptocurrency exchange, and two of its senior executives on Monday, alleging that in wooing business from American investors, they had chosen to “knowingly disregard” laws governing certain U.S. financial markets.

headline: Man Exonerated in Alice Sebold Rape Case to Get $5.5 Million
abstract: Anthony J. Broadwater spent 16 years in prison after being wrongly convicted in the assault in Syracuse, N.Y., which Ms. Sebold, a well-known novelist, described in her memoir “Lucky.”
lead_paragraph: New York State has agreed to pay $5.5 million to a man who spent 16 years in prison after being wrongly convicted of raping the author Alice Sebold when she was a college student in Syracuse, N.Y.

headline: Fox News Fires Producer Who Accused Network of Coercion
abstract: The producer, Abby Grossberg, has said the network pushed her to give a false deposition in a $1.6 billion defamation lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: Fox News Media has fired a producer who last week accused the network of discrimination and of coercing her into providing misleading testimony in a blockbuster defamation case, according to court documents filed on Monday.

headline: Review: In a New Yasmina Reza Play, a Superfan Becomes Celine Dion
abstract: In “James Brown Wore Curlers,” the French playwright tries out a more far-fetched premise than in her previous hits, and produces less satisfying satire.
lead_paragraph: “No realism,” the French playwright Yasmina Reza indicates twice in the opening pages of her new play “James Brown Wore Curlers,” which had its world premiere this past weekend in Munich.

headline: Deadly Shooting at a Christian School in Nashville
abstract: Students filed out of a private Christian school holding hands while law enforcement responded to the scene.
lead_paragraph: Students filed out of a private Christian school holding hands while law enforcement responded to the scene.

headline: Pro-DeSantis Super PAC Hires Another Former Trump Aide
abstract: Matt Wolking, who was part of the 2020 Trump campaign, will coordinate strategic communications for Never Back Down, a super PAC backing Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida.
lead_paragraph: A top communications aide for former President Donald J. Trump’s 2020 presidential campaign has become the latest former Trump official to join a super PAC supporting Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida amid escalating tensions between the two Republicans.

headline: Lana Del Rey Plunges Into the Deep, but Never Abandons the Shallow
abstract: The singer and songwriter’s ninth album, “Did You Know That There’s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd,” asks big, earnest questions and isn’t afraid to get messy.
lead_paragraph: “I wrote you a note, but I didn’t send it,” Lana Del Rey sings on her rangy ninth album, “Did You Know That There’s a Tunnel Under Ocean Blvd” — a 16-song, 78-minute collection as sprawling, hypnotic and incorrigibly American as an interstate highway.

headline: Biden Trip to Belfast Stirs Concerns About Slighting Britain’s New King
abstract: President Biden is expected to mark the anniversary of a landmark peace accord, but his timing, and his itinerary, have raised questions about the signal they send to a close ally.
lead_paragraph: President Biden plans to visit Northern Ireland next month to mark the 25th anniversary of a landmark peace agreement there. But his trip is stirring concern in diplomatic circles because Mr. Biden will not meet King Charles III, which British and American officials said could be interpreted as a snub, given that he also plans to skip the king’s coronation.

headline: N.J. Attorney General Seizes Control of Paterson Police Department
abstract: The state takeover comes after calls for the Justice Department to investigate this month’s fatal police shooting of Najee Seabrooks, 31.
lead_paragraph: Three weeks after a deadly police shooting in Paterson, N.J., the state’s attorney general, Matthew J. Platkin, announced on Monday that his office would take over day-to-day operations of the city’s troubled police department.

headline: Biden Acts to Restrict U.S. Government Use of Spyware
abstract: The president signed an executive order seeking to limit deployment of a tool that has been abused by autocracies — and some democracies — to spy on dissidents, human rights activists and journalists.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Monday signed an executive order restricting American government use of a class of powerful surveillance tools that have been abused by both autocracies and democracies around the world to spy on political dissidents, journalists and human rights activists.

headline: Review: A South Korean Troupe’s Physical Risks and Daunting Tasks
abstract: The contemporary dance group Bereishit performed two works by its founder, Park Soon-ho, at NYU Skirball.
lead_paragraph: The South Korean contemporary dance company Bereishit takes its name from the first word of the Torah, meaning “in the beginning.” The group’s founder, Park Soon-ho, has said: “We named the dance company after that word because I cherish beginnings, including those with new dancers and new experiences.”

headline: World Bank Warns of ‘Lost Decade’ for Global Economic Potential
abstract: Adding to crises like the pandemic, recent stress in the banking system is a new threat to world growth, experts at the organization said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The World Bank warned on Monday that the coronavirus pandemic and Russia’s war in Ukraine had contributed to a decline in the global economy’s long-term growth potential, leading to what could be a “lost decade” that would mean more poverty and fewer resources to combat the impact of climate change.

headline: Scotland’s Top Party, Reeling From Divisions, Picks a New Leader
abstract: Humza Yousaf is on course to become the first Muslim to lead a democratic western European nation, and when that happens, he will confront several daunting obstacles.
lead_paragraph: The pro-independence Scottish National Party on Monday elected Humza Yousaf, the country’s health secretary, as its top official, putting the 37-year-old minister on track to become the first Muslim to lead a democratic western European nation.

headline: Review: In ‘Día y Noche,’ Opposites Intertwine
abstract: David Anzuelo’s generous, unwieldy play about an oil-and-water friendship between two high school boys opens at 59E59 Theaters.
lead_paragraph: Let’s get this out of the way: The highlight of David Anzuelo’s new play, “Día y Noche,” is a wild, riotously funny sex scene that brings Act 1 to, well, a climax. It involves a trio of teenagers, Martin, Danny and Edna, enacting an unconventional scenario punctuated by Edna yelling encouragements in a fake French accent as she writhes in ecstasy, looking feral and her eyes bulging.

headline: Fed Vice Chair Calls Silicon Valley Bank a ‘Textbook Case of Mismanagement’
abstract: The Federal Reserve’s top bank cop blamed Silicon Valley Bank’s leaders, while previewing the central bank’s review of its faulty oversight.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve’s vice chair for supervision blamed Silicon Valley Bank’s demise on poor internal management and excessive risk-taking and detailed the steps that Fed supervisors took to address the snowballing problems that ultimately killed the company, according to prepared remarks ahead of a congressional hearing on Tuesday.

headline: A Battle Over Daylight Saving Time Raises Tensions in Lebanon
abstract: Two government leaders delayed the time change so Muslims would not have to break their daytime fast an hour later during Ramadan. But after a firestorm ensued, they backtracked.
lead_paragraph: When two of Lebanon’s top leaders decided to delay daylight saving time by a month, they were aiming to ensure that Muslims would not have to break their dawn-to-sunset fast an hour later during the holy month of Ramadan.

headline: Senator Blumenthal Letter to Colleges and Universities
abstract: Senator Richard Blumenthal, Democrat of Connecticut, sent a letter to 66 colleges and universities, demanding information about their efforts to partner with sports betting companies.
lead_paragraph: Senator Richard Blumenthal, Democrat of Connecticut, sent a letter to 66 colleges and universities, demanding information about their efforts to partner with sports betting companies.

headline: The Covenant School is a small academy housed at a Presbyterian church.
abstract: A mass shooting at a private school is rare; most recent high-profile cases have occurred at public schools.
lead_paragraph: The Covenant School in Nashville is a small, private Christian school, with an enrollment of around 200 students in preschool through sixth grade.

headline: A.I. Is Being Built by People Who Think It Might Destroy Us
abstract: Silicon Valley’s futurists have gone from utopian to dystopian.
lead_paragraph: All of a sudden, it’s as if we’ve come face to face with a new species on our smartphone screens.

headline: Senator Seeks Details of Schools’ Deals With Betting Companies
abstract: Senator Richard Blumenthal, asserting that gambling causes “very real harm” to students, has asked 66 colleges to provide information about their marketing relationships with sportsbooks.
lead_paragraph: Pressure is continuing to build upon colleges and universities that have partnerships with sports betting companies.

headline: Who is Itamar Ben-Gvir?
abstract: The influence of Itamar Ben-Gvir, a rising far-right lawmaker, was underscored when he said he would agree to a delay of the divisive judicial overhaul.
lead_paragraph: He was barred as a teenager from serving in the Israeli Army because he was considered too extremist. He admires a hard-line rabbi who wanted to strip Arab Israelis of their citizenship. Until recently, he hung a portrait in his home of Baruch Goldstein, who shot dead 29 Palestinians in a West Bank mosque in 1994.

headline: Supreme Court to Hear Dispute Between Maine Hotel and Disability Activist
abstract: The hotel argues that the activist, Deborah Laufer, was not entitled to sue it over inadequate disclosures because she did not intend to stay there.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court agreed on Monday to decide whether a disability rights activist may sue hotels for violating a federal disability law, despite having no intention of staying at the properties.

headline: Bobbi Ercoline, Whose Hug Became a Symbol of Woodstock, Dies at 73
abstract: Embracing her boyfriend, a blanket around them, she appeared on the cover of the ubiquitous soundtrack album of “Woodstock,” the 1970 documentary film about the music festival.
lead_paragraph: Bobbi Ercoline, who one morning during the Woodstock music festival rested her head on her boyfriend’s chest and in that drowsy moment became a symbol of 1960s hippiedom, died on March 18 at her home in Pine Bush, N.Y. She was 73.

headline: Isn’t She Beautiful? He Certainly Thought So.
abstract: Ivan Bart, who helped kick-start the careers of some of today’s most recognizable models, has left his role as president of the agency IMG Models.
lead_paragraph: On the April cover of British Vogue, three models wearing dresses that hug their hourglass figures are described by three words: “The New Supers.”

headline: Most mass shooting suspects are male.
abstract: In a database of 172 U.S. shootings involving at least four victims over the last five and a half decades, all but 4 of the perpetrators were male.
lead_paragraph: Most assailants in mass shootings in the United States are male, according to the Violence Project, which maintains a national database of mass shootings dating to 1966.

headline: Former National Enquirer Publisher Testifies Again in Trump Inquiry
abstract: The grand jury investigating a hush-money case against the former president met again on Monday, but the timing of any potential indictment remained unclear.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates on Donald Trump’s indictment.

headline: Biden Condemns School Shooting in Tennessee
abstract: President Biden called on Congress to pass an assault weapons ban following the school shooting in Nashville.
lead_paragraph: President Biden called on Congress to pass an assault weapons ban following the school shooting in Nashville.

headline: Paul Rusesabagina, ‘Hotel Rwanda’ Dissident, Departs Rwanda for Qatar
abstract: His release ended more than two and a half years of captivity, during which he was tried on terrorism charges and sentenced to 25 years in prison.
lead_paragraph: Paul Rusesabagina, the human rights activist, left Rwanda on Monday, more than 900 days after he was duped into re-entering the country, charged with terrorism and sentenced to 25 years in prison before being released after monthslong negotiations brokered by the United States.

headline: This story was published in error.
abstract: This story was published in error.
lead_paragraph: This story was published in error.

headline: Looking Back, Was the Iraq War Justified?
abstract: Readers disagree with a column by Bret Stephens, who doesn’t regret supporting the war. Also: Fury against Macron; student-athletes.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Contaminated Meat is the Surprising Cause of Some U.T.I.s
abstract: Certain strains of E. coli, a bacteria commonly associated with food poisoning, can lead to painful urinary infections.
lead_paragraph: Scientists are pointing to a surprising cause of some urinary tract infections: E. coli bacteria in meat. A new study used statistical modeling to estimate that E. coli, commonly known as the bacteria behind many food-borne illnesses, may cause hundreds of thousands of U.T.I.s in the United States annually — likely a small fraction of overall U.T.I.s, but enough to intrigue, and in some cases concern, experts.

headline: Sahadi’s Gets Into the Wine and Spirits Business
abstract: Pick up rare and lesser-known bottles from the Middle East and Mediterranean, dig into matzo ice cream from Eli Zabar, and more.
lead_paragraph: Sahadi’s, a Brooklyn store for Middle Eastern spices, grains, condiments and other products that was established more than 125 years ago, has added wines and spirits to its inventory. Adjacent to its Industry City branch that opened in 2019, the company has installed an airy wine and spirits store with a particularly uncommon focus: the lesser-known products of the Mediterranean region and the Middle East. Shelves are crowded with rarities like Armenian Zulal Voskehat, a white wine, and include selections from Georgia, Greece, Lebanon and Turkey, along with spirits like mastiha and Arak. Wines made with grapes from the region are featured. Even some from France, like Maury, a fortified dessert red, tend toward the unusual. The inventory also includes local producers like Fort Hamilton and St. Agrestis for spirits, and Paumanok Vineyards for wines. Prices are moderate; many of the wines are poured at the cafe and bar run by Sahadi’s inside the food store.

headline: Where Feeding the Dead Is a Fading Tradition
abstract: The gravesite customs of Tomb Sweeping Day — in which ancestors are offered elaborate home-cooked feasts — are shifting across East and Southeast Asia.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — While growing up in Hong Kong, Cherry Tang accompanied her uncles to their family’s ancestral gravesite each spring as they lugged a whole roasted suckling pig up a subtropical hillside.

headline: ‘Succession’: What to Know
A Romantic Mexico City Dinner to Toast a Growing Fashion Brand
