abstract: How the designer Olivia Villanti, of the line Chava Studio, threw a party and a collection launch that felt sophisticated yet low key.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2022, the clothing designer Olivia Villanti passed seven weeks driving through France, Switzerland, Italy, Croatia and Montenegro with her husband, Guillaume Guevara, an entrepreneur, and their young son. While on the trip, she would spend most weekends scavenging flea markets, picking out shirts with details like an elegant cutaway collar or an unusual cuff stitched to fold back without cuff links. When the couple returned home to Mexico City, where Guevara, 41, grew up and where they moved in 2020 after 16 years together in New York, Villanti, also 41, unpacked several duffels of old clothes and began designing the latest (and largest) collection for her nearly three-year-old made-to-order women’s wear line, Chava Studio.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing: Netanyahu Shifts Course
abstract: Also, a Taiwanese ex-president’s trip to China and U.S. diplomacy in Africa.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced that he would delay his government’s contentious plans to overhaul Israel’s judiciary, after days of massive street protests, counter-protests and strikes that halted some health services and blocked flights from leaving Israel’s main airport. Follow live updates.

headline: Gladys Kessler, Judge Who Curbed Deceptive Tobacco Ads, Dies at 85
abstract: In a landmark case, she ruled in 2006 that cigarette companies had been deceiving the public about the health hazards of smoking, violating racketeering laws.
lead_paragraph: Gladys Kessler, a federal judge who in a historic ruling in 2006 found that the tobacco industry had violated civil racketeering laws for decades by “repeatedly, and with enormous skill and sophistication” deceiving the public about the health hazards of smoking, died on March 16 in Washington. She was 85.

headline: Promised tanks arrive in Ukraine from Germany and Britain.
abstract: The deliveries of advanced equipment are expected to assist Kyiv with a potential spring offensive.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine has begun receiving the bulk of the advanced battle tanks it has been promised by its Western allies.

headline: Lyft’s Co-Founders to Step Down as Company Struggles
abstract: Lyft has been slow to bounce back from early pandemic problems even as the business of its much bigger rival, Uber, has improved.
lead_paragraph: Lyft’s co-founders said on Monday that they would step down from their day-to-day responsibilities at the company, which has struggled through layoffs and disappointing financial results even as Uber, its biggest rival, has strengthened.

headline: Love, Absence and Loss, Filtered Through Philosophical Poems
abstract: In Brenda Shaughnessy’s collection “Tanya,” the self is fluid and love is “timelessness itself.”
lead_paragraph: Attempt to ferret out the origins of the name “Tanya,” and you’ll find yourself awash in contradiction. A Russian name, it’s a diminutive of “Tatiana,” one source declares. Another insists the name is not Russian at all. A third states that this very Russian appellation means “fairy queen.” Some websites contend that “Tanya” comes from a Latin or Greek root meaning something like “define.”

headline: Netanyahu Is Gambling With Israel’s Future
abstract: “The ax has not come down yet, but it’s still hanging.”
lead_paragraph: Karnit Flug was the governor of the Bank of Israel, the nation’s central bank, from 2013 to 2018. “One of my biggest challenges was the strengthening of the shekel,” she told me on Monday.

headline: Supreme Court Hears a Free Speech Challenge to an Immigration Law
abstract: The justices considered whether the law, which makes it a crime to encourage unauthorized immigrants to come to or stay in the United States, runs afoul of the First Amendment.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court heard arguments on Monday in a First Amendment challenge to an unusual federal law that makes it a crime to “encourage” unauthorized immigrants to come to or stay in the United States.

headline: Chiefsaholic, the Fan Who Dressed as a Wolf, Is Said to Be on the Lam
abstract: Xavier Babudar, known as Chiefsaholic, missed a Monday court hearing on charges that he robbed a bank in Tulsa, Okla. The court and his bail bondsman are looking for him.
lead_paragraph: Before this year’s Super Bowl, the Kansas City football superfan known as Chiefsaholic was a source of fascination in the sports world. How, people wondered, did a man known for wearing a wolf mask to games and placing large bets end up in jail on charges that he robbed a bank in Tulsa, Okla.?

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: After Doling Out Huge Loans, China Is Now Bailing Out Countries
abstract: Beijing is emerging as a new heavyweight in providing emergency funds to debt-ridden countries, catching up to the I.M.F. as a lender of last resort.
lead_paragraph: Since the end of World War II, the International Monetary Fund and the United States have been the world’s lenders of last resort, each wielding broad influence over the global economy. Now a new heavyweight has emerged in providing emergency loans to debt-ridden countries: China.

headline: School Shooting in Nashville Leaves 6 Dead
abstract: The shooting occurred at a private school that serves about 200 students in preschool through sixth grade.
lead_paragraph: The shooting occurred at a private school that serves about 200 students in preschool through sixth grade.

headline: Netanyahu Delays Bid to Overhaul Israel’s Judiciary as Protests Rage
abstract: The Israeli prime minister called for dialogue as civil unrest and work stoppages reached a crisis point, grinding the country to a halt.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said on Monday that he was delaying his government’s campaign to exert greater control over the judiciary, backing off in the face of furious public protest that has plunged Israel into one of the deepest crises of its history.

headline: Biden Officials Hold Off on More Airstrikes in Syria, for Now
abstract: The administration says it is seeking to avoid a wider war with Iran and its proxies while protecting U.S. personnel from attacks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A few days after an American civilian contractor in Iraq died in a rocket attack by Iran-backed militias in December 2019, President Donald J. Trump retaliated by ordering a drone strike that killed a top Iranian general.

headline: Wright Brothers’ Airplane Factory Is Badly Damaged in Fire
abstract: The Dayton Fire Department in Ohio said that it was still investigating what caused the fire at the historic site, where the Wright brothers first manufactured planes starting in 1910.
lead_paragraph: A fire that broke out at a building complex in Dayton, Ohio, on Sunday damaged a factory founded by Wilbur and Orville Wright, the brothers who were the first people to successfully fly an airplane.

headline: United Auto Workers Usher In New Era of Leadership
abstract: Shawn Fain, who ousted the incumbent president, is presiding over a convention to chart the union’s approach in contract talks this year.
lead_paragraph: The United Auto Workers union has opened a new chapter in its storied history, and it may end up looking a lot like its combative past.

headline: Targeting Mayorkas, G.O.P. Takes Its Immigration Message to the Border
abstract: Republicans have been making regular trips to the border with Mexico in hopes of dramatizing the United States’ immigration challenges. But they rarely account for the reality on the ground.
lead_paragraph: PHARR, Texas — Inside a college classroom barely six miles from the United States border with Mexico, House Republicans this month orchestrated the made-for-TV moment they had traveled here for, getting a top immigration official to concede that the government has yet to stop migrants from crossing into the country without authorization.

headline: U.N. Official Heads to Ukrainian Nuclear Plant as Safety Fears Grow
abstract: The official met with President Volodymyr Zelensky to discuss the Zaporizhzhia plant, amid worries that a Ukrainian offensive could raise the already-high risk of disaster.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations’ chief nuclear energy official met on Monday with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine to discuss what he describes as increasingly dire fears about a battle-scarred nuclear plant on the front line of the war, ahead of his first visit to the plant in almost seven months.

headline: ‘John Wick: Chapter 4’
North Carolina Expands Medicaid After Republicans Abandon Their Opposition
abstract: The state’s Democratic governor signed a bill expanding the health insurance program for low-income people days after the measure cleared the Republican-controlled legislature.
lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — North Carolina on Monday became the 40th state to expand Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act, the latest sign of how Republican opposition to the health measure has weakened more than a decade after President Barack Obama signed it into law.

headline: Inside the U.S. Pressure Campaign Over Israel’s Judicial Overhaul
abstract: President Biden and his advisers bombarded the Israeli government with warnings that the country’s image as the sole democracy in the Middle East was at stake.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the 48 hours before Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu reluctantly delayed his effort to overhaul the Israeli judiciary, his government was bombarded by warnings from the Biden administration that he was imperiling Israel’s reputation as the true democracy at the heart of the Middle East.

headline: The Nashville school shooter had a ‘manifesto’ and maps, police say.
abstract: The assailant was described as a former student at the school who was heavily armed and “prepared for a confrontation with law enforcement.”
lead_paragraph: The attacker who fatally shot three children and three staff members at a Nashville school on Monday was identified as a former student at the school who the police said appeared to have written a manifesto about the attack and drawn maps of the campus.

headline: Israel’s Crisis Has a Distinctly American Flavor
abstract: Israel has learned some unhealthy habits from the United States.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — Hours before Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu delayed a proposed judicial overhaul that has prompted mass protests, the head of one of Israel’s most powerful unions made a small, seemingly off-topic remark as he announced a nationwide strike Monday.

headline: Netanyahu Attempts Another Juggling Act, Maybe His Toughest Yet
abstract: Israel’s prime minister, who has long thrived by pitting one force against another, is caught between his far-right coalition and public anger over the government’s plan to weaken the judiciary.
lead_paragraph: Little more than a year ago, it seemed that the political career of Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel’s longest-serving leader, was all but over. Out of power, he was struggling to maintain relevance. State prosecutors had offered his lawyers a plea deal that would have let him avoid jail in his ongoing corruption trial, in exchange for leaving politics for seven years.

headline: Hoping for a Comeback in a Town With Little to Come Back To
abstract: Officials have vowed that Rolling Fork, Miss., ravaged by a tornado, will come back better than ever. But first people need food, water, shelter, medicine and life’s other necessities.
lead_paragraph: ROLLING FORK, Miss. — There’s no funeral home that’s capable yet of burying the dead.

headline: South Carolina Powers to a Third Straight Final Four. Virginia Tech Makes Its First.
abstract: South Carolina wore down Maryland with its swarming defense, while Virginia Tech overpowered Ohio State to claim the last spot in Dallas.
lead_paragraph: GREENVILLE, S.C. — The script has become routine for South Carolina in this year’s N.C.A.A. women’s basketball tournament. In the first half, South Carolina, the reigning champion, often looks surprisingly vulnerable, perhaps on the verge of its first loss this season, primed to be on the wrong side of a monumental upset in a March that has been filled with them.

headline: Like a Doornail
abstract: Daniel Kantor and Jay Kaskel show you how they feel.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: ‘Perry Mason’ Season 2, Episode 4 Recap: More Than Meets the Eye
abstract: Perry, Paul and Della aren’t the only people searching for answers about Brooks McCutcheon.
lead_paragraph: Life, like a murder case, has its ups and downs. First, the down: Perry, Paul and Della have learned that the brothers Mateo and Rafael Gallardo have been lying and did indeed murder Brooks McCutcheon. Now, the up: Perry, Paul and Della all hooked up. Call it a glass-half-full situation.

headline: U.S. and Japan Reach Deal on Battery Minerals
abstract: While the terms of the deal are limited, the agreement appears to provide a model for resolving recent trade spats between the United States and some of its closest allies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States and Japan have reached an agreement over supplies of the critical minerals used to make car batteries, a deal that will likely put to rest a contentious issue in the relationship with Japan and could be a model for resolving similar disputes with other trading partners.

headline: Corrections: March 28, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, March 28, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Saturday about senators urging President Biden to send evidence of war crimes to the International Criminal Court referred imprecisely to the positions of the United States and Russia on the International Criminal Court. While both countries initially signed the treaty establishing the court, neither is currently a party to it.

headline: Highland Park Shooting Survivor Asks: ‘How Is This Still Happening?’
abstract: After surviving a mass shooting in July, a mother vacationing in Nashville goes to the site of another shooting and demands action.
lead_paragraph: As a spokesman for the Nashville Police wrapped up a news conference on the mass shooting at an elementary school, an exasperated mother stepped up to the cluster of microphones and cried out: “Aren’t you guys tired of covering this?”

headline: China’s Cities Are Buried in Debt, but They Keep Shoveling It On
abstract: China has long pursued growth by public spending, even after the payoff has faded. Cities stuck with the bill are still spending — and cutting essential services.
lead_paragraph: In 2015, when Shangqiu, a municipality in central China, laid out a plan for the next two decades, it positioned itself as a transportation hub with a sprawling network of railways, highways and river shipping routes.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: A delay in Israel’s plan to overhaul the judiciary.
lead_paragraph: After days of intense civil unrest, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced that he would delay contentious plans to overhaul Israel’s judiciary. Netanyahu’s move, after the assent by a powerful right-wing ally, was an attempt to give him time to try to de-escalate the crisis and manage competing demands.

headline: Netanyahu Cannot Be Trusted
abstract: The Israeli prime minister has become an irrational actor.
lead_paragraph: Thank goodness that Israel’s civil society has forced Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to pause, for now, his attempt to impose his control over Israel’s independent judiciary and gain a free hand to rule as he wishes. But this whole affair has exposed a new and troubling reality for the United States: For the first time, the leader of Israel is an irrational actor, a danger not only to Israelis but also to important American interests and values.

headline: The I.O.C. defers discussion on whether Russian and Belarusian athletes will compete in the 2024 Olympics.
abstract: The International Olympic Committee declined to make a decision on Tuesday on whether Russian and Belarusian athletes will be allowed to compete in the 2024 Olympics in Paris, beginning two days of meetings in Switzerland by focusing on other issues.
lead_paragraph: The International Olympic Committee declined to make a decision on Tuesday on whether Russian and Belarusian athletes will be allowed to compete in the 2024 Olympics in Paris, beginning two days of meetings in Switzerland by focusing on other issues.

headline: Assailant Shoots Out Doors to Enter Nashville School
abstract: Surveillance video shows an attacker whom the police identified as Audrey E. Hale driving up to the Covenant School in Nashville, and then shooting out the entrance doors to get into the building.
lead_paragraph: Surveillance video shows an attacker whom the police identified as Audrey E. Hale driving up to the Covenant School in Nashville, and then shooting out the entrance doors to get into the building.

headline: Final Four Is New Ground for South Carolina’s Challengers
abstract: Virginia Tech is in its first Final Four, while Iowa last went in 1993, and L.S.U. in 2008. South Carolina, the reigning champion, knows what to expect.
lead_paragraph: GREENVILLE, S.C. — Aliyah Boston carefully cut off a piece of the net on Monday night after South Carolina had beaten Maryland to advance to the women’s Final Four. As she made the snip, she asked a South Carolina staffer if she was doing it correctly this time.

headline: Word of the Day: pulverize
abstract: This word has appeared in eight articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word pulverize has appeared in eight articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 11 in the obituary “Gallagher, Watermelon-Smashing Comedian, Is Dead at 76” by Douglas Martin:

headline: A First Step Toward Mandatory Composting
abstract: New York plans to require composting of yard waste, like leaves, twigs and grass clippings.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Composting is coming to New York City. We’ll find out when and what it will mean. We’ll also get details on a $5.5 million payment to a man who was wrongly convicted of raping the author Alice Sebold when she was in college.

headline: Late Night Recaps Donald Trump’s Waco Rally
abstract: Hosts raised their eyebrows over the former president’s choice  of venue, near the Texas compound where the Branch Davidian cult met with disaster 30 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Mindfulness
abstract: When are you most present?
lead_paragraph: When in your daily life are you most naturally mindful? That is, when do you find yourself being present and “pulled into the moment” most easily? Is it when you’re playing a sport or game? Cooking? Talking to friends? Pursuing a hobby? Something else?

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: No Longer at Starbucks Helm, Howard Schultz Is the Focus at Labor Hearing
abstract: After giving up the chief executive’s job (again), Mr. Schultz still casts a long shadow over Starbucks’ policy, not least in fighting unionization.
lead_paragraph: When Howard Schultz of Starbucks testifies before a Senate committee on Wednesday about the company’s labor policies, he will no longer be its chief executive. But his presence will underscore his continuing sway over a company he has run on and off since the 1980s.

headline: Elusive ‘Einstein’ Solves a Longstanding Math Problem
abstract: And it all began with a hobbyist “messing about and experimenting with shapes.”
lead_paragraph: Last November, after a decade of failed attempts, David Smith, a self-described shape hobbyist of Bridlington in East Yorkshire, England, suspected that he might have finally solved an open problem in the mathematics of tiling: That is, he thought he might have discovered an “einstein.”

headline: Math Lesson: Investigating Houston’s Strategy to End Homelessness
abstract: In this lesson, students will use scatter plots and line of best fit to compare rates of homelessness in four American cities. Then they’ll find out what one city is doing to tackle the problem.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “How Houston Moved 25,000 People From the Streets Into Homes of Their Own” by Michael Kimmelman (also available on audio)

headline: Seized by More Protests, France Is Caught in a Tense Impasse
abstract: On a new day of strikes and marches, President Emmanuel Macron’s government rejected a call by labor unions to suspend his pension overhaul.
lead_paragraph: Stuck in a highly charged standoff, France was gripped on Tuesday by another round of strikes, street demonstrations and sporadic violent protests against President Emmanuel Macron’s pension overhaul.

headline: Alexander Skarsgard Explains the Answer to Everything. (It Involves Doing Some Math.)
abstract: It’s time to completely rethink how we measure our economic success.
lead_paragraph: It’s time to completely rethink how we measure our economic success.

headline: Alexander Skarsgard Explains the Answer to Everything. (It Involves Doing Some Math.)
abstract: It’s time to completely rethink how we measure economic success.
lead_paragraph: Partha Dasgupta is a Cambridge University economist who in 2021 prepared a more than 600-page report for the British government about the financial value of nature.

headline: I Am Going Blind, and I Now Find It Strangely Exhilarating
abstract: Now that I signal my disability with a white cane, I find that I have tapped a well of visible kindness.
lead_paragraph: I have been gradually going blind for the past 20 years. I didn’t pay attention — I thought I needed better glasses — until one night I popped out to go to the bathroom in a crowded movie theater. When I returned, the people and the seats had disappeared. I couldn’t see anything except the screen. I stood in the back of the theater until my partner, Laurie, came to find me. This was disconcerting, but I went about my business in my usual state of cheerful denial.

headline: 9 Ways to Bring Every Generation but Leave the Family Drama at Home
abstract: Travel’s big rebound has many extended clans planning long-delayed trips. Here are some tips on how to make sure grandparents, parents and grandchildren all have a great time.
lead_paragraph: Three generations packed in a van, navigating winding roads and family dramas: It sounds like a scene from Season 2 of “The White Lotus.” But the show’s fictional Di Grasso clan isn’t the only extended family hitting the road together as Covid retreats. Real-life parents, grandparents and grandchildren are packing their bags for long-delayed multigenerational trips.

headline: Is Homelessness an Issue Where You Live?
abstract: The New York Times asked 30 people to share their experiences of homelessness. What can we learn from their stories?
lead_paragraph: This Student Opinion is a companion writing prompt to our lesson “Math Lesson: Investigating Houston’s Strategy to End Homelessness.”

headline: What the Republican Push for ‘Parents’ Rights’ Is Really About
abstract: The culture war that conservatives are currently waging over education is, like the culture wars in other areas of American society, a cover for a more material and ideological agenda.
lead_paragraph: You may have heard the phrase “parents’ rights.”

headline: Chris Christie, Putting Out Feelers for a 2024 Run, Takes Aim at Trump
abstract: A speech in New Hampshire looks back on 2016 and ahead to another potential campaign — one that would have to start from square one.
lead_paragraph: GOFFSTOWN, N.H. — Chris Christie wants a New Hampshire do-over.

headline: Thanks to Their Versatility, the Mets Are Feeling Good
abstract: Edwin Díaz’s injury would crush some teams, but the Mets, with a deep and experienced roster, have remained optimistic.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — It is one of baseball’s enduring little mysteries, how a game so rich in possibilities also offers so many precedents. You may see something new at the ballpark every day, yet if you stick around a while, you feel like you’ve seen it all before.

headline: Where Spirits Are Remixed and Assigned to New Bodies
abstract: In Sharon Dodua Otoo’s novel, “Ada’s Room,” readers follow the many lives of one woman through unexpected eyes.
lead_paragraph: At the beginning of Sharon Dodua Otoo’s novel, Ada is a grieving mother in 15th-century Ghana. Then, Ada is a mathematician in Victorian England. Next, she is a Polish sex slave in a concentration camp in Germany. Finally, Ada is a pregnant Ghanaian woman looking for an apartment in modern-day Berlin.

headline: Dollar General Is Deemed a ‘Severe Violator’ by the Labor Dept.
abstract: Since January 2017, OSHA has cited the company for 111 instances of workplace safety violations and imposed more than $15.5 million in penalties.
lead_paragraph: For years, the Labor Department has operated a Severe Violator Enforcement Program, which targets companies with unsafe working conditions like manufacturers or construction firms with a high number of injuries or deaths.

headline: The Unexpected Joys of a Quarantine Hotel
abstract: 138 hours in solitude turned out to be just the vacation this writer needed.
lead_paragraph: Here was exactly the kind of hotel I had never sought to enter: a generic block in an industrial corner of Osaka, Japan — Rinku Town — across from a vast, empty parking lot and a 24-hour big-box store called Trial. A large, very full bus had collected me at the international airport this stormy night in midwinter, and deposited me, a few minutes later, at the entrance. But I was not permitted to step into the lobby, I was told, and I had to drag my two suitcases through a back entrance and down a long series of windowless service corridors.

headline: Silicon Valley Bank’s Risks Went Deep. Congress Wants to Know Why.
abstract: Lapses at the bank will be a focus as a top Federal Reserve official testifies to House and Senate committees this week.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The nation’s top financial regulators will face a grilling from lawmakers on Tuesday over the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank as they push to understand why the firm was allowed to grow so rapidly and build up so much risk that it failed, requiring a government rescue for depositors and sending shock waves across global markets.

headline: Sharing a Love for Africa Across Generations
abstract: Fifty years after her own first safari, a grandmother takes her adult granddaughter on a trip to Kenya, hoping to pass along her passion.
lead_paragraph: Sammy spotted the wildlife first.

headline: How Wide Can You Go?
abstract: The Great Shoulder Resurgence of 2023 is coming. Here’s why.
lead_paragraph: Here is a fun game to play: Say the words “shoulder pads” and ask people what springs to mind. Bad 1980s fashions? Margaret Thatcher? Joan Crawford? David Byrne in “Stop Making Sense”?

headline: For This Brooklyn Family, Myth and Reality Are One and the Same
abstract: In Soraya Palmer’s debut novel, “The Human Origins of Beatrice Porter and Other Essential Ghosts,” two sisters find solace and salvation through enduring Black diasporic tales.
lead_paragraph: What happens to stories that are born of another land? When they migrate multiple times and across multiple generations? Soraya Palmer’s ambitious and passionate debut, “The Human Origins of Beatrice Porter and Other Essential Ghosts,” is a thoughtful exploration of these questions.

headline: Dr. Fauci Could Have Said a Lot More
abstract: If officials don’t trust the public, the public won’t trust them.
lead_paragraph: Covid had just reached American shores on Feb. 9, 2020, when Newt Gingrich invited Anthony Fauci, the longtime head of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, and the British zoologist Peter Daszak onto his podcast, “Newt’s World.”

headline: Tinkering With ChatGPT, Workers Wonder: Will This Take My Job?
abstract: Artificial intelligence is confronting white-collar professionals more directly than ever. It could make them more productive — or obsolete.
lead_paragraph: In December, the staff of the American Writers and Artists Institute — a 26-year-old membership organization for copywriters — realized that something big was happening.

headline: Is Empowering Corporate Women Enough?
abstract: Turmoil at Chief, a women’s networking organization, raises a long-simmering question: Is amassing power for corporate women a worthy goal in itself?
lead_paragraph: For admission to Chief, a women’s leadership network, members pay up to $7,900. That gets them executive coaching, big-name speaker sessions, a Rolodex of female executives and, for an extra cost, access to five sleek clubhouses. Chief is essentially an “old boys’ club” — for the ladies. The venture capital-backed company has grown to over 20,000 members and over $1 billion in value since it started in 2019.

headline: Costly Court Race Points to a Politicized Future for Judicial Elections
abstract: A crucial election for Wisconsin’s Supreme Court has drawn tens of millions of dollars in spending, turning an officially nonpartisan contest into a bare-knuckle political fight.
lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — It is a judicial election like no other in American history.

headline: In ‘Unstable,’ the Sins of the Father Are Comedy Gold
abstract: Rob and John Owen Lowe star in a new Netflix series that exaggerates their barbed father-son dynamic, but only a little. “I’ve made fun of him my whole life,” John Owen said.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — John Owen Lowe was 11 or 12 when he first realized that his father wasn’t quite like the other dads. So what was it like to grow up with a father this famous, this problematically handsome?

headline: A Fishing Family at Sea in a Changing Singapore
abstract: Rapid modernization takes its toll in Rachel Heng’s impressive epic “The Great Reclamation.”
lead_paragraph: The question of change — whom it affects and how — sits at the core of Rachel Heng’s second novel, “The Great Reclamation,” a stunning historical fiction set against the backdrop of Singapore’s struggle for independence during and after World War II. The novel is vast in scope: We are there to witness the last days of British colonial rule, the devastating consequences of the Japanese invasion (and later expulsion), land reclamation initiatives and the push toward Merdeka, the Malay term signifying freedom.

headline: One of the Luckiest Lightning Strikes Ever Recorded
abstract: Brazilian researchers captured on camera the brief moment when lightning rods on buildings released an upward discharge to attract incoming lightning.
lead_paragraph: Benjamin Franklin invented lightning rods in the 18th century, and the devices have been protecting buildings and people from the destructive forces of lightning ever since. But the details of how lightning rods function are still the subject of scientific research.

headline: Trump’s Legal Jeopardy and America’s Political Crossroads
abstract: David French takes stock of the cases involving the ex-president and the challenges they present to the political system.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s legal troubles are mounting. A Manhattan grand jury investigation into the hush-money payment to Stormy Daniels could soon make Trump the first former American president ever to be criminally indicted.

headline: The Agony of Putting Your Life on Hold to Care for Your Parents
abstract: Randi Schofield is the sole provider for an ailing father and, at the same time, for her own children — a situation now common among Americans in their 30s and 40s.
lead_paragraph: Randi Schofield tried her best to not dwell on all the ways her life changed, on the pieces of herself that got lost in the shuffle. She was a 34-year-old single mother who, not long ago, was in the throes of a big life transition. She had left her full-time job of eight years as a personal bailiff to a local judge. She was burned out, ready for something new.

headline: A Plan to Lift the Fog of War in Ukraine? It’s in the Cards.
abstract: To help soldiers quickly distinguish friend from foe, the Pentagon is issuing playing cards with pictures of 52 different NATO weapons systems.
lead_paragraph: With billions of dollars in weapons, the West has sought to give Ukraine the upper hand in its war with Russia. But the dizzying array of arms headed to the battlefield could make it hard for troops to tell friends from foes.

headline: Plan B for Fixing Penn Station Would Wrap Madison Square Garden in Glass
abstract: The previous proposal to help pay for the renovation of the station, which could cost up to $10 billion in state funds, has been shelved.
lead_paragraph: A year and a half after Gov. Kathy Hochul championed a plan to help fund the renovation of Pennsylvania Station by allowing the construction of up to 10 towers around the transit hub, that proposal has been mothballed, and an alternate project has emerged as a possible front-runner to replace it.

headline: When Your Family Becomes a Noah’s Ark-Style Experiment With Race
abstract: In his memoir, “Skinfolk,” Matthew Pratt Guterl chronicles his life growing up in a multiracial family in suburban New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: I will, as far as I know, occur once. This thing I call “Chloé” is singular; it lives once, dies once. But I am also born into a body, a time, a class and a place, and those biographical facts carry sociopolitical meaning that precedes me. I cannot be fully explained by historical signifiers, but I’m never free of them either. To be alive is to grapple with these two truths, to struggle at the intersection of self and society, interiority and exteriority, individuality and environment.

headline: To Get Into This Party, You’ll Need the Right Name. (It’s Ryan.)
abstract: “I love them all already,” said one Ryan of the many others in attendance. “It’s like they have a vibe. They understand me.”
lead_paragraph: Last weekend, hundreds of people packed into a bar in Lower Manhattan for a very exclusive party. “First name must be Ryan,” the flier for the event said. “No Bryans allowed.”

headline: Torture and Turmoil at Ukrainian Nuclear Plant: An Insider’s Account
abstract: The former director of Europe’s largest nuclear facility describes abuse of Ukrainian workers and careless practices by the Russians who took control of the plant.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — By the time Russian soldiers threw a potato sack over his head and forced him to record a false video statement about conditions at Europe’s largest nuclear facility, Ihor Murashov had already witnessed enough chaos at the plant to be deeply worried.

headline: Why You Need Window Blinds (Even if You Don’t Think So)
abstract: Designers consider window shades and blinds essential for many reasons. But there are so many options — how do you choose the right ones?
lead_paragraph: Most windows need a little help from window coverings to manage light levels or provide privacy. But sometimes it’s just about making them look their best.

headline: ‘We’re Going Away’: A State’s Choice to Forgo Medicaid Funds Is Killing Hospitals
abstract: Mississippi is one of 10 states, all with Republican-led legislatures, that continue to reject federal funding to expand health insurance for the poor, intensifying financial pressure on hospitals.
lead_paragraph: GREENWOOD, Miss. — Since its opening in a converted wood-frame mansion 117 years ago, Greenwood Leflore Hospital had become a medical hub for this part of Mississippi’s fertile but impoverished Delta, with 208 beds, an intensive-care unit, a string of walk-in clinics and a modern brick-and-glass building.

headline: We Will Never Reach Peak Croissant
abstract: Ten years after the Cronut, croissants are still taking on new shapes, sporting swirls and stripes and drawing crowds.
lead_paragraph: When the baker Amadou Ly spotted the right moment to pull his croissant dough from the roller, it flowed like silk over his wooden counter. It had taken three days of precisely executed fermentation and lamination, the exacting process of folding fat into flour to create a supple dough.

headline: Film Club: ‘Meet the World’s Most Honorable Bank Robbers’
abstract: In Lebanon the economic collapse is forcing citizens to use extreme measures to get their savings. Is robbing a bank to withdraw your own money an immoral act?
lead_paragraph: Note to Teachers: Please preview the film to make sure it is appropriate for your students.

headline: As King Charles Moves to Center Stage, So Do His Impersonators
abstract: Long overshadowed by other royal look-alikes, Charles imitators are experiencing newfound popularity ahead of the king’s coronation in May.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In the days after Queen Elizabeth II’s death last year, Charles Haslett, 66, along with many other Britons, was overcome with sadness. But he didn’t have much time to linger on those feelings.

headline: The Fight Over ‘Cop City’
abstract: A planned training facility and the woods surrounding it have become an unlikely battleground for the debate on policing in the United States.
lead_paragraph: This episode contains descriptions of violence.

headline: A Win for Israel’s Protesters
abstract: Demonstrations forced Israel’s prime minister to delay a judicial overhaul.
lead_paragraph: Much of life in Israel came to a halt yesterday: Hospitals stopped providing nonemergency care, planes were grounded at the country’s main airport, and malls and banks closed. The disruptions were part of an escalation in protests against the government’s proposed judicial overhaul, which has plunged Israel into one of its gravest political crises ever.

headline: As Migrants’ Desperation Mounts at the Border, a Fire Kills Dozens
abstract: The fatal blaze comes as border cities across Mexico have been flooded with migrants turned back from the United States and more arriving from other countries.
lead_paragraph: CIUDAD JUÁREZ, Mexico — Katiuska Márquez said she was begging for money on the streets of Ciudad Juárez on Monday afternoon when Mexican migration officers took her and her family to a migration detention facility just across the border from El Paso, Texas.

headline: More Rain and Snow Are Lashing California
abstract: Up to three feet of snow was forecast for the Sierra Nevada and other higher elevations, less than a week after tornadoes battered parts of the state. More than 18,000 customers were without power on Tuesday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: California is enduring another round of heavy rain and mountain snow, continuing a relentless stretch of extreme weather across the West that has proved dangerous, deadly and disruptive to millions of people in recent months.

headline: Banking Regulators Prepare for Tough Questions From Lawmakers
abstract: Three top officials will testify in Congress about the turmoil caused by the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank, and their role in it.
lead_paragraph: Starting on Tuesday, representatives from three of the country’s top banking regulators — the F.D.I.C., the Fed and the Treasury Department — will testify before Congress about how problems at Silicon Valley Bank were allowed to metastasize and threaten the U.S. banking system.

headline: With Judicial Overhaul on Hold, Israeli Negotiators Seek Compromise
abstract: After days of turmoil, lawmakers began tentative efforts to find common ground on a government plan to overhaul the judiciary that has divided Israelis.
lead_paragraph: A day after widespread civil unrest forced Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to delay a plan to weaken the judiciary, his government and the opposition in Parliament on Tuesday began the first direct negotiations between them to reach a compromise since the plan was introduced nearly three months ago.

headline: ‘According to the Chorus’ Review: Backstage Truths
abstract: In Arlene Hutton’s play at 59E59 Theaters, the members of a Broadway cast reveal their hopes and fears tucked away in a quick-change room.
lead_paragraph: Even longtime theatergoers could learn a few fun tidbits from the new play “According to the Chorus.” That, for example, when members of a Broadway ensemble are in costume, they are not supposed to eat, smoke or hold a dog. Or that they often drive the dressers who help them in and out of said costumes bonkers — and vice versa.

headline: Quotation of the Day: South Carolina Returns to Final Four to Find a Different Cast of Challengers
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, March 29, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “It doesn’t matter if it was UConn in front of us, Ohio State or the Lakers.”

headline: Corrections: March 29, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, March 29, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about a shooting at a private Christian elementary school in Nashville misstated the ratio of students to teachers at the school. It has a student-to-teacher ratio of 8 to 1, not 1 to 8.

headline: Twined Together
abstract: Ben Zoon’s puzzle is all mixed up.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Temple University President Resigns as Crime Rises Near Campus
abstract: Jason Wingard, the first Black president of the university, faced criticism over his handling of a strike and fears about rising crime in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: The president of Temple University in Philadelphia resigned on Tuesday after a brief and tumultuous tenure plagued by worsening crime around campus, a strike by graduate students and a loss of confidence in his leadership among some faculty members.

headline: Junta Disbands Aung San Suu Kyi’s Political Party in Myanmar
abstract: The regime has dissolved dozens of opposition parties ahead of the next general election, including the popular National League for Democracy.
lead_paragraph: The political party of Myanmar’s imprisoned opposition leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, has been officially dissolved, in yet another blow to the Southeast Asian nation’s democracy.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Russia bombards a town near Bakhmut.
lead_paragraph: In Avdiivka, a town in eastern Ukraine where just a few hundred people remain, the shelling barely stops. Residents hide in basements, as the thud of Russian artillery reverberates every minute or two. The assault is part of Russia’s effort to capture the area around Bakhmut.

headline: The head of the U.N.’s nuclear watchdog visits Ukraine’s embattled Zaporizhzhia plant.
abstract: The director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, Rafael Mariano Grossi, arrived at the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant in southern Ukraine on Wednesday to discuss conditions at the facility that has been shelled several times since Russian troops seized it last March.
lead_paragraph: The director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, Rafael Mariano Grossi, arrived at the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant in southern Ukraine on Wednesday to discuss conditions at the facility that has been shelled several times since Russian troops seized it last March.

headline: Word of the Day: abrogation
abstract: This word has appeared in six articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word abrogation has appeared in six articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 30 in the Opinion column “Resisting the Worst of the Web Is Not Futile” by Kara Swisher:

headline: Stephen Colbert Calls Nashville Shooting ‘Horrible and Familiar’
abstract: “Not doing anything about this is an insane dereliction of our collective humanity,” Colbert said on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Penmanship
abstract: How’s your handwriting?
lead_paragraph: How often do you write by hand? Is your penmanship legible when you do? How much do you care about how it looks? In what circumstances or settings do you tend to write by hand rather than digitally? What, for you, is different about writing by hand? Which way of writing do you prefer?

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: The Way You Watch Sports on TV Is Changing. Here’s Why.
abstract: The slow collapse of regional sports networks that broadcast baseball, basketball and hockey games has implications for viewers and for the sports themselves.
lead_paragraph: The system of regional sports network television channels — which televise most Major League Baseball, N.B.A. and N.H.L. games and pay billions of dollars to teams each season — is slowly collapsing, and the way consumers watch sports on TV is changing.

headline: Hakeem Jeffries’s Path to Power in the House
abstract: Democrats in the House of Representatives have an enigmatic new leader whose style has been influenced by the Black church, hip-hop and his time as a corporate lawyer.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll look at the rise of Representative Hakeem Jeffries, the House minority leader. We’ll also find out about a name change for the agency responsible for attracting visitors and conventions to New York City.

headline: Taiwan’s President Heads to the U.S., Bracing for China’s Retaliation
abstract: President Tsai Ing-wen is expected to meet Speaker Kevin McCarthy next week, risking a show of force from Beijing, which opposes any such exchanges.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — As President Tsai Ing-wen of Taiwan heads to the United States, she is laying out a diplomatic agenda calibrated to strengthen ties with the West and assert her island’s autonomy, while trying to avoid moves that might ignite a crisis with China.

headline: UBS Brings Back Ex-C.E.O. to Manage Takeover of Troubled Credit Suisse
abstract: Sergio Ermotti, who left in 2020, will rejoin UBS as it absorbs Credit Suisse, which faces new accusations that it violated a tax evasion plea agreement.
lead_paragraph: UBS said on Wednesday that it was bringing back Sergio P. Ermotti, a former chief executive, as the Swiss banking giant prepares to take over Credit Suisse, its troubled rival.

headline: U.S.-Israel Tensions Over Judicial Overhaul Burst Into Open
abstract: In response to sharp criticism by President Biden, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said that Israel would make its own decisions.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel responded defiantly on Wednesday to sharp criticism from President Biden over his government’s contentious judicial overhaul plan, declaring that Israel was “a sovereign country” that would make its own decisions.

headline: Seeing the World Through Kids’ Eyes
abstract: To find out how children’s travel experiences differ from their parents’, we enlisted families around the world to share their perspectives — and their pictures.
lead_paragraph: To find out how children’s travel experiences differ from their parents’, we enlisted families around the world to share their perspectives — and their pictures.

headline: How Has the Threat of Gun Violence Affected You?
abstract: How often is gun violence on your mind? How has it affected your mental health, quality of life or daily behavior?
lead_paragraph: The threat of gun violence is a reality Americans constantly live with. As of the publishing of this post, the Gun Violence Archive had counted 130 mass shootings in the United States in 2023 alone. That number includes the shooting on Monday at a private Christian elementary school in Nashville in which a 28-year-old killed three children and three adults.

headline: Go On, Take the Kids to Mykonos: Adult Resorts Open Up to Families
abstract: Parents fed up with being cooped up have driven a pandemic surge in family trips, and properties from Mexico to the Poconos are getting makeovers to meet the demand.
lead_paragraph: For six years, the Grand Fiesta Americana in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, catered to guests looking for relaxation and romance — as long as they left the kids at home.

headline: As a Doctor, I Know Being Ready to Die Is an Illusion
abstract: It is easier to search for readiness than to process what its absence means.
lead_paragraph: Nine years ago, near the end of my residency training, I sat opposite a patient, wondering whether he’d accepted that he was dying. He was in his 60s, an artist with sinewy arms and serene eyes, someone I’d come to know well over the past three years. Cancer had broken into his liver and bone marrow, robbing him of hunger and energy.

headline: We’re About to Find Out How Far the Supreme Court Will Go to Arm America
abstract: The Biden administration has asked the justices to overturn an appeals court decision on guns that can charitably be described as nuts.
lead_paragraph: How much further will the Supreme Court go to assist in the arming of America? That has been the question since last June, when the court ruled that New York’s century-old gun licensing law violated the Second Amendment. Sooner than expected, we are likely to find out the answer.

headline: ‘Ted Lasso,’ Season 3, Episode 3 Recap: Zava Superstar
abstract: What will the signing of a world-class striker mean for AFC Richmond?
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Zava era. For those who skipped the first two episodes of this third season of “Ted Lasso” — and honestly, shame on you; go back, do the homework and rejoin us — Ted’s team has signed one of the greatest players of the age, a mercurial striker named Zava. (He is based closely on the real-life star Zlatan Ibrahimovic.) This was accomplished by Rebecca rudely accosting him while he was using a urinal last episode. Whatever works, right?

headline: ‘Abbott Elementary’ and the Joys of Living Outside the Main Edit
abstract: The sitcom has tweaked the mockumentary formula to teach an invaluable lesson about the value of life off-camera.
lead_paragraph: There is a scene, early in the second season of ABC’s “Abbott Elementary,” that neatly captures some most contemporary questions about the power and ubiquity of video. Teachers at Abbott, a public elementary school, are in their lounge, watching something alarming. A charter-school company has been running what’s essentially an attack ad against them, featuring unflattering video clips of them on the job. As they process seeing themselves eviscerated onscreen, a question hovers over the proceedings like chalkboard dust: How did the charter school obtain this footage in the first place? The answer comes from the school’s principal, Ava Coleman, who explains that she welcomed in the interloping camera crew — because she had a hard time telling them apart from the regular camera crew, the one supposedly filming the show we’re watching.

headline: I Know How Nuclear War Is Waged, So I’m Calling for Peace With North Korea
abstract: Pursuing a long-overdue official end to the Korean War could be a game changer.
lead_paragraph: Not many people know how to wage nuclear war. I’m one of them.

headline: How the Right Turned Radical and the Left Became Depressed
abstract: A new poll offers the outline of a unifying theory of right-wing recklessness and liberal anomie.
lead_paragraph: One of the notable dynamics of American life today is that conservatives report being personally happier than liberals but also seem more politically discontented. The political left has become more institutionalist, more invested in experts and establishments, even as progressive culture seems more shadowed by unhappiness and even mental illness. Meanwhile conservatives claim greater contentment in their private lives — and then go out and vote for paranoid outsiders and burn-it-down populists.

headline: He Fatally Shot His Girlfriend. Then He Wrote About It in His Diary.
abstract: James R. Ray III, a former Marine, is charged with killing Angela Bledsoe in the home they shared in an affluent New Jersey commuter town.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — The murder case against James R. Ray III was never short on drama.

headline: To Die on Her Own Terms, a Connecticut Woman Turns to Vermont
abstract: Connecticut does not allow medical aid in dying, so Lynda Bluestein sued Vermont to take advantage of that state’s law. Now, legislators may make the practice more broadly available.
lead_paragraph: Thanksgiving is typically a joyous time for the Bluestein family. Their Bridgeport, Conn., home is filled with laughter, music and even a cooking competition. But last fall, the mood was somber.

headline: This Vegan Soup Is Rich With Peanuts, Potatoes and Comfort
abstract: The flavors in a bowl of South American sopa de maní are soulful and steadying.
lead_paragraph: On the last morning of his life, in a little adobe schoolhouse in the Bolivian high-mountain village La Higuera, the Argentine revolutionary Che Guevara ate a bowl of sopa de maní. It was Oct. 9, 1967. There was no road to the village, only a horse trail. Guevara was wounded and captured by the Bolivian Army the day before, but he did not know that this was the end, that he would be executed within hours. In one account of that day, a 19-year-old teacher brought him breakfast from her house: a soup rich with peanuts, an Indigenous crop, and fortified by noodles and potatoes. In an oral history published in The Guardian more than four decades later, she remembered that “he was so hungry he ate it all without catching breath.”

headline: For $18,500 (and Up), You, Too, Can Travel Like James Bond
abstract: When the (real) world is not enough, new luxury tours offer fans a chance to engage with their favorite film and TV worlds.
lead_paragraph: From the post-apocalyptic bleakness of the TV show “The Last of Us” to the glamorous European destinations in the sprawling James Bond movie franchise, one source of travel inspiration is taking on fresh appeal as pandemic restrictions recede: the fictional worlds of film and television.

headline: Do You Live in a ‘Tight’ State or a ‘Loose’ One? Turns Out It Matters Quite a Bit.
abstract: What has happened to produce such intense hostility between left and right?
lead_paragraph: Political biases are omnipresent, but what we don’t fully understand yet is how they come about in the first place.

headline: Rift Between Gaming Giants Shows Toll of China’s Economic Crackdown
abstract: Activision Blizzard and NetEase could not agree on a new deal to distribute video games in China, cutting millions of players from the games in January.
lead_paragraph: Last October, executives at the Chinese gaming company NetEase and the American video game developer Activision Blizzard joined a Zoom videoconference to discuss the future of their 14-year partnership to offer Activision’s games like World of Warcraft in China.

headline: Republicans Face Setbacks in Push to Tighten Voting Laws on College Campuses
abstract: Party officials across the country have sought to erect more barriers for young voters, who tilt heavily Democratic, after several cycles in which their turnout surged.
lead_paragraph: Alarmed over young people increasingly proving to be a force for Democrats at the ballot box, Republican lawmakers in a number of states have been trying to enact new obstacles to voting for college students.

headline: Is It a Melon or a Cucumber? It’s a Cucumber Melon, and It’s Delicious
abstract: These heirloom cucumber varieties, some of which date to ancient Egypt, ‘are never bitter, and always easy on the digestion.’
lead_paragraph: Jay Tracy was just trying to solve a problem: He wanted to identify which cucumber varieties might perform best in hot, dry Tucson, Ariz., where he lived in 2009.

headline: Is True Love Possible? Readers Are Turning to This 1990s Novel for Answers.
abstract: Norman Rush’s “Mating” has achieved handshake status among younger readers thinking seriously about romantic relationships.
lead_paragraph: Katherine Champagne had never heard of “Mating,” the award-winning novel by Norman Rush, until one afternoon in 2020, when she popped into a random room on Clubhouse in the early days of that social media app.

headline: Will Ambitious Plans for a ‘New’ New York Get Crushed in Albany?
abstract: The State Legislature appears ready to block plans to significantly expand housing in the city and suburbs.
lead_paragraph: Since the pandemic began to wane, New York-watchers have stoked fears about an urban doom loop: Millennials like me — liberated from the chains of our desks — would abandon Midtown Manhattan and perhaps the city or state altogether in search of lower costs of living. The commercial tax base would be obliterated, leaving no funds to support essential services like the subway.

headline: Eastern Kentucky Needs Flood Relief, Not Another Federal Prison
abstract: Exploitation is not an economic development strategy.
lead_paragraph: Along the riverbanks of Eastern Kentucky, the redbud trees are just starting to bloom, their branches still lumbering under the weight of last summer’s catastrophic flood: Lawn chairs, trampolines, twisted gutters and school backpacks remain high in the treetops, each item a persistent and disorienting sign of how life here was turned upside down last July when shallow streams surged more than 18 feet in 10 hours in parts of the state, killing more than 40 people and leaving hundreds homeless. Yet while residents reach for the possibility of renewal, the largest regional investment being offered is a federal prison proposed for Letcher County, the heart of the flood zone.

headline: What We Know About the Nashville School Shooting
abstract: Investigators were still searching for a motive in the killing of six people at the Covenant School. The police said the assailant was being treated for an emotional disorder.
lead_paragraph: Questions have continued to swirl around the mass shooting this week at the Covenant School, a Christian elementary school in Nashville, with investigators still trying to determine the motive behind the attack that killed six people.

headline: Transgender Activist Who Made History in Bangladesh Is Onstage in New York
abstract: Tashnuva Anan Shishir, who became her country’s first transgender news anchor in 2021, is performing in “Public Obscenities” at Soho Rep.
lead_paragraph: When Shayok Misha Chowdhury wrote the character of Shou for his new bilingual play, “Public Obscenities,” about a couple who interviews queer locals in Kolkata, India, he was “super worried” about casting the role. The performer would not only need to be of the appropriate gender but also a Bangla speaker with the right “linguistic fluency” to capture the character, who speaks “exuberantly and forthrightly and confidently,” he told me recently.

headline: How Should Gwyneth Paltrow Dress for Court?
abstract: At the celebrity ski trial of the century, Ms. Paltrow can’t deny her own profile, but she can’t fully lean into it either.
lead_paragraph: Gwyneth Paltrow, wellness guru, entrepreneur and actress, has given the world many things: conscious uncoupling, rectal ozone therapy and, now, a week and a half into that limited series officially known as Sanderson v. Paltrow and unofficially as the Gwyneth Paltrow Ski Crash Trial that is taking place in Park City, Utah, and streaming on the Law & Crime network, a new style subgenre that ought henceforth to be known as courtcore.

headline: In This ‘Peter Pan,’ Something Always Goes Awry. That’s the Plan.
abstract: Broadway’s slapstick comedy “Peter Pan Goes Wrong” is full of daring sequences. What does it take? Countless rehearsals (and bruises).
lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon, the actor Greg Tannahill sat perched atop a London rooftop, one leg extended, one arm outthrust. A pair of carpenters would then whisk Tannahill from his rooftop and into a nursery. And then out of it. And then back in again. A window frame would come free. Tannahill, now jerked upside down, would mewl and scream and clamber down a wall. Once he finally righted himself, the flight harness would wrench him upside-down again.

headline: How ChatGPT and Bard Performed as My Executive Assistants
abstract: Google’s Bard chatbot fared far worse than OpenAI’s ChatGPT, but human assistants might soon be out of their jobs.
lead_paragraph: By now, plenty of us know that artificially intelligent virtual assistants like OpenAI’s ChatGPT and Google’s Bard can pull off sensational stunts, such as winning coding contests, passing bar exams and professing love to a tech columnist.

headline: The Incredible Challenge of Counting Every Global Birth and Death
abstract: In rural Colombia, as in many parts of the world, tallying births and deaths is one of the most desperately needed public-health measures. It’s a lot harder than it sounds.
lead_paragraph: The roads surrounding the Jerusalén-San Luis Alto Picudito Indigenous reservation in Putumayo, Colombia, are treacherous on a good day. Made mostly of gravel and mud, they narrow to barely the width of a small truck in some places, and in others, especially after a storm, they yield almost completely to the many rivers with which they intersect. They also twist and turn and bump without stop. So, in the most difficult months of her pregnancy, when everything tasted like cardboard and it hurt even to sit or stand, Marleny Mesa avoided traveling altogether. This meant skipping checkups at the clinic in Villagarzón, which could take two hours or more to get to. But Marleny wasn’t overly worried. A nurse had assured her early in her pregnancy that her blood work was good and that everything looked fine. As a midwife herself, Marleny knew that making the trip would be riskier than missing a few doctor’s visits.

headline: How a TikToker Brought Hundreds of Transplants to a Midwestern City
abstract: People hoping to become homeowners have answered the call to relocate to Peoria, Ill., where the housing is affordable and a one-person welcoming committee awaited them.
lead_paragraph: Mariela Munguía was idly browsing TikTok when something piqued her attention, prompting her to double back mid-scroll: a video about a two-bedroom house for sale in Peoria, Ill., for less than $50,000.

headline: The Yankees Cap Goes Viral in Brazil: ‘Is It Basketball?’
abstract: The New York Yankees logo is everywhere in Brazil. What it means, however, is up for interpretation.
lead_paragraph: Matheus Gustavo arrived for his second day of work at a hat shop in Rio de Janeiro wearing a black New York Yankees cap. His new job, for the most part, was selling Yankees hats. On the displays around him, about three out of four caps promoted that baseball team in the Bronx.

headline: How Ukraine’s Battered Steel Industry Galvanized Its War Effort
abstract: Ukraine’s iron- and steel-producing factories have made body armor, helmets and armored plates for vehicles — and steelworkers risked their lives rolling out heavy machinery at the beginning of the war to help physically block the Russian advance.
lead_paragraph: Inside the gloom of the vast Zaporizhstal steel plant, a towering blast furnace wheezes like a giant black lung, inhaling chunks of iron ore, thermal coal and limestone, blending them at temperatures reaching several thousand degrees with oxygen-enriched air, and then exhaling vapor and molten metal.

headline: Israel’s Far-Right Government Backs Down, for Now
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s decision to delay a contentious plan to weaken the judiciary came after weeks of social turmoil.
lead_paragraph: For months in Israel, the far-right government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has been pushing a highly contentious plan to fundamentally change the country’s Supreme Court, setting off some of the largest demonstrations in Israel’s history.

headline: Hervé Renard Set to Coach France at Women’s World Cup
abstract: Renard has vast experience in Africa and led Saudi Arabia at last year’s World Cup. But he has never coached a women’s team.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Hervé Renard, a French coach with vast experience in international soccer but none leading a women’s team, was set to be hired to lead a France squad that will be among the favorites at the Women’s World Cup in July.

headline: Obamacare Keeps Winning
abstract: Its North Carolina victory is a sign of larger changes.
lead_paragraph: The government benefits began their existence as objects of partisan rancor and harsh criticism. Eventually, though, they became so popular that politicians of both parties promised to protect them.

headline: Macy’s C.E.O. Jeff Gennette to Depart
abstract: Tony Spring, who runs Bloomingdale’s, will replace Jeff Gennette as chief executive in February. Mr. Gennette has led the chain since 2017.
lead_paragraph: Macy’s is shuffling its leadership team, announcing on Wednesday that Jeff Gennette, the chief executive since 2017, will retire in February after four decades with the department-store chain. He will be succeeded by Tony Spring, who runs the company’s luxury Bloomingdale’s chain.

headline: $2 Million Homes in Washington, New Mexico and Massachusetts
abstract: A Tudor Revival house in Seattle, a 2021 home in Santa Fe and a circa 1750 Colonial in Concord.
lead_paragraph: This house is in Mount Baker, a southeastern Seattle neighborhood prized for its well-maintained 1920s homes and proximity to Lake Washington. It is a 10-minute walk from open waterfront space with a boat launch area and from Genesee Park and Playfield, which has a grassy meadow and a dog park. A shopping center with a Safeway grocery store is about half a mile away, and public elementary and high schools are within a mile.

headline: UBS Taps an Ex-C.E.O. to ‘Pilot’ Its Takeover of Credit Suisse
abstract: Sergio Ermotti helped the bank recover after the 2008 financial crisis, but faces a tougher task this time.
lead_paragraph: UBS unexpectedly said on Wednesday that it was bringing back Sergio Ermotti as C.E.O., as the Swiss bank begins the tough task of digesting its archrival, Credit Suisse.

headline: F.D.A. Approves Narcan for Over-the-Counter Sales
abstract: The nasal spray reverses opioid overdoses and public health officials hope that making it more widely available could save lives and reduce the nation’s high rates of drug fatalities.
lead_paragraph: Narcan, a prescription nasal spray that reverses opioid overdoses, can now be sold over the counter, the Food and Drug Administration said on Wednesday, authorizing a move long-sought by public health officials and treatment experts, who hope wider availability of the medicine will reduce the nation’s alarmingly high drug fatality rates.

headline: How to Use Narcan Nasal Spray
abstract: Narcan, a naloxone nasal spray, is now approved for over-the-counter sales and should be widely available by late summer. Experts say that these sprays can swiftly reverse an opioid overdose and are easy to use. Here’s how.
lead_paragraph: Narcan, a naloxone nasal spray, is now approved for over-the-counter sales and should be widely available by late summer. Experts say that these sprays can swiftly reverse an opioid overdose and are easy to use. Here’s how.

headline: 10 Questions About Narcan
abstract: The F.D.A.’s decision to allow the overdose-reversing nasal spray to be sold over the counter means it will become much more widely available. Here is some guidance for using it correctly.
lead_paragraph: Narcan, a nasal spray that can quickly reverse an opioid overdose, has now received federal approval to be sold over the counter. By late summer, it should be widely available — not just on pharmacy shelves but also at convenience stores, big box chains and possibly through online retailers.

headline: How To Use Narcan to Save a Life
abstract: Narcan and other naloxone nasal sprays swiftly reverse an opioid overdose and are easy to use.
lead_paragraph: Narcan and other naloxone nasal sprays swiftly reverse an opioid overdose and are easy to use.

headline: The Boss Paid for Dinner, and Then Complained the Next Day. What Do We Do?
abstract: An email from her husband’s visiting boss about a higher-than-expected charge from dinner rattled a reader enough to send a check. Was it an overreaction?
lead_paragraph: My husband’s boss, an executive at a multinational firm, came to our city on vacation and invited us to dinner. We made reservations at our favorite restaurant. When the bill came, the boss’s husband picked up the check and said: “We’ve got this.” We thanked them and said we hadn’t intended for them to pay. The next day, my husband received an email from his boss saying he just saw the credit card charge, which was larger than expected. He planned to ask the restaurant if there was an error. We were embarrassed; we ordered more to drink than them. So, we pulled up the menu online, totaled our share with tax and tip, and sent them a check. (It was $37 more than their share.) We apologized for not insisting on splitting the bill. Did we do the right thing?

headline: On Opening Day, Teams Put Their Best Arms Forward
abstract: Aces around the majors are ready to go, with the Yankees’ Gerrit Cole facing Logan Webb of the Giants and the Mets’ Max Scherzer facing Sandy Alcantara of the Marlins.
lead_paragraph: Optimism abounds on opening day. Just about every team — sorry, Oakland and Washington — starts the year believing the playoffs are in its future, and every player is hoping to get off to a fast start.

headline: Californians Share Their Pandemic Silver Linings
abstract: How things have changed three years since the coronavirus pandemic began.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic has been defined by so much loss. Of lives, jobs, relationships. Of normalcy.

headline: Living In ... Wallkill, N.Y.
abstract: This Ulster County hamlet may not be as hip as some Hudson Valley towns, but it’s more affordable. And everyone turns out for the spring Duck Derby.
lead_paragraph: This Ulster County hamlet may not be as hip as some Hudson Valley towns, but it’s more affordable. And everyone turns out for the spring Duck Derby.

headline: Wallkill, N.Y.: An Escape From ‘Hip and Trendy’
abstract: This Ulster County hamlet may not be as fashionable as some Hudson Valley towns, but it’s more affordable. And everyone turns out for the spring Duck Derby.
lead_paragraph: Wallkill, N.Y., isn’t hip, and it barely has a downtown — but homes there often cost less and come with more land than those in higher-profile Hudson Valley communities.

headline: Ukraine says it will use legal means to remove pro-Russian monks from a revered Orthodox site.
abstract: Representatives of the monks and priests have vowed to ignore an eviction order.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s government says it will use legal means to evict monks and priests from an Orthodox monastery complex in Kyiv if they do not leave by a Wednesday deadline, arguing that their loyalty to a parent church in Moscow undermines Ukraine’s efforts to fight back against Russia’s military invasion.

headline: The Tricky Thing With Humanism, This Book Implies, Is Humans
abstract: Sarah Bakewell’s sweeping new survey of the philosophical tradition, “Humanly Possible,” says that putting your faith in human behavior means confronting complacency and nihilism — but it can be worth it.
lead_paragraph: “I am human, and consider nothing human alien to me”: The famous line from the Roman playwright Terence, written more than two millenniums ago, is easy to assert but hard to live by, at least with any consistency. The attitude it suggests is adamantly open-minded and resolutely pluralist: Even the most annoying, the most confounding, the most atrocious example of anyone’s behavior is necessarily part of the human experience. There are points of connection between all of us weirdos, no matter how different we are. Michel de Montaigne liked the line so much that he had the Latin original — Homo sum, humani nihil a me alienum puto — inscribed on a ceiling joist in his library.

headline: Can New York Fix Its Housing Crisis? It Depends on the Suburbs
abstract: The governor’s quest, to force suburbs around New York City to build more housing, is meeting with resistance.
lead_paragraph: Scarsdale, N.Y., a village about 20 miles north of New York City known for Tudor-style architecture and large, lavish estates, may seem like an unusual setting for an aging, five-story parking garage that neighbors have described as “an eye sore,” “decrepit,” “unsafe” and “seedy.”

headline: Power Your Run With Better Breathing
abstract: If you’re not using your diaphragm efficiently, you’re not getting the most out of your workout, experts say.
lead_paragraph: Most runners know that in order to get better, they need to train the major muscle groups that are activated during a run — the quads, the glutes, the hamstrings, the calves.

headline: Elon Musk and Others Call for Pause on A.I., Citing ‘Profound Risks to Society’
abstract: More than 1,000 tech leaders, researchers and others signed an open letter urging a moratorium on the development of the most powerful artificial intelligence systems.
lead_paragraph: More than 1,000 technology leaders and researchers, including Elon Musk, have urged artificial intelligence labs to pause development of the most advanced systems, warning in an open letter that A.I. tools present “profound risks to society and humanity.”

headline: King Charles Arrives in Germany for First State Visit as Monarch
abstract: Charles and Camilla, the queen consort, visited the Brandenburg Gate in Berlin to start their three-day trip.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Making his first official overseas trip as Britain’s new monarch, King Charles III began a three-day state visit to Germany on Wednesday, with Camilla, the queen consort, greeting a crowd of hundreds of spectators at the landmark Brandenburg Gate in Berlin.

headline: A Smoky Egg Salad to Rule Them All
abstract: Ali Slagle’s new recipe uses romesco sauce for big flavor.
lead_paragraph: Since I was about 13 and saw a tiny photo of one in an outdated Spanish language textbook, I’ve been dreaming about going to a calçotada — a Catalonian get-together where people grill loads of calçots, a spring onion as slender as a baby leek, and then eat them heaped with romesco sauce.

headline: ‘Spin Me Round,’ ‘Small Town Crime’ and More Streaming Gems
abstract: This month’s recommended viewing includes a pair of unconventional rom-coms, genre titles with a lot on their minds and two must-see docs for music lovers.
lead_paragraph: The director Jeff Baena and the actor Alison Brie first teamed for his 2016 film “Joshy,” and she’s been in every film he’s made since — not only starring in but co-writing his two most recent, “Horse Girl” (2020) and this slightly demented rom-com riff. Brie stars as Amber, the manager of the Bakersfield franchise of an Olive Garden-style chain restaurant called Tuscan Grove, who is offered the chance to spend a week at the chain’s training institute in Italy. She takes the leap, clutching an “Eat, Pray, Love” paperback, her imagination full of romantic visions that are, to put it mildly, not to be met. Brie is as starry-eyed and sympathetic as ever, and she and Baena’s stock company of players — including Molly Shannon, Fred Armisen and Baena’s offscreen partner Aubrey Plaza — are reliably uproarious.

headline: DNA Confirms Oral History of Swahili People
abstract: A genetic analysis of dozens of ancient skeletons from East Africa helps pin down the origins of coastal Swahili society.
lead_paragraph: A long history of mercantile trade along the eastern shores of Africa left its mark on the DNA of ancient Swahili people.

headline: UConn’s Adama Sanogo Is Fasting for Ramadan and Leading His Team
abstract: Sanogo, a 6-foot-9 forward, couldn’t eat before either of Connecticut’s last two N.C.A.A. tournament games, but against Gonzaga, he powered up at halftime.
lead_paragraph: Connecticut led Gonzaga by just 7 points when the sneakers stopped squeaking on the court for halftime and the teams headed toward their locker rooms in their regional championship game in the men’s N.C.A.A. tournament last weekend.

headline: Review: In This Eco-Thriller, the Animals May Be Having Their Revenge
abstract: The British experimental theater company Complicité turns the Nobel laureate Olga Tokarczuk’s novel “Drive Your Plow Over the Bones of the Dead” into a thought-provoking, entertaining spectacle.
lead_paragraph: Some books lend themselves to stage adaptation more than others, and the experimental theater company Complicité has a strong track record of turning awkward novels into plays. The British troupe, led by the director Simon McBurney, has already created acclaimed productions from Mikhail Bulgakov’s “The Master and Margarita” and Max Porter’s “Grief Is the Thing With Feathers.”

headline: Quiz: What Makes A.I. Chatbots Go Wrong?
abstract: You read Part 3 of our weeklong series on artificial intelligence. Now test your knowledge.
lead_paragraph: You read Part 3 of our weeklong series on artificial intelligence. Now test your knowledge.

headline: The Liberal Maverick Fighting Race-Based Affirmative Action
abstract: For decades, Richard Kahlenberg has pushed for a class-conscious approach to college admissions. He may finally get his wish, but it comes at a personal cost.
lead_paragraph: ROCKVILLE, Md. — For the college class he teaches on inequality, Richard D. Kahlenberg likes to ask his students about a popular yard sign.

headline: Disney Lays Off Ike Perlmutter, Chairman of Marvel Entertainment
abstract: The move, part of a cost-cutting campaign, followed Mr. Perlmutter’s unsuccessful effort to shake up Disney’s board.
lead_paragraph: Isaac Perlmutter, the famously frugal Marvel Entertainment chairman who unsuccessfully worked to shake up the Walt Disney Company’s board in the past year, has been laid off as part of a cost-cutting campaign.

headline: China’s Soccer Experiment Was a Flop. Now It May Be Over.
