lead_paragraph: The brawl at the beginning of Ursula Meier’s “The Line” makes for a fitting start to a film about damage — the kind that only family can cause.

headline: What’s More Provocative Than Sincerity?
abstract: Ryder Ripps built a career as a digital art troll, and now he’s calling out his former boss Kanye West and Bored Ape Yacht Club for bigotry. Is his crusade real?
lead_paragraph: Over his 15-year career, the artist and creative director Ryder Ripps has built websites for the likes of Kanye West, who is now known as Ye, and Kenzo, designed album covers for musicians such as Grimes and Pop Smoke, and shown his work in respected New York galleries. But across mediums, what he does never entirely changes. He finds things online and repurposes them.

headline: Bankers are convicted of allowing a Putin ally to deposit millions in Swiss accounts.
abstract: The accounts were opened in the name of Sergei P. Roldugin, a concert cellist nicknamed “Putin’s wallet.”
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Four bankers have been convicted of failing to conduct due diligence on Swiss accounts that were opened in the name of a musician with close ties to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and used to make deposits worth tens of millions of dollars.

headline: The Indie-Rock Trio boygenius Returns, Confident and Connected
abstract: Julien Baker, Phoebe Bridgers and Lucy Dacus reunite to take new chances on their first full album together, “The Record.”
lead_paragraph: A streak of conspiratorial glee runs through “The Record,” the full-length debut album by boygenius. “It’s a bad idea and I’m all about it,” Julien Baker announces in “$20,” the album’s brashest rocker, which leaps around with hard-strummed, odd-meter guitar riffs. Baker goes on to boast, “In another life we were arsonists.”

headline: The Math of Putting Tiles Together
abstract: This week, mathematicians announced the discovery of a single tile shape that produces aperiodic patterns. It’s the latest advance in a field that stretches back decades.
lead_paragraph: This week, mathematicians announced the discovery of a single tile shape that produces aperiodic patterns. It’s the latest advance in a field that stretches back decades.

headline: House Passes G.O.P. Energy Bill, Pushing to Roll Back Biden Climate Measures
abstract: The legislation, which had no chance of making it through the Senate, would expand mining and fossil fuel production while repealing some elements of a major new law to combat climate change.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A divided House of Representatives on Thursday passed an energy bill aimed at expanding mining and fossil fuel production in the United States that would repeal sections of the landmark climate change legislation that President Biden signed into law last summer.

headline: Sam Bankman-Fried Pleads Not Guilty to Additional Set of Charges
abstract: Prosecutors this week charged Mr. Bankman-Fried with orchestrating a $40 million bribe to Chinese officials to unfreeze funds held by his trading firm, Alameda Research.
lead_paragraph: The disgraced cryptocurrency executive Sam Bankman-Fried pleaded not guilty on Thursday to an array of criminal charges, including new accusations that he committed bank fraud and bribed a foreign official.

headline: Severe Storms in the Midwest Could Bring Tornadoes to Over a Dozen States
abstract: One week after devastating tornadoes tore through the mid-South, more appear likely, this time threatening a much larger region.
lead_paragraph: Widespread and potentially severe thunderstorms, including the possibility of damaging winds and tornadoes, are likely on Friday for over a dozen states in the Midwest and the mid-South, potentially affecting over 30 million people.

headline: Wall St. Bonuses Drop 26% as Deal-Making Cools
abstract: The bumper payouts earlier in the pandemic have waned, as banks cut costs and worries about financial stability loom over markets.
lead_paragraph: Bonuses for Wall Street workers fell 26 percent in 2022, as a slowdown in deal-making cast a chill on the industry after a surge in previous years.

headline: Review: A Concerto Makes Two Soloists a Many-Tentacled Creature
abstract: Felipe Lara’s sensational Double Concerto, with Claire Chase and Esperanza Spalding, was played by the New York Philharmonic under Susanna Mälkki.
lead_paragraph: Placing an old piece in new surroundings can make you think about it in a fresh way. Until the New York Philharmonic played Charles Ives’s short, indelible “The Unanswered Question” on Wednesday at David Geffen Hall under Susanna Mälkki’s baton, I had never thought of it as a tiny double concerto.

headline: Lobbyists Begin Chipping Away at Biden’s $80 Billion I.R.S. Overhaul
abstract: The tax preparation industry is alarmed over the prospect that the Internal Revenue Service will devise its own free tax-filing system.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration’s $80 billion overhaul of the Internal Revenue Service is facing a new line of attack, this time from lobbyists representing tax preparers who fear that the agency’s growing power will cripple their businesses and infringe upon taxpayer privacy.

headline: Review: A New Zealand Troupe’s Oceanic Feelings
abstract: Atamira Dance Company’s “Te Wheke” at the Joyce Theater drops you into its world and trusts you can swim in it.
lead_paragraph: In Maori, “te wheke” means “the octopus,” both the cephalopod and a mythological creature. Or so I gather from the program of “Te Wheke,” the work that Atamira Dance Company performed during its debut at the Joyce Theater on Wednesday.

headline: Defense in Proud Boys Sedition Trial Encounters Hurdles
abstract: Plans by the defendants’ lawyers to make an aggressive case to the jury have been scaled back as prosecutors have undercut testimony from defense witnesses.
lead_paragraph: When the five Proud Boys now on trial for sedition charges stemming from the Capitol attack opened their defense two weeks ago, they were planning to make an unusually robust case to the jury.

headline: 11 New Books Coming in April
abstract: A thrilling shipwreck tale by David Grann, newly translated fiction by Han Kang and plenty more.
lead_paragraph: In her second novel, Hammad follows a British Palestinian actor who travels to Israel, where her sister lives, in the wake of a breakup. Soon, she is pulled into a production of “Hamlet” staged in the West Bank, prompting a deeper look at her own political and artistic values.

headline: Sheet-Pan Recipes for When You’re Down
abstract: Sometimes you need meals that require minimum effort.
lead_paragraph: I keep a running list of topics I want to cover in this newsletter, and I had a couple in mind for this week. Breakfasts that get me out of bed in the morning! Vibrant recipes for the spring produce creeping into farmers’ markets!

headline: Teaching Conservative Principles on Campus
abstract: Readers discuss a guest essay about how liberal professors can mentor conservative students. Also: Child abductions; talking with teens; art scams.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Spinning Gold’ Review: For the Records
abstract: A son’s tribute to the Casablanca Records impresario Neil Bogart gives short shrift to the art and the artists.
lead_paragraph: “Where’s the tingle?” might be the grouse come the end of “Spinning Gold,” a drama about Neil Bogart, the music-business impresario who founded Casablanca Records. Nearly every music biopic has a moment in which the dawn of a hit song stirs us anew. And while the executives often get their minute, they aren’t the main attraction. Not so with this movie, which was written and directed by Timothy Scott Bogart, a son of Neil Bogart. (The elder Bogart died of cancer in 1982, at 39.)

headline: Fiona and Ian Are Retired as Hurricane Names
abstract: Names are retired when a storm causes history-making destruction or death and reusing them would be insensitive, the World Meteorological Organization said.
lead_paragraph: Fiona and Ian are being retired from the rotating lists of Atlantic tropical cyclone names because of the death and destruction that storms with those names caused last year, the World Meteorological Organization said.

headline: ‘Rye Lane’ Review: A Lively Modern Rom-Com With a British Accent
abstract: Raine Allen-Miller’s feature debut revives the genre with exuberant performances and a vibrant South London setting.
lead_paragraph: The director Raine Allen-Miller’s debut feature, “Rye Lane,” is self-assured in a way that recent, by-the-numbers rom-coms from the likes of Netflix have shied away from. Whereas some films make the mistake of equating “crowd-pleasing” with “generic,” Allen-Miller brings us right into the heart of South London alongside her characters. Every detail of the film is full of specificity, even as the dreams and insecurities of its two leads are ubiquitous genre staples.

headline: ‘Imagining the Indian’ Review: Fighting Offensive Imagery
abstract: This documentary, subtitled “The Fight Against Native American Mascoting,” argues that Native-themed sports team branding fits into a history of systemic racism.
lead_paragraph: In July 2020, the National Football League team in Washington announced that it would shed a name that was long considered a slur against Indigenous people. The decision was a victory in the campaign by Native American activists to eliminate disparaging sports team names and iconography.

headline: DeSantis’s Allies Discover Disney Evaded Florida’s Move to Rein It In
abstract: The Florida governor’s new Disney World oversight board belatedly realized that the company had quietly sidestepped its control.
lead_paragraph: Over the past two months, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida has repeatedly declared victory in his yearlong effort to restrict the autonomy of Disney World, the state’s largest employer. “There’s a new sheriff in town,” he said numerous times, including at a news conference last month on Disney property, hours before appointing a new, handpicked oversight board.

headline: Macron, Trying to Move Past Pension Fury, Announces Water Plan
abstract: President Emmanuel Macron of France presented conservation proposals after an exceptionally dry winter. But his government is still dogged by pension protests.
lead_paragraph: President Emmanuel Macron of France wanted to talk about water.

headline: Biden Calls on Regulators to Increase Oversight of Certain Banks
abstract: The proposals, which would not require congressional approval, are a response to Silicon Valley Bank’s failure this month, which sent shocks through the financial system.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Thursday called on financial regulators to toughen oversight of medium-size banks that faced reduced scrutiny after a regulatory rollback during the Trump administration, his most aggressive response yet to the failure of two banks this month that rattled the nation’s financial system.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: I know people, and maybe you do too, who shun microwaves and stand well away from power lines and sleep in a separate room from their phones, all on the theory that they don’t want to interfere with their body’s normal electromagnetic functioning. I tend to smile indulgently at these people, not necessarily because they’re wrong — I’m no expert! — but because their quest seems so quixotic these days: That ship has sailed, and it has a power motor.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? Kim Petras and More
abstract: I’m a technology reporter for The Times. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.
lead_paragraph: I’m a technology reporter for The Times. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.

headline: The U.S. imposes sanctions on a Slovakian accused of trying to broker a Russia-North Korea arms deal.
abstract: A White House spokesman said the man would be in violation of several U.N. Security Council resolutions.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration said on Thursday that it was imposing sanctions on a Slovakian national accused of trying to broker a weapons deal between Russia and North Korea.

headline: Imagine T. Rex. Now Imagine It With Lips.
abstract: The apex dinosaur’s terrifying teeth were sheathed in lip-like tissue, some paleontologists say. Imagine them more akin to Komodo dragons than crocodiles.
lead_paragraph: Brimming with serrated teeth bigger than bananas, Tyrannosaurus rex’s fanged maw is iconic. Many depictions of the prehistoric predator show its teeth sticking out even when its mouth is closed, like a snaggletoothed crocodile.

headline: Vatican Repudiates ‘Doctrine of Discovery,’ Used as Justification for Colonization
abstract: Indigenous communities have long called on the Vatican rescind the concept, which had been used over the centuries to seize land from people in the Americas, Africa and elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: The Vatican formally repudiated on Thursday the “Doctrine of Discovery,” a legal concept based on 15th-century papal documents that European colonial powers used to legitimize the seizure and exploitation of Indigenous lands in Africa and the Americas, among other places.

headline: Mark Russell, Piano-Playing Political Satirist, Dies at 90
abstract: Washington was his main quarry. Did he have any writers? “Oh, yes — 100 in the Senate and 435 in the House of Representatives.”
lead_paragraph: Mark Russell, a master of political satire who stood at a star-spangled piano and kept the cognoscenti in stitches for six decades with musical parodies and professorial tomfoolery that tweaked politicians and captured the silly side of Washington, died on Thursday at his home there. He was 90.

headline: Ask Wirecutter: What Are the Best Buy-It-for-Life Products?
abstract: A reader asks about the things that can be passed on for generations.
lead_paragraph: A reader asks about the things that can be passed on for generations.

headline: At Least 35 Are Killed in India When a Temple’s Well Cover Collapses
abstract: Rescuers struggled to reach other Hindu worshipers who were trapped and injured in a packed temple in Indore during a religious festival.
lead_paragraph: At least 35 people were killed on Thursday when they plunged into a well after its cover collapsed inside a packed temple in the central Indian state of Madhya Pradesh, local officials said.

headline: He Was Mentally Ill and Armed. The Police Shot Him Within 28 Seconds.
abstract: The shooting of Raul de la Cruz in the Bronx has renewed the debate over whether police officers are equipped to respond to people in emotional distress.
lead_paragraph: A desperate call for help from a father in the Bronx whose adult son struggles with his mental health ended when responding officers shot his son within 28 seconds of their arrival, saying he had brandished a knife.

headline: The Sports to Watch This Weekend
abstract: It’s time for the honest-to-goodness Final Fours for men and women in college basketball.
lead_paragraph: It’s time for the honest-to-goodness Final Fours for men and women in college basketball.

headline: ‘A Thousand and One’ Review: A New York Love Story
abstract: A mesmerizing Teyana Taylor stars in A.V. Rockwell’s feature directing debut, about motherhood and survival in a fast-changing city.
lead_paragraph: The first time you truly see Inez De La Paz, the galvanic center of “A Thousand and One,” she is framed against a wall that’s as red as a fire alarm. Inez is on the move, as she often is in this heart-clencher, the low-angle camera worshipfully pointed up at her. And no wonder: Inez is a dynamo, a force. She’s tough and beautiful, mouthy and unwaveringly loyal, but if she moves fast it’s often because she has no other choice. All she has is forward momentum, her unbending will and the small, somber boy at her side.

headline: Kushner Firm Got Hundreds of Millions From 2 Persian Gulf Nations
abstract: The infusion of money from interests in the two Persian Gulf monarchies reflects the close ties to Middle Eastern countries established by Jared Kushner, former President Donald Trump’s son-in-law.
lead_paragraph: Wealth funds in the United Arab Emirates and Qatar have invested hundreds of millions of dollars with Jared Kushner’s private equity firm, according to people with knowledge of the transactions, joining Saudi Arabia in backing the venture launched by former President Donald J. Trump’s son-in-law as he left the White House.

headline: Federal Judge Strikes Down Obamacare Requirement for Free Preventive Care
abstract: The decision by a judge in Texas, which applies nationwide and could have far-reaching implications for millions of Americans, is almost certain to be appealed by the Biden administration.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge in Texas who once declared the Affordable Care Act unconstitutional issued a far-reaching ruling on Thursday that prevents the Biden administration from enforcing a provision of the law that provides patients with certain types of free preventive care, including screenings for cancer, depression, diabetes and H.I.V.

headline: ‘Star Trek: Picard’ Season 3, Episode 7 Recap: Moral Ambiguity
abstract: It turns out Starfleet is not the force for good that “The Next Generation” had us believe.
lead_paragraph: For much of “Star Trek: The Next Generation,” Starfleet was presented as the most virtuous force in the universe — a body with the aim to do good. No conquest. No fighting. Just good old fashioned exploration. Any time a photon torpedo was fired, it was because the Enterprise was forced to fire by hostile forces. If there were corrupt admirals here and there, they were just bad apples. If the Federation tried to move Native Americans away from their home without their permission to satisfy a silly treaty, it was with noble intentions: to avoid war.

headline: 4 Days After Netanyahu Fired Him, Defense Minister Is Still on the Job
abstract: Yoav Gallant, Israel’s defense minister, was fired on Sunday, setting off unrest, but Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu never formally confirmed his dismissal.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — He was technically fired on Sunday night, prompting a surge of unrest that a day later led the Israeli government to suspend its deeply contentious judicial overhaul.

headline: Just Try Looking Away From Gwyneth Paltrow’s Ski Crash Trial
abstract: The actress-turned-businesswoman is at the center of a trial that has become a fierce debate over a simple question: Who skied into whom? The online public is rapt.
lead_paragraph: Gwyneth Paltrow rose to fame as a young actress, but her influence spread broadly when she pivoted to businesswoman in 2008 by founding Goop, a lifestyle brand that famously sold vaginal wellness eggs that were the subject of a $145,000 false advertising settlement.

headline: March News Quiz for Students: Bank Failures, Girl Scout Cookies, "Last of Us"
abstract: Have you been paying attention to the news in March? See how many of these questions you can get right.
lead_paragraph: Have you been paying attention to the news in March? See how many of these questions you can get right.

headline: Elon Musk Tried to Meet With F.T.C. Chair About Twitter but Was Rebuffed
abstract: Mr. Musk requested a meeting with Lina Khan, the chair of the F.T.C., which has been investigating Twitter’s privacy and data practices.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk tried engaging with the Federal Trade Commission as the agency intensified an investigation into Twitter’s privacy and data practices, according to documents reviewed by The New York Times, in a sign of the billionaire’s hands-on approach to the inquiry.

headline: TKTK: "Retirement has been a blast!"
abstract: TKTK: TIAA helped Richard live the life he wanted in retirement.
lead_paragraph: TKTK: TIAA helped Richard live the life he wanted in retirement.

headline: Gego: Drawing in Space at the Guggenheim
abstract: In “Measuring Infinity,” the kinetic constructions of the Venezuelan sculptor Gertrud Goldschmidt climb, twist, dangle — and dazzle.
lead_paragraph: Air, light, height, with a tingle of vertigo, are what the Guggenheim Museum’s spiraling rotunda is about. Which makes it a near-ideal setting for the buoyant, lucent, constellational work of the German-born Venezuelan artist Gertrud Goldschmidt, who called herself Gego, and who made some of the most radically beautiful sculpture of the second half of the 20th century.

headline: Teenagers on What Their Families’ Native Languages Mean to Them
abstract: “I’m not that embarrassed,” one student said of his accent, “because it’s a flex to know multiple languages.”
lead_paragraph: Do you speak any languages besides English at home? Did your parents, grandparents or great-grandparents when they were growing up? Do you or anyone else in your family have what might be considered an accent?

headline: The Headless Statue of a ‘Roman Emperor’ Is Seized from the Met
abstract: Investigators said there was evidence that the bronze, on loan to the museum and valued at $25 million, had been stolen from Turkey.
lead_paragraph: Septimius Severus ruled ancient Rome as emperor for nearly two decades, and a seven-foot-tall statue that researchers say depicts him presided over the Greek and Roman galleries at the Metropolitan Museum of Art for the past 12 years.

headline: TKTK: "Retirement has been a blast!"
abstract: TKTK
lead_paragraph: TKTK

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Our TV critic recommends a roller-rink show for young viewers, a dreamy restaurant reality show and a music competition series that bucks the usual format.
lead_paragraph: ‘Saturdays’When to watch: Now, on Disney+, or Fridays at 9 p.m., on Disney.

headline: Stream These 9 Titles Before They Leave Netflix in April
abstract: A bunch of great TV shows and movies are departing for U.S. subscribers this month. Catch them while you can.
lead_paragraph: This month’s assortment of titles leaving Netflix in the United States includes three hysterically funny series, two of must-see documentaries, two comic-book adaptations that buck expectations and one of the scariest movies the streamer has to offer. See them before they leave. (Dates reflect the last day a title is available.)

headline: In Arrest of American Reporter, Russia Doubles Down on Isolation From West
abstract: The Kremlin, which accused a Wall Street Journal correspondent of being a spy, made a move not seen since the Cold War, further raising the barriers between Russia and the West.
lead_paragraph: With the arrest of a Wall Street Journal correspondent on Thursday, President Vladimir V. Putin signaled to the world that he was doubling down on Russia’s wartime isolation.

headline: Closing Arguments in Gwyneth Paltrow’s Ski Crash Trial
abstract: Terry Sanderson, a retired optometrist, accused Gwyneth Paltrow of crashing into him during a 2016 ski run at a Utah ski resort. The actress says she is the victim.
lead_paragraph: Terry Sanderson, a retired optometrist, accused Gwyneth Paltrow of crashing into him during a 2016 ski run at a Utah ski resort. The actress says she is the victim.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: The rise of exclusive, application-only gyms. Also: Private dinners where clothes aren’t allowed, and why people are still buying Crocs.
lead_paragraph: The rise of exclusive, application-only gyms. Also: Private dinners where clothes aren’t allowed, and why people are still buying Crocs.

headline: Michael Blackwood, Who Captured 20th-Century Artists on Film, Dies at 88
abstract: He made cinéma vérité documentaries — more than 160 — about musicians (Thelonious Monk), architects (Frank Gehry), composers (Philip Glass) and sculptors (Isamu Noguchi).
lead_paragraph: Michael Blackwood, a prolific documentarian who explored the work of 20th-century artists, architects, musicians, dancers and choreographers in more than 160 films and yet never became widely known, died on Feb. 24 at his home in Manhattan. He was 88.

headline: Nebraska’s Fight Over Transgender Care Turns Personal and Snarls Lawmaking
abstract: One state senator has been filibustering for weeks, trying to block a bill that would ban transition-related medical treatment for young people.
lead_paragraph: LINCOLN, Neb. — Ash Homan, a 12-year-old from Omaha, spoke confidently as he urged Nebraska lawmakers not to ban transition-related care for transgender minors.

headline: Trump Is Indicted, Becoming First Ex-President to Face Criminal Charges
abstract: The Manhattan district attorney, Alvin L. Bragg, has not announced the charges that former President Donald J. Trump will face when he is arraigned next week.
lead_paragraph: A Manhattan grand jury indicted Donald J. Trump on Thursday for his role in paying hush money to a porn star, according to people with knowledge of the matter, a historic development that will shake up the 2024 presidential race and forever mark him as the nation’s first former president to face criminal charges.

headline: How Did No-Mandate Sweden End Up With Such an Average Pandemic?
abstract: Reconsidering the country’s libertarian Covid response.
lead_paragraph: If you know one thing about Sweden’s pandemic, it is almost certainly that the country followed a radical, contrarian public health path. Its hands-off approach to Covid-19 mitigation — no stay-at-home orders to begin with, and no mask mandates later on — was one that many on the pandemic left quickly derided as sadistic public policy and many on the pandemic right praised as enlightened.

headline: Here are the key events that led to the indictment.
abstract: Donald J. Trump will become the first United States president, current or former, to face criminal charges.
lead_paragraph: The investigation by the Manhattan district attorney’s office into Donald J. Trump’s hush-money payments to a pornographic film star, which led to the indictment of the former president, has spanned nearly five years.

headline: This is what will happen when Trump is arrested in the coming days.
abstract: Donald J. Trump will likely face standard processing when he is taken into custody, but the unprecedented arrest of a former commander in chief will be anything but routine.
lead_paragraph: He will be fingerprinted. He will be photographed. He may even be handcuffed.

headline: I Worry About a Failed Prosecution of Trump, but I Worry More About No Prosecution
abstract: There are legitimate concerns about this indictment, but how could we give the boss a pass after convicting his fixer?
lead_paragraph: In 1872, President Ulysses S. Grant was arrested by a police officer for speeding in his horse-drawn coach in Washington. The officer stuck out his hand to signal a stop, and Grant obeyed and then accompanied the officer to the police station.

headline: Your Friday Briefing: Trump Indicted
abstract: Also, an American journalist arrested in Russia and a Chinese billionaire’s downfall.
lead_paragraph: A New York City grand jury hearing evidence in an investigation of the former president voted to indict Donald Trump for his role in paying hush money to a porn star, according to four people with knowledge of the matter. He became the first former U.S. president to face criminal charges.

headline: What to Know About State Moves to Ban Transgender Health Care
abstract: States across the country are considering laws that would restrict gender-related medical care.
lead_paragraph: States across the country are considering laws that would restrict gender-related medical care.

headline: 6 U.S. Service Members Suffered Traumatic Brain Injuries in Syria Attacks
abstract: The Pentagon said the injuries were diagnosed during routine screenings in the days after the strikes by Iranian-backed militants.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Six American service members suffered traumatic brain injuries in separate attacks by Iranian-backed militants in Syria last week, the Pentagon said on Thursday.

headline: Charges do not legally bar Trump from running for president.
abstract: Any indictment or conviction would not bar Mr. Trump from running.
lead_paragraph: The vote by a Manhattan grand jury to indict former President Donald J. Trump raises novel legal and political questions because he is running for the Republican nomination for president again.

headline: A President Faces Prosecution, and a Democracy Is Tested
abstract: For more than two centuries, American presidents were effectively shielded from indictment. But the case against former President Donald J. Trump breaks that taboo and sets a new precedent.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates on Donald Trump’s indictment.

headline: Donald Trump, Now Under Indictment
abstract: Readers speculate about the impact and wisdom of bringing the hush money charges.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Five Arrested in Migration Center Fire That Left 39 Dead in Mexico
abstract: The authorities said arrest warrants had been obtained for three government migration officials, two private security workers and a migrant accused of starting the blaze.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Mexican officials said on Thursday that they had arrested five people for their role in the fire in a Ciudad Juárez migrant detention center that killed at least 39 people.

headline: Even Donald Trump Should Be Held Accountable
abstract: A grand jury’s decision to indict Donald Trump is a necessary part of the American justice system.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in American history, a grand jury has indicted a former president of the United States, The Times reported on Thursday. Donald Trump spent years as a candidate, in office and out of office, ignoring democratic and legal norms and precedents, trying to bend the Justice Department and the judiciary to his whims and behaving as if rules didn’t apply to him.

headline: In Berlin, King Charles of Britain lauds Germany’s support for Ukraine.
abstract: “Together we must be vigilant against threats to our values,” the British monarch said to German lawmakers.
lead_paragraph: King Charles III of Britain addressed Germany’s Parliament, the Bundestag, on Thursday during his first international trip as monarch, emphasizing the close ties between the two nations and applauding the military aid Berlin has given to Ukraine.

headline: Trump denounces indictment as ‘political persecution.’
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s statement echoed what has been an extraordinary and blistering effort to try to prevent the Manhattan district attorney, Alvin L. Bragg, from indicting him.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump responded to the news that he had been indicted in a statement, calling the Manhattan grand jury vote “political Persecution and Election Interference at the highest level in history.”

headline: Lolita the Orca May Swim Free After Decades at Miami Seaquarium
abstract: The killer whale, also known as Tokitae, has been in captivity for more than 50 years. Amid increasing pressure, the Seaquarium has agreed to release her.
lead_paragraph: The killer whale Lolita, which has entertained generations of visitors with colossal leaps and sloppy belly flops that splashed crowds at the Miami Seaquarium, will be returning to her native waters after more than 50 years in captivity, the owner of the marine life aquarium and Miami-Dade County officials said.

headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Jury Finds Gwyneth Paltrow Not Liable in Damages Over the Crash
abstract: The verdict came after more than a week of testimony that covered skiing etiquette, medical history and celebrity culture.
lead_paragraph: A jury on Thursday found that Gwyneth Paltrow was not at fault over a crash with another skier on a Utah slope in 2016, a verdict that capped a week of testimony that explored skiing etiquette, medical history and celebrity culture.

headline: DeSantis Reunites With a Key Adviser as Campaign Plans Unfold
abstract: A central area of expertise for Dustin Carmack, who will leave his post at the Heritage Foundation, is national security, with a focus on cybersecurity.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida plans to install his former congressional chief of staff as a senior adviser specializing in national security when he formally begins his presidential campaign, according to three people briefed on the plans.

headline: The Necessity of Patriotism (Even in Times Like These)
abstract: America is rebounding, but will cynicism stop the renewal?
lead_paragraph: Dear Zoomers,

headline: Mets Get Some Bad News, but Walk Away With a Win
abstract: The ace right-hander Justin Verlander’s being put on the injured list will test the team’s depth, but Max Scherzer and the Mets’ bullpen were enough to beat Miami.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Thursday was supposed to be the triumphant opening act of the Mets’ highly anticipated 2023 season. Steven A. Cohen, the team’s billionaire owner, committed a record $377 million to payroll, according to estimates, and that’s before the roughly $105 million luxury tax bill arrives. Money doesn’t guarantee a championship but it certainly improves the odds.

headline: Opening Day Gives Yankees Plenty of Reason to Dream
abstract: Everything went well in the Bronx. Gerrit Cole cruised, Aaron Judge homered and Anthony Volpe made his major league debut in an easy win over San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: Admission to a ballgame comes with no promises, which is part of the allure. No reviews to consider, no spoilers to avoid. Bring your hopes and expectations and see if they match with reality.

headline: In Test of N.Y. Gun Law, Sheriff’s Deputy Accused of Attempted Murder
abstract: Vito Caselnova faces a charge of possessing a firearm in a so-called sensitive location under a contentious provision of the state’s revised gun law.
lead_paragraph: The chaotic scene, captured by a police officer’s body-worn camera, lasts less than 30 seconds. The officer, arm extended and ready to fire, shoves a bystander out of the way and rounds a corner onto a darkened street as a half-dozen shots ring out.

headline: Gunman in 2017 Las Vegas Shooting Was Angry at Casinos, New F.B.I. Files Show
abstract: While investigators concluded that the motive of Stephen Paddock was unclear, newly released records include an account that he was angry about the casinos’ treatment of wealthy clients.
lead_paragraph: The man who fatally shot 60 people at an outdoor music festival in Las Vegas in 2017 had been angry over what he saw as casinos scaling back on perks for V.I.P. gamblers like himself, according to an account provided to the F.B.I.

headline: Indictment elicits extensive coverage, and some gasps, on TV.
abstract: The news of the indictment of former President Trump immediately took over cable news channels and the country’s main broadcast networks on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The news of the indictment of former President Trump immediately took over cable news channels and the country’s main broadcast networks on Thursday.

headline: At Mar-a-Lago, Trump’s Camp Is Caught Off Guard
abstract: The former president’s aides had believed that any action by the grand jury was still weeks away.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates on Donald Trump’s indictment.

headline: Corrections: March 31, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, March 31, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about Mississippi’s rejection of federal funding to expand health insurance for the poor misstated the share of residents of the Mississippi Delta who are Black. It is about two-thirds, not nearly 35 percent.

headline: Finland Clears Last Hurdle to Joining NATO
abstract: Finland’s entry into the military alliance after Turkey formally signed off is a significant defeat for President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Finland won final approval on Thursday to join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization after decades of nonalignment, a major shift in the balance of power between the West and Russia that was set off by the invasion of Ukraine.

headline: One key player did not cooperate with prosecutors: Trump’s financial gatekeeper.
abstract: There is one central player who did not cooperate with the Manhattan district attorney’s office: Mr. Trump’s longtime financial gatekeeper.
lead_paragraph: As prosecutors built a criminal case against Donald J. Trump for his role in a hush money payment to a porn star, they interviewed several key witnesses: Mr. Trump’s onetime fixer, the former publisher of the National Enquirer and the actress herself.

headline: DeSantis says Florida wouldn’t aid Trump’s extradition to New York.
abstract: The Republican governor called the indictment of the former president ‘un-American.’
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, who is widely expected to challenge Donald J. Trump for the Republican presidential nomination in 2024, called the indictment of Mr. Trump “un-American” and said that his state “will not assist in an extradition request” should one come from New York authorities.

headline: Washington State Man Charged in Series of ‘Swatting’ Calls
abstract: The man, Ashton Connor Garcia, 20, falsely reported bombs, shootings and other threats, prosecutors said. In some cases, the calls prompted police officers to enter homes and detain people.
lead_paragraph: A 20-year-old Washington State man was arrested Thursday on federal charges that he made more than 20 hoax calls to law enforcement agencies last year and falsely reported bombs, shootings and other threats that sometimes led police officers to enter victims’ homes and detain them, prosecutors said.

headline: Blended Numbers
abstract: Rich Norris returns to the New York Times Crossword after 15 years.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: ‘Life of Pi’ Review: A Boy and a Tiger, Burning Brightly
abstract: Human ingenuity and animal grace course through this rich, inventive play about difficult choices and the stories we tell to make sense of them.
lead_paragraph: The butterflies enter first, quivering gaily atop their sticks. Then a giraffe pokes her head in. A goat gambols. A hyena cackles. One zebra runs on. Then another. An orangutan swings through while her baby reposes on a branch nearby. Above, monkeys and meerkats chitter. In the first act of “Life of Pi,” a menagerie — menacing, delightful — entrenches itself on the stage of Broadway’s Gerald Schoenfeld Theater.

headline: Variety: Encyclopedia Search
abstract: Will Shortz presents a simple letter grid with graceful complexity.
lead_paragraph: ENCYCLOPEDIA SEARCH — This variety puzzle, by Will Shortz, is the kind of throwback challenge that’s simple to replicate — you could draw it on a napkin at the bar, or scrawl it on a chalkboard — and work through in an analog fashion. I’m old enough to remember encountering puzzles like this in the newspaper, jotting down a few entries in the margins as they popped into my head, and waiting a week for an answer key to see the official results.

headline: Republicans Erupt in Outrage and Rush to Defend the Defendant
abstract: Many in the party said Donald Trump could benefit from a wave of sympathy among Republicans, with his base of supporters likely to be energized by a belief in a weaponized justice system.
lead_paragraph: Republican leaders in Congress lamented the moment as a sad day in the annals of United States history. Conservative news outlets issued a call to action for the party’s base. One prominent supporter of Donald J. Trump suggested that the former president’s mug shot should double as a 2024 campaign poster.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Online Grudges Fuel Surge of Teen Murder Across New York City
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, March 31, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “The kids involved are kids. They’re kids.”

headline: Conspiracy theorists online grasp for explanation behind indictment.
abstract: Mr. Trump tried rallying his base as the expected indictment drew near.
lead_paragraph: On social media channels associated with extremists and conspiracy theorists, people searched for an explanation behind former President Donald J. Trump’s indictment on Thursday, with some calling him a victim of a Democratic witch hunt to suppress his influence and others describing him as a grand master playing political chess to reclaim the presidency.

headline: See How Baseball’s New Rules Changed the Game
abstract: Opening day suggested how much difference a pitch clock can make.
lead_paragraph: Thursday was opening day for Major League Baseball and the first taste of rules designed, among other things, to speed up a lagging game.

headline: A Secret Crush Goes Public in a Work Meeting
abstract: Emily Liu had the face of Jake Klinker, her colleague and crush, pinned to her screen during virtual meetings — until another co-worker inquired about it.
lead_paragraph: In March 2020, Emily Yang Liu spent hours each day in virtual meetings with her team at Google, which was working on building Covid-19 exposure notifications technology. To keep herself engaged, she pinned her work crush, Jacob Michael Klinker, to her screen.

headline: ‘Mom, I’m Telling You, She’s the One’
abstract: Alexandra Howard and Dr. Brandon von Tobel knew on their first date six years ago that they had each found someone special.
lead_paragraph: In April 2017, Alexandra Elizabeth Howard was out to dinner with her neighbors in Manhattan’s NoLIta neighborhood. When they asked how her online dating was going, she pulled out her cellphone to show them her Bumble account. It was then that she saw a message from Dr. Brandon Zachary von Tobel, asking her out for a drink that very night.

headline: The Joke (Surprise, Surprise) Was on Them
abstract: Dr. Amit Raj’s cousins kept nudging him to ask Dr. Ami Modi out. So he got her on board to pretend they were dating. Soon enough, they really were.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Amit Raj got so tired of his two cousins constantly pestering him about going out with their friend Dr. Ami Deepak Modi that during the summer of 2010 he decided to play a joke on them.

headline: When Climate Change Melts Your Relationship
abstract: Everything was going great until I told him to dump his kerosene lamp for an LED.
lead_paragraph: My boyfriend and I had been dating for six months when we had the biggest fight of our relationship over the carbon footprint of a kerosene lamp. We had finished dinner in the cozy cabin of his sailboat and were about to begin a game of gin rummy to determine who would do the dishes when Doug stood up and banged his head on the kerosene lantern that dangled from the ceiling. He cursed as the lantern swung back and forth, dribbling kerosene onto the table.

headline: When Two Acrobats Fall Head Over Heels — for Each Other
abstract: Caitlin Reichel and Kristy Graziano met at a holiday party in Orlando, Fla., in 2016, but it would take three more years to become a couple.
lead_paragraph: Caitlin Skye Reichel was doing handstands at a corporate holiday party in Orlando, Fla., the first time Kristy Marie Graziano laid eyes on her.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Donald Trump was indicted.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump will be the first former U.S. president to face criminal charges. A grand jury in New York City voted to indict him for his role in paying hush money to a porn star during his 2016 presidential campaign, people with knowledge of the matter told The Times.

headline: In Taiwan’s Waters, a Hunt for Tiny, Wriggling ‘Gold’
abstract: For generations, people have fished for baby eels in the island’s estuaries. But they seem to be getting harder to find.
lead_paragraph: The hunters waded into the water after dark, their headlamps beaming as they tossed nets into the crashing waves over and over again.

headline: Why Do Russians Still Want to Fight?
abstract: The war in Ukraine may be a horror, but it’s also an opportunity.
lead_paragraph: From the perspective of a Russian soldier, the war in Ukraine must look nightmarish. In over a year of combat, nearly 200,000 Russian troops have been killed or wounded, according to American officials, in a military operation that has proved both incompetent and ill equipped. Morale is reportedly low and complaints common. And yet a significant number of Russian men are still keen to fight — more, in fact, than at the war’s outset. What explains the disconnect?

headline: Word of the Day: bleat
abstract: This word has appeared in eight articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word bleat has appeared in eight articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 19 in “Covid Stopped the Music. Now This School Is Striking Up the Band Again” by Sarah Diamond:

headline: Late Night Is Tickled by Trump’s Indictment
abstract: “He was right — we’re finally saying ‘Merry Christmas’ again!” Stephen Colbert said of Donald Trump on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Once Before, an Ex-President Was in Jeopardy in New York
abstract: Ulysses S. Grant was all but ruined by his involvement in investment banking, but unlike Donald Trump, he was never indicted.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at the indictment of former President Donald Trump in the context of presidential history in New York. We’ll also look at why subway token-booth clerks have stepped out of their booths.

headline: ‘Keep TikTok’
abstract: What do you think this image is communicating?
lead_paragraph: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: A Former Marine, Reporting on the Front Lines of a Different War
abstract: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, who served as an infantryman in Afghanistan before joining The Times in 2017, takes on a new role: Ukraine correspondent.
lead_paragraph: Since Russia invaded Ukraine more than a year ago, journalists at The New York Times have covered the tragedies, devastation and death tolls, as well as Ukraine’s resistance and resilience. As the war grinds on with no end in sight, The Times has created a new role for Thomas Gibbons-Neff, the former Kabul bureau chief: Ukraine correspondent.

headline: ‘I Don’t Want to Let Them Down’
abstract: As South Carolina seeks its second straight N.C.A.A. women’s basketball championship, Coach Dawn Staley carries the hopes of her family, her team and the generation of coaches she has inspired.
lead_paragraph: GREENVILLE, S.C. — Dawn Staley greeted her players at midcourt on Monday with a pregame ritual, briefly dancing a two-step called the Baltimore Shuffle. After the South Carolina women’s basketball team dispatched Maryland to reach the Final Four of the N.C.A.A. tournament, the Gamecocks cut down the net at one basket. Staley, their coach since 2008, slipped it like jewelry over her Louis Vuitton sweatsuit. A “netlace,” she has called it through the years.

headline: ‘Murder Mystery 2’ Review: The Case of the Innocuous Sequel
abstract: Adam Sandler and Jennifer Aniston return as private detectives in this Netflix follow-up comedy.
lead_paragraph: For a certain brand of Adam Sandler films, you know what you’re going to get: something cheerfully lowbrow, easygoing and listlessly comforting when used as background programming. Such movies are what make the actor’s longstanding partnership with Netflix perhaps too suitable a match, as the bulk of the company’s original content has been gradually cheapened to a similar brand. With “Murder Mystery 2,” the sequel to the 2019 comedy “Murder Mystery,” it’s much of the same.

headline: With its arrest of an American reporter, Russia doubles down on isolation.
abstract: With the arrest of a Wall Street Journal correspondent on Thursday, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia signaled to the world that he was doubling down on the country’s wartime isolation.
lead_paragraph: With the arrest of a Wall Street Journal correspondent on Thursday, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia signaled to the world that he was doubling down on the country’s wartime isolation.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of boygenius's album "The Record."
lead_paragraph: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of boygenius's album "The Record."

headline: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: This week’s picks include Emily St. John Mandel’s latest novel, a biography of the Getty dynasty and more.
lead_paragraph: This week’s picks include Emily St. John Mandel’s latest novel, a biography of the Getty dynasty and more.

headline: How I Hold It Together: Cher’s Advice and More
abstract: Jancee Dunn, Well's weekly newsletter columnist, shares her strategies for self-care.
lead_paragraph: Jancee Dunn, Well's weekly newsletter columnist, shares her strategies for self-care.

headline: Do You Speak Real Estate? Take Our Home Buyer’s Quiz.
abstract: Ready to purchase a home? Test your knowledge of real estate vocabulary.
lead_paragraph: Ready to purchase a home? Test your knowledge of real estate vocabulary.

headline: Hamlet, and a Political Awakening, Stir in the West Bank
abstract: Isabella Hammad’s new novel, “Enter Ghost,” recounts an actor’s return to Palestine amid a sea of troubles.
lead_paragraph: Ordinarily, coming-of-age stories build to a pivotal moment when protagonists who are not yet adults become them. “The Catcher in the Rye” remains a prevailing model. But in real life, only the lucky — or unlucky — among us grow up just once. More often, coming-of-age happens repeatedly, in irregular and bewildering bursts.

headline: Google C.E.O. Sundar Pichai on Bard, A.I. ‘Whiplash’ and Competing With ChatGPT
abstract: “Am I concerned? Yes. Am I optimistic and excited about all the potential of this technology? Incredibly.”
lead_paragraph: For years, Google was seen as one of the most cutting-edge developers of A.I. But, with OpenAI’s release of ChatGPT, and other chatbots beating Google to market, is that distinction still the case? Google’s chief executive is in an unenviable position: Scramble to catch up or, in the face of potentially harmful technology, move slowly.

headline: My Favorite Song | Alex Newell
abstract: The actor and singer Alex Newell on Whitney Houston’s “How Will I Know.”
lead_paragraph: The actor and singer Alex Newell on Whitney Houston’s “How Will I Know.”

headline: What New Rules Would Improve Your Favorite Sport?
abstract: Major League Baseball is implementing some of the biggest changes in the sport’s history to make games more fun and action-packed. Will they help bring in younger fans?
lead_paragraph: The new baseball season is here. Are you a big fan? Or, do you find the games to be too long and boring?

headline: How Big Tech Camouflaged Wall Street’s Crisis in March
abstract: Investors in the S&P 500 are highly dependent on the fate of Microsoft, Apple and other big technology stocks. A rally in March showed how this can mask turmoil in the rest of the market.
lead_paragraph: The fate of the S&P 500 index — used by investors as a barometer for the health of corporate America, and cited by presidents as a measure of their handling of the economy — often comes down to just two companies: Apple and Microsoft.

headline: You Think Your Dog Is Special? Meet Elphinore.
abstract: In M.T. Anderson’s “Elf Dog & Owl Head,” a scrappy hound scampers out of a magical world and into our own.
lead_paragraph: M.T. Anderson won the National Book Award in 2006 for the first volume of “The Astonishing Life of Octavian Nothing, Traitor to the Nation.” He also won, in my head, the award for Best First Line of 2002, with his novel “Feed,” which begins: “We went to the moon to have fun, but the moon turned out to completely suck.” (“Feed,” too, owns the distinction of having been right about social media two years before Facebook even launched.) Anderson’s work is invariably funny and piercingly intelligent and never quite what you expect — any writer whose oeuvre extends from “Symphony for the City of the Dead” to “Burger Wuss” is working all possible sides of a street that has more than the usual number of sides.

headline: Alex Newell From ‘Shucked’ Sings Their Favorite Whitney Houston Song
abstract: After growing up listening to powerhouse voices, the actor brings their own back to Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Amid the sweet, folksy ballads (and many, many corn jokes) of “Shucked,” the new Broadway musical opening April 4, comes a soulful, commanding number performed by Alex Newell that provides the show some unexpected heft — a song full of riffs and modulations and belted notes that seem to reach both ends of the actor’s expansive range.

headline: The Solution to Israel’s Crisis Might Be in America’s Constitution
abstract: It might learn from the American experience that a crisis can open unexpected vistas for the Jewish state.
lead_paragraph: The political crisis engulfing Israel has raised profound and fundamental questions about the roots of democratic legitimacy. Now that the government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has blinked, and a vote on its proposed transformation of the judiciary has been delayed, Israelis might just have a chance to consider those broader questions and negotiate toward some long-needed political reforms. As they contemplate such prospects, they should consider the experience of America’s Constitution makers.

headline: Why Money Makes Everyone So Anxious
abstract: With tax day looming, we asked experts to share tips for managing stress.
lead_paragraph: Some people look forward to tax season as a time of unexpected bounty; others approach it with as much enthusiasm as a deer might have for bowhunting season. For much of my career, I’ve been a self-employed person with erratic earnings. I usually owe. I put off filing for as long as possible, and then I often request an extension.

headline: ‘Yellowjackets’ Season 2, Episode 2 Recap: Dig In
abstract: This week, the Yellowjackets may have bitten off a little more than they can chew — in one sense anyway.
lead_paragraph: “She wants us to.”

headline: 12 Ways to Save on Family Travel
abstract: Like everything else these days, the cost of a family vacation is rising. With spring break season upon us, here’s how to keep costs under control.
lead_paragraph: In the seasonal surge to the skies and roads, spring break promises a recharge — and a financial pinch. That’s especially true this year, when flight prices are up 20 percent compared with last March and April, according to the travel booking app Hopper, and hotels in the United States are averaging $316 a night, up 64 percent in the same time frame.

headline: There Is No Point in Hiding That We Threw Parades for War Criminals
abstract: Ticker-tape parades are an honor that we bestow as a people, and to edit the record of them is to blot out our own mistakes.
lead_paragraph: The Manhattan borough president, Mark Levine, recently demanded that the names of Philippe Pétain and Pierre Laval, notorious for leading the French collaborationist government in World War II, be removed from the stretch of Lower Broadway where they were recognized with ticker-tape parades over 90 years ago.

headline: The Republican Party Says It Wants to ‘Protect Children,’ but Not All Children
abstract: When Tucker Carlson, Christopher Rufo and Moms for Liberty say jump, the only question is: “How High?”
lead_paragraph: Here are a few of the things the Republican Party is prepared to do to protect children.

headline: Has Bitcoin Benefited From the Banking Crisis? Not in the Way Its Fans Hoped.
abstract: Bitcoin’s price has soared since banks failed this month, but there’s little evidence that the surge is being driven by investors treating the virtual currency as a financial alternative.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after Silicon Valley Bank failed this month, the price of Bitcoin soared above $25,000, reaching a threshold the digital currency hadn’t touched since June. This week, Bitcoin reached nearly $30,000, up 70 percent for the year.

headline: A Transcendent Memoir About Family, Class and the Contours of Loss
abstract: In her second memoir, “A Living Remedy,” Nicole Chung explores death and grief, and the way they’re shaped by structural issues in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Nicole Chung is a chronicler of loss. In her debut memoir, “All You Can Ever Know,” she wrote about what has become known as disenfranchised grief — sorrow that is not publicly acknowledged or socially supported — as she explored the circumstances of her adoption. Now, in her second memoir, “A Living Remedy,” Chung’s anguish is focused on the glaringly visible: the broken U.S. health care system; the brutality of capitalism; the hurt of everyday racism; and the devastating shock of losing her adoptive parents and the family narrative that, for so long, was all she knew.

headline: Don’t Sacrifice Good Jobs to Tame Inflation
abstract: When the Federal Reserve uses interest rate hikes as a blunt tool, American workers are the inevitable casualty.
lead_paragraph: Despite the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and the shock waves it sent through the banking sector — due, in part, to the bank’s risky exposure to higher interest rates — the Federal Reserve raised interest rates again, the ninth increase in the past year. Jerome Powell, the chairman of the Fed, has made one thing crystal clear: He is not going to let up on his war on inflation. American workers are the inevitable casualty.

headline: Retired and Buying a Starter Home. It’s Forever.
abstract: Many older home buyers say ownership was worth the wait, as they finally make a major real estate investment and consider their financial legacy.
lead_paragraph: Danette Jenkins was just about to celebrate her 55th birthday when she closed on her first apartment in New Jersey. Hilary Lensky was 66 when she got the keys to her condo in South Florida. And Dorothy Kopelman was 80 when she decided to finally stop renting in New York City.

headline: For ‘Dope’ Window Shopping, Try … the Upper East Side?
abstract: The interior décor store KRB is part shop and part workshop for experiments in blending objects of diverse quality, use and provenance.
lead_paragraph: On a recent mild afternoon, on the northwest corner of Lexington Avenue and East 73rd Street, a cluster of students from the nearby St. Jean Baptiste High School stopped to ogle the phantasmagorical contents of a shop window.

headline: Don’t Ban TikTok. Fix Internet Privacy.
abstract: Blocking the popular app isn’t the solution.
lead_paragraph: There’s been an average of more than one school shooting per week in the United States so far in 2023, so it’s great to see lawmakers from both parties finally reaching consensus on how to protect America’s children: Ban TikTok.

headline: How Much Did You Spend on Your Family Vacation?
abstract: We took a close look at people’s vacations — what their trips cost and what they chose to spend on for travels both near and far.
lead_paragraph: There’s no single set of rules when it comes to how and what to spend on travel, whether on a local road trip a few hours away or a jaunt to a far-flung destination dreamed of for decades.

headline: The Fed Is Doing Too Much, All at Once
abstract: In its fight against inflation, the Federal Reserve has contributed to the bank failures and economic instability that it is now trying to fix, our columnist says.
lead_paragraph: Beating inflation is crucial for the Federal Reserve. But so is promoting full employment. And don’t forget about preserving the stability of the financial system.

headline: Here’s What Happens as the Era of Mass Incarceration Winds Down
abstract: A generation that was locked up during the era of harsh drug sentences is facing a life outside prison. What can be done to help them?
lead_paragraph: In 2004, Charles Bryant, then a father in his 30s, was arrested in the Bronx with not quite 50 grams of crack — a quantity roughly equal to four robust pats of butter. He was charged with conspiracy to distribute narcotics, and based on policies established at the height of the war on drugs, he was sentenced to 25 years in prison. The timing seemed especially ill-fated, given that the United States Sentencing Commission that year was again calling attention to the racial disparities produced by what was known as the 100-to-1 rule. This meant that the same sentence would be applied to a dealer holding 50 grams of crack as the one selling 100 times that amount in cocaine, enough to fill a briefcase, privileging the high roller who sold powder to bond traders getting high in the bathroom at Raoul’s and crushing the corner hustler who funneled its cheaper derivative to the poor.

headline: For Ukrainian Convicts, a Strange Odyssey Through Russian Prisons
abstract: When Russian troops left Kherson, they took with them 2,500 Ukrainian convicts from local prisons. For some, it was the start of a bewildering, five-country journey highlighting the war’s absurdity.
lead_paragraph: Oleksandr Fedorenko’s odyssey began with a triumph for his native Ukraine.

headline: Many Democracies Have Prosecuted Ex-Leaders. The Politics Can Be Tough.
abstract: Scholars say it is important to hold the powerful legally accountable, but there are likely to be charges — well-founded or not — that prosecutors have political motives.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates on Donald Trump’s indictment.

headline: In Search of Romance? Try Moving Abroad.
abstract: For some American women, relocating outside of the United States has improved their dating lives. But some warn that finding love involves more than a change of address.
lead_paragraph: Kacey Margo has been going on plenty of fun dates ever since she moved to Paris in October 2019. Men frequently approach her with the dramatic antics seen in Disney movies.

headline: Women’s Sports Are Raking in Investments. The Final Four Shows Why.
abstract: With stars, story lines and skill, the TV rights for the women’s Division I basketball tournament could be worth over $80 million, part of a larger wave of investors flocking to women’s sports.
lead_paragraph: I’d waited all season for this. Watching from courtside during the Seattle regional last weekend, I finally learned what the Caitlin Clark experience is all about. Dagger 3-pointers, of course. But also one-hand passes streaked to every corner of the court. Slithering dribble-drives past stunned defenders. And more rebounds and sprinting layups than I could count.

headline: Her Views From Close Up Are on Everyone’s Radar
abstract: Lois Dodd, at 95, is finally getting her largest museum show yet at the newly expanded Bruce Museum in Greenwich, Conn.
lead_paragraph: For more than seven decades, Lois Dodd has been creating acutely observed and quietly influential paintings, finding her subjects close to home.

headline: Millennials Pay for a Dose of ’90s Nostalgia
abstract: At the second annual 90s Con, aging millennials traveled from across the United States to connect with the stars of their youth.
lead_paragraph: HARTFORD, CONN. — The stars were out at 9:30 a.m. in the Connecticut Convention Center.

headline: Practical but Not Pretty. That’s Pro Tennis at Miami’s N.F.L. Stadium.
abstract: Five years ago, the Miami Open had to abandon Crandon Park on Key Biscayne for Hard Rock Stadium and its parking lot. It remains a work in progress.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — No one really wanted to move the Miami Open 18 miles north from the idyll setting of Key Biscayne to a suburban N.F.L. stadium and its parking lot.

headline: French Anger at Macron Seeps Into Unexpected Corners
abstract: Even Bordeaux, known for its surrounding vineyards and conservative politics, has become a flashpoint. The City Hall’s charred doors attest to that.
lead_paragraph: The ancient wooden doors are adorned with an ornate metal knocker and a small grilled window, for guards to peek through. Once an imposing part of the elegant facade of Bordeaux’s City Hall, they look more like towering pieces of charcoal since being set on fire last week, after a protest against the French government’s retirement law.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, March 31, 2023
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: A Movie Confronts Germany’s Other Genocide
abstract: “Measures of Men” tells the story of the systematic massacre of Herero and Nama people in what is now Namibia. Its maker hopes the film will bring a debate about Germany’s colonial guilt into the center of society.
lead_paragraph: Germany is often praised for its willingness to confront the darkest moments of its history, but in recent years, activists have pointed to a blank spot in the country’s culture of remembrance. Decades before the Holocaust, Germany perpetrated the 20th century’s first genocide: From 1904 to 1908, German colonial officials systematically killed tens of thousands of Herero and Nama people in what is now Namibia. This atrocity is little known outside academic circles, and there are few memorials or pop cultural depictions of those events.

headline: Eurozone Inflation Continues to Fall, as Energy Prices Ease
abstract: The rate of inflation in countries using the euro slipped to 6.9 percent in the year through March, from 8.5 percent the previous month, but underlying price gains edged higher.
lead_paragraph: The eurozone’s rate of inflation fell sharply in March, as energy prices across the region continued to fall from record levels reached last summer, but prices for food remained stubbornly high.

headline: Knitters Say Stitching Helps Them Follow the Thread in Meetings
abstract: An official in Wales was called out for knitting in a virtual meeting, setting off a debate over etiquette. Experts say the fine-motor movement activates the parts of the brain used for focus.
lead_paragraph: Is it rude to knit at work?

headline: As Israel’s Crises Pile Up, a Far-Right Minister Is a Common Thread
abstract: Bezalel Smotrich, the finance minister, is a longtime advocate of contentious plans to overhaul the judiciary. He has also exacerbated tensions with Palestinians and Israel’s allies.
lead_paragraph: As protests and unrest swept across Israel this week, many Israelis issued impassioned calls for moderation and dialogue to resolve one of the most serious domestic crises in the country’s history.

headline: Fox News Hosts Back Trump, After Months of Keeping Some Distance
abstract: Despite recent criticism, the network’s star personalities joined other leading conservatives in denouncing the indictment as politically motivated and a possible cause for unrest.
lead_paragraph: “This cannot stand,” the Fox News host Jesse Watters told his viewers. “This doesn’t feel right. Something feels terrible.”

headline: The Indictment of Donald Trump
abstract: The former president will face criminal charges over his role in paying hush money to Stormy Daniels.
lead_paragraph: A Manhattan grand jury has indicted Donald J. Trump for his role in paying hush money to a porn star, according to people with knowledge of the matter. The precise charges are not yet known, but the case against him has kicked off a historic moment in American politics.

headline: In a Land With No Soccer, Group Hopes to Use It to Score Climate Goals
abstract: The Marshall Islands Soccer Federation aims to draw interest in the sport — and to growing global warming events in the Pacific.
lead_paragraph: Soccer has very little presence in the Marshall Islands. The atoll nation, with a population of 60,000, has no domestic fixture, dedicated playing fields or organized local teams, let alone a national team — making it a global anomaly.

headline: Donald Trump Indicted
abstract: He is the first former U.S. president to face criminal charges.
lead_paragraph: A former American president has been indicted.

headline: Why Tetris Consumed Your Brain
abstract: Tetris exploded in popularity after a race in the 1980s to secure global rights for the Soviet-made video game, a tale retold in a new movie. It is still captivating minds decades later.
lead_paragraph: Rotating a colorful shape before slotting it into the perfect position is such a satisfying experience that Tetris has joined chess in the pantheon of universally recognizable games.

headline: Pope Is Expected to Be Released From the Hospital on Saturday
abstract: Francis, who has been coping with a variety of health issues, was taken to the hospital on Wednesday. He is being treated with antibiotics for bronchitis, according to the Vatican.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis is expected to be discharged from the hospital on Saturday and will preside over Palm Sunday celebrations, the Vatican said on Friday, after he was unexpectedly hospitalized earlier in the week for a respiratory infection.

headline: Trump’s Indictment and What’s Next
abstract: The fallout will be widespread, with ramifications for the 2024 presidential race, policymaking and more.
lead_paragraph: A Manhattan grand jury has indicted Donald Trump over his role in paying hush money to a porn star, making him the first former president to face criminal charges. It’s a pivotal moment in U.S. politics — there was an audible on-air gasp when Fox News anchors reported the news on Thursday — with ramifications for the 2024 presidential race, policymaking and more.

headline: She Gets Them, and She’s One of Them, Too
abstract: Morgan Maher’s new book, “Girls in Bed,” captures a young generation of creative talent in confidently vulnerable images.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Last December, the photographer Morgan Maher was crashing at a friend’s house in the Silver Lake neighborhood, and she’d made the living room space fully her own.

headline: Wimbledon Drops Ban on Players From Russia and Belarus
abstract: The All England Club’s decision is a reversal of a policy that drew criticism last year. It will open the door for several top players to compete as neutrals.
lead_paragraph: Tennis players from Russia and Belarus will be allowed to compete at Wimbledon this summer after tournament officials reversed a policy that had barred them last year in the months after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

headline: View the Solution
abstract: This contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: This contains spoilers!

headline: Solve the Puzzle
abstract: We recommend solving this puzzle before you read the column, to avoid spoilers.
lead_paragraph: We recommend solving this puzzle before you read the column, to avoid spoilers.

headline: A Puzzle Is a Journey
abstract: Wyna Liu, a New York Times Crossword editor, examines a nontraditional puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Lab, a series that examines nontraditional puzzles that push boundaries.

headline: A Federal Tool Could Soon Make It Easier to Compare Credit Cards
abstract: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, which already provides some card details, is asking banks for more information about who qualifies for which cards.
lead_paragraph: Consumers may soon have an online tool from the federal government that is aimed at making it easier to comparison shop for credit cards.

headline: New Rules Will Make Many Electric Cars Ineligible for Tax Credits
abstract: The Biden administration hopes its guidelines for up to $7,500 in tax credits will encourage automakers to reduce their reliance on China for batteries and raw materials.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration on Friday released new rules that will significantly shorten the list of electric vehicles that qualify for federal tax credits. Officials hope the change will push carmakers to move their supply chains out of China and to the United States or its allies.

headline: How San Bernardino County Became the Largest County in the Contiguous U.S.
abstract: The Southern California county is bigger by area than Switzerland, Belgium and dozens of other countries.
lead_paragraph: SAN BERNARDINO — Stretching across more than 20,000 square miles, from the edge of the sprawling Los Angeles metropolis in the west to California’s desert border with Nevada and Arizona in the east, San Bernardino County is by far the largest county in the lower 48 states.

headline: A Renewed Arms Race in Asia and More: The Week in Reporter Reads
abstract: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: The Fed’s Preferred Inflation Gauge Cooled Notably in February
abstract: A closely watched measure of price increases provided encouraging news as the Fed considers when to stop raising rates.
lead_paragraph: The measure of inflation most closely watched by the Federal Reserve slowed substantially in February, an encouraging sign for policymakers as they consider whether to raise interest rates further to slow the economy and bring price increases under control.

headline: Joy, vindication and anxiety: Democrats absorb a consequential moment.
abstract: “We’ve been waiting for the dam to break for six years,” one Democrat in South Carolina said of Donald Trump’s indictment.
lead_paragraph: In some ways, it was the turn of events Democratic voters had dreamed of and some of the party’s lawmakers had long demanded: After years of telling lies, shattering norms, inciting a riot at the Capitol and being impeached twice, Donald J. Trump on Thursday became the first former president to face criminal charges.

headline: Twitter’s Blue Check Apocalypse Is Upon Us. Here’s What to Know.
abstract: Elon Musk, Twitter’s owner, is changing the platform’s longstanding practice of verifying accounts. That has implications for a range of users.
lead_paragraph: The blue check mark on Twitter has long conferred a special status. Only certain accounts — typically those of public figures whose identities were confirmed — have been bestowed the symbol.

headline: Are Big Profits Keeping Prices High? Some Central Bankers Are Concerned
abstract: Companies’ rising profit margins could be contributing to persistent inflation, a European Central Bank policymaker says.
lead_paragraph: After months of  fretting about whether workers’ pay rises would keep inflation uncomfortably high, central bankers in Europe have another concern: large company profits.

headline: Oscar Pistorius, Olympian Convicted of Murder, Is Denied Early Release From Prison
abstract: Mr. Pistorius, who has maintained that the killing was an accident and that he is remorseful, has served almost half of his 15-year sentence.
lead_paragraph: A South African parole board on Friday denied an early release for Oscar Pistorius, the South African double-amputee whose historic run at the 2012 Summer Olympics was quickly overshadowed by a conviction for murdering his girlfriend, Reeva Steenkamp.

headline: At Liverpool, a Red Alert
abstract: A rough stretch, starting with Saturday’s game against Manchester City, will define Liverpool’s season. The harder work comes after that.
lead_paragraph: Every year, in December, the BBC devotes an evening of programming to one of Britain’s longest-running broadcasting traditions. The Sports Personality of the Year Award was first presented in 1954; almost seven decades later, it is still going strong, a fixture in the country’s sporting consciousness.

headline: Bragg’s office criticizes top Republicans for aiding ‘Trump’s efforts to vilify’ him.
abstract: The letter described as unfounded the three members’ allegations that the investigation was politically motivated.
lead_paragraph: A day after filing charges against Donald J. Trump, the Manhattan district attorney’s office wrote a letter criticizing three influential congressional Republicans for their efforts to interfere in the investigation into the former president.

headline: PGA Tour-LIV Golf Rivalry Could Make for a Tense Masters Dinner
abstract: Players from the competing tours will be shoulder to shoulder at the traditional Champions Dinner. Feelings about that are mixed.
lead_paragraph: This might get awkward.

headline: Dior’s Gateway to India
abstract: The stakes are getting higher in fashiontainment. What a flex.
lead_paragraph: Ah, the symbolism. On Thursday evening, about 850 local and international celebrities, artists, editors and influencers (and editor-influencers, since they are increasingly becoming one and the same) gathered in Mumbai in front of the historic Gateway of India as multicolored lights played on the nearby Taj Mahal Palace hotel and cool breezes blew in off the Arabian Sea. They were there for the first official Dior show in the country, smartphones in hands to blast selfies to the world.

headline: Quiz: What’s the Future for A.I.?
abstract: You read Part 5 of our weeklong series on artificial intelligence. Now test your knowledge.
lead_paragraph: You read Part 5 of our weeklong series on artificial intelligence. Now test your knowledge.

headline: Belarus, echoing Russia, raises the prospect of nuclear conflict.
abstract: Because of the conflict in Ukraine, President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus said, “a third world war loomed on the horizon with nuclear fires.”
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Less than a week after President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said he would position nuclear weapons in neighboring Belarus, the Belarusian president on Friday joined his close ally in raising the prospect of nuclear war in an apparent attempt to pressure the West to back away from its support for Ukraine.

headline: Gerhard Richter’s (Sort of) Gifts for a New Museum Go on Show
abstract: One hundred works by the German artist will be a highlight of a new Berlin museum. But the building’s costs have ballooned, and Richter is taking a cautious approach to handing the pieces over.
lead_paragraph: Four large abstract paintings made with layered streaks of black, gray, red and green are the centerpiece of a new Gerhard Richter exhibition that opens Saturday at the Neue Nationalgalerie in Berlin. In the corners of the gallery hang four photographs from the Nazi death camp at Birkenau that show prisoners moving corpses from a heap.

headline: Here’s how indictments work in the United States’ legal system.
abstract: Grand jurors hear from only one side of the case, the prosecution’s, and can indict a defendant with a simple majority.
